A Pakistani paramilitary soldier on Friday stood guard at the site of a bomb blast at a religious school in Quetta, Pakistan. Five people were killed and 10 were wounded in the explosion. The police said the school was affiliated with a pro-Taliban political party, but a local party leader denied any knowledge of the school.

FINKELSTEIN--Lenore Zee , died September 18, 2008, after living 82 full years as a wife, mother, grandmother, godmother, sister and friend. She is survived by her son Jared, her daughter-in-love Liz: her treasured grandchildren Zoe and Ethan, her sisters Rosalind, Estelle and Evelyn and her brother Mike; and their families. She had been married to Arthur Finkelstein, who predeceased her, for almost 49 years. She will be missed by all of us. Private services. Contributions in her memory can be made to Cancer Hope Network, Twp North Road. Suite A, Chester, New Jersey 07930.

Telecom Italia, Italy's largest phone company, and its labor unions reached agreement on a revised plan to cut 5,000 jobs, after an earlier version of the plan led workers at the company to go on strike. The reductions will be on a voluntary basis, mainly through early retirement, Bruno Di Cola, secretary general of the Uilcom union, said. Telecom Italia will also hire 600 workers at its fixed-line network business and convert 300 temporary contracts into full-time positions, Mr. Di Cola said. Telecom Italia's chief executive, Franco Bernabe, above, has focused on cutting costs and trimming debt, which totaled 35.4 billion euros ($51 billion) at the end of March, to offset increased competition and regulatory pressure on prices. The official said that Ms. Palin, the Republican vice-presidential nominee who has been governor of Alaska for 20 months, requested the meeting several days ago as part of an effort to become familiar with the leaders of key American allies.

Adored wife of Maurice LaBonne and loving mother of Andrew and Abbe and daughter-in-law, Adriana, passed peacefully at her home in the arms of her family and surrounded by her closest friends on September 18, 2008. SOKOL--Evelyn , of Huntington Station, on September 18, 2008. Irrepressible jokester and mother of Daniel, Bob, and Ellen. A celebration of her life will be held at her home on Sunday, September 21, from 2-5.

On Friday's edition of ''The Oprah WinfreyShow,'' Ms. Winfrey announced her latest book club pick: ''The Story of Edgar Sawtelle,'' the debut novel by David Wroblewski, below, which came out in June and was warmly received by critics. The story, influenced by both ''Hamlet'' and the works of Stephen King, is about a mute boy with a deep connection to the dogs bred at his family's Wisconsin kennel. ''I think this book is right up there with the greatest American novels ever written, I really do,'' Ms. Winfrey said. The book was a popular summer read and was ranked ninth on the most recent New York Times best-seller list, where it has held a place for 13 weeks. ''When you read it, you will understand why I had to choose it,'' Ms. Winfrey said. The endorsement is likely to make the book even hotter, and throughout the day on Friday it was slowly moving up the top-selling book lists on both Amazon.com and BarnesandNoble.com.

The historic nature of the presidential campaign has stimulated a great deal of interest among voters all year, but now they are even more focused on the election. In the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, 63 percent of voters said they were paying a lot of attention to the campaign, up from 51 percent before the parties held their conventions. In September 2004, 52 percent said they were concentrating a lot on the race between President Bush and Senator John Kerry.

On that afternoon five years ago, Randy and Jill Keel arranged to meet on familiar and neutral ground. The setting was the coffee bar in a cavernous bookstore here, a place they had used other times in the two years since they had separated. Oddly anonymous in such a public place, they could speak bluntly, and angrily if necessary, outside the earshot of their four children. Mr. Keel had spent the previous months practicing this day's words with a therapist. He had known the essence of what he had to say for far longer. ''I'm gay,'' he told his wife. Ms. Keel, for her part, felt less shock than relief, for something inexplicable about their breakup had just been explained.

Republicans denounced an e-mail message that Senator Barack Obama's campaign manager, David Plouffe, sent to supporters on Friday that used the fiscal crisis as fodder for a fund-raising appeal and accused Senator John McCain of lying. ''With Wall Street in crisis and families struggling, Barack offered a solid plan to strengthen the middle class, including tax cuts for nearly all Americans,'' Mr. Plouffe wrote in the message. ''John McCain continued the same old politics -- lying about Barack's plan and offering more of the same George Bush policies, including more tax breaks for Big Oil and no solutions for working families.''

The jury in the O. J. Simpson armed robbery case visited the Palace Station hotel in Las Vegas to inspect the 330-square-foot room where Mr. Simpson confronted two collectibles dealers in September 2007 and departed with dozens of pieces of memorabilia related to his football career. After the field trip, the trial resumed in court with prosecutors playing audio secretly recorded of the incident, in which Mr. Simpson and a group of men are heard bursting into the room and threatening to harm the dealers if they did not cooperate. The alleged victims are heard after the Simpson group left calling police and hotel security to complain that they had been robbed at gunpoint by Mr. Simpson. Mr. Simpson is charged with 12 crimes related to the incident and faces a potential life sentence if convicted on all of them. He said that he executed the raid to retrieve keepsakes that were once stolen from him and that he was unaware that any of his cohorts had carried or brandished guns.

YUVA--John J. , formerly of Westbury, NY. suddenly on September 17th, 2008. Beloved husband of Jeannie. Loving son of Catherine and (late) Joseph. Dearest brother of Patricia Weiss (Gary). Loving uncle of Sarah Kay and Julliette. Family will receive friends on Sunday and Monday from 2-4pm and 79pm. at Donohue-Cecere Funeral Home located at 290 Post Ave. Westbury, NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday 10am at St. Brigid's RC Church. Cremation Private. Guestbook at www. donohue-cecere.com

HOGAN--Madeleine M. (Mrs. John V. Hogan) , of Forest Hills Gardens and Northport, NY, passed away on Sunday, September 14. Predeceased by her loving husband, John V. Hogan, her parents, Ray E. and Dorothy Blanks Miller, of Wilmington, DE and Forest Hills; and by her son, Richard John. Madeleine died peacefully with her loving family around her. She leaves behind sons Doug and Russell, daughters-in-law Nancy, Deborah and Joanne, former wife of Richard, and seven grandchildren: Caitlin, Ashley, Lindsay, Lesley, Scott, Nora, and Ella Hogan, all of whom miss her deeply. Madeleine attended Pine Manor College and the University of Arizona, she was a music librarian at Adelphi University and a graduate student of composer, Leo Kraft. Long time member of the West Side Tennis Club and St. Luke's Episcopal Church, she loved opera, the New York Philharmonic, playing bridge with good friends and the QE2. We shall always cherish her memory. A funeral service will be held Saturday, September 20 at 1:00pm at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, NY 11375. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

STEINWAY--Henry Z . The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the passing of its former President and Chairman, Henry Z. Steinway, on Thursday, September 18 in New York City at the age of 93. A great grandson of the firm's founder, Mr. Steinway was actively involved with the Company up to the time of his death, maintaining an office at Steinway Hall in Manhattan. Born in New York City in 1915, Mr. Steinway began his association with the firm as a factory apprentice in 1937 following graduation from Harvard. He rose through the ranks, becoming Factory Manager in 1946 upon discharge from the service, and was named Vice President in 1947. He served with distinction as President from 1955 to 1977, and as Chairman from 1977 to 1980. In 1980 he became a Consultant to the Company, a position which he held to present day. He married Polly Zinsser in 1944, who survives him, as does his sister Lydia Steinway Cochrane, and his five children. Henry Z. Steinway was a true piano man, and his familiar presence at Steinway Hall was our greatest treasure. An avid correspondent with curators, customers, Steinway dealers and celebrated artists through the years, Mr. Steinway enjoyed a perspective of the changing musical world that few in our industry will experience. Though his typewriter is silenced, our lives have been forever enriched by his personal warmth, his candor, and by his unwavering faith in the instrument that bears his name. To Polly and to Lydia, his children and grandchildren and his extended family, we offer our love and our heartfelt condolences. He will be sorely missed. The Board of Directors, The Management, and all of the employees of Steinway & Sons worldwide

BILLERBECK--Harry Allen , on September 14th. Beloved husband of Enid. Loving father of Susan Whalen and Carol Kane; beloved brother of Helen Peace and Betty Burke; beloved grandfather of five, Christina and Sydney Whalen, Kendall, Peter and Courtney Kane and beloved uncle of two nieces and two nephews. A Memorial Gathering on Saturday, 12pm to 2pm at the Rumson Country Club. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Riverview Medical Center Foundation, 1 Riverview Plaza, Red Bank, NJ 07701. Thompson Memorial Home, Red Bank is in charge of services.

BRAWER--Andrew J. , 60, of New York City, on September 16, 2008. A visionary and deeply committed textile entrepreneur, President and CEO, of Brawer Bros., Inc. Andy Brawer was the head of his family and his company. During his lifetime, Andy brought prosperity and growth to his company and love, generosity, guidance, support, and humor to his family. He was deeply loved by family and friends, and known as a powerhouse throughout the textile industry. His spirit will always be kept and honored by those who knew him best and loved him completely. He is and will always be the best part of us. We miss you terribly. Andy is survived by his wife Carole, son Adam (Keely White), daughters Marleena (Rob) Fass, Heather (Pete) Holmes, Kim (Lance) Aromando, brothers Charles and Peter, and four grandchildren Reid, Declan, Cole, and Leah. Services are Sunday, 11:00am at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

LEVY--Shirley R. , died September 18, 2008, after living 86 full years as a wife, mother, grandmother and kindergarten teacher. She is survived by her four children and their families: Mitchell Levy and his partner, Sheri Lockhart, Toby Levy and her husband Rick Holman, Fred Levy and his wife Jennifer and Donald Levy and his wife Barbara Bennett; her grandchildren William Levy and his wife Tina, Elyse Levy, Asher Holman, Michael and Jessica Levy, and Jacqueline and Andrea Levy. She had been married to Melvin J. Levy for 55 years, who predeceased her. A service to share her memories will be held at 9:30am on Sunday, September 21, 2008 at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to be made to the Institute for Retirees in Pursuit of Education, Brooklyn College, 2900 Bedford Avenue, Room 3160 Boylan Hall, Brooklyn, NY 11210-2889.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the conversion of methane at landfills into energy misstated the process used to create power at the Covanta Energy Corporation’s American Ref-Fuel incinerator in Hempstead, N.Y. The power results from the combustion of solid waste, not from the capturing of methane.

A headline and a picture caption last Sunday with the Night Out column, about two executive producers of the television series “Lost,” misspelled the given name of one of them. He is Carlton Cuse, not Carleton.

A brief report last Sunday about “The Pet Dragon” misspelled the author’s given name. He is Christoph Niemann, not Cristoph. The report also misstated the book’s retail price. It is $16.99 — not $17.89, the price of the library edition.
An article last Sunday about an exhibition of works by the poet and artist John Ashbery misstated the given name of a poet with whom Mr. Ashbery attended Harvard. He was Frank O’Hara, not John.

An article on Sept. 7 about the band TV on the Radio misidentified the owners of Headgear recording studio in Brooklyn. The owners are Alex Lipsen, Dan Long and S. F. Norton; the studio is not owned by Dave Sitek, a member of TV on the Radio. (Mr. Sitek owns Stay Gold, a studio in the same building.) The article also misidentified a recording studio used by the band Liars. It has recorded with Mr. Sitek at Hickory Lane studios, not at Headgear. And the article misstated the cause of damage to the building that houses Headgear. The external wall was damaged after concrete was poured against it; it was not damaged by a bulldozer.

Randy Cohen’s response (Sept. 7) to the question from a Jewish couple about a Persian Gulf study cruise was unsatisfying. Where was the anger at the untenable situation in which they were placed by the sponsoring group? It is outrageous that any group would take the liberty, without prior consultation, to list participants by another faith to avoid possible problems with governments in the region. If Jews or others need to have their identity masked, then the tour operator should rethink the itinerary rather than yield to blatant discrimination.

An article last Sunday about the Arts Access Program at Matheny Medical and Education Center in Peapack referred incorrectly to the recruitment of Lyn Sanders, the current director. An article last Sunday about efforts to restore voting rights to felons referred incorrectly to the role of the American Civil Liberties Union in providing information to Senator Barack Obama’s presidential campaign about how to register former felons. An article last Sunday about groups that harvest surplus fruit and donate it to food banks, using information from one such organization, gave an outdated name for that group and misstated the number of food banks it serves. THE DYLAN.

Art and commerce have always been cozy in Amsterdam. And now, as a building boom shakes up this free-spirited city (cutting-edge architecture, a subway line on the way), the Dutch capital has emerged as a cultural juggernaut, with everyone from designers to D.J.’s flexing their creative muscles. [?][?][?]BY STEVE KORVER.

OUDEMANHUISPOORT A covered alley filled with books and prints where Van Gogh once looked for bargains.Friday Book Market On Spui square, row after row of antiquarian book dealers joined by roving lute players.
Inspired by Rudy Giuliani’s cleanup of Times Square, Amsterdam is hoping to make its red-light district a draw for more than just the beer-and-.

Concept dining is “in the elevator,” as the Dutch say. Following on the heels of big ideas like dining in bed (at Supperclub) and dining in the dark (Ctaste), the latest theme is a twist on a classic mantra: odd location, odd location, odd location. At these six spots, the cooking is as much of a draw as the surprising settings.

The streets around the canals are packed with independent shops specializing in everything from toothpaste to teddies. The quirkiest assortment is in the NINE STREETS, a recently unified district of dozens of stores with its own Web site (de9straatjes.nl).

When Au Bon Marché, the 1920s Art Deco-style department store in Paris, was being demolished in the 1970s, a few intrepid Dumpster divers brought a haul of stained glass and gold latticework back to Amsterdam. The salvage formed the basis for Deco Sauna, a popular spa with a Turkish bath, Finnish sauna and solarium, along with therapists offering massage and beauty treatments. Herengracht 115; 011-31-20-623-8215; saunadeco.nl.

Hirofumi Kurino,the fashion oracle behind United Arrows Ltd. — he’s a co-founder of the 100-store Japanese retail giant, which sells everything from street-inspired sportswear to bespoke suits — has tastes as wide-ranging as the brand. “We try to be original and creative, like our customers,” he says. “They’re more style-conscious than label-obsessed, so we help them mix it up.” Kurino is shown here in the United Arrows flagship store in Tokyo’s Harajuku (011-81-3-3479-8180; 3-28-1 Jingumae Shibuya-ku; united-arrows.co.jp).

STYLE MAP | ZURICH: Bahnhofstrasse has always been one of the most expensive shopping stretches on the planet, chockablock with blue-chip boutiques like Prada, Louis Vuitton and Chanel. But detour off Zurich’s most moneyed boulevard and you’ll find indie boutiques sprouting up all over --- from the charming old Town section of Nierdorf to the side streets off Langstrasse, the city’s recently spruced up red-light district. Gone are the days of megaclubs pumping out house music for ravers. This party town’s image has gotten a new gloss with the rise of quirky, style-centric lounges featuring everything from exotic dancers to experimental D.J.’s.

More than a decade before Jack Kerouac and the Beats went on the road, another group of writers crisscrossed the country for art. Beginning in 1935, the W.P.A. Federal Writers’ Project put thousands to work documenting the young nation, with a payroll that included journalists and novelists like Studs Terkel, John Steinbeck and Zora Neale Hurston. The American Guides series they produced is today a collectible bookshelf of literary Americana and a monument to our small towns and back roads before the emergence of mass culture. So when Matt Weiland and Sean Wilsey decided to create a “road trip in book form” in 2006, they turned to the W.P.A. guides for inspiration. The two friends are heavy hitters on the belles-lettres circuit: Weiland is deputy editor of The Paris Review, and Wilsey is a longtime editor of the quarterly McSweeney’s. But you’ll still wonder how they managed to coerce or cajole so much talent into “State by State” (Ecco, $30). Fifty-one writers serve as guides and fellow wayfarers in this part almanac, part literary anthology, from the journalist George Packer on Alabama to the novelist Edward P. Jones on Washington, D.C. Along the way you get Jim Lewis’s one-night stand in Wichita, Kan.; Alison Bechdel’s graphic memoir of going native in Vermont; Dave Eggers on Illinois; plus William T. Vollmann on California, Ha Jin on Georgia and Alexandra Fuller on Wyoming. How should readers use this book? “The way each original W.P.A. state guide is used now,” Weiland says. “As a kind of guidebook to the soul of each state.” [?][?][?]BLAKE WILSON.

As first-tier American cities like New York, Los Angeles and Miami have become euro-fueled luxury romper rooms, creative types with more ideas than cash are fleeing to second cities, where it’s possible to pain, play, cook, build – and still eat. So much easy experimentation has not made “provinces” the country’s true cultural hotbeds. Here’s what’s happening in Baltimore and beyond. [?][?][?]CHARLES RUNNETTE.

Trendy streets are slow to form in Paris, which makes the one-year evolution of the rue André del Sarte an overnight sensation. The blocklong strip, bookended by a bank and a leafy cliff below Sacré-Coeur, had been home to mostly art and graphic design studios, but now boutiques and restaurants are moving in. The transformation was kick-started when the folks behind the popular area restaurant La Famille opened Chéri Bibi (No. 15, 011-33-1-42-54-88-96), a hipster canteen that serves simple food and turns into a party after dessert. At about the same time of night at No Problemo, on the corner (14 rue Charles Nodier, 011-33-1-42-54-39-38), the house tartare gets pushed aside to make room for live music. During the day, shoppers will find shoes and clothes from independent labels like Gaspard Yurkievich at Ysasu (No. 19, 011-33-9-50-58-67-81), as well as Béatrice Knoch’s gold and silver jewelry next door at No. 17 (011-33-1-42-57-97-09). And this month, the street gets its official stamp of coolness when A.P.C. opens a space at No. 20 that will sell past seasons’ collections — perfect for the neighborhood’s budding bobos. The A.P.C. designer Jean Touitou, who has a nose for all things emerging, said of the new location, “It’s a part of Paris that I’d never thought about before. I was walking around by accident and found it beautiful.” [?][?][?]CHRISTINE MUHLKE.

Nashville may be country at heart, but it’s hungry for more than biscuits and gravy, and a recent influx of business tycoons and record execs from the coasts has brought about a culinary awakening. Jeremy Barlow’s Tayst (2100 21st Avenue South; 615-383-1953; entrees $17 to $32) features a changing menu based on his finds from the Nashville Farmers’ Market — although the bread pudding made with Krispy Kreme doughnuts is a staple. At Radius10 (left; 1103 Mcgavock Street; 615-259-5105; entrees $24 to $31), Jason Brumm also puts Southern staples in fancy dress, as in black truffle grits and strawberry shortcake with mascarpone mousse, while at Ombi (2214 Elliston Place; 615-320-5350; entrees $14 to $28), Laura Wilson tips her hat gently to down-home flavors with crawfish croquettes alongside the scallops with lemon risotto. At Andrew Chadwick’s at Rutledge Hill (37 Rutledge Street; 615-254-8585; entrees $22 to $36), the chef takes the high road all the way, with dishes like salmon with tomato foam. And at the new Miro District Food and Drink (1922 Adelicia Street; 615-320-1119; entrees $13 to $34), the owners of the popular Watermark are bringing the Mediterranean to Music City, serving the likes of lamb with ratatouille and harissa. [?][?][?]KATHY BARUFFI.

Traveling comes with enough emotional baggage already — who needs to pay an extra $25 to find your suitcase mangled and manhandled on the luggage carousel? Which is why Globe-Trotter, the British luxury brand commemorating its 110th anniversary this year, has created the onehundred&ten, which they’ve pronounced “the lightest suitcase in the world.” Designed by Ross Lovegrove using a proprietary carbon-fiber-and-Kevlar material, the suitcase is as light as a tray table (three pounds) and as durable as a 747 (five times stronger than its weight in steel). $3,525; available only at Moss (mossonline.com). [?][?][?]ALEX HAWGOOD.

Globetrotting aesthetes may have to add some stops to the new cultural grand tour this fall. Taking cues from Art Basel and the Venice Biennale, design fairs all over Europe are turning from dry industry events into lively tastemaker affairs. The London Design Festival (through Sept. 23) kicks things off with work by David Adjaye at the Southbank Center, and then it’s on to Valencia’s annual furniture fair (Sept. 23-27), where visitors will get a chance to gauge Spain’s reputation as a hotbed of design. During Vienna Design Week (Oct. 2-12), trend spotters can tour exhibitions and attend lectures before signing up for the Designsafari tour, which heads to Prague for Designblok ’08 (Oct. 7-12), a showcase of Czech talent. And considering Budapest’s decorative arts legacy, the city’s Design Week (Oct. 3-12) is worth the train ride from Prague. The party stops off at Ljubljana, Slovenia’s 44-year-old Biennial of Industrial Design (Oct. 2-Nov. 2) before winding down with some East-meets-West innovation at the Istanbul Design Week (Oct. 16-20). [?][?][?]MONICA KHEMSUROV.

Adding to its inaugural New York-Paris route, next month the upstart will pamper jet-setters — only 64 at a time, in roomy cabins with yards of legroom — all the way to the reigning capital of cool, Amsterdam.

Although Egypt’s seaside metropolis was one of the most vibrant cities of the ancient world — economically, culturally, intellectually — it has only recently begun drawing international attention again.

Could the grand hotel of yesteryear be dead? At a time when travelers are spoiled for choice, the one-size-fits-all approach of traditional big-hotel service is giving way to ever more tailored experiences. And hotel companies are adapting not by making themselves over but by introducing new brands: 40 in about as many months, including offshoots of major players like Hyatt, expansions from the likes of the Gansevoort and the Fontainebleau, and fledgling chains like SLS and Missoni. Whether it’s pampering guests or simply getting out of their way, what these new brands all have in common is that they just want to make you happy.

UTOPIAN / (YOO TO\ PE\ EN) / ADJ. / having the characteristics of a utopia, a place of perfection. Of late, used to denote places that, for one reason or another, have retained a sense of idealism, e.g., “Have you been to Amsterdam lately? It’s buzzing with designers and artists and entrepreneurs with cool ideas — a kind of utopian creative capital.”.

The towering wood door swings open, and it’s the glow that strikes me first. My hosts, Daniele Kihlgren and Michele Zasa, lead me out of the blazing afternoon heat and into a vast Neolithic cave with 20-foot-high walls that seem to be lit from within. The walls are carved out of soft tufa stone the color of honey and pockmarked with hundreds of pits and crevasses, chiseled by the shepherds who have lived here over the past 2,500 years. Zasa, a local guide, points out fossilized seashells embedded in the double-height rock ceiling and a pear-shaped cistern once used as a well. In hushed tones we admire the graceful vaulted archways that look as though they’ve been splattered with lumpy cake batter. Despite having lasted millennia, they appear oddly fragile. There’s an agreeably musty odor in the cool air, and it’s profoundly quiet. Kihlgren hands me a massive iron skeleton key that falls with a dull thud to the bottom of my purse. This is where I’ll be spending the night.

In the pre-’60s at the University of Michigan, rebellion consisted of listening gleefully to the anthropologist Leslie White going mano a mano with God. White was one of those maverick intellectuals and politicians, like Thorstein Veblen, Charles Beard and Robert La Follette, who came out of the rural American heartland to off the pieties-and powers-that-be. Some of these intellectuals were village atheists from the beginning. Others, like White, only shook off the idiocies of rural life when they went to the city and the university.
Life along Bangkok’s Chao Phraya River is vibrant with a number of restaurants, ranging from the cheap and cheerful to the more elegant, cloth-napkin variety.

David Frum’s political view of inequality (Sept. 7) reads like an internal memo from the court of Louis XVI — equality is not a value to be pursued for its own sake but a concession that might have to be endured to avoid imminent revolution.

Clive Thompson (Sept. 7) suggests that aspects of the social media resemble 20th-century America. I would argue that the unfettered freedom of online communication resembles mid-1800s print journalism: local newspaper accounts of the burgeoning Civil War offer narratives qualifying as gossip, half-truths and lies.

Dexter Filkins’s excellent report (Sept. 7) raises the question: If the Taliban and Al Qaeda are in a tribal war along the remote border hills of Pakistan, why is America wasting the lives of its personnel in a war that will be fought anyway (as it has, uninterrupted, for centuries) and “possibly lost”? Our support of Pakistan, although its complexity is completely incomprehensible to most Americans, can surely be remotely provided. To sacrifice American lives — for people that, quite frankly, have little understanding of us but much contempt — is wrong.

RICK WAGONER, chairman of General Motors, unwrapped the production version of the series hybrid Chevrolet Volt as part of the company's 100th anniversary celebration on Tuesday. The Volt, whose small gas engine does not drive the wheels but keeps the 16 kilowatt-hour lithium-ion battery pack charged, will look nothing like the concept car that G.M. carted around to auto shows for years.

STEINWAY--Henry Z. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the passing of its former President and Chairman, Henry Z. Steinway, on Thursday, September 18 in New York City at the age of 93. A great grandson of the firm's founder, Mr. Steinway was actively involved with the Company up to the time of his death, maintaining an office at Steinway Hall in Manhattan. Born in New York City in 1915, Mr. Steinway began his association with the firm as a factory apprentice in 1937 following graduation from Harvard. He rose through the ranks, becoming Factory Manager in 1946 upon discharge from the service, and was named Vice President in 1947. He served with distinction as President from 1955 to 1977, and as Chairman from 1977 to 1980. In 1980 he became a Consultant to the Company, a position which he held to present day. He married Polly Zinsser in 1944, who survives him, as does his sister Lydia Steinway Cochrane, and his five children. Henry Z. Steinway was a true piano man, and his familiar presence at Steinway Hall was our greatest treasure. An avid correspondent with curators, customers, Steinway dealers and celebrated artists through the years, Mr. Steinway enjoyed a perspective of the changing musical world that few in our industry will experience. Though his typewriter is silenced, our lives have been forever enriched by his personal warmth, his candor, and by his unwavering faith in the instrument that bears his name. To Polly and to Lydia, his children and grandchildren and his extended family, we offer our love and our heartfelt condolences. He will be sorely missed. The Board of Directors, The Management, and all of the employees of Steinway & Sons worldwide STEINWAY--Henry Z., age 93, died at his home on September 18. Husband of Polly Zinsser Steinway, father of William T., Daniel K., Kate D., Henry E. and Susan Z. Steinway, grandfather of Sarah Zolan, Alexander Zolan, Andrew Steinway, Miranda Steinway, Charlotte Steinway, Henry A.S. Steinway and Ruth McCormack, all of whom loved him dearly. Funeral will be private, memorial service will be at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Museum of Making Music, 5790 Armada Dr., Carlsbad, CA 92008.

REALITY shows are usually classified along structural lines -- competition shows, makeover shows, dating shows, etc. This snapshot of the 2008 fall reality television season takes a different approach. We've grouped the shows by the primal human need to which they respond. Because reality isn't worth much without a roof over your head, some food on the table and a new pair of harem pants, after all. Defining a reality show is also a subjective exercise. We've taken a broad view: any nonfiction (and nonnews, nonsports or nontalk) show that's roughly in prime time (sorry, ''Flip This House''); is on one of the six major English-language broadcast networks or one of the Top 25 nonnews cable channels, as they were ranked by Nielsen at the beginning of the year (sorry, Animal Planet, CMT, National Geographic, Oxygen, Travel and WE, among others); and is presenting new episodes between now and the end of the year (sorry, ''Deadliest Catch'' and ''American Idol''). The resulting 120-plus shows represent a good share of what's new in reality. Some of these series won't actually appear, and shows that aren't on this list will, because when it comes to reality, the networks will change their minds on a dime (or for a dime). MIKE HALE

EARLIER this month, the Connecticut State Police announced it had recovered a 1957/58 Ferrari 250 GT that was stolen from a warehouse in Spain in 1993. The car (serial number 0799 GT) was seized in Sharon, Conn., from the current owner, who, according to The Hartford Courant, was not aware it was stolen when he bought it in 2001 for $550,000. The police declined to comment further on the investigation.

A new thin silhouette has reached the streets of New York in all its conservative force. The look, launched in Paris a few years ago by the designer Hedi Slimane, features skinny trouser legs, skinny ties, and sweaters instead of jackets (unless they are Thom Browne's shrunken models). The buff gym-trimmed Herculean body has a challenger in the new interest in a lean frame, accentuated by clothing.

LANDRUM--Jacqui, 1943-August 29, 2008, Dancer, Choreographer and Teacher. We mourn the passion of Jacqui Landrum. An innovative explorer within her craft, Jacqui was a dancer whose devotion to studying the body in motion enabled her to create a legacy of expression that will be carried forward by the students she cherished. At an early age Jacqui performed around the country with the Larry Muldonado Dance Troup. Jacqui's first professional job as a choreographer was for Hollywood A Go Go, where she became an originator of Freestyle Jazz and Go Go dance moves for television. In 1977, Jacqui and her husband Bill Landrum established their own company, Landrum Dance Theatre. Bill recalls that ''dancers from all forms of the craft were drawn to Jacqui because she had the ability to transcend technique.'' Legendary dancer and friend Paula Kelly paid tribute to Jacqui, recalling her ''artistic principals, core truthfulness, and honest, old school knowledge.'' Jacqui and Bill taught stage movement and drama at USC for seventeen years. In tandem with their teaching, Bill and Jacqui established their prolific careers as choreographers for film, television, and theater. The films they contribute their unique style to included; Oliver Stone's The Doors, Paul Verhoeven's Basic Instinct as well as The Big Lebowski, Barton Fink, and O Brother, Where Art Thou for the Coen brothers. They were also nominated for an American Choreography Award for their work on O Brother, Where Art Thou, and won another for their work on a Discover Card commercial. Always on the cutting edge, Jacqui and Bill were also among the first to adopt dance therapy as physical fitness. Jacqui was a key factor in broadening the appeal of Pilates in Los Angeles, influencing and inspiring dancers with her unique and enthusiastic perspective. Jacqui's continued to expand to the world of Gyrotonics. Jacqui's immersion into Gyrotonics and Gyrokinesis was powerful. For her, Gyrotonics was the culmination of the ultimate body/ mind/spirit potential. A life long student Jacqui never stopped pushing herself to new levels. Jacqui and Bill launched their private studio in the 1990s. The studio allowed them to offer their dance, Pilates, and Gyrotonics expertise to both dancers and laymen alike. As a teacher, Jacqui took great pride in her students' evolution and found great reward in sharing the connections she had discovered between movement and spirit Jacqui's final days were spent in the company of her friends and beloved husband. The breadth and reach of Jacqui Landrum's influence in the world of dance and movement will not be forgotten. The lessons she so delighted in learning and passing on will carry forward in the spirit of all those she inspired. A celebration of Jacqui's life will be announced later this year.

In their practices before last season's game against Dallas, the Green Bay Packers asked Aaron Rodgers to play the role of Tony Romo. When an injury left them without a quarterback in that game, they asked Rodgers to be Brett Favre. These days, just being Aaron Rodgers has been enough. The Packers are 2-0, and Rodgers has completed 70 percent of his passes. Fans in Green Bay now view his relief appearance against the Cowboys, when he threw for 201 yards and his first career touchdown pass, as proof that he was ready to take over for Favre.

BALIS--M. Earl, died on September 15, 2008 surrounded by a loving circle of family and friends. A biochemist, he spent his professional life at Sloan Kettering Institute beginning in 1949 when it was a small group of scientists focused on one problem: curing cancer. Throughout his life, he never lost his appreciation for the miracle of life and the wonder of science. He was a great bridge player, an adequate tennis partner, and an enthusiastic singer. He is survived by his beloved wife of 63 years, Bernice, his daughters, Andrea and Ellen, sonsin-law, George and Douglas, and grandchildren, Jesse and Sophia. He was beloved and he will be missed. Donations in his honor to the Hospice of Palm Beach County, Florida will be appreciated and will help others, which he would love.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''When a Secret Opened the Door to Candid Sports Reporting,'' Sept. 14: In 1947, after the Yankees won the World Series from the Brooklyn Dodgers, the team president, Larry MacPhail went on a rampage during the victory party. He called his ace relief pitcher, Joe Page, a bum; fired his general manager, George Weiss; and got into a physical struggle with Dan Topping, who owned a third of the team. MacPhail then resigned in tears. Tom Meany reported these events in the exceptional newspaper PM, (1940-48), concluding that MacPhail ''set a record for sobbing in a seven-game series.''

When a big Wall Street firm goes belly up, one bet you can take to the bank is that memorabilia will be offered for auction on eBay within hours. On Wednesday, two days after Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, more than 450 Lehman-branded items were being offered. Among them were numerous Lehman Brothers Emergency Evacuation Kits; a bright orange Lehman Brothers stress ball; and seven brand-new desk-decorating cubes that open up to reveal Lehman Brothers' operating principles. (''Demonstrating smart risk management'' is one of them.)

BROSNAN--Doris R, born September 4, 1916; died September 12, 2008. Loving mother of William and Jeffrey, devoted grandmother of Andrew. A Renaissance Woman for the ages. Brilliant, worldly, well-read, introspective, opinionated, stubborn with a heart of gold. Her Sewanhaka High School students will never forget their American History or Problem of Democracy classes. The last 31/2 decades of retirement in San Diego were busy with her cofounding the Institute of Continued Learning at UCSD, play-reader for the Old Globe Theater and past president of the La Jolla chapter of the National Kidney Foundation. Numerous lives were touched with love. Services private. Donations may be made to Children of Fallen Soldiers Relief Fund.

CRONK--Alice Douglass, 85, died 10 September 2008 at the Indian River Medical Center in Vero Beach, FL. She was born in Baltimore, MD and lived in Florida for the past 15 years, in both Sebastian and Vero Beach, having retired from Mahwah, New Jersey. She received her bachelors degree in Home Economics from Cornell University and her masters degree from Columbia Teacher's College in New York. She started her career as an assistant food editor for Family Circle Magazine, American Can Company and BBDO Advertising Agency, which handled Betty Crocker and Campbell Soup advertising. For most of her nearly 50 year career, she operated as a free lance food stylist, working for, among others, Bon Appetit Magazine. She was a highly respected specialist in a very specialized field. She was an active member of the Sebastian Chapter of the PEO and multiple local Quilting Clubs. Survivors include son Jay Douglass Cronk and his wife Sara Cronk, of Glenwood, MD, daughter Kimberly Bower and husband Chris Bower of Glenside, PA, and two granddaughters, Alice and Audrey. She was preceded in death by brothers William Edward Douglass and Carleton Douglass. Memorial contributions may be made to the Humane Society of Vero Beach, PO Box 644, Vero Beach, FL 32961. A private gathering to celebrate her life will be held at a later date. Services are by Cox - Gifford - Seawinds Funeral Home & Crematory, Vero Beach. A guest book may be signed at seawindsfh.com.obit.php.

LeVINE--Marge. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our beloved member. We extend our condolences to her family. Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Richard C. Laskey, President LeVINE--Marge, nee Schild. Loving and devoted wife of 52 years to Bob LeVine who passed away in 2006. Mother of Robin and Bob Ballin, Gail and John Vanderheyden, Lon LeVine and Jan Wooten. Grandmother of Amy, Jaime, Nick and Sarah. Sister of Lore and Mel Mallin. Her love, guidance and generosity have been an inspiration to us all. Services today 2pm, Guttermans, Jericho Tpke., Woodbury.

LORING--Charles Raymond ''Ray'', 65; Georgetown, MA. Died September 6, 2008 mountain hiking with friends in New Hampshire. Studied at Yale University, and Brandeis University Graduate School of Music. Composer, arranger, music educator. A classically trained concert pianist, Ray scored music for PBS series ''NOVA'', ''Frontline''; History Channel; Discovery Channel; historical museums, chamber orchestras. The Astoria Jazz Band of NYC performed his arrangement at the Kennedy Center in 2004. Ray taught music at Endicott College, Amherst College, and Gordon College, where services were held September 13, 2008. Survived by father Howard Loring; cousins Eileen Murray (California), Charlotte M. Chapin (Florida); and Kathleen Brown (Massachussets).

Plucked From Above And Carved Into Stone In much of India, the gods are not creatures of distant myth to be worshiped as abstractions, and few things in the country express the continuous presence of the gods in everyday life better than the ancient, massive stone temple complexes of Tamil Nadu. Though Kerala, the state just to the west, draws larger tourist crowds, Tamil Nadu is an increasingly popular destination and is one of India's most developed states.

CHODOSH--Paul L., M.D. The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary deeply mourns the passing on September 5 of an esteemed physician and colleague of more than 58 years. Dr. Chodosh completed his residency in Otolaryngology/ Head & Neck Surgery at the Infirmary and later became a Surgeon Director and renowned practitioner in Head & Neck Cancer Surgery. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Peter Frelinghuysen, Chairman, Board of Directors Steven D. Schafer, M.D., Professor and Chair, Department of Otolaryngology D. McWilliams Kessler, President

MANDEVILLE--Philip Kempton, 52, died Wednesday, September 10, at home in Sherman, CT. Born in New York City, Kemp was the son of Hubert T. Mandeville and Ann Adams. A graduate of Fairfield Country Day School, the Hotchkiss School and St. Lawrence University, he was most recently self-employed as a financial computer consultant. Previously, he was Vice President of the Mandeville Foundation in New York City from 1985-2002. In that role, he helped support such diverse causes as The Sherman (Conneticut) Chamber Ensemble and the Andrew Glover Youth Program, an alternative-to-prison program in Manhattan. He was an active leader in many community groups: Naromi Land Trust (board, treasurer), Sherman Chamber Ensemble (board), Sherman Nursery School (board), Lake Mauweehoo Club (vice-president), Sherman Library (volunteer). He was also a member of the Yale Club of New York City. He was an avid guitar player and member of the Sherman Bluegrass Ensemble and other groups. Kemp is survived by his wife of 26 years, Nancy Gage Mandeville, and three children, Elizabeth, William, and Allison. He is also survived by his brothers Christopher, Matthew, Jonathan, William, and Ross, and his sisters Meredith Mandeville Hollis and Morgan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Andrew Glover Youth Program, Inc., 100 Centre St., Room 1541, NY, NY 10013.

PRESSURE AT THE TOP Work-life balance is elusive at the very top. So says a new book, ''The Secrets of C.E.O.'s: 150 Global Chief Executives Lift the Lid on Business, Life and Leadership.'' Steve Tappin, a managing partner at the executive search firm Heidrick & Struggles, and his co-author, the journalist Andrew Cave, interviewed 150 current and former business bosses for the book. Based on what they heard, they include a ''C.E.O. health warning'' citing the risk of ''tremendous strain on your health, happiness and close family relationships.'' One executive said he had relocated 19 times as he rose to the top. Another confessed to seeking an astrologer's advice at a tough moment.

Survived by wife Patricia Cruz, children Pamela Cruz of NYC, Michele Davidson of, Gregory Cruz and Cassandra Lulaj, grandchildren and loving family. Iovanne Funeral Home 203-865-8961, www.iovanne.com. Contributions to www.hospice.com.

LICHAW--Richard I., 74 years old, died on September 15, 2008. Beloved husband of the late Pessia. Devoted father of Stephen and Alisa Lichaw, Ellen Coughlin, Donna Lichaw and Daniel Lichaw. Cherished grandfather of Samantha, Eden and Shana. Services were held on Wednesday.

FRANCO--Daisy. The Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research (IPTAR) mourns the death of our esteemed colleague and friend Dr. Daisy Franco. Dr. Franco's commitment and passionate involvement with IPTAR spanned 60 years as a key member and leader. Hers was an instrumental voice in shaping IPTAR as a center for contemporary Freudian Analytic Thinking. With her guiding principles, integrity, energy and formidable intellect, Dr. Franco helped move our organization to the forefront in areas of developmental theory, gender studies and feminist psychoanalysis. She was formally recognized for her contributions in 1998 as a ''Woman Analyst of Distinction at IPTAR.'' Dr. Franco influenced and mentored scores of patients and generations of analysts as the Dean of our Institute, supervisor, teacher and psychoanalyst, researcher and author. She was a woman of enormous kindness, conviction, spunk and style, who believed in the power of working toward consensus in all of her professional endeavors. Joseph Cancelmo. Pres. For the IPTAR Community

GOTTLIEB--Sophie, died on September 18th. Beloved wife of Bernard. Adored mother of Judy Gomberg (Ira), Bettie Ann Walensky and Roberta Jurik. EVANS--Judith London, on September 12 after a year long battle with cancer. She was valiant to the end and surrounded by family. She was 61 years old. Judith was born and raised in Montgomery, Alabama, and in 1971, a few years after graduating from Emory University in Atlanta, came to TIAACREF, the financial services institution that serves thousands of universities and colleges across America. She stayed for 36 years. She actually made history at the corporation all through her years there. She was the first woman to represent TIAACREF with institutional clients, working with dozens of colleges and universities around the country and served as a role model and mentor for many women who followed her. In 1988, Judith opened the New York City Regional Office and became the first woman to lead a TIAA-CREF local office. By 1994, Judith's office was responsible for 175,000 TIAACREF participants in the region in 1,000 participating institutions. In the most recent chapter of her career, she served as director of corporate meetings and special events, and managed the unit responsible for regional meetings for employees and clients all across the country. Herb Allison, president of TIAA-CREF from 2002 to 2008 wrote of her: ''Judith was a remarkably gracious, kind and caring person with a superb intellect. Her contributions to the culture and reputation of TIAA-CREF were uniquely valuable. As a colleague, Judith was a special joy. Her astute advice and subtle support behind the scenes helped me in countless ways.'' Judith was also deeply committed to Emory University. From 1992 to 1995, she served on the inaugural Dean's Council, was also involved with the creation of the Tam Institute for Jewish Studies and with women's issues on campus through the Center for Women. In 2006 she was one of two alumni to receive the Emory University Distinguished Alumni and Faculty Award. In her personal life, she was active in Jewish affairs as a life member of Hadassah and in many fundraising activities for various institutions. In addition to her husband Eli Evans and her son, Joshua, she is survived by Jack London, a brother in Montgomery, AL; Mark London in Washington, D.C. Contributions should be sent to the Tam Center for Jewish Studies at Emory University; the Brotherhood Synagogue in NYC; or, in honor of Dr. Jeffrey Tepler, her unusually empathetic oncologist, to the Judith Evans Lung Cancer Research Fund, c/o Dr. David Nanus, Weil Cornell Medical College 525 East 68th St., NY, NY 10021.

B. D. Wong could charm his way out of just about anything. That makes him perfectly suited for ''Herringbone,'' the unorthodox one-man musical in which he is starring, to glowing effect, at the McCarter Theater Center. You can take ''Herringbone,'' which had its New York premiere at Playwrights Horizons Theater in 1982, one of two ways. It is either the straightforward story of a semitalented little boy possessed by the spirit of a vindictive dead dancer, or an allegory about the dangers of success.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''This Season, There's U.S.C., and After That, Everybody Else,'' Sept. 14: Yes, Southern California overwhelmed a dreadful Virginia team (as did Connecticut last weekend), and it outclassed an Ohio State team that has made a habit of being outclassed by each and every quality opponent it has faced in the last two years. Addiction was the illness that took him, but never the essence of who he was. Also survived by his loving grandmother, and numerous dear aunts, uncles, cousins and friends, including the Abreu and Reuben/Glanzman families of Somerville and the Frias family of Hudson. HUI--Kerry Hishta. The energetic and successful Director of Development and Communications for Episcopal Social Services of New York, Inc., died on Thursday, September 11th at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City. Her unexpected death was the result of a brain aneurysm. She was 49. Ms. Hui came to Episcopal Social Services with a distinguished career of over 25 years in the field of philanthropic and fundraising administration. During her three-year tenure at ESS, she revitalized the development activities of the 177year old social services agency, nearly tripling the total annual revenue solicited from individuals, private foundations, and corporations. She also instituted an ongoing upgrade of the organization's publications and branding to reflect the breadth and professionalism of its nonsectarian outreach. In addition to her prodigious fundraising skills, Ms. Hui was known for the vitality and collegiality with which she approached her work. As an always-popular visitor among the young children in Episcopal Social Services' Early Head Start and After-School Programs, she took pride in the knowledge that the solicitations she made directly benefited disadvantaged and vulnerable children in New York City and their families. Her unfailingly warm and hospitable attitude toward her co-workers helped to cultivate the feeling of community she felt was so important to support the agency's Foster Care, Early Childhood Education, and Family Preservation workers. ''It's all about the children'', she was often heard to say. A graduate of Georgetown University, Ms. Hui began her development career as Assistant Regional Director of Development at that institution's Washington, DC and New York City offices before opening a development and alumni relations office in Los Angeles. Later relocating to the East Coast, she served as Director of Corporate and Foundation Relations for Connecticut's Fairfield University; Director of Development for the Leonard N. Stern School of Business at New York University; and Director of the $40 million Parsons Campaign at the Parsons School of Design in New York City. In 2000, she became the first Director of Development at the Corporation for Supportive Housing, diversifying the base of support for the New York Citybased national organization, and two years later became Director of Institutional Advancement at the Marymount School in New York City, where she managed all aspects of the school's development, alumnae and parent relations, special events, and communications. Funeral services were held on Saturday, September 13th at Our Lady of Pompeii Church in Greenwich Village. Ms. Hui is survived by her beloved husband, Kai Hui of New York City; her parents Annette and Charles Hishta of Roanoke, Virginia; and her brothers Kevin Hishta of Atlanta, Georgia, and John Hishta of Arlington, Virginia. A Memorial Fund in Ms. Hui's honor has been established by the Episcopal Social Services Board of Directors. Marshall Green, Board Chair Kenneth Kramer, Board President Robert H. Gutheil, Executive Director

SMALL as it was, Martin, an East Village boutique that sold unassumingly chic basics, left a gaping hole in the market when it closed its doors three years ago. Or so it seemed to its cultlike customer base, which included Sofia Coppola, Sarah Jessica Parker and scores of other stylish New Yorkers. All would agree, no one could cut a pair of jeans quite like its owner, Anne Johnston Albert, who shuttered the shop for greener pastures in Great Barrington, Mass. But now, Martin is back, with an online store and a collection of pieces ''you want to pack for a weekend,'' as Ms. Albert put it. Included are old favorites like the long whisper-weight tank top, the fitted moleskin jacket and her classic jeans, now in straight- and wide-leg styles, as well as new favorites like a cashmere poncho, handmade in the Berkshires. ''It's all stuff I want to wear,'' she said.

Former president of the National Hardwood Association and former president of Cold Spring Country Club. So proud of being an Eagle Scout along with his brothers Edward, Bernard and Leon. Incredible stepfather to James, Stacy, Jill and Peter Margolin and ''Pappa Al'' to their children. A celebration of his life will be held in October. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Humane Society of Boca Raton, FL.

LEIF--Leonard, age 97. Beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather died in his sleep on Monday, September 15th. He was interred next to his loving wife, Rae, on September 18 in the El Camino Memorial Park in San Diego, CA. He is survived by his son Robert; granddaughters, Liza and Stephanie; great-granddaughters, Erica and Sophia, and great-grandson, Benjamin. While he was a partner in Newport Knitting, which manufactured children's sweaters, he co-developed the process to spin acrylic fiber into yarn. Subsequently he was a consultant to Safer Textiles and a member of the Briar Cliffs Country Club.

Galveston officials announced Saturday that residents would be allowed to return Wednesday starting at 6 a.m. Those whose property is behind the seawall will be allowed to assess the damage and determine if they wish to remain, said the city manager, Steve LeBlanc. Those in areas not behind the seawall, including the city's battered west end, will be allowed to assess the damage and gather important belongings but must leave, Mr. LeBlanc said. Those areas do not have basic services like water, sewer, natural gas or electricity, he said.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the conversion of methane at landfills into energy misstated the process used to create power at the Covanta Energy Corporation's American Ref-Fuel incinerator in Hempstead. The power results from the combustion of solid waste, not from the capturing of methane.

SCROGGINS--Dick. Dick Scroggins, corporate real estate executive, avid sailor, and longtime Greenwich, CT resident, passed away on September 9. He was 75 years old. The cause was cancer, his family announced. Mr. Scroggins retired in 1996 as Senior Vice President, Corporate Real Estate and General Services, American Express Company, after a 37-year career in corporate real estate. In 1982, the International Association of Corporate Real Estate Executives, NACORE, certified him a Master of Corporate Real Estate. At American Express, he headed an organization responsible for a number of major real estate projects worldwide including regional operating centers and two headquarters buildings in New York City. In 1992, he was honored by his peers as the first winner of the NACORE New York Annual Award for Outstanding Corporate Real Estate Executive. He served as president of the NACORE New York chapter, and as a director of NACORE International. He served as chair of the Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of Greater New York and also of the Heritage Trail of Lower Manhattan. He was a director of the Downtown Lower Manhattan Association and was a member of the Advisory Committee --Plan for Lower Manhattan. In 1992 he was presented a Certificate of Appreciation by David Dinkins, Mayor of New York, for his ''leading role in the City's vital real estate industry, and for his expertise to the notfor-profit sector for the benefit of all New Yorkers.'' Richard Muir Scroggins was born December 11, 1932 in Detroit, Michigan. He is the son of Florence Scroggins of Ridgefield, CT and the late Olin Scroggins of Farmington, Michigan. Mr. Scroggins joined the U.S. Naval Reserve in May 1950, and served on active duty at the Grosse Isle Naval Air Station. In September 1951, he was accepted into the Navy ROTC Program at the University of Michigan where he earned a bachelors degree in business administration. He was a member of Sigma Nu Fraternity. In June 1955 he was commissioned in the U.S. Marine Corps. After completing six months of platoon leader training, he was assigned as adjutant of the headquarters squadron, Marine Corps Air Facility, New River, North Carolina. On June 30, 1956 he married Jeanne Joslyn, a career teacher from Sycamore, Illinois. Mrs. Scroggins died in 2004. After release from active duty, Mr. Scroggins held sales and real estate positions at Shell Oil Company, Burroughs Corporation and Ford Motor Company. In 1969 he was assigned to head the dealership real estate program for Ford of Europe, based in London. He returned to the U.S. in 1974 to become director of Leasing and Property Management at Ford Motor Land Development Corporation. He joined American Express in 1975 as Vice President, Real Estate. Mr. Scroggins and his family owned several sailboats that made passages on the North Sea and along the Atlantic Coast. He is a member of the Greenwich Boat and Yacht Club, the Islamorada Fishing Club and the Marine Corps League. He is a 25-year member of the First Church of Round Hill where he served as trustee and chair of the Endowment Committee. He also served for a number of years as president of the Rockview Drive Association. Surviving are his mother, daughters, Laura Scroggins Wolf of Marstons Mills, MA, Lisa Scroggins Lee of Ridgefield, CT, Sarah Scroggins Zejda of Stamford, CT and four grandchildren. Burial will be private. A service to celebrate his life will be held on October 3, 11am at the First United Methodist Church, Greenwich, CT. Donations in his memory may be made to AMERICARES, 88 Hamilton Avenue, Stamford, CT 06902, or The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, 2090 Seventh Avenue, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10027.

On Olympic National Park, a narrow but well-marked trail gives hikers access to the park's highest plateau, an exposed and windy stretch known as Grand Ridge. Starting in a glade of mountain hemlock and lodgepole pine, the trail rises above the forest and runs along a meadow that, when I passed through recently, was covered with wildflowers: purple lupine, red columbine, white wild carrot, all blossoming in a field of green. Passing the meadow, the trail gains altitude via some tightly carved switchbacks over loose dry scree on its way above treeline and the summit of Elk Mountain. Elk Mountain is not a peak so much as a rocky, tundra-covered ridge, maybe five feet wide, from which the land falls away in great sweeping voids. To the north, the mountains tumble down toward the coast of the Olympic Peninsula, the shimmering Strait of Juan de Fuca and, just at the extreme line of sight, the hazy blue hills of Vancouver Island. To the south, across deep timbered valleys, the view gives on to a succession of jagged peaks known as the Needles and the thick, gleaming ice field atop Mount Olympus.

EN ROUTE FROM DHARAMSALA TO NEW DELHI AFTER A VISIT TO THE DALAI LAMA, MAY 12, 2008 His Eminence Tsona Rinpoche, 42, a Tibetan Buddhist monk and member of the legislative assembly of Arunachal Pradesh, an Indian state on the Chinese border: ''Almost 11 legislative members from Arunachal Pradesh, including the chief minister, went to the Dalai Lama to show our very much concern about incidents that happened in Tibet. Many innocent people have died, and His Holiness is trying to resolve those problems. In Arunachal Pradesh, we have a similar dialect and society to Tibet. China is always claiming our territory. In our assembly there are 60 members. I am the lone member in the assembly as a Buddhist monk, but around 30 or 40 members are Buddhist. Because I have been recognized as the reincarnation of a great master, I am always associated with the Dalai Lama. He's not after power; his concern is only that Tibetan people should be happy, that the culture, society and language should be preserved.'' As told to Seth Kugel

GOLDEN--Hyman. Founding Partner of Snapple Beverage Corporation dies at 85. Hyman Golden passed away on Sunday, September 14, 2008, due to complications from a stroke at the age of 85. He is survived by his devoted wife of 59 years Mitzi, and their three children; Sharon Golden Brenner, Dr. Bruce Golden and wife Marla, Robert Golden and wife Donna. He was an adoring grandfather to all seven of his grandchildren: Jonathan, Maryssa, Barry, Richard, Corey, Jake and Remi. Hymie, as known to his family and friends, grew up in Middle Village, Queens. He began his career first as a window washer then business broker for the industry. It wasn't until he was in his fifties that he went on to become the founding partner of the Snapple Beverage Corporation. He was a devoted family man who will be dearly missed. Dad, your memory will be an inspiration to Mom and to us. We will always be proud of you and of all your accomplishments. Contributions may be made to The NS-LIJ Health System Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021. In Memory of Hyman Golden designated to NSU Hospital Stroke Fund.

THE NEWS City officials in Galveston, Tex., which was devastated by Hurricane Ike, began allowing evacuated residents to return to inspect their property during daylight, only to close the city again a few hours later when the access road became choked with traffic. BEHIND THE NEWS Most of the city still lacks power and is strewn with rotting and toxic debris and pools of insect-ridden standing water that officials say make it hazardous to inhabit even the few intact buildings. Local utilities said it might take months to restore power to all parts of eastern Texas. A 1959 state law may prevent hundreds of beachfront houses destroyed by the hurricane from ever being rebuilt.

PRENSKY--Henry David, D.D.S., born in New York City December 5, 1917, died of complications from chronic emphysema in Palm Beach Florida on September 16, 2008, at the age of 90. Community leader, organizer of Floridians for Healthcare, Palm Beach Democratic Club, lecturer, founding member of the Board of Directors of the School of the Arts Foundation, Dreyfoos School of the Arts, West Palm Beach. Memorial Celebration to be announced in Palm Beach. Dr. Prensky is survived by his son, William; a daughter, Catherine Prensky Mason of New York City; three grandchildren, Joel Mason of Wisconsin, and Josh Mason and James Regan of New York City; and three great-grandchildren. No information on service yet, but donations for the Bryna Prensky Visual Arts Scholarship Fund or the David Prensky Music Scholarship fund for graduating seniors at the Dreyfoos School of the Arts can be sent to: School of the Arts Foundation, P.O. Box 552, West Palm Beach, FL 33402.

ROOSEVELT--J. Willard, of Orient died May 18, 2008 at home. He was 90. He grew up in NY, NY, went to Groton and Harvard; studied piano with Nadia Boulanger in Paris and Gargenville, France. He was a musician and composer, taught music for many years at the Hartt School of the University of Hartford, CT, Mannes College The New School for Music in NY, NY, Fairleigh Dickinson University in New Jersey and The Longy School of Music in Cambridge, MA, and was a member of the Long Island Composer's Alliance. He served in the Pacific during WWII as Commander of the USS Greene, APD. Son of Kermit and Belle Willard Roosevelt, his grandfather was President Theodore Roosevelt. Greatly loved by all, he is survived by his wife Carol of Orient, son Dirck of Cambridge, MA, daughter Elizabeth Aldred of Brewster, MA, three grandsons, a greatgranddaughter and many nieces and nephews. Family and friends are invited to attend a memorial service at the Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace, 28 E 20 St., NY, NY on September 27, 2008 at 3 PM. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Music Program of the Harlem School of the Arts, NY.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Cyclists Say Apology Is Too Little, Too Late,'' Sept. 16: These cyclists do not deserve an apology from the United States Olympic Committee. If they felt the air in Beijing was polluted, they could have at least waited a while before putting on masks. What they did was at best ungracious and at worst downright insulting to the host country. They seem to have forgotten that they were guests.

The photographer Olaf Otto Becker works best in a haze. ''Sun and shadows often design an image on their own,'' he says. ''I want to show a landscape's mood.'' His photographs are often the result of trips to remote places like Greenland -- the subject of his 2007 book, ''Broken Line'' (Hatje Cantz) -- and, for this issue, the high-altitude Andean nation of Bolivia (''Day of Ascension,'' Page 132). Becker's poetic documentation of the natural world has given his work unexpected political implications. In 1998, on one of his early trips to Iceland, Becker snapped a picture of an impressive glacier; when he returned four years later, it had vanished. ''Even the polar bears are having trouble finding shelter and food,'' he says. While he makes no claim to being the next Al Gore, he hopes his photographs show the ''worth of these regions.'' But for Becker, it's bittersweet: ''An icecap melting into a rushing river can be very beautiful, but this transition itself is something worth thinking about.'' AMBROISE TÉZENAS

It’s the third week of pre-school. Kids are still settling in, and many are still crying when their parents drop them off in the morning. During these first weeks of school, pre-school teachers do a lot of waiting and wondering — waiting patiently for the separation tears to end and wondering what fascinating young characters will begin to emerge in this year’s class. My students’ parents, however, are already thinking about next year — they’re worried about getting their kids into kindergarten.

I've had more time to read the Dodd proposal -- and it is a big improvement over the Paulson plan. The key feature, I believe, is the equity participation: if Treasury buys assets, it gets warrants that can be converted into equity if the price of the purchased assets falls. This both guarantees against a pure bailout of the financial firms, and opens the door to a real infusion of capital, if that becomes necessary -- and I think it will.
