Just two of the three leagues in the Canadian Hockey League were in action on Sunday. Of note in the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League is the performance of the Cape Breton Screaming Eagles, who earned their fifth consecutive victory with a 5-2 decision at Saint John. In the Western Hockey League, the Brandon Wheat Kings needed a three-goal third period and a shootout to defeat the Regina Pats, 4-3.
The weekend's results in motorsports

Lexicon | "Attention, you fubsy, niddering oppugnant agrestics: some perfectly cromulent words need saving." That's how Fark.com plugs this article about words soon to be excised from a big dictionary published by Collins -- unless people come up with good reasons why not by February. [London Times]
A reader recently wrote:

They are two of the most senior members of the State Senate, political fixtures in the politics of New York City. Yet, both Martin Connor and Efrain González Jr. faced abrupt and unanticipated defeats in the Democratic primary two weeks ago in a city where incumbents rarely lose.

The following is the first in a series of reflections from Micheline Maynard, a business correspondent in Detroit, about her recent switch from a Lexus S.U.V. to a hybrid electric Toyota Prius. Share your own thoughts and experiences on the topic here.

As Congress and the Bush administration rush to pass a $700 billion rescue package for financial institutions, many will be seeking historical parallels. While the Resolution Trust Corporation is often cited in news stories, it is not the most apt example. Two that seem more relevant are the Home Owners Loan Corporation, set up during the Depression to refinance home loans, and the Swedish central bank's response to a real estate bubble in the early 1990's. In researching both, I came across some source material that makes for interesting reading.

The onward march of biomass, a little-heralded form of renewable energy that uses residue from sawmills and other forms of wood waste to generate electricity, continues. A few weeks ago I reported on Austin officials' approval of a 100-megawatt biomass plant in east Texas. When built, Austin Energy - the local utility that plans to purchase the power - said it would become the largest in the country.

Henry Paulson's $700 billion Wall Street bailout: Paul Krugman doesn't like it, and neither does William Kristol. A somewhat surprising number of opinion-slingers have joined in the bipartisan opposition.

Andrew M. Cuomo, the attorney general of New York State, has been getting a lot of attention on Wall Street lately, making comments that liken short-sellers to "looters after a hurricane" and extracting big settlements from financial firms that sold auction-rate securities.

Recently, geezers, as the online magazine Slate calls members of Senator John McCain's generation, were the focus of a special section called "Slate Goes Gray." I am of two minds about passing along the link to an anthology of essays that includes several that arguably ridicule the elderly. But along with the ridicule, "Slate'' offered much useful information and provided a raft of interesting links. So here goes.
Morgan Stanley will sell up to a 20 percent stake in itself to Japan's Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group "as soon as practicable," as it seeks more capital to stay afloat amid the market turmoil.

Once relegated to the realm of national laboratories, supercomputers have started to move downstream. These days, any business with $25,000 to $100,000 to spare can buy a computing system capable of cranking through very difficult tasks. And, in fact, more businesses than ever have started to buy exactly these types of systems as competitive pressure mounts to perform complex operations faster.

Politics | A columnist says history shows qualifying as a V.P. pick isn't that hard. Goldwater's 1964 choice became the star of American Express's "Do you know me?" commercial. Also: "When Henry Gassaway Davis was put on the Democratic ticket in 1904, he was 80 and labeled 'the reminiscence from West Virginia.' " And let's not forget Chester A. Arthur. [Boston Phoenix]
Scenes from the fashion parade that preceded the 60th Primetime Emmy Awards at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles.

In a stark reversal of its longtime stand on the issue, the editorial board of The Daily News said that the city's term limits law should be changed to allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to seek a third term.

Updated, 9:25 a.m. | JetBlue Airways briefly evacuated its existing terminal, Terminal 6, at Kennedy International Airport around 7:50 a.m., after a suspicious package was reported, according to the authorities. It reopened the terminal around 8:15 a.m. The evacuation happened just hours before the airline was scheduled to dedicate its new 26-gate, $800 million Terminal 5 at Kennedy Airport.

Gov. David A. Paterson said on Sunday that he would give Andrew M. Cuomo, the state's attorney general, broad powers to investigate the Long Island Rail Road as part of a wide-ranging review his administration would seek of how disability and pension benefits were potentially manipulated by L.I.R.R. supervisors, workers and retirees.
HBO earned 26 Emmy awards on Sunday, "consolidating its reputation as a powerhouse of U.S. television," Reuters reports.
Before we go to the chalkboard (above), here's our question for Week 3:Why don't coaches do this more often?By "this," I mean a different look, an innovative scheme, a funky formation.

Merrill Lynch's John Thain and Lehman Brothers' Richard Fuld Jr. made different strategic decisions over the last year that shaped radically diverse outcomes for their employees and shareholders. But the chaotic backdrop also spelled death for some companies and unlikely survival for others. Indeed, had the government bailout arrived sooner, Lehman, like Merrill, might still exist.
Heard at the 60th annual Primetime Emmy Awards, via the Associated Press:

More financial regulators across the globe are following the lead of the United States and Britain to curb the short sales of financial stocks in a move aimed at returning stability to financial markets, The International Herald Tribune reported.

The candidates spent much of the weekend weighing in on the current fiscal crisis - on the campaign trail and on television - and we're likely to hear more about it from them on Monday as they travel to critical battleground states and begin to ready themselves for their first major face off of the general election on Friday night.

As Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. blanketed the Sunday talk shows to promote the Bush administration's $700 billion bailout package, Congressional Democrats began to set their own terms for a plan to rescue the nation's financial institutions. Democrats hope to include greater legislative oversight of the Treasury Department, more direct assistance for homeowners and limits on the pay of top executives whose firms seek help, David M. Herszenhorn, Stephen Labaton and Mark Landler of The New York Times reported.
Lawmakers return to Capitol Hill today for what is scheduled to be the last week of the 110th Congress, facing a daunting stack of legislation and little time to enact it.
Washington Mutual was still opening its books to potential buyers over the weekend, but despite interest from a number of parties, a takeover is far from certain, noted The New York Post.

One of the problems with this blog is that I ruffled a few feathers back when Bush had an 80 percent approval rating, and somehow I wasn't impressed. People remember, and as a result, any unmoderated comment stream that I run gets overrun with insults and obscenities; so comments on this blog have to be moderated. And the moderator (not me) has other work.
Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage, has reached a deal to buy the Asian operations of Lehman Brothers, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the matter.

The financial crisis that began in the United States spread to many corners of the globe. Now, the American bailout looks as if it is going global, too, a move that could raise its cost and intensify scrutiny by Congress and critics, wrote Nelson D. Schwartz and Carter Dougherty in The New York Times.

Frazzled traders and money managers spent an angst-filled weekend struggling to fathom the sweeping bailout the Bush administration proposed for financial institutions in the United States and what it will mean for the world's markets.

Even as policy makers worked on details of a $700 billion bailout of the financial industry, Wall Street began looking for ways to profit from it, according to The New York Times' Jenny Anderson, Vikas Bajaj and Leslie Wayne.

Major shareholders of American International Group concerned about the company's $85 billion loan agreement with the federal government are to meet on Monday to examine alternatives to the bailout plan, The Wall Street Journal reported citing an unnamed source.

Senators John McCain and Barack Obama warned Sunday that there should be more oversight built into the government's $700 billion plan to stabilize the financial markets but said the potentially enormous expenditure would not force them to scale back their ambitious governing agendas.

The Bush administration is working with Congress to fill in the details of its plan to take the bad mortgage-related debt off the books of banks and financial institutions and stabilize the financial markets. But with Congress scheduled to begin its election-year recess at the end of this week, the administration has little time to pull the plan together. The New York Times asked three economists to offer their thoughts about the administration's actions.
A bit off the Paulson plan topic, but not entirely ...

General Electric is best known as an industrial powerhouse, with manufacturing prowess in businesses that range from giant generators to jet engines to alternative energy technologies like wind mills and solar panels. Yet, the company is as much a bank as a blue-chip industrial company and last week found itself engulfed in the market turmoil, noted The New York Times' Steve Lohr.

The Treasury Department started a campaign last week to educate Americans about the importance of credit. The campaign was not designed for Wall Street banks, currently awaiting the details on their $700 billion government bailout, but for 18- to 24-year-olds, who are presumably too young to bring the financial system to its knees, reported The New York Times' Amy Schoenfeld.

Hedge funds usually thrive when markets turn volatile. But, as Landon Thomas Jr. wrote in The New York Times, even these fast-money investors are struggling to cope with the wild swings in the markets, raising concerns that some may not survive.
In the wake of winning approval to morph into a bank, Morgan Stanley has put merger talks with Wachovia on hold.

A group of the world's biggest hedge funds are gearing up to sue Britain's Financial Services Authority for millions of pounds of losses incurred as a result of the regulator's ban on short-selling last week, The Telegraph reported without specifically naming the funds.
Deutsche Bank aims to raise about 2 billion euros, or $2.9 billion, in a share sale on Monday to finance the purchase of almost 30 percent in Deutsche Postbank.
British Prime Minister Gordon Brown is trying to persuade the U.S. government to return $8 billion to Lehman Brothers in Britain, The International Herald Tribune reported.

The current Wall Street meltdown may have left thousands of financial professionals around the globe without jobs, but here's a tiny glimmer of good news: China is hiring. China Investment Corporation, the nation's sovereign wealth fund, is seeking to hire 30 people with global investment expertise as part of its expansion plans, Bloomberg reported.
Executives at the state-owned German bank KfW may face criminal charges after the bank seemingly lost 350 million euros in a failed swap deal with Lehman Brothers, The Telegraph reported.
Morgan Stanley's Asian private equity arm is set to launch a tender offer to take control of Japan's Ten Arrows via a $105 million management buyout, according to Finance Asia.

Zentiva, the Czech drug company, agreed Monday to be acquired by Sanofi-Aventis after Sanofi raised its bid. The new deal, valued at $2.6 billion, will give Zentiva shareholders $69.71 per share in what amounts to a 9.5 percent increase on the original offer, which Zentiva had rejected.
In a move to inject funds into one of Russia's biggest investment banks, billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov has agreed to buy half of Renaissance Capital, Bloomberg News reported.

Challenge Games has secured $10 million in venture capital from Silicon Valley firms Globespan Capital Partners and Sequoia Capital, its second round of financing in two months, according to The Austin American Statesman.

Hollywood, apparently, is still in the money, according to The New York Times' Brooks Barnes. The crisis on Wall Street is roiling companies around the globe, but bank-financed credit is continuing to flow into the movie business, albeit on a much more moderate basis.

The United Arab Emirates central bank has set up a 50 billion-dirham, or $14 billion, fund for banks operating in the country. The move is designed to help ease liquidity constraints caused by the seizure of global credit markets, Bloomberg reported.

First-round bids are due Monday in an auction of 50 radio stations owned by CBS, The New York Post reported. Industry watchers, along with CBS chief executive Leslie Moonves, are curious to find out how large the gap is between buyers' valuations and the seller's sense of worth, the Post wrote.

LDK Solar, a Chinese solar wafer manufacturer, pulled off a mini-coup Friday by succeeding in raising $200.4 million through a follow-on offering that came at the end of one of the most volatile weeks in Wall Street history.

Andrew Lahde, whom The Financial Times calls the best-performing hedge fund manager of the past two years, is closing shop and returning money to investors, the newspaper reported. Mr. Lahde, the founder of California's Lahde Capital, has concluded that the risk of losing money from a bank collapse is too high, The Financial Times said.

Iran | An Iranian blogger and women's rights campaigner writes about the suppression of Internet activism under Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. But the voluble Iranian President seems to be holding his own tongue online too. He hasn't posted anything on his blog since last year. Guess he'll make up for it at the United Nations this week. [New Statesman, Ahmadinejad.ir, BBC]

India has been the hot new place for United States venture investors for a couple of years now, attracting billions of dollars in venture capital. Are there enough promising companies to use all that cash?

Experience, a nurturing approach and a keen eye have made Union Square Ventures, which has built its portfolio making small bets on young companies, a magnet for Web entrepreneurs. Meanwhile, co-founder Fred Wilson has become something of a rock star among the startup set, reported The New York Times' Claire Cain Miller.

Medicine | A parapsychologist comments on a big grant for British and American hospitals to study near-death experiences in cardiac-arrest patients, to find out "whether consciousness can survive when the brain is no longer working." She implies: Are they out of their minds? [Guardian, BBC]

Lexicon | A Johnson & Johnson heir blogs about Wasps, their private clubs and their language. Acronyms like N.O.C.D. and P.L.U., of course, mean Not Our Class, Dear and People Like Us. "Canadian" means Jew, "Eskimo" means African-American and "Hawaiian" refers to "anyone who pronounces the phrase 'how are you' as 'how ahhh yaaa' (they are howahhhyaaa-n, or Hawaiian)." [Vanity Fair]

Economics | One theory for "witch killings" in Renaissance Europe and today: people tend to lash out in tough economic times. An economist who studied such killings in Tanzania found that "the murders are much more common during years of drought or flood" and that the women tend to be old and from poor households that need to free up resources. [Slate]

Society | A feminist critic says Betty Friedan got this right: "Postwar America had taken the ideal of femininity to absurd extremes. Women in the '50s were encouraged to be childlike, passive, dependent, and 'fluffy.' " But her "fatal mistake" was attacking the women along with the culture. "Friedan's lamp seems less illuminating than incendiary." [New York Sun]

Alberto Contador of Spain won the Vuelta a España in Madrid, giving him a victory in each of cycling’s three major races. He won this year’s Giro d’Italia and the 2007 Tour de France.
Dinara Safina will move to No. 3 in the WTA world rankings after dominating Svetlana Kuznetsova, 6-1, 6-3, to win the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo.
Salomon Kalou scored late as Chelsea salvaged a 1-1 draw against Manchester United and stretched its home unbeaten streak in the league to 85 games.

Hideki Matsui wanted to play in the last game at Yankee Stadium to have a fitting farewell before surgery on his right knee. He singled and scored the Yankees' first run Sunday before grounding out and flying out, finishing his season at .294. He will have surgery on Monday in New York, and he is glad he did it this way.

Greg Biffle made it 2 for 2 in the Chase for the Sprint Cup, making a late pass with nine laps to go and holding off Matt Kenseth and Carl Edwards on Sunday in Dover, Del. Biffle, Kenseth and Edwards — Roush Fenway Racing teammates — engaged in a thrilling run over the final 20 laps in the Camping World RV 400, but Biffle made another textbook move to the outside late in the race to pull away.

Mary Garber, one of the country’s first female sportswriters, died Sunday in Winston-Salem, N.C. She was 92. Her death was announced by Rose Rush, a long-time friend whose father was an editor at The Winston-Salem Journal.
Derek Jeter told the last 54,610 people to sit in the blue seats at Yankee Stadium that they were the greatest fans in the world.
David Mantle and Billy Martin Jr. paid homage on Sunday night to Babe Ruth and Billy Martin, two Yankee greats.
“Lakeview Terrace,” the new thriller starring Samuel L. Jackson as a creepy cop terrorizing his new neighbors, Patrick Wilson and Kerry Washington, earned $15.6 million this weekend.

“Lakeview Terrace” (Sony/Screen Gems), the new thriller starring Samuel L. Jackson as a policeman terrorizing his new neighbors, Patrick Wilson and Kerry Washington, earned $15.6 million, ousting the Coen brothers’ “Burn After Reading” from first place at the box office over the weekend, according to estimates from Media by Numbers, a box office tracking firm. “Burn After Reading” (Focus Features), starring George Clooney and Brad Pitt, slipped to second place with earnings of $11.3 million. It has made $36.4 million in two weeks. New releases grabbed third and fourth positions: “My Best Friend’s Girl” (LionsGate), the romantic comedy starring Kate Hudson, Dane Cook and Jason Biggs, earned $8.3 million and the animated comedy “Igor” (MGM) was close behind with $8 million. “Righteous Kill” (Overture Films), the action film starring Al Pacino and Robert De Niro, took fifth place with $7.7 million for the weekend and $28.8 million in two weeks. Over all the weekend was relatively weak with revenues of $93 million, 4 percent lower than the same weekend last year.

MORSON--David M., M.D. , died September 19, 2008 at the age of 95 after a wonderful and fruitful life. He was the beloved husband of Shirley, the father of Daniel (Diana), Gary (Katie) and grandfather of Eric, Michele, Phillip, Sandra, Emily, Alexander and great-grandfather of Cameron and Callie, uncle to Ilana. Beloved brother of Myron Morson and Mabel (Harry) Tannenbaum. He was blessed with love and friendship to name but a few, Paul and Sandra Schipior, Steve Blumenkranz, Karen Johnson, Terrance and Ann Coyle, Robert Hayton, Diane Herzman, Irene and Josh Blumenkranz, Bebe B. Ishaq, Bebe Imanaden and Ora Frederick. He served on the Oncology staff of Montefiore Hospital since 1948. He worked until the age of 90 for the State Commission of the Blind. He served as Captain and General Medical Officer in the U.S Army in World War II. In the battles and campaigns of the Mediterranean Theatre, Sicily, Naples -Foggia, Rome -Arno, South France, Rheinland, Central Europe and Eastern Europe displaced persons camp. The funeral service will be at the Plaza Funeral Chapel on Amsterdam Ave and 91st at 10am on Monday, September 22, 2008. GARBER--Sidney. The Board of Directors, faculty and staff of the NYU Child Study Center mourn the passing of Sidney Garber, father of our Board Chair Brooke Garber Neidich. Sidney was a dedicated family man, a generous citizen and a world renowned jeweler. Our thoughts and sympathy are with his wife Deanna and with Brooke and her family. Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D. Arnold and Debbie Simon Chair and Professor of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry NYU Langone Medical Center Director, NYU Child Study Center GARBER--Sidney. The Board of Trustees, faculty and staff of the NYU Langone Medical Center offer heartfelt sympathy to Brooke Garber Neidich, New York University trustee, NYU Langone Medical Center trustee and founding board chair of the NYU Child Study Center, and her family on the death of her father Sidney Garber. Mr. Garber was a devoted family man, a respected businessman and a generous philanthropist. We join in mourning his passing and extend our sympathies. Robert I. Grossman, Saul Farber Dean and CEO Kenneth G. Langone, Chair, Board of Trustees NYU Langone Medical Center GARBER--Sidney, prominent Chicago jeweler, passed away peacefully Saturday, September 20, at the age of 89, in Wainscott, NY. He is survived by his wife, Deanna Berman Garber, his daughter Brooke Garber Neidich (Daniel), son Blair Garber (Barbara Parker), beloved older sister Esther Port, niece Norma Lee Newberger, grandchildren Jon, Stephen, and Mallory Neidich and nephews Matthew Newberger and Dr. Todd Newberger (Dr. Lori Newberger) and great-niece Sarah Beth. Born in Chicago in 1919, Sidney Garber attended the University of Illinois at Urbana, until his enlistment in the Army Air Corps. Lt. Garber, a decorated veteran of WWII served as Lead Navigator of the 454th BG 737th Sq. 15th AF from 1944-45. The son of a watchmaker, Mr. Garber opened his first store in 1946. Over the next half century he became one of the preeminent independent jewelers in America. Sidney Garber built his business on innovative elegance and a commitment to excellence in design and craftsmanship. A private graveside service is planned for Monday in Wainscott. A memorial service will be held at Chicago Sinai Congregation at a later date. Donations may be made to the NYU Child Study Center Open Door Fund, 577 First Avenue NY, NY 10016.

No Counter to a Punch Quarterback Mike Teel will not be punished for throwing a punch at his teammate Glen Lee in the waning seconds of Rutgers's loss to Navy on Saturday. Coach Greg Schiano said in a conference call Sunday that the incident ''was over and done with,'' and that he felt no need to suspend Teel. (AP)

SHENKER--Joseph . Pioneering educator and advocate for cooperative education, died on September 20, after a brief battle with pulmonary fibrosis, He was 68. Dr. Shenker had recently retired as provost of th C.W. Post Campus of Long Island University. He became one of the youngest college presidents in the nation at age 29, when he was appointed acting president of Kingsborough Community College/CUNY in Brooklyn. During his 40-year career in higher education he never held a position of less authority. At the age of 30, Dr. Shenker became the founding president of LaGuardia Community College/CUNY in Queens in 1970. During his 18year tenure there, LaGuardia became the first Community College in the nation to require its full-time students to participate in cooperative education inteniships to gain professional work experience prior to graduation. On August 14, 2008, in honor of his dedication and service, The City University of New York renamed the original building of LaGuardia Community College as Joseph Shenker Hall. From 1988 until 1995, he served as president of the Bank Street College of Education in New York. In 1995, he was appointed provost of the C.W. Post Campus, where he more than doubled the freshman class and led major renovation and new construction projects, including the Pratt Recreation Center and Kahn Discovery Center. In 2008, he was awarded the Long Island University Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters. In addition to his stellar leadership qualities, he cared deeply for the tens of thousands of students, faculty members., staff and administrators whose lives he touched. A gentle and devoted family man, he was the beloved husband of Susan Smyth Shenker, and father of Deborah Singer, Karyn, Sarah and Jordan. Loving grandfather of Joshua and Rachel Singer and Ava Gould. Devoted father-in-law of Gregg Singer and Shannon Gould. Loving cousin of Sandra Shenker Weitz and Vladimir Doubovis. A funeral service will be held at 2pm on Wednesday, September 24 at Tilles Center for the Performing Arts on the C.W. Post Campus of Long Island University, 720 Northern Blvd., Brookville, N.Y. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held at a later date. Burial services are private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be to: Joseph Shenker Endowed Scholarship Fund, Attn: Development Office, C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University, 720 Northern Boulevard, Brookville, NY 11548 or Fiorello H. LaGuardia Community College Foundation Joe Shenker Scholarship. Fiorello H. LaGuardia Community College, Attn: Jose Orengo, E-5 13 / Development Office, 31 - 10 Thomson Avenue, Long Island City, NY 11101.

Four television series collections will be released tomorrow: the second season of ''Brothers & Sisters,'' and Season 4 for ''CSI: N.Y.,'' ''Two and a Half Men'' and ''Boston Legal.'' The steady stream of full-season collections for current series offers viewers, along with online viewing and old-fashioned summer re-runs, plenty of ways to watch TV. Apparently, fans are ready to snap up the collections. Of the top 10 series, only one dates to mid-August, ''South Park,'' which went on sale Aug. 12. ''The Office'' was released on Sept. 2, and ''Smallville'' and ''Grey's Anatomy'' premiered on Sept. 9. SHELLY FREIERMAN

When the first issue of The New York Sun hit the streets six years ago, reviving one of the storied names in American journalism with a new conservative tone, some of the analysts who followed the newspaper industry predicted that there would be rough going. It had been years since a brand-new newspaper had tried to capture the minds of readers in New York, not to mention money from advertisers. The Sun's editors and reporters loved the David-and-Goliath odds they faced, competing against long-established papers with larger staffs and bigger budgets. They prized their scoops, even as the paper ran up million-dollar losses year after year.

CAVALLO--Ellen R., of Chadds Ford and Lancaster, PA, and formerly of Matawan, NJ died Thursday, September 18th at the Hospice of Lancaster County following a courageous battle against a lengthy illness. She was the adored wife of her loving and devoted husband Vincent T. Cavallo with whom she shared 49 years. Born in Brooklyn, NY, she was the daughter of Mike and the late Jeanette Blitzer. She attended Brooklyn College. She volunteered in various endeavors including serving as an emergency medical technician and aide at an elementary school for underprivileged children. Mrs. Cavallo was a beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and sister. In addition to enjoying her time with family she also enjoyed antiquing and collecting almost everything unique and beautiful and developed an in depth knowledge of antique quilts. By far, her greatest joy was her children and her six grandchildren with whom she enjoyed spending time. Preceded in death by her sister Karen Vallone, in addition to her husband she is survived by three children; her daughter Carolyn Daniels and husband Gordon of Chadds Ford, PA, sons Daniel Cavallo and wife Alice of Windermere, FL, and Peter Cavallo and wife Louise of Colchester, England, and six grandchildren Ellen, Steven, Michael and Matthew Daniels and Christine and Elizabeth Cavallo and sister Diana Blitzer and niece Lauren Vallone of Chicago, IL. Family and friends are invited to visit on Wednesday, September 24th between 9am and 10am at St. Cornelius Church, 160 Ridge Road, Chadds Ford, PA a Mass of Christian Burial will follow at 10am. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Hospice of Lancaster County, P.O. Box 4125, Lancaster, PA 17604-4125 or any charity benefiting children. scheidfuneralhome.com

With the nation gripped in an economic drama, the campaign rhetoric will be heavily devoted to bailouts, markets and wallet issues, especially as the candidates start the week by appealing for the votes of blue-collar workers in Northern swing states. But by midweek much of the candidates' attention -- and all of the campaign energy -- will be shifting south, to Oxford, Miss., where Senators John McCain of Arizona and Barack Obama of Illinois will meet for their first debate. Both campaigns know the debate could be a pivotal moment in the race. The 90-minute event, scheduled for 9 p.m. Friday, Eastern time, at the University of Mississippi, will discuss foreign policy and national security. Given the interest in the race so far, viewership is expected to be high.

KINGS OF LEON ''Only by the Night'' (RCA) There was a time, not long ago, when Kings of Leon made music redolent of garage rock and Southern grit, all snarl, wriggle and yowl. But while ''Only by the Night,'' the band's fourth album, gestures vaguely in that direction, its sights are set on far grander vistas. ''I see a storm bubbling up from the sea,'' Caleb Followhill sings in the opening track, his voice awash in reverb. ''And it's coming closer,'' he adds ominously.

PREPARING TO TRADE Frazzled traders and money managers spent an angst-filled weekend struggling to fathom the vast bailout that the Bush administration proposed for financial institutions in the United States -- and what it will mean for the world's markets. After intense lobbying from bankers around the world, the United States subsidiaries of most foreign banks holding toxic American mortgage debt now expect to be eligible for the bailout, a shift that is likely to draw fire from American lawmakers. [C1.]

The National Bureau of Economic Research is a group of academic economists, based in Cambridge, Mass., that publishes a steady stream of papers from economists. Some of the papers are far too technical to be of use to an average reader. But many of them are fascinating andat least somewhat accessible. (In my column, I've previously written about papers published by the bureau on happiness and the art market, among other decidedly non-technical subjects.)

Martin Morse, 31, started out on the floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange when he was 21. When he was 25, his boss gave him $100,000 and told him to make money with it. He lost it all, but his backer let him continue. Now he has his own business as a commodities trader for crude oil and natural gas, works the London market overnight from his penthouse condo and is on the floor of the exchange by the time the bell sounds in the morning. During Monday's turbulent trading, he said: "We basically sat there like everybody else on the sidelines and watched, hoping not to get our uniforms dirty. We all just kind of sat there like deer in the headlights."

A state judge has upheld a decision to designate two six-story buildings on the Upper East Side - part of a Progressive Era model tenement complex that offered airy and light-filled apartments to poor workers - as New York City landmarks. The legal status of the buildings has been the source of contention for many years.Backing up a decision by the Landmarks Preservation Commission, the City Council voted in February 2007 to protect the two buildings from demolition or alteration, reversing a 1990 decision by the Board of Estimate - which no longer exists - to strip the buildings of their landmark status.

The article suggested that the Yukon Gold is richer in fat and flavor than the Copper River, and is worth seeking out. My mind raced: "Wait there's salmon tastier than Copper River? Can it be???" Updated, 3 p.m. | Local police departments in 13 states and security agents from Amtrak and the federal Transportation Security Administration carried out a show of force at 150 railroad stations from Virginia to Vermont on Tuesday morning. The drill included random searches of passengers and their belongings, as well as other, unspecified security measures, the authorities said. [See updated article.] "You'll see police where you wouldn't normally see them,'' said Clifford Black, a spokesman for Amtrak, said Monday night. "It's an exercise to familiarize law enforcement agencies with the railroad environment.'' He said that in most cases the police "will just be there,'' but that they would in some cases inspect luggage, briefcases and other belongings.

And a new study finds that "tactical crisis containment is expensive and frequently inadequate. In most financial meltdowns a comprehensive solution was required." Put glibly, there is "no such thing as a free crunch." [Economist]

The 13th century castle in Belgium featured in Raising the Roof last week was auctioned off for €3.3 million (about $4.9 million) on Monday. After 800 years in the same family a court ordered Corroy-le-Château sold to settle a long-running family dispute.

A capsule summary on Monday about the Emmy Awards misidentified the actor shown in an accompanying photograph in some editions. He was Alec Baldwin of “30 Rock” — not Jeremy Piven of “Entourage,” who was shown in earlier copies.

An article on Saturday about the companies expected to benefit most from the federal government’s rescue plan for the financial system misstated the founder of one such company, the American International Group. It was founded by Cornelius Vander Starr — not Maurice R. Greenberg, who was its longtime chief executive. The same error appeared in articles on May 22 and Feb. 21, 2008, and on Aug. 3, 2005.

Because of an editing error, the Moscow Journal article on Monday, about the financial hurdles faced by The New York Sun, which has said it will close by the end of September if it does not receive new backing, misspelled the name of the Italian newspaper cited as an early model for The Sun. It is Il Foglio, not Il Folio. And a picture caption misidentified one of the editors at a planning meeting. The editor shown standing is Geoffrey Foster, the sports editor, not Kelly Sherin, the photo editor.

An article on Monday about the victory by the United States over Europe in the Ryder Cup misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a referee on the golf course on Sunday. He is John Paramor, not Paramour.

A picture caption on Friday with the continuation of a front-page article about new restrictions on short selling of stocks reversed the identifications of the leaders of two British banks that merged after the shares of one of them, HBOS, plummeted, possibly because of short selling. Andy Hornby, chief executive of HBOS, was third from left, and Eric Daniels, chief executive of its purchaser, Lloyds TSB, was fourth from left.

HAYES--Johnny, a former TVA director and iconic national Democratic fundraiser known for his irresistible charm, deep loyalties and desire to help others, died Saturday. He was 67. His family issued a statement through Dep Governor Brunson saying Hayes died of stomach cancer at his home 30 miles NE of Nashville. Hayes was Al Gore's campaign finance chairman when he was elected to the US House in 1976 and his subsequent Senate victories as well as his presidential bids in 1988 and 2000. ''He was a great friend and a wonderful ally,'' Gore said in a statement. ''I never would have been elected to Congress without him. He was the key, for me and for many others.'' ''A great many people across Tennessee, across our nation, have lost a friend today,'' Gov Bredesen said in a statement. ''Many knew Johnny as a powerful business and political leader; Andrea and I knew him as a friend.'' Hayes founded an insurance firm that grew into one of the largest agencies in Middle Tennessee. He served in then-Gov Ned McWherter's administration from 1991-1993. In 1993, Gore nominated Mr. Hayes to become TVA director. Roy Neel, a longtime associate of Gore and his current COS, said, ''Particularly this day and time when politics has become so cutthroat and mean and personal, it was never personal with Johnny. He had great friends in every part of the political spectrum, but he never forgot there were more important things than politics or winning. They just don't make them anymore like Johnny.'' Ronnie Steine, a Tennessee elected official said, ''The key to Johnny's success in everything he did was the ability to relate to people one-on-one. By the end of a conversation you felt you had a friend for life.'' Mr. Hayes was known for having built one of the most extensive collections of political memorabilia. Funeral services will be held in Gallatin, TN and a tribute in connection with his political collection will be scheduled early next year. Our hearts go out to our dear friend, Johnny's daughter, Amy, and all of the members of the Hayes family. Hilary Ballon and Orin Kramer Don Mullen Gail Britton and Peter Knight David and Hermine Heller Emily and Harold Ford Tracy and Jay Snyder Dylan Glenn Ali Pratt Bridget Siegel Bibb Hubbard and Stephen Goodin Erik Gordon

A Spanish soldier was killed Monday in a car bombing, the third in 24 hours in northern Spain, according to news reports. The explosion occurred outside an army barracks in Santona, after a warning by the Basque separatist movement ETA, Spanish national radio reported. The bombings followed Constitutional Court decisions outlawing political parties that embrace Basque separatism.

FRAIMAN--Arnold Guy, 82, of New York City and Norfolk, CT, died September 20, 2008. He attended Poly Prep Country Day School, Princeton University, and Columbia Law School, where he was an Editor of the Law Review. During WWII, he was an Army Lieutenant. He spent three years as an Assistant US Attorney (S.D.N.Y.), and then joined Dewey Ballantine. By Court assignment, he served as Associate Counsel for Rudolph Abel, the Russian spy, receiving an award from State and local bar associations for outstanding service in defense of civil liberties. After a stint as Commissioner of Investigation of the City of New York, he was elected to the New York State Supreme Court (1st Dept.). During his 16 years on the bench, he tried numerous complex commercial and major product liability cases. He belonged to the American, New York, and City Bar Associations. A loyal Princetonian, he was President of his class for its 50th reunion and on the Executive Committee. Arnold played tennis, ran in over 40 marathons, cycled with the Century Road Club Association, and started a sculling school in Wellington, FL. He was a member of The Century Association in New York, and the Doolittle Club and Norfolk Country Club in CT. Arnold is survived by his wife Genevieve, a lawyer, his children Susan and Peter, his grandchildren Sarah, AJ, and Cory, and his brothers Rob and Mel. A memorial service will be held at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church on Thursday, October 16 at 4 pm.

Oil prices posted their biggest one-day gain on Monday, jumping more than $16 a barrel as investors dashed into commodities on concerns about the government's plan to bail out the financial system. After a wild last hour of trading, crude oil futures surged as high as $130 a barrel before finally settling at $120.92, a record jump of $16.37. In the last four days, oil prices have risen $29. The dollar also weakened on Monday, creating an incentive for commodities to serve as a currency hedge. Gold, silver and copper all posted strong gains.

KAIMOWITZ--Ruth, 90, died peacefully on September 22, 2008. She was the devoted wife of the late William, beloved mother of Carol and Jeffrey (Llyn) and cherished grandmother of Simon. Born and raised in the Bronx, she was a former resident of Dobbs Ferry and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Shiva in Manhattan on September 24 and 25, 4-8pm and in Hartford on September 26 and 28, 2-6pm. Donations in her memory may be made to the Seabury Health Center, 200 Seabury Dr., Bloomfield, CT 06002 or to the Alzheimer's Association.

A car owned by a Palestinian rammed a group of Israeli soldiers and civilians just outside the wall of the Old City in Jerusalem late on Monday, wounding several people, before one of the soldiers shot the driver dead, a police spokesman said. The spokesman, Micky Rosenfeld, described the occurrence as a terrorist attack, ruling out the possibility of an accident. ''It was obviously a direct hit,'' he said. ''The vehicle came at them at a fast speed.'' Nineteen people were taken to hospitals, most of them soldiers.

GOODMAN--Vera S., widow of Sol Goodman died peacefully September 20 in Vero Beach, FL. Longtime resident of Palm Beach and West Orange and Short Hills, NJ, she leaves her daughters Nancilee Wydra and Robyn Goodman with a great legacy of love for the arts and commitment to charities. Grandmother to Zachary Wydra and great-grandmother to Maren and Ellsworth, she will be missed. Tributes may be sent to VNA and Hospice Foundation, 1110 35th Lane, Vero Beach, FL 32960.

HELP, BUT WHAT KIND? Most economists say the nation's financial crisis is so perilous that an expensive intervention is required. Considerable disagreement centers on how to go about it. [A1.]

PLAYER In Germany, the American midfielder Michael Bradley made his debut in the Bundesliga, playing 65 minutes in Borussia Mönchengladbach's 1-0 loss to Hertha Berlin. Bradley, 21, a son of the United States national team coach Bob Bradley, joined the team on a $6 million transfer from Heerenveen of the Netherlands. TEAM In Argentina, two of the country's biggest teams -- Boca Juniors and River Plate -- continue to struggle. Boca is fifth in the 20-team league after Sunday's loss to visiting Tigre, and the defending champion River is 17th after a loss at San Martín de Tucumán.

ARONSON--Sara P., RN, BS, MPH, 74, of Queens, NY. Born August 7, 1934. Died September 17, 2008. A graduate of Beth Israel School of Nursing, she began her career in obstetrics at Beth Israel before joining the NYC Department of Health in pediatric care at Bronx Lebanon. She continued her education earning a BS from Hunter College and a Masters from the Columbia University School of Public Health. Miss Aronson joined the faculty of the Hunter-Bellevue School of Nursing as an instructor of Community Health Nursing. Author of the text, ''Communicable Disease Nursing'' (1979), she was appointed director of the RN Pathway Program. She retired from this position in 1999. She served two terms as President of Alpha Phi, Hunter College's chapter of Sigma Theta Tau, the International Honor Society of Nursing, fulfilling the society's mission of nursing scholarship. Miss Aronson's life and career were dedicated to enhancing the professionalism of nursing as a critical enabler of healthcare services. Her impact has been felt by generations of nursing professionals. Beloved by all who knew her, she will be remembered as a consummate professional, loving cousin, neighbor and friend.

A squadron from the Russian Navy's North Sea Fleet sailed for Venezuela on Monday, a navy spokesman said, in a bid to bolster military links with Latin America as relations with the United States continue to deteriorate. The convoy will take part in joint maneuvers with the Venezuelan Navy in November, a Russian Navy spokesman said. Stung by the condemnation of its actions in the war with Georgia, Russia appears to be redoubling its efforts to strengthen ties with Latin American countries. Russia denied, however, that the war had any connection to its navy exercises with Venezuela.

MORSON--Dr. David. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our member, Dr. David Morson, beloved husband of Shirley, father of Daniel and Gary. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to all of their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Roger Meltzer, President

After two years of exploring a half-mile-wide crater, the Mars rover Opportunity will head for an even wider destination: a crater 13.7 miles wide. (Manhattan, at 13.4 miles long, would fit inside it.) In the larger crater, named Endeavour, the Opportunity would be likely to see deeper layers of rock, providing more information about Mars's geological past. To get there, the rover needs to drive about seven miles. That would match its total driving distance since it landed in January 2004, and NASA warns that the rover might not make it. At a pace of about 110 yards a day, the trip would take two years, and the rover has already far outlived its original mission target of three months.

BENEROFE--Stanley, passed away September 20, 2008. An accomplished business executive and entrepreneur, Stanley began his career designing military aircraft. He co-founded Barr Laboratories, a generic pharmaceutical company, and later became CEO of the Electrical and Engineering Group of Avnet, where he was a Corporate Senior VP and a member of the Board of Directors. Stanley also spent the last thirty years working in various capacities at Marwit Capital. Most recently, he coowned i.n.c. Printing and Graphics Corp. An avid photographer, Stanley traveled, taking award-winning photographs in places such as Yellowstone National Park. A proud husband, father, and grandfather, he spent many summers with his grandchildren exploring nature at Grandparents Camp in the Adirondacks. The family will sit Shiva at 5 Charles Lane, Rye Brook, NY from 2pm to 8pm on September 23rd and 24th and at 28 Madison Dr Plainsboro, NJ on September 26th 2pm to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, Stanley requested donations go to protect Yellowstone National Park (yellowstoneassociation.org) or Lake George (lakegeorgeassociation.org). Stanley is survived by his wife, Carol, children David, wife Maria, Steven, wife Carole, Susan, and grandchildren Andrew, Scott, Kara, and Jonathan.

MICHEL--Vicki Joan. Born Brooklyn, NY, December 23, 1940, died San Francisco, CA, September 4, 2008. Graduated from Bronx High School of Science in 1957, B.S. in History of Science from UCLA, director of the Southern California Counseling Center in Los Angeles, M.A. in psychology from CSPP, J.D. from Loyola Law School, associate director of the Pacific Center for Health Policy and Ethics at USC; law professor, bioethicist and consultant at the intersection of bioethics, health, and law. Among her many accomplishments her gift for friendship and her ability to mentor and inspire stand out. She is survived by her sister, Lindy Michaels, daughters Deborah Michel Rosch and Lisa Michel, granddaughters Amelia and Catherine Rosch.

An article on Saturday about the companies expected to benefit most from the federal government's rescue plan for the financial system misstated the founder of one such company, the American International Group. It was founded by Cornelius Vander Starr -- not Maurice R. Greenberg, who was its longtime chief executive. The same error appeared in articles on May 22 and Feb. 21, 2008, and on Aug. 3, 2005.

HALPERN--Pauline T., age 90, on September 20, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Adored mother of Roberta and the late Richard. Dear sister, sister-in-law and aunt. Hunter College alumna. The transformation of Wall Street picked up pace on Monday as Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, the last big independent investment banks, moved to restructure into larger, less risk-taking organizations that will be subject to far greater regulation by the Federal Reserve. The changes came after Goldman and Morgan Stanley on Sunday night received permission from the Federal Reserve to become bank holding companies. The change means they will be able finance their activities with insured deposits but in return must reduce the amount they can borrow to make the kind of big trading bets that drove huge profits, and massive bonuses for executives, over the last several years of Wall Street's latest Gilded Age.

SHENKER--Dr. Joseph. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Hunter College alumnus, esteemed educator, and dearest friend of the University Joseph Shenker, Founding President of La Guardia Community College. Known for his innovative work in postsecondary education for over four decades, he served with exemplary distinction and honor as CUNY's Dean for Community Colleges, Acting President of Hunter College and Kingsborough Community College, and Acting Vice Chancellor for Faculty and Staff Relations, prior to his outstanding service as President of The Bank Street School of Education and as Provost of the C.W. Post Campus of Long Island University. He pioneered the establishment of the first Middle College High School in the United States, at La Guardia Community College, and later the International High School in Queens. He created one of the nation's first community college programs for deaf adults, fully articulated with Lehman College. In recent years, he generously worked closely with CUNY to establish privately financed student scholarship programs in memory of Julius C.C. Edelstein and Albert H. Bowker. This past spring, The CUNY Board of Trustees named the main building at La Guardia Community College, ''Joseph Shenker Hall''. His profound commitment to the use of education to positively transform lives remains an enduring inspiration. His warmth, grace, dignity, and friendship will always be remembered. Our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Susan, the family, and many friends. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr., Chairperson Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor SHENKER--Joseph. With great sorrow, the entire Long Island University community mourns the loss of Dr. Joseph Shenker, who served as provost of the C.W. Post Campus for 13 years. Dr. Shenker played an instrumental role in increasing enrollment and transforming the Campus. We will be forever grateful for his extraordinary leadership, his collegiality and his devotion to the education and well-being of our students. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Susan, and to his family and friends. A funeral service will be held at 2pm on Wednesday, September 24 at Tilles Center for the Performing Arts on the C.W. Post Campus. Edward Travaglianti, Chairman, Board of Trustees Long Island University David J. Steinberg, President, Long Island University Paul H. Forestell, Provost, C.W. Post Campus Long Island University SHENKER--Joseph. The Hunter College community mourns the passing of our proud alumnus, Hall of Fame member and acting President of Hunter College (1980). His distinguished career in education will long be remembered. Jennifer J. Raab, President Hunter College

Senator John McCain heads into the first presidential debate with a track record as a scrappy combatant with the instincts of a fighter pilot, prepared to take out his opponent and willing to take risks. He has used fairly consistent techniques during his roughly 30 debates on the national stage: he is an aggressive competitor who scolds his opponents, grins when he scores and is handy with the rhetorical knife. Just ask Mitt Romney, whom Mr. McCain filleted on several occasions in the primaries, perhaps most infuriatingly for Mr. Romney when Mr. McCain misleadingly asserted that Mr. Romney favored a timetable for withdrawal from Iraq.

BENJAMIN--Walter, on September 22, 2008 at the age of 80. Beloved husband of Lillian, cherished father of Caryn (and Paul), Marcella (and Cliff), Jeffrey (and Andrea), Francine (and Curtis), adored grandfather of Shoshana, Joshua, Zachary, Ariel, Jesse, Judith, Olivia and Charlie. The kidnappers of 11 European tourists and 8 Egyptians who were ambushed in a remote desert area of southwestern Egypt on Friday night have demanded $6 million to free them, an Egyptian government official said early Tuesday. PARRISH--Louise, Master Goldsmith and teacher. Born on December 20, 1925 in Montreal, PQ, Canada, died on September 18, 2008 at her home in Manhattan. From 1974 to 2008, Ms. Parrish was a teacher of ancient and classical jewelry at the Kulicke Stark Academy of Jewelry Arts and later at the Jewelry Arts Institute. She was also a co-founder 31 years ago with her longtime friend Winifred Wager of Parrish/Wager a business which encompassed classical and contemporary handmade gold pieces. Another aspect of the business was the restoration of pre-Colombian gold artifacts. Ms. Parrish will be forever loved and sadly missed by her students, friends, colleagues and jewelry partner. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions may be made to the Foods Programs at the Holy Trinity Catholic Church, 213 W. 82nd St., New York, NY 10024.

Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO GARBER--Sidney, prominent Chicago jeweler, passed away peacefully Saturday, September 20, at the age of 89, in Wainscott, NY. He is survived by his wife, Deanna Berman Garber, his daughter Brooke Garber Neidich (Daniel), son Blair Garber (Barbara Parker), beloved older sister Esther Port, niece Norma Lee Newberger, grandchildren Jon, Stephen, and Mallory Neidich and nephews Matthew Newberger and Dr. Todd Newberger (Dr. Lori Newberger) and great-niece Sarah Beth. Born in Chicago in 1919, Sidney Garber attended the University of Illinois at Urbana, until his enlistment in the Army Air Corps. Lt. Garber, a decorated veteran of WWII served as Lead Navigator of the 454th BG 737th Sq. 15th AF from 1944-45. The son of a watchmaker, Mr. Garber opened his first store in 1946. Over the next half century he became one of the preeminent independent jewelers in America. Sidney Garber built his business on innovative elegance and a commitment to excellence in design and craftsmanship. A private graveside service is planned for Monday in Wainscott. A memorial service will be held at Chicago Sinai Congregation at a later date. Donations may be made to the NYU Child Study Center Open Door Fund, 577 First Avenue NY, NY 10016.

Singapore, which plays host to its first Formula One Grand Prix this weekend, is known for keeping things in order. That apparently extends to one of its other new attractions, the Singapore Flyer.

As I arrived in Singapore this evening my mind was swamped with all sorts of thoughts about the state of Formula One, some of which are reflected in readers comments in the preceding posts. Others came as a result of just arriving in Singapore at night and crossing over the bridge into town from the airport highway and being struck with the first sight of the track and the pit lane and the start finish line and the tires the mechanics had laid out to prepare for the weekend's festivities. Later, as I wended down the off ramp in the taxi we caught sight of more of the track - the backside of the pit building - and really saw the splendor of this night-lit circuit. It's said to be four times brighter than a stadium, and I believe it. What a great sight it is.And so on to my hotel near "Little India," a strip of streets full of Indian restaurants and stores. I ate in one of those restaurants, and on the other side of the street as I paid my bill I caught a glimpse of two signs, one on a store and one on the street corner, that looked kind of funny to me in the context of the arrival of Formula One to this new Monaco of the East. (Monaco in F1 terms: Money, glitz, wheeling and dealing, glamor, etc.) The one was a rather old fashion looking sign that said: Race Course Lane. In fact, it has nothing to do with the F1 track, and I suspect has something to do with an old horse racing track. It seemed like such a huge contrast of the old colonial to the new colonial - F1 camping out in Asia.

The Giants color analyst Dick Lynch died today. He was a genial man whose basic decency came through in his broadcasting. Readers, please send us your thoughts. (Update: see below for the Times obituary)
(Anna Bauer)
Update: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. says he is willing to limit pay packages for Wall Street chiefs whose firms avail themselves of the buyout.

Someone has some fun with the facade of the bank founded by Alexander Hamilton. Just kidding, we're pretty sure:

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday appointed a retired internist, Dr. Michael A. Stocker, as the new chairman of the board of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, replacing Charlynn Goins. The 16-member board oversees the corporation, which was founded in 1970 and is the nation's largest municipal health care system.

Perhaps the most surprising aspect of Boise State's upset victory at Oregon on Saturday was that the Broncos did it with minimal contributions from the star tailback Ian Johnson. Part of that was because of how the Oregon defense played: the Ducks boast a stout defensive front and dared Boise to pass. Johnson finished with just 40 yards on 19 carries.
Typewriter tin of yesteryear: industrial design with grit.
From our friends at City Room:

John McCain has suspended his presidential campaign and is asking the presidential-debate commission to postpone Friday night's debate with Barack Obama, because he wants to be in Washington to work on the response to the financial crisis.

Updated, 5:20 p.m. | The city is doing an all-out bicycling push over the next few years, creating 200 miles of new bike lanes and paths and exploring the concept of bike sharing. But a city study found that one of the biggest obstacles to increased bicycle commuting is not safety, but rather the lack of secure bike parking at work -- particularly in areas like Midtown Manhattan. Having a safe place to store a bike at work is an urban amenity that ranks somewhere with having unfettered roof access or a key to a community garden.

Citing the economic crisis, Senator John McCain said today he would temporarily suspend his campaign and return to Washington, asking Senator Barack Obama and the Commission on Presidential Debates to postpone the first head-to-head, scheduled for Friday night. Read developing report
While most people were watching the debate over a $700 billion bailout for the big bankers on Wall Street, Main Street scored a victory in the House of Representatives.

The economic crisis provides an incredible laboratory in which voters can watch the test subjects react before their very eyes, Katharine Q. Seelye writes in her latest Web column. Yet many voters will not be waiting to see what develops, possibly sacrificing the ability to make an informed decision by voting early. Go to column

Should anyone doubt the power of words to move someone, behold the sight of 740 young women walking five kilometers along Pelham Parkway on Wednesday to raise money and awareness for African women they have never met.

--The BBC's Sept. 24 account of the trial of the transgendered Turkish singing sensation Bulent Ersoy, whose antiwar comments about the country's conflict with the Kurds have landed her on trial for "attempting to turn the public against military service." Earlier this year, Ersoy, now legally female, divorced her husband, a contestant on a Turkish "American Idol"-style show. When the going gets tough, the tough get flowing.
With the uncertainty fostered by the financial crisis, it seems fair to ask whether early voting lets citizens make informed decisions.
Daniel Meyer takes a crack a defining "comfort food," via eating at two of the East Coast's toniest restaurants. An odd route, but ultimately a successful one. --MB
Goldman Sachs seems determined to ride the Buffett train as far as it can take it.
The publishers of The Seminal, a group political blog, have apparently uncovered the original draft of Henry Paulson's economic bailout. It's even shorter than three pages! It begins:

The software maker Adobe Systems once again faces the big test: will customers upgrade to its latest set of media creation products? This is a huge question for a company that brings in close to $900 million in revenue each quarter and depends on giving customers a reason to buy the latest and greatest code for growth.

One evening newscast actually gained viewers in the television season that ended last week: "NBC Nightly News." But NBC's slight gains were offset by declines by ABC and CBS, capping another season of viewer erosion for the prestigious programs.

The Long Island Power Authority's announcement on Tuesday that it will study whether it is feasible to build a large wind farm 10 miles off the south shore of Queens left some industry watchers scratching their heads.

In the criticism of the federal government's economic bailout strategy, free-market conservatives have been among the most specific in identifying what they see are its flaws. Lawrence B. Lindsey, a former director of the National Economic Council in the Bush White House and a visiting fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, takes a more stand-back perspective. Writing in The Weekly Standard this week (and before the news of Warren Buffett's $5 billion investment in Goldman Sachs), Dr. Lindsey offered a primer in what he calls "Depression-era Monopoly."

We skated last night and we were talking on the bench about players who make the guys around them better and players who, conversely, play down a level when they are with lesser skaters. And that seems to be the story on last night's Hockeyville 2008 telecast of the Sabres-Canadiens game from Roberval.

Transportation | "Suddenly a bicycle seems like the remedy for many modern ills, from petrol prices to pollution and obesity." So sales are way up. Want to cash in? "Because frame- and component-makers are happy to sell to potential competitors, there are in effect no barriers to entry to the bike business." Except, of course, competition. [Economist, with graph here]

More than 750,000 adults in New York are at increased risk of heart attack or stroke because they have high blood pressure that is not under control, according to a study released Wednesday by the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. The study found that 26 percent of New Yorkers have high blood pressure -- slightly less than the national average of 30 percent.

It's taken far too long, but finally the Bush administration is showing a new urgency and a new focus on Afghanistan, the anti-terror war frontline it effectively abandoned when it invaded Iraq in 2003.

The initial Treasury stance on the bailout was one of sheer demand for authority: give us total discretion and a blank check, and we'll fix things. There was no explanation of the theory of the case -- of why we should believe the proposed intervention would work. So many of us turned to our own analyses, and concluded that it probably wouldn't work -- unless it amounted to a huge giveaway to the financial industry.
(Anna Bauer)

Strong ratings for the new whodunit crime show "The Mentalist" helped CBS eke out a slight victory on Tuesday as the most-watched network despite Day 2 of ABC's ratings juggernaut "Dancing With the Stars." According to Nielsen's estimates, the new 9 p.m. drama, with the Australian actor Simon Baker in the lead role, attracted 15.5 million viewers, nearly 5 million better than CBS's premiere of "The Unit" in the same time period a year ago.
In the current market turmoil, many financial services workers have turned to other pursuits. But others have found new niches on Wall Street.

Internet | "When I catch a whiff of it, I realize I'm still tangled up in your Aqua Net." The blog Dear Old Love collects anonymous notes to people once loved (or liked), whether the feeling was mutual or not. Another example: "I saved your letters for years. Finally, I threw them away. Now, I'm wondering if you would re-write them. At least the good parts." [Dear Old Love]
The New York Stock Exchange held a conference call today to answer questions from companies on the new short-sale rules.

I'm just seeing this now, but Eric Posen argued on The Volokh Conspiracy last night that the Senate Democrats' alternate rescue plan would actually give Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. more authority than would Mr. Paulson's original plan.
