From Brad Stone at Bits:
From Westwood Capital's David Alpert, as reprinted on Executive Suite:

Two news items today, and readers should feel free to comment.Michael David Smith of FanHouse writes: "My fellow Lions fans, our long local nightmare is over. Detroit Lions President, General Manager and all-around incompetent executive Matt Millen is no longer running the team into the ground, Jay Glazer reports."

Move over Tata, your forthcoming $2,500 Nano has just been pre-empted by another tiny and inexpensive Indian-made car, and this one is all-electric. It's a narrow, top-heavy three-door hatchback known as the Reva, and it's been taking the world by storm, or at least 13 countries. Business Week reports that nearly 3,000 have been sold. And the United States could be in its minuscule sights.

Wind and solar power companies had something to celebrate on Tuesday when the Senate overwhelmingly passed major tax legislation that would extend $17 billion in renewable energy tax incentives that otherwise expire on Dec. 31. Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill say they want to support wind and solar power, and so does the White House.

Harvey Silverglate is a lawyer, newspaper columnist, blogger, civil liberties activist and author ("The Shadow University: The Betrayal of Liberty on America's Campuses," written with Alan Charles Kors). I've known him for many years, and consider him as close to a free-speech absolutist - in the worthy tradition of former Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black - as anyone currently engaged in the never-ending battle against censorship. One doesn't have to agree with every position Silverglate takes - I doubt he expects that. But it's good for the culture and the country to have him out there, arguing, badgering, publicizing, provoking.
Derby County, relegated from the English Premier League after compiling a dismal record, is another club under an American ownership with some grand plans.

As Congress continues to debate an estimated $700 billion dollar plan to bail out the nation's financial institutions, Americans are increasingly concerned about their own personal financial situations, believe that Senator Barack Obama will handle the economy better than Senator John McCain, and are divided over solutions to the current crises, according to several recent polls.

Assemblyman James F. Brennan announced on Wednesday that he was ending his campaign for comptroller next year. In a statement, Mr. Brennan, a Democrat from Brooklyn, said his campaign did "not have the financial and organizational resources to sustain a yearlong, citywide effort."

Politics | What if the Electoral College deadlocks at 269-269? And the Democratic House picks Obama as president, but the Senate, with Lieberman voting Republican, deadlocks at 50-50, so Vice President Cheney steps in to break the tie? President Obama, with Vice President Palin? "It would be like a scene from the movie 'Scream' for Democrats." [Washington Times]

A few words on Frida Giannini's latest Gucci collection before I fire up the curling iron and go blearily to the Tod's party, where Gwyneth Paltrow is the guest of honor and there is certain to be mob panic. Giannini has become an expert not so much in expressing an idea as packaging it. Everything is presented in easy-to-digest units-the boyish pantsuit in cotton or linen (with perky fedoras), the swingy mini caftan (now in a tropical print), the sexy safari section (some adorable poncho dresses and mean python jackets washed to a lovely thinness), and the filmy evening dress. There was sort of a travel experience embedded in the show, with some of the pantsuit colors evocative of an airline palette.

More news from the breast milk beat: PETA is urging the makers of Ben & Jerry's ice cream to replace cow's milk with human breast milk, to lessen the suffering of dairy cows and their babies on factory farms and benefit human health at the same time. (PETA.org)
By my estimate, I had interviewed Mike Mussina maybe twice before I approached him at his locker after the Yankees game on Saturday. I introduced myself as Mike Schmidt, my name.

Digg, the news site with the nerve to substitute the votes of the unwashed, unpaid masses for the refined talent of professional editors, has raised a new round of venture financing, the company said Wednesday.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa. - Early Tuesday morning, the area near Gate A at Beaver Stadium buzzed with activity. Penn State students turned recycling bins into drums, then thumped fight songs and chants. Frisbees and footballs sailed every which way. The place was a thicket of textbooks, folding chairs and bicycles.
This is the scale of 1 World Trade Center, the Freedom Tower, which is now beginning to emerge from below ground: the contract for the electronic security system alone is worth $20,407,680.
While both campaigns have been trying to paint the candidates' ages as a negative factor, voters do not seem to share their views, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

For a certain group of voters, whatever happens from now to Election Day - debates, new advertisements, October surprises - will have no impact on their vote. They will have already cast their ballots for president, taking advantage of early voting that is allowed in more than 30 states.
A theme for the Big Ten this year, besides the tumble of its national reputation, has been the spread of the spread.
The reports that Omar Minaya is poised to receive a four-year contract extension are hardly surprising.

It was a dozen years ago that Julia Harrison, then a city councilwoman from Queens, created a stir with remarks she made regarding the influx of Asian residents in her district, which was centered in Flushing.
This dish is a Mediterranean standby that is at home in pizzas, bruschetta, pastas and more.
Two systems may threaten the East Coast in the coming week...
B.J. Novak, a producer, writer and actor for the NBC series "The Office," has thrived off-screen as his on-screen character has fallen on hard times, Edward Wyatt reports in today's New York Times.

In The Times's special section Business of Green, Jad Mouawad takes a hard look at hydrogen fuel-cell technology, and the hurdles facing full-scale development of what has long been considered by many the salvation of sustainable mobility.

Real Estate | Witold Rybczynski says a present-day house as affordable as the original $9,900 Levittown model should carry a sticker price of $121,500. But even in today's lousy market, the median house price is almost twice that. Reason: not size or construction costs. It's "the cost of serviced land." Blame resistance to growth, and to local taxes. [Wilson Quarterly]
City officials filed administrative charges against two brothers who were helping to dismantle a tower crane when a co-worker fell to his death.

I spend so much time online, and since I rely on Net access for my job, I recently decided to treat myself to my cable company's "Boost" service. For $15 more a month, it gets you much faster Internet speed (along with a bunch of stuff I don't care about, like Web hosting space).

Warren E. Buffett's $5 billion investment in Goldman Sachs is being hailed as a major vote of confidence in Wall Street's prospects. Since the credit crunch began last year, financial firms have gone cap in hand to many investors, including Mr. Buffett, seeking capital to shore up their tattered balance sheets.
A reader, Patrick McNulty, posed this question for Hugh Willoughby: "Hugh, can weather modification change the size of such large hurricanes?"

The Mets may have finally found a game plan to get them into the postseason: don't let the bullpen pitch more than an inning. That's how they won Tuesday night, with Johan Santana going eight strong innings and handing over a 6-2 lead to the bullpen in the ninth.
There is a growing group of campaigners and business leaders who say the rich world should pay people in poorer countries to preserve their forests and jungles.
[flickr video=http://flickr.com/photos/themomentblog/2884092809/]

The last 24 hours have been very busy on this pale blue dot. Joe Davis's valuable daily digest of environmental coverage for the Society of Environmental Journalists includes links to several significant news stories (see below), and in the meantime I'm querying methane and Arctic specialists about the startling story from The Independent (UK) on Tuesday reporting on a "methane time bomb" discovered by an international expedition along the continental shelf off Siberia.

To the list of beliefs about paella that are not ironclad, add the most obvious: it must be made with rice. Fideua (pronounced FID-a-wah), a dish associated with Valencia -- where paella supposedly originated -- is essentially paella using noodles in place of rice.

In an unusually close vote that followed an equally unusual public debate, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted on Wednesday morning to begin charging city and state agencies for the use of E-ZPass payment tags by vehicles on official business. The move is expected to bring in $10 million in additional revenue a year, but representatives of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg derided the proposal and voted against it.

Updated For the second time in a week, the McCain campaign has issued scathing commentary against The New York Times, this time complaining of unfair treatment in a memo about an article examining ties between the firm of its campaign manager, Rick Davis and Freddie Mac, the mortgage giant.
What we're looking at on the Web today ...

Paul Berman's books include "Terror and Liberalism" and a two-volume history of the generation of 1968, "A Tale of Two Utopias" and "Power and the Idealists." His most recent book is an edited anthology, "Carl Sandburg: Selected Poems."
Gallup published an interesting poll today. It shows that Barack Obama's support among white women has actually grown since John McCain selected Sarah Palin as his vice presidential running mate.

Africa | A Cape Town scholar applies philosophy to South Africa's crime rate of 400 murders a week and a rape every 26 seconds: "Once a government fails that badly to provide law and order, any old Hobbesian will tell you that the social contract no longer applies." So a friend gets a gun, his daughter is raped, and the law of survival prevails. [London Review of Books]

On Tuesday, I noted the following apparent anomaly: Why would regulators restrict short-selling on approximately 900 equities by non-market-making investors, but not put temporary restrictions on insider sales by executives in those same companies?

Updated The Democratic vice-presidential nominee, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., speaking two days before the first presidential debate, accused Senator John McCain of pursuing "dangerously wrong" policies on Iraq, Iran and terrorism.
Some quick news and notes around the juniors before we get to the scores and the standings.

Ramon Jimenez looked up at the television in his law office, smiling as he watched a news story about the noisy challenge by a multiracial group of Bronx Democrats against their party's county leader, Assemblyman José Rivera.
Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Summer's over. It's fall, or as President Bush calls the change in the weather, "the end of global warming."
Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Exciting stuff going on over at the United Nations earlier today. President Bush addressed the U.N. General Assembly. Apparently, his father couldn't get him out of it.

Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Sources from Barack Obama's campaign say that during Friday's first presidential debate, Obama's going to try to get John McCain to lose his temper. Yeah, Obama plans to do this by constantly repeating the phrase, "Matlock is gay."
This is not a good market to be a seller.
The National Association of Realtors just released its report on existing home sales for August and the results offered scant signs of improvement for the housing market.
The 32-story office tower at 745 Seventh Avenue is no longer "where vision gets built."

Today's guest blogger is Daniel Alpert, a managing director at Westwood Capital, whom I've quoted quite a bit in my column the last few months. Why? Because he has been dead spot on in anticipating virtually every iteration of this crisis. Last night he sent me (and others) this note about the testimony of Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. and Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke. It aptly sums the current the state of play. I asked him if I could reprint his note here at Executive Suite. Happily, he agreed.
You'll see a post here from Bob McTeer, who is on our panel of daily economists.
Editor's Note: In the second of our Daily Economist posts, Bob McTeer rebuts the idea that government interventions encourage bad behavior.

Andrew Leonard has an interesting theory about what Paulson and Bernanke may be thinking -- namely, that mortgage-related securities are wildly underpriced, and that the Treasury can create a market that will lead to major upward revaluations, and we'll all live happily thereafter. I would quarrel with that theory -- at least so far, the losses acknowledged by the financial system still fall short of the true, "hold-to-maturity" losses we can expect given the decline in housing prices; plus, does it really take $700 billion to create "price discovery"?

We've found someone who likes Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's plan to spend $700 billion to buy bad mortgage-related assets from Wall Street: William H. Gross, the chief investment officer of PIMCO (and Morningstar's fixed-income manager of the year for 2007).
Henry M. Paulson Jr. is not going to win any shareholder democracy awards, judging by the deal the government struck with the American International Group.

Lawmakers are sounding deeply skeptical of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's $700 billion plan to rescue the financial system. And many taxpayers -- who would be on the hook for the plan's ultimate cost, whatever that is -- aren't so happy about it either.
High-tech electronic signs on station platforms that announce how long riders will have to wait for the next train are still a distant dream in most of New York's subway system.

With the fiscal crisis now framing the presidential race and the influence of money and lobbyists on the candidates and their campaigns an ever-present concern, the McCain campaign is being buffeted by the news that a consulting firm owned by Rick Davis, who is managing Senator John McCain's presidential bid, was being paid $15,000 every month since 2005 by Freddie Mac, the troubled mortgage lender.

Is an ad for a gentlemen's club (a euphemism for strip club) perched on a taxi offensive, even if it doesn't show a woman's body? Some people believe it is. City Room received an e-mail message from a concerned father who was alarmed by the number of taxi-top advertisements he had seen promoting New York strip clubs, like Flash Dancers and New York Dolls.
Construction on the Second Avenue subway will cost about $3,000 every minute of every day next year. Then the real money begins.
With cars getting so small, soon we'll all be driving like this. Evidently the clip is of a British stunt driver, channeled by Asian TV:
For the groups that have long espoused a cap-and-trade system as the most promising tool to curb climate change, this is a week of firsts.

More of your user-generated comedy (send via the comment link below):

Yesterday, Catherine Rampell offered a theory of candy-bar economics: vending machines that accept debit cards charge higher prices, because people don't really notice how much they're paying. As a follow-up, I sent an e-mail to Amy Finkelstein -- a young M.I.T. economist who has written a paper arguing that electronic toll systems, like E-ZPass, typically lead to toll increases -- to see what she thought about candy-bar economics. Shereplies:

So I am sitting at the Marni show this morning, grateful for that shot glass of rose tea a waiter handed out, and enjoying the Peter Blake circles and rainbow colors, only more saturated and with the metallic gloss of sequins, when a model walks by in a bolero made of tiny, tiny furrows of color, all packed together in a softness that makes me think it's fur.
GridPoint, a provider of smart-grid technology, has snagged a hefty $120 million in its fifth-round funding.

A day after acquiring the Asian-Pacific unit of Lehman Brothers, the investment bank Nomura of Japan agreed to take over some of the bank's European and Middle Eastern operations as well, The New York Times's Julia Werdigier writes.
Sustainable Spaces, a San Francisco home construction firm, has raised its first round of venture capital.
T. Boone Pickens, it seems, has taken a bath on his energy investments.

As the fate of Linens 'N Things, the Apollo Management-owned retailer that has filed for bankruptcy protection, seems increasingly dire, a second executive has left the company this month, The New York Post reported.

Geography | New Yorkers are among the most neurotic and crabby people in America while North Dakotans are some of the nicest, according to a "personality map" of the United States compiled by Cambridge University researchers. Some traits, like New York's, feed into stereotypes, but others don't. The conscientious Floridian? [London Telegraph, Wall Street Journal]
The Associated Press recaps last week's ratings:
Yahoo's new board on Tuesday approved a new round of discussions with Time Warner over the future of its AOL unit, The Financial Times reported, citing a person familiar with Yahoo's thinking.
John Paulson's hedge fund emerged Tuesday as the biggest short seller of British banks, The Financial Times reported, citing filings made under a new regulatory regime.

Even before the ink dries on a proposed $700 billion bailout for the financial industry, Wall Street players have begun jockeying to be the first ones to snap up distressed investments on the cheap, according to The New York Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin and Eric Dash.

Books | A biography recounts the life of Oscar Wilde through the "staggering" range of books he read, arguing they were the greatest influence on his life. As a teen, Wilde loved French fiction, particularly Balzac. And after his "indecency" conviction, a piercing wound was the auctioning of his cherished book collection to pay creditors. [Literary Review]

Warren E. Buffett, the country's most famous investor and one of the world's richest men, announced on Tuesday that he would invest $5 billion in Goldman Sachs, the embattled Wall Street titan, in a move The New York Times's Ben White says could bolster confidence in the financial markets.
As one by one Wall Street's pure-play investment banks have become a thing of the past, it will be many months before it is clear where Wall Street's downward spiral will stop.
Congress wants Wall Street to feel it where it hurts: the wallet.

The White House waged a multifront campaign Tuesday to persuade Congress to accept its vast economic bailout plan, though many in Congress, still unhappy with what they were hearing, continued to push for changes that would provide stronger protection for taxpayers and impose tougher terms on financial institutions.

Wall Street and the Bush administration's record of financial oversight came under attack at the United Nations on Tuesday, with one world leader after another saying that market turmoil in the United States threatened the global economy, according to The New York Times's Neil MacFarquhar.
When it comes to the Bush administration's $700 billion Wall Street rescue, there is no deficit in terms of Congressional derision, The New York Times's Carl Hulse writes.

Congress took on the $700 billion bailout on Tuesday with what Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, called "the most palpable sense of national crisis since we gathered here in this building immediately following the 9/11 attacks."
For the M&A bankers that have been tossed on the stormy seas engulfing Wall Street investment banks, the idea of joining a boutique advisory may seem like the equivalent of a very cushy life raft.
Longs Drug Stores rebuffed a renewed takeover push by Walgreen, while Longs' largest shareholder said it was willing to take the risk a deal with Walgreen could bring, to get the best price.
Électricité de France will buy British Energy for $23.18 billion in a deal that gives the French company a dominant role in the British nuclear power industry, the companies confirmed Wednesday

Major European banks have begun expanding across the Continent, amassing large pools of capital and customers. Yet bank regulation at the European Union level has hardly kept up, The New York Times's Matthew Saltmarsh says.

Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor and chairman of biotechnology company ImClone Systems fired off a letter to the chief executive of Bristol-Myers Squibb, calling Bristol's revised take-over offer of $62 a share "absurd."

McAfee's move to buy Secure Computing nearly completes the enterprise-security mosaic that McAfee is trying to create, but it also raises a question, The 451 Group says: How well can it integrate all of these far-flung pieces?

The Federal Bureau of Investigation, under pressure to look at possible criminal activity in the financial markets, is expanding its corporate fraud inquiries in the wake of the tumult in the last 10 days, The New York Times's Eric Lichtblau reported.

Federal regulators have subpoenaed recent trading records from several Nymex traders as part of a widening investigation into the sharp rise in oil prices on Monday, according to The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques.

Politics | A Village Voice blog catches flak for suggesting that rappers cool it with their endorsements of Barack Obama (comments at bottom of this post; language advisory). It asks, "Really, isn't there something to be said for keeping the particularly trigger-happy faction of the party under wraps, much like the right does with their lock-and-load lunatics?" [Village Voice]

Stock prices in Asia were mixed early Wednesday as investors continued to struggle with forecasts about the impact the financial turmoil in the United States will have on other parts of the world, The New York Times's David Barboza reported.

Wingecarribee Shire, an idyllic collection of towns and villages with names like Yerrinbool and Burrawang, is nestled among eucalyptus trees and deep sandy gorges in southeastern Australia. Kangaroos, koalas and wallabies wander in its nature reserves, attracting visitors from Sydney, two hours away.
GMAC, the home and auto lender, will sell its home services unit to Brookfield Asset Management of Canada as it expands efforts to raise cash.

Google and Yahoo's deal to let Google place some ads on Yahoo's search pages, currently under review by the Justice Department, should be allowed with limits, the American Antitrust Institute said on Tuesday.
Chancellor Angela Merkel vowed on Tuesday that Germany would strive to keep in place the so-called Volkswagen Law allowing the state of Lower Saxony to hold a blocking minority of Volkswagen.

One year ago today the Well blog posted its first item, "DNA Isn't Destiny," which looked at how lifestyle choices can influence our health. While we certainly had high hopes for the blog, none of us had any idea what we had started.

Lexicon | Deletionpedia is where Wikipedia pages go to die -- an archive of more than 60,000 articles that Wikipedia editors deem too obscure to be worthy of even the status of, say, a complete list of "Jetsons" episodes. Censorship, you cry? Nay, we say! Your "list of films with monkeys in them" lives on! [Arstechnica, Industry Standard, Slashdot]

Science | A leading scientist talks about the politics of therapeutic cloning -- the creation of stems cells from a clone of a patient -- to provide an endless supply of stem cells imprinted with your personal DNA. It could mean transplants that resist rejection -- and a sea change in medicine on a par with changes wrought by antibiotics and vaccines. [Discover]
The United Nations is investigating the impact of a controversial new development on old Edinburgh's status as a World Heritage site.
Video
The designers Christian Lacroix, Karl Lagerfeld and John Galliano each created costumes for Ms. Fleming’s gala showcase for the Metropolitan Opera.
A serial killer pleaded guilty to eight slayings and was sentenced to eight consecutive life terms in prison.
A former Jefferson County commissioner pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice in an investigation of bond sales that financed the county’s almost-bankrupt sewer system.
A woman admitted that she helped her 14-year-old son build a cache of weapons, but investigators still do not know whether she was aware her son was planning a deadly school attack.
Gulf Coast officials asked lawmakers for fast federal money for hurricane recovery and a minimum of bureaucratic red tape.
The House overwhelmingly passed a bill that would give one-time payments to Filipino veterans who fought for the United States in World War II.
The $179 T-Mobile G1 is the latest in a string of challenges to Apple’s popular iPhone.
1. Brett Favre couldn't beat the Patriots, but Chad Pennington (with quite a bit of help from Ronnie Brown) could.Last Week: N/A

It is three weeks into the season, and the Brett Favre-powered Jets are 1-2. Could Chad Pennington have done better?Favre has better numbers over all - his six touchdown passes are tied for the third-most in the league - but the Dolphins haven't suffered; they have outscored and outgained the Jets. The key difference between Pennington, right, and Favre is turnovers. Favre has four this season, Pennington one. The Jets are minus 4 in turnover margin, and each of Favre's turnovers has hurt.
I talked to Tim Kawakami for a print notebook item that ran Wednesday.

Two years ago, the Yankees watched the scoreboards at the Rogers Centre in Toronto. That night, they needed Boston to lose to clinch their ninth consecutive A.L. East title. When the Red Sox score went final, the Yankees' clubhouse erupted in celebration.
Nicholas D. Kristof interviews Somaly Mam, who was sold to the brothels as a young teenager and now runs shelters for rescued girls.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. delivers a speech on foreign policy, Sept. 24, 2008. (Video: MSNBC)
Vikas Bajaj discusses the difficulties in figuring out how to value failed mortgages that are part of the government's $700 billion bailout plan.
Warren Buffett said his Berkshire Hathaway would buy $5 billion in preferred shares of Goldman Sachs, heartening investors.

An article in some editions on Saturday about the sudden and mysterious shuttering of all Manhattan branches of Burritoville, a Mexican fast-food restaurant, misstated the given name of the company’s president. He is Jeffrey Bernstein, not Jonathan. And a reporting credit with the article misstated the surname of a contributor. She is Karen Zraick, not Drake.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Friday about relatives’ approval of a plan to dig up the grave where the Spanish poet Federico García Lorca is believed to be buried referred to him incorrectly. While he was executed by rightist forces soon after the Spanish Civil War started, virtually all of his writing was done before the war. He was not a “Spanish Civil War poet.”.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a deadly bombing outside the United States Embassy in Sana, Yemen, misidentified the militant group that had vowed to retaliate for a Yemeni counterterrorism force raid on a Qaeda safe house Aug. 11. It was the Yemeni branch of Al Qaeda — not Islamic Jihad, a little-known Yemeni group that took responsibility for the embassy attack.

Because of an editing error, the Moscow Journal article on Monday, about Russian audience sensitivities to “Hitler Kaput!” a new Russian film that satirizes the brutal struggle against the Nazis during World War II, misidentified the actor in the lead role. He is Pavel Derevyanko — not Oleg Dolin, who plays the lead in another Russian film, “Wild Field.” (Because of a production error, a passage from this correction was merged in some editions on Tuesday with a Metro correction, below, about The New York Sun.).

An article on Tuesday about the players who starred in the final scheduled game at Yankee Stadium against the Baltimore Orioles on Sunday night misstated the score in the fourth inning when the Yankees’ José Molina hit what would become the last home run at the ballpark. It was tied, 3-3; the Yankees were not trailing by a run.

An article on Tuesday about a House debate on a bill that would limit diversion of water from the Great Lakes’ natural basin referred incorrectly to Quebec, which has adopted a document similar to the bill. Quebec adjoins the St. Lawrence River, which is part of the lakes’ ecosystem, but it does not border the lakes.

An article on Monday about Patricia Q. Stonesifer, who was named chairwoman of the Smithsonian Institution’s Board of Regents, the institution’s governing body, attributed an erroneous distinction to her. She will be the second person to hold the position, not the first. (Roger W. Sant, chairman of the board’s executive committee, preceded her in the job, which was created last year.).

An article on Thursday about Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s record on race and civil rights misstated the timing of a 1978 teachers’ strike over pay issues raised by a busing plan in his hometown, Wilmington, Del. The school district announced the end of the strike on Nov. 20, two weeks after Mr. Biden was re-elected to the Senate. It was not settled in October before the election.

An article on Monday about the financial hurdles faced by The New York Sun, which has said it will close by the end of September if it does not receive new backing, misspelled the name of the Italian newspaper cited as an early model for The Sun. It is Il Foglio, not Il Folio. And a picture caption misidentified one of the editors at a planning meeting. The editor shown standing is Geoffrey Foster, the sports editor, not Kelly Sherin, the photo editor. (Because of a production error, a passage from this correction was merged in some editions on Tuesday with an International correction, above, about the Moscow Journal.).

An article on Tuesday about a new compound that eliminates the explosive potential of ammonium nitrate fertilizer misstated, in some editions, the year of the deadly bombing of the federal building in Oklahoma City. It was in 1995, not 1996.

An article last Wednesday about wild game and other food in Alaska misstated the outcome of a ballot measure in August that called for banning the aerial hunting of wolves, a practice that supporters said helps preserve the moose population. The measure was rejected, not approved.

An article last Wednesday about various labels on egg cartons misidentified the organization that approves the American Humane Certified label. It is the American Humane Association, not the American Humane Society.

Arkansas was penalized for violations involving the sprinter Tyson Gay and a former assistant coach.

The veteran trainer Nacho Beristain will prepare Oscar De La Hoya for his Dec. 6 fight with Manny Pacquiao, De La Hoya said. He began searching for a new trainer three weeks ago after Floyd Mayweather Sr., his longtime cornerman, agreed to train Ricky Hatton for his Nov. 22 bout with Paulie Malignaggi. Mayweather accepted the job before De La Hoya completed plans for his 147-pound fight at the MGM Grand Garden in Las Vegas.

The trainer Larry Jones said he planned to retire after next year’s Breeders’ Cup. His filly Eight Belles collapsed and died after finishing second in the Kentucky Derby. “I’m just physically tired, and it seems like I have a hard time keeping everybody happy,” Jones said. He said that he called several clients and told them not to buy any horses with the intention of having him train them. ¶Average prices at the final session of Keeneland’s September Yearling Sale dropped more than 15 percent from 2007. The Metropolitan Opera plans to introduce an online service providing video and audio recordings of its operas. The service, Met Player, is scheduled to begin on Oct. 22. It will allow users to hear 120 audio recordings and watch 50 full-length operas collected from the Met’s archives, with more to be added in subsequent months. For a monthly subscription fee of $14.99 or an annual cost of $149.99, users will have access to the entire service. Individual videos and audio recordings can also be streamed for small fees. A preview of the service is available at metplayer.org/preview.

The Columbus Symphony Orchestra will resume performances at the Ohio Theater, above, next month after an agreement between managers and musicians on a new three-year contract, The Columbus Dispatch reported. The symphony’s management suspended operations in June after the musicians’ union rejected proposals by the orchestra’s board to cut costs by reducing its roster of full-time musicians, their salaries and performance weeks. The new deal reduces some base salaries and pension contributions for orchestra musicians, and adds a new health plan with higher deductibles. “This is not a win-win; it’s a survival issue at best,” Jim Akins, a musicians’ union official and principal tuba player, said in The Dispatch.

The official unveiling of the renovated Petit Trianon, a chateau on the grounds of the Palace of Versailles, is scheduled for Wednesday. Designed by the architect Ange-Jacques Gabriel at the request of Louis XV, the neo-Classical chateau became a beloved getaway for Marie Antoinette, who forbade all but the closest members of her inner circle to visit it. Despite her wishes, the chateau is scheduled to reopen to the public officially on Oct. 2, as part of France’s Grand Versailles renovation and restoration project, which began in July 2007.

WASSYNG--Seymour , loving husband of Dubby Wassyng, died September 20, age 91, in Great Neck. He attended Cooper Union and worked as an industrial and package designer. He was art director at Revlon, Seagrams, partner in Schwartz-Wassyng, and later Sy Wassyng Inc. He is survived by Wendy Wassyng Roworth and husband John of Providence, Peter Wassyng of Oxnard, Eric and Lynne Wassyng of Centreville, VA, Emily Wassyng and husband Win Lockwood of Brooklyn, and granddaughters Alexis Roworth, Vanessa Roworth, and Samantha Wassyng.

He carries with him the love and memories of family and many friends.

For a certain group of voters, whatever happens from now to Election Day -- debates, new advertisements, October surprises -- will have no impact on their vote. They will have already cast their ballots for president, taking advantage of early voting that is allowed in more than 30 states. Georgia was the first out of the gate on Monday with statewide early voting, though limited early voting also began in parts of Kentucky and Virginia. As of Tuesday, 18,377 Georgians had cast their presidential ballots, said Matt Carrothers, spokesman for Georgia's secretary of state.

Warren E. Buffett, the country's most famous investor and one of the world's richest men, announced on Tuesday that he would invest $5 billion in Goldman Sachs, the embattled Wall Street titan, in a move that could bolster confidence in the financial markets. Until now, Mr. Buffett, who has navigated the stock market with legendary prowess, has largely refrained from investing in the stricken financial industry, saying repeatedly that things could get worse.

TABER--George , health care leader and land conservationist, died of cancer, Saturday, September 20, 2008 at the age of 79. George H. Taber was Chairman for 18 years and Chairman Emeritus of the University Pittsburgh Medical Center. When he retired in 2000 UPMC was a $3.5 billion organization and now has double the revenues with 20 hospitals and 48,000 employees. George Taber joined UPMC while a Vide President, Trustee and Director of the Richard King Mellon Foundation. His philanthropic actions at the Mellon Foundation realized among the largest of land conservation programs in the United States as well as abroad, with land grants into the hundreds of thousands of acres benefitting the National Park Service and the US Fish and Wildlife Service among others. Notable grants were the expansion and protection of Civil War battlefield sites such as Antietam, Fredericksburg, Petersburg, Chancellorsville and Manassas. He was a graduate of Harvard College and Saint Marks School. He is survived by his wife, Janet Beebe Taber, and three sons, Stephen Taber of So Paulo, Brazil, Michael Taber of Fairfax, Vermont, and John Taber of Freedom, Pennsylvania, and five grandchildren.

deGUNZBURG--Baroness Jacqueline , born in Nice, France April 7, 1915. With great sorrow, we announce the passing of Baroness de Gunzburg, September 20, 2008 in Morges, Switzerland in her 94th year. She will be deeply mourned by her children, Baron Jean-Louis de Gunzburg, Madame Eliane de Gunzburg-Beckman, Baron Gerard de Gunzburg and their spouses; her grandchildren, Veronique Heim-Albersmeier and her spouse, Jacques Heim, Alexia de Gunzburg, Gregory de Gunzburg; and her twin great-grandchildren, Julia and Vanessa Albersmeier. New York was her home for over 60 years, where she was involved with the French-American community and was an active contributor for many years to the ''French-American Aid for Children'' and the ''Committee of French-American Wives''. Baroness de Gunzburg was an avid traveller and had many interests. Her warmth and kindness endeared her to her many wonderful and dear friends. She will be greatly missed by her family and her loyal friends. A funeral service was held in Saint-Prex, Switzerland on September 24th.

While both campaigns have been trying to paint the candidates' ages as a negative factor, voters do not seem to share their views, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The average age of a president of the United States when he takes office is 55. Both presidential nominees this year fall well outside of that average: Senator Barack Obama will be 47 at the inauguration on Jan. 20, and Senator John McCain will be 72 (which would make him the oldest first-term president in history).

SHENKER--Joseph . The Trustees of Bank Street College of Education, together with the entire Bank Street community, deeply mourn the passing of Joseph Shenker, President from 1988-1995. He established the Principals Institute, created the College's first Diversity Committee, spearheaded efforts to put Bank Street at the forefront of quality teacher training, greatly increased outreach to the public schools, and led the first capital campaign. We remember Joe Shenker with admiration and affection, and will always be grateful for his devoted leadership and service. Elizabeth D. Dickey, President Anthony Asnes, Chair of the Board of Trustees

Green Inc. is a new blog from The New York Times devoted to energy and the environment. It's a daily churn of insights, observations and dispatches from that often contentious place where business, politics and sustainability meet. Here are excerpts from some of the first entries, which can be read in their entirety at greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com.

SAUL KRAVITZ knew his house was inefficient. The kitchen was cold in the winter and hot in the summer. It was always hotter or colder upstairs than downstairs. And his gas and electric bills were too high. Mr. Kravitz, an engineer at the J. Craig Venter Institute in Rockville, Md., had conducted his own assessment and concluded that his 41-year-old house was well sealed but probably needed some insulation. ''I was convinced I had a pretty tight house,'' he said.

IN 1989, Arnold J. Goldman was the world's undisputed sun king. His realm was a desolate patch of the Mojave Desert north of Los Angeles, where his company, Luz International, created the world's largest solar energy installation. At the time, Luz's plants generated roughly 90 percent of the solar energy on the planet. Two years later, his reign was over, done in by an uninterested public. While the solar field that Luz built for Southern California Edison still runs today, the company went kaput, unable to compete profitably with the lower costs of companies producing electricity from traditional sources.

GARBER--Sidney, prominent Chicago jeweler, passed away peacefully Saturday, September 20, at the age of 89, in Wainscott, NY. He is survived by his wife, Deanna Berman Garber, his daughter Brooke Garber Neidich (Daniel), son Blair Garber (Barbara Parker), beloved older sister Esther Port, niece Norma Lee Newberger, grandchildren Jon, Stephen, and Mallory Neidich and nephews Matthew Newberger and Dr. Todd Newberger (Dr. Lori Newberger), great-niece Sarah Beth and his wifes children Dana Sanders (George), Jodi Berman (Jeffrey Schwamm) and Jay Berman (Michelle). Born in Chicago in 1919, Sidney Garber attended the University of Illinois at Urbana, until his enlistment in the Army Air Corps. Lt. Garber, a decorated veteran of WWII served as Lead Navigator of the 454th BG 737th Sq. 15th AF from 1944-45. The son of a watchmaker, Mr. Garber opened his first store in 1946. Over the next half century he became one of the preeminent independent jewelers in America. Sidney Garber built his business on innovative elegance and a commitment to excellence in design and craftsmanship. A private graveside service was held September 22nd in Wainscott, NY. A memorial service will be held at Chicago Sinai Congregation at 15 West Delaware Place on Monday, October 6th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the NYU Child Study Center Open Door Fund, 577 First Avenue NY, NY 10016. GARBER--Sidney. In my previous post, “Student in a Strange Land,” I mentioned briefly that our school, the International Community School (I.C.S.), works with a very diverse population of students and families. I.C.S. represents over 40 different countries and 50 languages. One of the communities we serve is Clarkston, Ga., which is home to about 26,000 refugees. It is often said that Clarkston is one of the most diverse square miles in the United States. A community as diverse as this presents a complex challenge: In a place with so many different values and belief systems, what role should an educator play?

I have been living in my rent-stabilized apartment for more than 30 years. When I become a senior citizen, will I still be subject to high-income rent deregulation, or do the laws provide special protections for seniors? (This is assuming that my rent will exceed $2,000 a month and that my income will exceed $175,000 two years in a row.)

In a previous Q&A, a reader who owned a co-op with his mother and brother and who was planning to rent out the apartment wanted to know whether the mother could take responsibility for the income from the rental because she was in a low tax bracket. The lawyer who answered the question said that under the tax laws, all three owners would have to claim their share of the income on their own tax returns.

Gasoline is more expensive. Milk, rice, butter, corn--it's all going through the roof." So, restaurants like his will "focus more on vegetable and grain dishes in which meat adds flavor, not heft." [Esquire]

After the past two weeks, few of us need convincing that the end of an era is upon us. Patricia Martin argued as much in a visionary book, "RenGen: The Rise of the Cultural Consumer -- And What it Means to Your Business," published in June of last year. Though Ms. Martin did not specifically forecast a financial meltdown, she came close and did observe that "we are sloughing off the old skin that defined us as unenlightened" -- as part of what she says is a death of an existing civilization.

I recently read Bryan Caplan's book "The Myth of the Rational Voter: Why Democracies Choose Bad Policies," which argues that voters are systematically biased against good economic policy. (Good economic policy in this case is generally defined as whatever ideas economists agree upon.) Professor Caplan argues that it is therefore in politicians' best interest to advocate bad economic policies. Inversely, any politician who pushes sound economic policies -- or worse, is a trained economist -- will have a tough time getting elected.

The war between Russia and Georgia has receded from the front pages, but the questions it has raised are still urgent. Russia's aggression toward Georgia, which greatly exceeded what was necessary to achieve its stated goals, and Moscow's continuing efforts to weaken and destabilize Georgia, make it clear that Russia is a real threat to several U.S. allies. From Azerbaijan to Latvia, the Kremlin's actions have been duly noted. The next American administration will confront the fallout of this war and face a hard challenge: It is not possible to craft Georgia policy without looking at the broader U.S.-Russia policy, while it is not possible to craft a broader U.S.-Russia policy without recognizing the role the U.S. plays in creating tension between Russia and Georgia.

Reclining seductively on the corner of Bowery and Houston Street is the mysterious wheat-pasted figure of a two-story-wide naked woman. First appearing Sept. 17, the mural, covering bricks and riot grates, is part of a two-week art show that opens tonight in a temporary downtown art space.

Scientists from the University of Colorado, Boulder, and the United States Geological Survey have provided Dot Earth with a closeup view of the remarkable rate of erosion along parts of Alaska's thawing Arctic Ocean coast. The video clip below is one month of crumbling, from late June through late July this year, at a point east of Barrow, the northernmost community in the United States. It's clear that simple thawing is much more of an influence than wave action at this spot.

Music | When Metallica fans say a record's too loud to hear the details, you know you've got a problem. The metal band's new album is stoking anew the aesthetic war over flattening music's dynamic range to make it seem louder and stand out on radio and iPods. Result: "a tidal wave of aural blandness." Hey, even Spinal Tap's amps only went up to 11. [Wall Street Journal]

Months of aggressive campaigning by both candidates have significantly altered the way voters perceive them - Senator John McCain is largely seen as someone who is spending more of his time attacking his opponent than spelling out what he would do as president, while Senator Barack Obamacontinues to be seen as a candidate who is spending more of his time explaining what he would do as president rather than attacking his opponent, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. This was not the case earlier this summer. In early July, both candidates were thought to berunning positive campaigns.In the latest poll, a majority of voters, 56 percent, said Mr. Obama is spending his time making it clear what he would do if elected, rather than attacking the Republican candidate. Most voters say the opposite of Mr. McCain. Only 38 percent of those polled said Mr. McCain was explaining what he would do as president, while 53 percent said he was attacking Mr. Obama. In July, 63 percent of the voters surveyed said Mr. McCain was running a positive campaign.

Sifting through the rubble of another lost weekend for the Pac-10, where Arizona State proved no match for Georgia and Boise State passed its way past Oregon, it's clear that the conference is on the way to one of its worst seasons in decades.

It had to happen sooner or later. After writing about the solar industry and its attending rebate programs for so long - after covering the expense, the state subsidies, the tax credits from the feds, the allure of lower electricity bills - I finally took a good hard look at my own roof, with its perfect southern exposure, and decided to take the leap.
Your team has no excuse.

On his blog this morning, the Harvard economist Greg Mankiw takes issue with my argument in Wednesday's column that the government should demand ownership stakes in any companies it bails out. But I think he -- or at least the anonymous friend whom he quoted in the post -- was swatting down a different case than the one I was actually making.

Editor's Note: Hung Huang, chief executive of a Chinese publishing empire, writes us from Beijing. For her first post we asked her to talk about how censorship affects the economic development of businesses like hers; below, she describes how government censors are paying less attention to material that was once considered too sexy for Chinese audiences, but still seem very concerned about politically sensitive information.
UBS said Thursday that it has hired Jeffrey Mayer, the former co-head of fixed income at Bear Stearns, as its new joint global head of fixed income for its investment bank.

Senator John McCain may have disappointed many expectant voters and debate viewers with the decision to suspend his campaign, but none more so than a late-night talk show host on CBS, Bill Carter reports.

Aired Wednesday night on NBC: John McCain wants to postpone Friday night's presidential debate, and he has temporarily suspended his campaign. Yeah, so, apparently, this news about Clay Aiken being gay has affected him more than anybody thought.

The nation's first cap-and-trade program for greenhouse gases got under way Thursday morning, with an auction that allowed utilities in 10 Northeastern states to bid on the right to emit carbon dioxide.

But nobody told his vice presidential candidate, Sarah Palin, who is still circling the theater in the white minivan, waiting to pick him up.

Watching a dozen new citizens take their oath of allegiance in the majestic Registry Room at the Ellis Island National Monument on Tuesday -- a moment to stir even an old reporter's heart -- it was easy to lose sight of the fact that the ceremony's principal purpose was to introduce the new Peopling of America® Center. The exhibition rooms in the $20 million center, which is to open in 2011, will broaden the scope of the immigrant story told at the museum.

When Daniela Andrier was speaking with Fabio Zambernardi, Miuccia Prada's right hand, about possible directions for the new Prada men's fragrance they wanted to create, Zambernardi proposed a somewhat unusual idea. In 2007, Andrier had created a women's scent for Prada called Infusion d'Iris; he told her that he had been fascinated by the Prada bath soap scented with the perfume. He proposed a masculine fragrance that smelled like this soap -- or, to be more precise, like the skin of a man who had, say, found the soap in a woman's bath and washed his body with it. Andrier thought about it and went to work.

"Because of the strong support Obama is attracting among younger voters, and as the number of Americans who are reachable only by cell phones rises, interest continues to grow in the question of whether public opinion polls that do not include cell phones are accurately measuring the relative levels of support for the two candidates," report those surveyors of the American soul at The Pew Research Center for the People & the Press. To remedy that, the center looks at "three major election surveys with both cell phone and landline samples since the conclusion of the primaries."

I've heard friends wonder, when presented with a nicely crisped piece of fish, "How do they get such a fabulous crust on there?" The fish isn't fried, nor is it breaded: it's just perfectly browned. The detectives among them notice that the fish is perfectly browned on one side only, and that's the key. In fact, it is cooked on one side only -- or nearly so.

Just four games in the junior ranks on Wednesday night. There are four more regular-season games on Thursday, which will also see the return of the United States Hockey League's Fall Classic preseason event, which is being contested in Sioux City, Iowa. In the early games at the USHL event, Sioux Falls beat Chicago, 5-4, Indiana downed Omaha, 6-2, and Green Bay defeated Lincoln, 3-2. More on these games in Friday's junior report.

The Big East will open conference play this weekend with Connecticut and Louisville, two teams coming off strong nonconference victories, meeting in prime time on Friday night. Both teams topped Big 12 opponents a week ago: Louisville beat Kansas State by 38-29, while UConn edged out the vastly improved Baylor Bears, 31-28. Louisville Coach Steve Kragthorpe, hoping to build upon last Wednesday's impressive home win, understands the importance of starting strong in conference play against a strong Connecticut team.

A naked and apparently emotionally disturbed man fell to his death from a building ledge in Brooklyn after an officer shot him with a Taser stun gun, the police said. The police and witnesses said he had been yelling at passers-by and swinging a long light bulb tube at officers before he fell. The man, identified by the police as Inman Morales, 35, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center with serious head trauma after falling about 10 feet to the ground, witnesses said. He was later pronounced dead.

At the invitation of President Bush, both of the presidential candidates plan to return to Washington on Thursday for meetings at the White House and on Capitol Hill to discuss the state of the economy and the government's massive bailout proposal.
Some of the most stressful jobs in finance today are at Goldman Sachs, including those of the chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein and the president, Gary Cohn.
General Electric, citing "recent dramatic developments in the financial markets," said Thursday that it cut its third-quarter and full year forecast and halted its stock-buyback plans.
One of the chief concerns about the Treasury Department's $700 billion bailout plan is that the same Wall Street firms that helped create the crisis could make a killing cleaning it up.

Throngs of depositors lined up outside the headquarters and branches of the Bank of East Asia in Honk Kong on Wednesday to withdraw their money, highlighting widespread anxiety in Asia that Wall Street's recent difficulties might spread across the Pacific, The New York Times's Keith Bradsher and Heather Timmons reported.

President Bush appealed to the nation Wednesday night to support a $700 billion plan to avert a widespread financial meltdown, and signaled that he is willing to accept tougher controls over how the money is spent, The New York Times' Sheryl Gay Stolberg and David M. Herszenhorn reported.

A new bout of anxiety gripped the credit markets on Wednesday as banks hoarded cash and investors once again rushed for the safest of investments, like Treasury bills, The New York Times's Vikas Bajaj and Michael M. Grynbaum said.

The following is one in a series of reflections from Micheline Maynard, a business correspondent in Detroit, on her recent switch from a Lexus S.U.V. to a hybrid electric Toyota Prius. Share your thoughts on the topic here.

What would you pay, sight unseen, for a house that nobody wants, on a hard-luck street where no houses are selling? That question is easy compared with the one confronting the Treasury Department as Washington works toward a vast bailout of financial institutions, The New York Times's Vikas Bajaj writes.

Federal regulators are moving quickly to broker a deal for Washington Mutual as the giant saving-and-loan comes under mounting financial pressure, The New York Times's Eric Dash and Andrew Ross Sorkin reported, citing people briefed on the negotiations.

Lehman Brothers chief executive Richard S. Fuld Jr. reached out to General Electric head Jeffrey Immelt about making an investment in the embattled bank prior to its collapse, The New York Post reported, citing unnamed sources.

Lehman Brothers' sale of its investment-management division has been held up by wrangling over how to run the business and pay fund managers, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the talks.
Maybe the American taxpayers should be asking Warren Buffett to be negotiating on their behalf, The New York Times's David Leonhardt muses.

World | Beyond Hillary and Sarah: an article says "gender-based quotas" to help women reach power are catching on globally. Some 110 countries have rules favoring the election of women, including Afghanistan, Iraq and Sudan. Post-genocide Rwanda allots 30 percent of its Parliament seats to women. Of course, not everyone's crazy about all this. [Economist]

Americans' anger is in full bloom, jumping off the screen in capital letters and exclamation points, in the e-mail in-boxes of elected representatives in the nation's capital, The New York Times' Sheryl Gay Stolberg reported.

In an effort to determine whether any traders were involved in abusive short selling, the Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered more than two dozen hedge funds to turn over trading information, The Wall Street Journal said citing unnamed sources.

Hedge funds are taking shelter. The Financial Times reported that funds charging large fees for sophisticated trading strategies aimed at outperforming the wider market have collectively put $100 billion in simple money market funds.
Private equity deal-makers' pay may drop by 75 percent after the credit crunch as firms take longer to invest their funds, British financier Guy Hands said in an interview with Bloomberg News.
After taking over the North American assets of Lehman Brothers, Barclays Capital Inc. has hired the firm's entire energy investment banking team in Houston.
Babcock & Brown, the infrastructure investment company, denied takeover speculation as its stock rose for a fifth day in Sydney trading, Bloomberg News reported.

To some Western analysts, it is beginning to look a lot like 1989. In recent days, Japan's once formidable megabanks and financial titans are returning to the world financial stage after an absence of almost two decades, buying pieces of Wall Street institutions, writes The New York Times's Martin Fackler.
Citigroup may sell its Primerica life insurance unit to J.C. Flowers & Company and Protective Life, Bloomberg News reported, citing people with knowledge of the talks.
Rosetta Stone, a maker of language learning software, has filed to raise up to $115 million in an initial public offering, MarketWatch reported.
BNP Paribas's chief executive, Baudouin Prot, said France's largest bank would consider acquiring "distressed" banks in the United States, according to Bloomberg News.
The Securities and Exchange Board of India is said to be likely to discuss clearing applications through the foreign venture capital investor route when its board meets on Oct. 6.
Thanks to recent tax discounts, a growing number of television series are being filmed throughout New York’s five boroughs.

Stifel Financial and The Western and Southern Life Insurance have priced a public offering of an aggregate of 1.7 million shares of Stifel common stock at $45 per share, according to The St. Louis Business Journal.
Austin Ventures has closed on two new venture funds totaling $900 million, according to The Austin Business Journal.

Film | On movie wisdom, "the information we absorb inadvertently while sitting in the dark": A Paris room always has the Eiffel Tower in the window. There's no such thing as a good rich man (unless incognito). Men and women who loathe each other fall in love and marry. And that likable minor character in the opening scenes? He's toast. [National Post]

Warren Buffett's $5 billion investment in Goldman Sachs shows that shaken investors have been calmed by the $700 billion U.S. financial sector bailout plan and they are reopening their wallets to the industry, fund manager Bill Miller said, according to Reuters.

Transmeta has hung up a for sale sign. The semiconductor technology maker which earlier this year passed on a $15.50 per share offer from Riley Investment Management, is now seeking another buyer, reported The Daily Deal.

HSBC chief Stephen Green has spoken out in support of plans by Britain's Financial Services Authority to assess banks' compensation structures and to perhaps force them to hold more capital, according to The Daily Telegraph.
Tanganyika Oil has announced it will be acquired by Sinopec International Petroleum Exploration and Production for 2 billion Canadian dollars ($1.9 billion).

Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines airlines are crossing off one more item on their checklist for becoming the world's biggest carrier, with shareholder votes at both companies Thursday expected to overwhelmingly back the deal combining the two.

Goldman Sachs doesn't intend to let its newly-raised $10 billion burn a hole in its pocket. The Daily Telegraph reported that the $5 billion Goldman received from Warren Buffett and the further $5 billion from institutional investors will be used to buy assets either from the U.S. government's planned $700 billion bail-out fund or from banks directly.

Science | Neuroscientists are studying how to rewire the mind to open up the holy grail of creativity. Most brains are lazy, relying on past experience to process perceptions. Seeing things differently (like, say, a Steve Jobs) requires "new neural pathways" to break this rote cycle. Quoth Mark Twain: "Education consists mainly in what we have unlearned." [Fast Company]
As India's equities are facing their worst year on record, JPMorgan Chase plans to double its private equity investments in the country to $1 billion.

Politics | A blogger wonders if Maine's moose hunters, sporting brethren of Sarah Palin, could tip a razor-thin Electoral College vote to McCain-Palin. While Maine looks heavily pro-Obama, its four electoral votes are not winner-take-all. So if hunter-heavy western Maine swings just one electoral vote to the moose-hunter ticket, well ... [New Republic]
A retrospective makes the Irish-born painter suddenly look fresh.

An article on Tuesday about a request from officials in Galveston, Tex., to Congress for about $2.2 billion in disaster relief misstated the number of patients evacuated from the University of Texas Medical Branch to other hospitals because of Hurricane Ike. It was 296, not “about 400.”.

Could France be the next bubble poised to burst? Data compiled by the Financial Times suggests France's housing market is "following a similar pattern to Spain," a report sure to make investors spew their lattes.

A jury has been seated in the trial of Senator Ted Stevens, a veteran Alaska Republican who is facing seven felony counts related to gift he received from an oil services contractor.

The Center for Capacity Building, a small program at the National Center for Atmospheric Research working to boost poor countries' ability to withstand drought and other climate shocks, saw its $500,000 annual budget eliminated this summer. After experts on resilience and development criticized the move in an article in The Times, on Dot Earth and on the Prometheus science-policy blog of Roger A. Pielke Jr., the Rockefeller Foundation took note.
The state agency that administers programs for poor families is cutting almost $80 million from its budget.
Spurred by the recent train crash that killed 25 people in Los Angeles, the House passed legislation requiring more rest for train workers and technology that can stop a train in its tracks.

Two liberal groups - one of them directed by a brother of the Democratic Party chairman Howard Dean - will begin running a graphic attack advertisement Thursday morning raising questions about Senator John McCain's health. Showing vivid and unflattering images of the fresh scar that appeared on Senator McCain's face immediately after his last operation for melanoma skin cancer eight years ago, the commercial ends with a screen headline that reads, "Why won't John McCain release his medical records?" (Mr. McCain, 72, did invite a limited group of reporters to inspect more than 1,100 pages of his medical records in May, though he gave them only a three-hour window in which to review the documents.)
A program that helps poor countries reduce their vulnerability to climate-related hazards will move to the University of Colorado, Boulder, under a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation.

New England’s rainy summer has fall-foliage experts predicting a top-notch season for autumn color. But if the thought of topping off the tank has you shaking in fear, consider some of the region’salternatives to gas-guzzling tours.

When Mike Mussina takes the mound Sunday, he’ll be going for the first 20-win season in his long and consistent career. Over the years, Mussina has had several brushes with notable achievements — earlier this week he called them “significant almosts” — including a perfect game broken up in the ninth inning and, in 1996, a blown save away from 20 wins. Indeed, no pitcher has ever won more career games than Mussina (269) without hitting 20 in one year.

A chart in some copies on Wednesday with an article in some editions about the Yankees’ failure to make the playoffs misstated the last season they missed the postseason. As the article noted, it was 1993 — not 1995. (There were no playoffs in 1994.).

The Patient Voices column on Tuesday, about Dr. Ron Davis, who has pancreatic cancer, misstated his role in the Ask Me 3 program, in which patients are encouraged to ask their doctors three crucial questions about their health. Although Dr. Davis promotes the program, he did not develop it.
An article on Wednesday about the positions of John McCain and Barack Obama on the proposed bailout of financial firms misstated the estimated cost of the package. It is $700 billion, not million.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Richard Armstrong, the next director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, misstated the date of the next Carnegie International, an exhibition organized by the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh, where Mr. Armstrong is the director. (Mr. Armstrong, who announced his resignation from the Carnegie in June, said he wanted to give his successor there sufficient time to organize the next international.) It is tentatively scheduled for 2012-13, not 2010. The current Carnegie International continues through Jan. 11.

An article on Sept. 16 about a political crisis in Thailand misstated the family connection between former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra and his brother-in-law, Somchai Wongsawat, who was nominated by the governing party to be the next prime minister. Mr. Somchai is married to a sister of Mr. Thaksin’s, not a sister of Mr. Thaksin’s wife.

A brief article on Tuesday about a study of soft drink consumption in schools misstated part of the findings. The study found that at schools where soft drinks were not sold, about 4 percent more students — not fewer — reported not having drunk any soda in the last week, compared with students at schools where soft drinks were sold.
An obituary on Tuesday about Nancy Hicks Maynard, a newspaper publisher and journalism educator, included a number of errors.

A dance review on Wednesday about a program by the Paris Opera Ballet that included “Triade,” by Benjamin Millepied, misstated the year that Mr. Millepied joined the New York City Ballet, where he is now a principal dancer. It was 1995, not 1985.

An obituary on Saturday about Mauricio Kagel, the avant-garde composer, misstated the name of a group with which he collaborated early in his career. It is Agrupación Nueva Música, not Agrupación Nuevo Mundo.

A front-page headline on Wednesday with an article about Warren E. Buffett’s plan to invest $5 billion in the Wall Street investment banking firm Goldman Sachs described that company as “ailing.” While its stock has been battered and it has agreed to tighter government regulation and wants to raise more capital from investors, “embattled” would have been a more accurate headline description of Goldman’s state than “ailing.”.

An article on Sept. 3 about the rise of the D.I.Y. craft movement misstated the title of an article in the August/September issue of American Craft magazine. The article, by Sabrina Gschwandtner, was titled “Let ’Em Eat Cake” — not “DIY Grows Up: The Politics of the Do-It-Yourself Movement,” which was a descriptive line on the magazine’s cover.

An article last Thursday about desks that include treadmills stated that Dr. James Levine, an endocrinologist at the Mayo Clinic, invented the first known treadmill desk. After the article was published, Seth Roberts, an emeritus professor of psychology at the University of California, Berkeley, pointed out that he had created such a desk in 1996, eight years before Dr. Levine.
Prosecutors commissioned construction of a full-size model of the hotel room that O.J. Simpson and five friends raided.

The Department of Defense has identified 4,165 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 599 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:.
President Bush’s explanation about how the rescue bill would unclog the lines of credit made the whole thing sound less important than a Liquid-Plumr commercial.
As the savings-and-loan comes under mounting financial pressure, regulators are moving quickly to broker a deal, according to people briefed on the talks.
Rivals of Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley shouldn’t expect relief soon. Neither should their shareholders.
“In Conflict” is a sober and very affecting docudrama about veterans of the war in Iraq.
Somehow, after frittering away a four-run lead, the Mets squandered numerous chances with runners in scoring position and lost a great opportunity to gain on Philadelphia.

Students at N.Y.U.’s Stern School of Business are charged with investing nearly $2 million of the university’s $2.2 billion endowment over the course of the semester.
Taro Aso, once an unpopular foreign minister, is now Japan’s prime minister. His success depends on his ability to modernize and quell regional tensions.
Until Washington takes more responsibility for addressing global warming, the states should take the lead.

A week after assigning three United States national team players to each of its seven franchises, Women’s Professional Soccer held its draft of international players in New York. The investigation into the eligibility of the Chinese women’s team in Beijing has been expanded to include members of the 2000 squad, which won the bronze medal in Sydney. International gymnastics officials are examining whether Yang Yun and Dong Fangxiao, in particular, were old enough to compete. The investigation is continuing a month after the Beijing Games ended, and there is no timetable for when it will be finished.

The United States Olympian Demetrius Andrade will make his professional debut Oct. 23 at the Northern Quest Casino in eastern Washington. Andrade, 20, from Providence, R.I., was the world champion amateur welterweight in 2007, but lost to South Korea’s Kim Jung-joo in a quarterfinal bout in Beijing last month. He angrily criticized the judging after his loss, echoing the complaints of several fighters on an American team that came home with just one bronze medal. His opponent for the October bout had not yet been selected.

Buddy Marucci and George Zahringer advanced to the final of the Senior Amateur Championship, winning quarterfinal and semifinal matches at Shady Oaks Country Club in Fort Worth. Marucci eliminated John Grace, a 17-time Shady Oaks club champion, 3 and 2, in the morning quarterfinals, then beat Frank Ford III of Charleston, S.C., 2-up in the afternoon semifinals. Zahringer, 55, a New Yorker who won the 2002 United States Mid-Amateur, edged Randy Nichols of Connersville, Ind., 1-up in the semifinals with a par on No. 18.

The architect Rafael Viñoly has been selected as the master planner for New York University’s new Abu Dhabi campus in the United Arab Emirates, the university is to announce on Thursday. The campus, to open in 2012, will be in the Marina District of Saadiyat Island and will eventually serve about 2,000 students. Other institutions planning projects on the island include the Louvre, the Guggenheim, the Sheikh Zayed National Museum and a performing arts center. The school will be the cornerstone of what N.Y.U. is calling Global Network University, where faculty members and students from New York or Abu Dhabi spend semesters at N.Y.U.’s study-abroad sites on five continents.

Metallica is No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a second week in a row after its new record, “Death Magnetic” (Warner Brothers), sold 337,000 more copies, and Ne-Yo opened in second place with “Year of the Gentleman” (Def Jam), which sold 250,000. In a week crowded with new releases, Nelly’s “Brass Knuckles” (Universal Motown) opened at No. 3 with 84,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan; “Learn to Live” (Capitol Nashville), the new country album by Darius Rucker of Hootie and the Blowfish, sold 60,000 to bow at No. 5; DJ Khaled’s new “We Global” (Def Jam) is No. 7 with 49,000; and Buckcherry’s “Black Butterfly” (Atlantic) reached No. 8 in its first week with 47,000 sales. Kid Rock’s sleeper hit “Rock N Roll Jesus” (Atlantic) fell one spot to No. 4.

The creative team behind “Dreamgirls,” the movie, is getting a shot at the Oscar show. Laurence Mark, who produced the musical film in 2006, was named producer of the 81st annual Academy Awards ceremony on Wednesday, while Bill Condon, the “Dreamgirls” screenwriter and director, was named executive producer. The Oscar show is scheduled for broadcast on Feb. 22 on ABC. A primary goal, Mr. Mark said, will be to bring a wider range of movies into the presentation, whose host has not been named. “The Oscars should, of course, celebrate excellence,” Mr. Mark said. “But we also think it might be fun to celebrate the films of the year in general.” About 32 million viewers, a record low, watched this year’s broadcast, which Jon Stewart hosted.

Ratings for the new crime show “The Mentalist” helped CBS eke out a victory on Tuesday as the most-watched network against Day 2 of ABC’s ratings juggernaut “Dancing With the Stars.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, “The Mentalist” attracted 15.5 million viewers. The show made its debut between CBS’s “NCIS” at 8 p.m., which garnered its largest premiere in its six seasons (17.7 million), and “Without a Trace” at 10 (11.4 million). But among adults 18 to 49 CBS ranked third behind ABC with its two-hour block of “Dancing With the Stars” from 9 to 11 (18.2 million) and Fox, which led the night in that age group but placed third in total viewers.

Having conquered the world of hip-hop, Kanye West, below, will next be dipping his bling-covered hands into a puppet show for Comedy Central, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. West, the multiplatinum-selling rapper, producer and occasional “Entourage” guest star, is an executive producer on a television pilot tentatively titled “Alligator Boots,” a hip-hop-influenced puppet comedy and variety series that is conceived as a harder, better, faster, stronger update of “The Muppet Show.” The series, being considered for Comedy Central’s 2009 schedule, would feature musical contributions from Mr. West and the rapper Rhymefest and different celebrity hosts in each episode.

MEANS--David , advertising executive, died peacefully on September 21, 2008. Mr. Means graduated from the Taft School and Amherst College, and served in the CIA in Korea. At NW Ayer, he was Executive Vice President, Chief Administrative Officer, and on the Board of Directors. He is survived by his wife Nancy; his children and their spouses, Elizabeth Means and Stephen Gardner, Susan Means Drake and Daniel Drake, David (Jr.)and Katherine Means; and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be 3pm, Friday, September 26 at St. Mark's Church in New Canaan. The family appreciates gifts to Waveny Care Center, 3 Farm Road, New Canaan, CT.

AUSTER--Ida Brown , on September 24, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Philip Auster and late Harvey Brown. Loving mother of Aaron and Myra, Lee and Nina and Stephen. Cherished grandmother of Seth and Hilary, Scott and Stephanie, Peter and Mackenzie, Lauren and Peter, Amy and Glenn. Great-grandmother of Lily, Parker and Sage. Devoted sister of Irving Schneider.
