MOSEL--Tad . (1922-2008) Memorial service for Tad Mosel, Pulitzer Prize playwright, will be held Monday, September 29, at 10am, St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Ave. at 53rd St. A reception will follow.

BALLARD--Jeannette Haien , died on September 23, 2008 after a precipitous decline in health following a heart attack on July 29. Born in the early 1920s to a small DutchAmerican family, Jeannette was the youngest of four children. Demonstrating precocious talents in both writing and music, Jeannette was home-schooled with her brothers before attending the University of Michigan; in 1943, 1944 and 1945, she won four University of Michigan English Department Hopwood Prizes for ''minor' and ''summer'' poetry and for her extended narrative poem, ''Rip Van Winkles Dream.'' In addition, Jeannette per formed extensively as a pianist throughout the mid-West before and immediately after her 1948 marriage to Ernest Ballard, then a law student at the University of Michigan. In 1950, the Ballards moved to New York City, from then on their permanent home. Pursuing her professional career under her maiden name, Jeannette Haien taught piano privately and, subsequently, as a member of the piano faculty of Mannes College of Music (1969-1991); she toured biennially with the cultural outreach programs of the United States Information Agency in Europe, Asia and Central America throughout the 1960s and 1970s. During the early 1980's, Haien turned her energies increasingly to writing and, in 1986, published ''The All of It,'' for which she garnered strong critical praise and the Sue Kaufman Prize for First Fiction awarded by the American Academy of Arts and Letters in 1987. Haien's second novel, ''Matters of Chance'' was published in 1997. Jeannette's husband of 60 years died on September 14 of this year. Jeannette Haien Ballard is survived by a daughter, Jean Ballard Terepka, and a grandson, Henry Ballard Terepka, both of New York City, in addition to two nieces and one nephew. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations in memory of Jeannette Haien Ballard may be made to the American Academy of Arts and Letters at 633 West 155 Street, New York City, NY, 10032-1799.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- Plaxico Burress will appeal his suspension by the Giants that will keep him away from the team for one game and almost two weeks of practice, according to his agent, Drew Rosenhaus. Burress, the star wide receiver who caught the game-winning touchdown in last season's Super Bowl, was suspended Wednesday, the Giants announced, for violating team rules.

DISERIO--Eugene A. , a retired attorney, died at his home in New Canaan, CT on September 22nd. He was 81. Mr. Diserio is survived by his wife, Roseanne C. Diserio, three daughters, a son and 11 grandchildren. He was a graduate of Fordham University and Fordham Law School and was a founding partner in the Stamford, CT firm of Diserio Martin O'Connor & Castiglione. Mr. Diserio was an active and involved civic leader, dedicated family man and poet.

FOLEY--Gerard M. , died peacefully at his apartment in New York City September 17, 2008 aged 92. He is survived by a daughter, Joan, of New Orleans, a son, Duncan, of New York City, five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Gerard Foley had a distinguished career as an industrial physicist specializing in temperature measurement. His remarkable photographs are available at http://wilowud.net. A Memorial will take place at the Williams Residence, 720 West End Avenue, Saturday, October 18, 2-4pm.

JACOBS--David R., M.D . Lenox Hill Hospital is deeply saddened by the loss of this esteemed physician, leader and friend. Dr. Jacobs served as Section Chief of Endocrinology and impressed colleagues and patients with his intellect, gentility and compassion. He was a longtime supporter of the Hospital's mission and his leadership and dedication will truly be missed. Our sincere condolences are extended to the Jacobs family. William O. Hiltz, Chairman, Board of Trustees Jack Ansell, M.D., Chairman, Department of Medicine Vicken Pamoukian, M.D., President, Physicians Attending Association Gladys George, President and CEO

LAMBO--Mary . The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Jill B. Greiss, President

OKEN--Madeline , 87, on September 22. She will be deeply missed by her daughters Dale Oken King and Barbara Greene, son-in-law Eugene, grandsons Andy and Michael. She will live on in our hearts. Donations: Lenox Hills Cardiovascular Foundation Inc., 130 E. 77th St., NY, NY 10075.

PRIME-TIME SPEECH President Bush, warning of ''a long and painful recession,'' appealed to the nation to support the $700 billion plan to rescue Wall Street. He invited both major presidential candidates and Congressional leaders to the White House to forge a compromise. The bailout plan has stirred Americans' anger in e-mail -- jumping off the screen in capital letters and exclamation points -- to lawmakers in Washington. [A25.]

Al Gore, the former vice president and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, is nothing if not passionate on the issue of global warming. But his usual fired-up remarks on the subject took a step into the Gandhian realm on Wednesday when he told an audience at the Clinton Global Initiative meeting in New York that the crisis was so severe and intractable that it was time for direct action. ''If you're a young person looking at the future of this planet and looking at what is being done right now, and not done, I believe we have reached the stage where it is time for civil disobedience to prevent the construction of new coal plants that do not have carbon capture and sequestration,'' he said at the third annual meeting of former President Bill Clinton's initiative, which arranges partnerships between the very rich and the very needy.

Diouraru Pataxo, a member of the Pataxo Ha-Ha-Hae tribe, carried legal documents to the Supreme Court in Brasília on Wednesday. A ruling was postponed on Wednesday in the case examining whether the tribe had rights to ancestral lands that were given away to farmers by a state government more than 30 years ago. The tribe is entitled to 133,400 acres in Bahia State, most of which was given away to farmers in the '60s and '70s, according to the National Indian Foundation, the Brazilian government agency that supervises tribal groups. The foundation said that fewer than 400 farmers occupied 99,000 acres of the land.

Shiva will be observed in Lawrence, NY. She will be missed by all who knew her. Rest in Peace.

SALOMON--Virginia . The Board of Trustees, medical staff, administration and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our heartfelt sympathy at the passing of Virginia Salomon, wife of William Salomon, long-time member of our Board of Trustees. Mr. Salomon, honorary chairman, Citi, has been a member of the Board of Trustees of HSS since 1979. Mrs. Salomon, known for her warmth and devotion to her husband and family, was Mr. Salomon's high school sweetheart and they were married in 1937. Her memory lives on with the naming in the couple's honor of the Virginia F. and William R. Salomon Rehabilitation Department at Hospital for Special Surgery. Steadfast supporters of HSS, Mr. and Mrs. Salomon demonstrated their commitment to advance the hospital by endowing the creation of a research chair, the Virginia F. and William R. Salomon Chair in Musculoskeletal Research. Mrs. Salomon was a woman of great style, intelligence and grace. She will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Salomon family. Dean R. O'Hare Aldo Papone Co-Chairs, Board of Trustees Thomas P. Sculco, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief Louis A. Shapiro President and CEO

CAVANAGH--Jim , died of cancer at age 88 on September 23, 2008 at his home in Rockland Place, Wilmington, Delaware. Jim was the son of the late James Francis Cavanagh and Elise Burns Cavanagh of Glen Head, Long Island, NY. He attended the Greenvale School in Long Island and graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, NH in the Class of 1938 and Yale University, New Haven, CT in the Class of 1942 with a BS in Chemistry. He secured his law degree in 1946 at Temple University, Philadelphia, PA. After college, he was employed by the DuPont Company to assist on the Manhattan Project, first in Joliet, IL and then in Belleview, Washington. On completion of the atomic bomb project, he was transferred to the headquarters of the DuPont Company in Wilmington, DE. He combined his legal and chemistry knowledge, Jim contributed significantly to the ElChem and Legal Departments at DuPont for 30 years. After three years of ''retirement'' and community volunteering, including being on the board of Planned Parenthood of Delaware, Jim joined the consulting firm of Monkman Rumsey in Centerville, DE. He was married to Caroline Pratt from 1941-1954, to Doris Jarmon from 1955-1971, to Anne Henning from 1972-1982. He remarried his first wife, Caroline Pratt, from 1985 until her death in 2003. Together they wintered in Vero Beach, FL and summered in Wilmington, DE from 1985-1996. Jim was a member of Wilmington Country Club of Wilmington, Delaware and the Yale Club of New York City. His special interests included skiing, tennis and squash, and traveling. He was very organized and loved to arrange trips, events, and especially parties. He is predeceased by his wife, Caroline Pratt Cavanagh; his younger sister, Elise C. Bradley and younger brother Frank Cavanagh; his brotherin-law and sister-in-law Tom Bradley and Marcia Cavanagh. Survivors include his sisters, Cora C. Cushney of Louisville, KY and Sara C. Schwartz or West Chester, PA; his children and their spouses -Katie Maslow (Harvey Eisen) of Bethesda, MD; Sheila Marshall (George) of Vero Beach, FL; Gary Santora of Wilmington, Delaware, Jim Cavanagh (Sara) of Hilton Head, SC; and his five grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Jim was the beneficiary of very attentive caregivers for many years and, at the end of his life, by the Compassionate Care hospice employees. The family extends its sincere gratitude for their caring. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 27, 2008 at 11am at Christ Church in Wilmington, Delaware. Interment will be private. Instead of flowers, the family suggests donations to Planned Parenthood of Delaware, 625 Shipley St., Wilmington, DE 19801. Services by Chandler Funeral Homes & Crematory www.chandlerfuneralhome .com

We must pass legislation to address this crisis. If we do not, credit will dry up with devastating consequences for our economy. IT'S easy to feel like Chicken Little when rock climbing. But it's not the sky that's falling, it's rocks and dirt dislodged by climbers above. Wearing a helmet these days is a must, because so many people have taken up the sport. Gary Neptune, the owner and founder of Neptune Mountaineering, a climbing store in Boulder, Colo., said he sells roughly 10 times as many helmets now as a decade ago and wears one himself. ''In the old days, you might have been the only person climbing in a whole canyon, and you could make safety judgments,'' he said. ''But you can't make judgments about what falls out of the sky.''

AND UNION SETTLE DISPUTE Major League Baseball announced it had reached an agreement with the players union over two draft picks whose status had been in dispute since the Aug. 15 signing deadline. KAHN--David Miller Kahn , of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida died at the age of 85 on September 23. He was born on April 21, 1923 in Port Chester, New York. He is survived by his wife of 56 years Barbara Heller Kahn, and his three children William H. Kahn of Saline, Michigan, James C. Kahn of Greenwich, CT and Caroline H. Kahn Bianchi of Rye, New York. He had five beautiful granddaughters whom he cherished, Julianne Kahn, Justine Kahn, Jenna Kahn, Marielle Bianchi and Madeleine Bianchi. He is also survived by his beloved sonin-law and daughters-in-law, Richard Bianchi, Jane Kahn and Sandra Kahn. During WWII he enlisted in the U.S Army as an Aviation Cadet. After training as a pilot for one year he was transferred to the Army Counter-Intelligence Corp. where he served as a special agent for four years until receiving an honorable discharge in 1946. After WWII, he received a Bachclor of Arts degree from Kentucky University. In 1950 he received his Juris Doctor from New York Law School. During his career he was admitted to practice in the New York State Supreme Courts and District Courts, as well as the United States Supreme Court. He was a Trustee of New York Law School where he endows The David Miller Kahn Scholarship Fund, for needy students. The Westchester County Bar Association honored him for 50 years of outstanding service to the legal community. Funeral Service Friday, 10:30am September 26, 2008, at Community Synagogue of Rye. Interment to follow at Riversville Cemetery on Memory Lane in Glenville, Connecticut. The family will sit shivah after the funeral service at the home of James and Jane Kahn, 14 Blind Brook Lane, Greenwich, CT. Services are being conducted by Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck. 914381-1809. zionmemorialchapel.com

DRAGO--Frances , died after a brief illness on August 6th, 2008. Devoted daughter of the late Ellen and Hugh G. Smith, New York Times' Dublin correspondent. Beloved mother of Maria. She is sadly missed by her loving family and friends. A funeral service was held in Dublin, Ireland on August 16th. Born in the Dublin suburb of Clontarf, as a young woman Frances emigrated to New York, working briefly with American Airlines and Alitalia, followed by a decades-long career at Sabena Belgian World Airlines. This is the second in a series on ways in which Washington's economic policies mimic the same types of financial irresponsibility it chastises Wall Street for. Financial gymnastics: Washington has complained that Wall Street banks made the securities, swaps and other complicated things they exchange incomprehensible in order to make them look more valuable. Politicians complain that banks dragged their feet about writing down the value of troubled assets and should quit grumbling about transparency-promoting accounting standards like mark-to-market provisions. Why can't Wall Street just be honest about what these things are worth, huh? Why do sneaky banks have to slice and dice the things they own to obfuscate, or outright misrepresent, their value?

The two-hour season premiere of "Grey's Anatomy" vaulted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday, averaging 18.3 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Although down from the show's fourth season debut a year ago, which drew 20.9 million, Thursday's episode easily led the night with the largest audience over all. ABC's "Ugly Betty" premiere came up shorter at 8 p.m. (9.8 million), down more than a million from last year's debut.

There they were on a Tokyo runway the other day, modeling different nappies for different needs, over black tights. Beforehand, there were skits instructing the audience how to tell when elderly loved ones need diapers, and how to use them. [Japan Today]
Three days ago. Seems like an eternity.

Finance | Beyond Wall Street: suburbs and smaller financial centers also face trouble ahead. Places with high concentrations of residents working in finance, real estate and insurance are Darien, Conn.; Bloomington, Ill. (State Farm) and Hoboken. Also threatened: Wilmington, Del. (credit-card firms) and Charlotte, N.C. (Bank of America). [Business Week]

The first time I walked into Buddakan, I thought to myself: what a shame that the restaurant postdated the HBO series "Sex and the City." Buddakan's colorful, theatrical design would have been a perfect backdrop for the show.
An editor draws my attention to a very interesting ad that just ran on Economix. In case you missed it -- our ads cycle through-- see the screenshot here.

The Administration for Children's Services has announced a series of public education forums around the city to help the public understand how to recognize and report child abuse and neglect. It is affiliated with the national Hope Shining campaign, which seeks to raise awareness of child abuse and help people identify signs of abuse.
(Anna Bauer)

I was on a bus in the Lower East Side on my day off when my cellphone rang with an unfamiliar number. The voice on the other end said, "This is Supreme Commander."

We weren't clairvoyant enough to predict the biggest upset of this week in college football - Oregon State's stunning victory over top-ranked Southern California on Thursday night. But that doesn't mean that our prognosticating skills are going to waste for Saturday's games. There is still plenty of football to be played, some of which will have a direct impact on the top 10. Is this Georgia's chance to get back to the top spot? Will Alabama surprise the Bulldogs between the hedges? And how about Penn State? Will a white out in Happy Valley be too much for Illinois to handle? The Quad's contributors think they know. See if you agree.
Fox's "Do Not Disturb," a situation comedy set at a posh New York hotel, is the first victim of the new television season.

1:23 p.m. | Updated: Senator John McCain's campaign said Friday morning that he will attend tonight's debate with Senator Barack Obama at the University of Mississippi, reversing his earlier call to postpone the debate so he could participate in the Congressional negotiations over the $700 billion bailout plan for financial firms.

Neil Irwin and Cecilia Kang point out in The Washington Post today that the bailout plan has two different camps of critics: those who think that the government should inject money directly into the financial system, rather than buy distressed assets; and those who want the government to buy mortgages directly, rather than buying the Wall Street securities based on the performance of mortgages.

As I expected, Greg Mankiw has more to say about why I might be wrong that the government should demand an ownership stake an any firms it bails out. (Here are parts one, two and three of our virtual debate.) To boil it down, he says that allocating ownership stakes to the government would make any auction of mortgage-backed securities a far more complicated process.

Germany | Oktoberfest purists say Bavaria's heritage is under threat from cheap imported Lederhosen and Dirndl dresses made in China, India and Eastern Europe. Authentic embroidered Lederhosen will set you back $875; a knockoff around $200. But the real deal "will last you your whole life if you don't get too fat." Wait a second: this is Germany. [Spiegel]
Marlon Brando, New York, 1951

The Mets caught a major break Thursday night just by playing the game against the Chicago Cubs, despite a persistent rain. If they had not been able to get the game in, they would be facing the prospects of playing a makeup game with the Cubs, who, having already clinched home-field advantage throughout the National League playoffs, had absolutely no desire to be penalized for the shortcomings of other teams (Hello Mets!!). Which brings us to the chaos of the Mets, Brewers and Phillies. (Heaven help us all if the Astros continue to hang around. I don't even want to think what could happen then.)

Aired Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Yesterday, Sarah Palin was in New York at the U.N. General Assembly to meet with leaders from other countries, because previously, her world experience had been limited to a visit to the Epcot Center in Orlando.

Now that Senator McCain has announced that he will participate in tonight's presidential debate, New Yorkers are making plans to gather en masse at events that combine a dose of politics with their regular Friday night partying. All times are 8 p.m. - one hour before the 9 p.m. Eastern debate - unless noted.The Manhattan Young Democrats and Democracy for New York City are hosting an event at The Tank Space for Performing and Visual Arts at 87 Lafayette Street in which comedians will precede the 9 p.m. debate, which will be screened. Among those scheduled to appear is Joe Quint, author of "72 Things Younger Than John McCain."

Following our discussion earlier on interesting gender-related wage gaps: Mothers earn about 6 percent less than childless women, even when productivity is taken into account. This so-called motherhood penalty seems to indicate that anti-mommy discrimination is afoot.

Doris Nowillo Suda knew that people in Long Island City loved her father, Nicolas Nowillo - that he had forged connections around the neighborhood and that he had a way of leaving an impression, even with strangers. But she said she did not know the extent of it, of how many people he knew and how busy he kept, until the aftermath of his shocking death early this month when, the police say, Mr. Nowillo, 65, suffered a fatal heart attack after being attacked by a homeless man while walking a neighbor from her car.

In my imagination, a bank - a real bank - is suffused with a hush, which is interrupted, rarely, by the low gong of a massive vault slamming shut. The sole personnel are the huissiers of Geneva fortresses, those solemn openers and closers of locked doors. Clients dress in bespoke suits and stand reverent before the ramparts that secure their annuities in gold bars and serve as bulwarks against their ruin. A bank's own practice of borrowing and lending on its clients' fortunes is not spoken of too directly, lest it cloud the illusion that when the money is out of sight, it's in the vaults.
A traditional rice dish colored by red peppers and emboldened by white wine.

Much of Connecticut has a love-hate relationship with Greenwich, home of countless hedge fund and banking millionaires, and the current financial turmoil is about to make those feelings a lot more complicated.

The failure of Washington Mutual came 119 years to the day after its founding in 1889. It was no secret that the bank was having trouble. Banks and private equity firms had perused the bank's books for weeks, but a deal did not materialize until it was seized by federal regulators.

The new Design issue of T Magazine features a cover with a chest of drawers that slide in two directions, and it's an apt metaphor for the different directions design is taking today. The issue looks at the renewed interest in clean, functional furnishings; checks out the design scene in Philadelphia; visits a cutting-edge artist who works in glass; and spends the weekend at a new shopping mall with its own condominiums. The British design guru Ilse Crawford gives us a peek at her sophisticated yet comfortable aesthetic, while the legendary designer and architect Mario Bellini invites us into his opulent but eclectic Milan palazzo. The Long Island City loft of an art dealer offers a look at his obsession with Italian design of the '60s and '70s, while a sleek guest house in upstate New York blurs the boundaries between indoors and out.
"How much does a tank of gas cost these days?" a friend from San Francisco asked recently.

After overcoming a 6-3 deficit and another poor performance by the bullpen, the Mets remain tied with the Milwaukee Brewers, who won Thursday with some heroics of their own, in the wild card race. New York is a game behind the Phillies, who were off Thursday.

I've been on leave from the paper for awhile working on a book about the national security problems -- beyond Iraq -- that the next president will inherit from the Bush administration. It's left me with a number of questions for John McCain and Barack Obama. Here are 10, just to get the ball rolling for tonight's debate:

You know that Paulson produced a lemon when Glenn Hubbard and Greg Mankiw have basically the same objections to the plan that I do. The plan doesn't directly address the key issue of undercapitalized financial institutions; instead, it relies on the assumption that mortgage-related toxic waste is underpriced, and that the Treasury can wave its $700 billion magic wand and make everything fine again.
Russell A. Harding, the disgraced former aide to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, is settling old scores online.

"If" is the qualifier we're all still using for Friday night's presidential debate at the University of Mississippi in Oxford. Senator John McCain, the Republican nominee, has still not committed to attending, citing the negotiations over the government's economic bail out package. He has said he hopes to attend. Those negotiations persisted late into the night on Thursday, and talks are expected to resume this morning.

With Shea Stadium set to close, the spectators who can claim perhaps the most peculiar relationship with the ballpark may be pilots who fly into La Guardia Airport. La Guardia is one of the few airports in the country where pilots use land markers instead of instruments to guide their landings, along with Seattle (a shopping mall) and Washington (a river). Shea, which from the sky looks like a blue circle with a green center, is a primary runway guidepost.
“Second Lives” confirms how thoroughly blurred the lines dividing art, craft and design have become over the past few decades. Roberta Smith reviews.
TPG's total loss of its investment in Washington Mutual may serve as a cautionary tale for buyout shops considering noncontrolling stakes in financial firms, Reuters suggests.

The day began with an agreement that Washington hoped would end the financial crisis that has gripped the nation. It dissolved into a verbal brawl in the Cabinet Room of the White House, urgent warnings from the president and pleas from a Treasury secretary who knelt before the House speaker and appealed for her support, according to The New York Times's David Herszenhorn, Carl Hulse and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

Senator John McCain is correct: He warned two years ago that Congress should rein in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the giant mortgage finance companies, before their financial risk-taking threatened the economy, and Senator Barack Obama did not. But The New York Times's Jackie Calmes, citing interviews and Senate records, writes that Mr. McCain has overstated the role he has played.
Ostara Nutrient Recovery Systems, a Vancouver, B.C.-based developer of water recycling technology, has raised $10.5 million from VantagePoint Venture Partners and Foursome Investments Limited.

Wall Street's woes are hurting General Electric, a corporate bellwether, raising fresh concerns that the impact of the financial turmoil will be severe on business profits and the wider economy, The New York Times's Steve Lohr reports.

The words coming out of Washington this week about the American financial system have been frightening. But many have raised the possibility that the Bush administration is fear-mongering to gin up support for its $700 billion bailout proposal.
Warren E. Buffett's move to buy Constellation Energy Group is causing anxiety among some of the nuclear power industry's biggest players, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Mario Gabelli turned the heat up on Cablevision Systems Thursday, saying that he planned to screen potential candidates for the media company's board.

After an exacavation earlier this year, two British archaelogists are suggesting a solution to the mystery of Stonehenge's purpose. They theorize it was a destination for pilgrims going to the prehistoric equivalent of Lourdes -- or, if you prefer, a health spa.
Tonight's debate should offer a striking contrast in substance and style as Senator Barack Obama and Senator John McCain face off in their first formal debate of the general election.

Shareholders of Wm. Wrigley Jr. have approved the company's $23 billion sale to Mars, a move that will end more than a century of family control as the chewing-gum company becomes part of what will now be the world's largest candy maker.

A run on the Bank of East Asia, one of Hong Kong's biggest and best-known banks, stopped Thursday as quickly as it had started the day before. It was a sign, The New York Times's Keith Bradsher noted, of how quickly the city's elite can rally to protect one of their own.

Delphi on Thursday said it had reached a preliminary agreement with its creditors' committee and former parent General Motors on changes to G.M.'s support for the auto-parts maker's plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection.

Global bank HSBC Holdings is cutting 1,100 jobs in its investment banking operation, or 4 percent of the unit's total, as it weathers the global financial crisis.

A federal appeals court heard oral arguments on Thursday about whether Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, should receive a new trial in an insider-trading case, The New York Times's Dan Frosch reported.
When you think about television, chances are that the name Sanyo does not come to mind.

Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group insurance company, may "materially decrease" his holdings in the company, whose shares have declined more than 90 percent this year, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday.
As Washington dickered, Wall Street waited.

E. Stanley O'Neal, the former Merrill Lynch chief executive who was forced out last fall, is considering joining Vision Capital Advisors, a small hedge fund and private equity group, The Financial Times reported, citing people close to the situation.

Biology | The idea that one human year equals seven dog years just won't hunt, scientists have long held. But people hang onto it like a mutt with a bone. It's a fun way to compare your life's progress with Fido's. But dog lifespans vary widely across breeds. And dogs mature much more quickly early in life. So we're barking up the wrong tree. [Wall Street Journal]
Fluidigm, a biotech company financed in part by Lehman Brothers' health-care venture capital arm, has pulled its initial public offering amid chaos in the financial markets.
Two activist investors have written to department store operator Dillard's urging a change in share structure, with the goal of diluting management's control of the board of directors.
Cramster, a social-networking Web site aimed at forming study groups, has nabbed $3 million in a funding round led by Shai Reshef, an investor who sold his education company to Kaplan.
Fortis , the Dutch bank and insurer, said it will sell additional assets to improve its solvency.

HSBC is not in talks to buy UBS, Reuters reported, after renewed speculation about interest from Europe's largest bank lifted shares of UBS, which is based in Switzerland, more than 5 percent on Thursday.

Washington Mutual, the giant lender that came to symbolize the excesses of the mortgage boom, was seized by federal regulators on Thursday night, in what is by far the largest bank failure in American history, The New York Times's Eric Dash and Andrew Ross Sorkin reported.

As Europe and Asia play down the need for an American-style bailout for their banks, The New York Times's Mark Landler says the crisis may threaten a different class of countries: those in Eastern Europe, Latin America and Africa that depend on foreign capital and shoulder American-style trade deficits.

Trans-Atlantic sniping over the global financial crisis intensified Thursday after President Bush cited an influx of foreign money into the United States as one of the root causes of the tight credit market, The New York Times's Eric Pfanner reported.

Medicine | A medical journal says a vast amount of cancer research is never published, perhaps because clinical trials show the drugs or treatments didn't work. That deprives other researchers of valuable knowledge. Why this happens: scientists, medical journals and drug firms all have an interest in touting breakthroughs and not failure. [Business Week, Oncologist]
The legions of voyeurs obsessed with celebrity real estate now have their own reference guide.

Space | Financial calamity, nukes -- That's all small beer to astronauts who met this week on preventing a collision between the Earth and an asteroid or comet. The Panel on Asteroid Threat Mitigation is supposed to let us know if there's anything we can do. "It's not a question of whether it's going to happen; it's just a question of when." [Scientific American]

Television | A writer wonders if PBS kids' shows ruined his life. After all, an L.S.U. professor blamed Mister Rogers' "you're special" ethos for spoiling college students. And "Sesame Street" bucked an American Academy of Pediatrics finding that tots under 2 shouldn't watch TV. And didn't those quick cuts and catchy tunes make us want our MTV? [Mental Floss]

The sheer scope of the Victoria and Albert Museum's new blockbuster exhibition "Cold War Modern: Design 1945-1970" (unitil 11 January 2009) is impressive. And the exhibit is timely, what with the current re-emergence of Cold War-like tensions. The event covers culture from both sides of the Iron Curtain -- including contemporary design, architecture, film and popular culture. (Note for readers too young to be familiar with the terminology: the "Iron Curtain" was the theoretical wall that separated Communist countries of Eastern Europe from the democracies of the west.) Jane Pavitt, curator of the exhibition, explains that the Cold War represented more than just a battle of political ideology and an arms race, but also "a contest between East and West to assert a superior vision of the future."

Business | An article asks, why can't the government get equity stakes from the companies it bails out, and not just in the present financial mess? (It did from the airlines in their post-9/11 bailout, after all.) Why don't taxpayers get to own a piece of the baseball teams whose stadiums they finance? Or of biotech startups they give grants to? Answer, in a word: lobbyists. [Fortune]

Frank McCourt, the owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers, has bought the operating rights for the Los Angeles Marathon and will switch the race from March 1 to Monday, Feb. 16, the Presidents’ Day holiday.
The United States Walker Cup captain Buddy Marucci won the U.S.G.A. Senior Amateur, beating George Zahringer, 2-up, at Shady Oaks Country Club in Fort Worth.

Ryan Malone and Martin St. Louis scored 2 minutes 18 seconds apart in the third period Thursday night to rally the Tampa Bay Lightning to a 4-2 preseason victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden. Dan Fritsche and Lauri Korpikoski scored for the Rangers. ¶Jean-Sébastien Aubin made 18 saves in the first two periods and Martin Biron stopped six shots in the third period in the Philadelphia Flyers’ 4-0 preseason victory over the Islanders in London, Ontario. isles (AP).

Cycling’s world governing body and Tour de France organizers agreed Thursday to end years of feuding over control of the sport. The deal followed telephone negotiations between Pat McQuaid, president of the International Cycling Union, and the Éditions Philippe Amaury group, which owns the Tour de France. At stake was the power of race organizers against the U.C.I., marked by fights over which teams could enter events such as the Tour.
Ronaldinho was dropped by Brazil for next month’s World Cup qualifiers against Venezuela and Colombia and his A.C. Milan teammate Kaká was recalled to the Brazilian squad after knee surgery.

The United States Walker Cup captain Buddy Marucci won the U.S.G.A. Senior Amateur, beating George Zahringer, 2-up, at Shady Oaks Country Club in Fort Worth. Marucci, 56, of Villanova, Pa., won for the first time in 51 starts in United States Golf Association events. Marucci, best known for losing to Tiger Woods in the 1995 United States Amateur final, received an invitation to play in the 2009 and 2010 United States Senior Opens and an exemption from local qualifying to next year’s United States Open. ¶Diane Lang won the U.S.G.A. Senior Women’s Amateur for the third time in four years, beating Toni Wiesner, 6 and 5, at Tulsa Country Club. Lang, 53, a Jamaican who lives in Weston, Fla., also won the 2005 and 2006 tournaments. The sixth player to win the event three or more times, she also was a semifinalist in 2007, making her 22-1 in four years in the event. lang (AP).

Cycling’s world governing body and Tour de France organizers agreed Thursday to end years of feuding over control of the sport. The deal followed telephone negotiations between Pat McQuaid, president of the International Cycling Union, and the Éditions Philippe Amaury group, which owns the Tour de France. At stake was the power of major race organizers against that of the U.C.I., marked by bitter fights over which teams could enter events such as the Tour.

Jarett Dillard is a senior receiver at Rice. He holds almost every Rice career receiving record and leads all active N.C.A.A. receivers in receptions, receiving yardage and touchdown receptions. He also graduated with a degree in political science. Jarett will be checking in with The Quad from time to time to give readers an inside look at his season. Avangard Omsk traveled to the Russian Far East on Thursday and picked up their third straight win with a 4-0 silencing of Amur Khabarovsk. Rangers prospect Alexei Cherepanov had a goal and an assist. But take solace, Blueshirts fans: at least Jaromir Jagr was held off the board.

In the second season of “Californication,” Hank Moody, the sex-addicted novelist played by David Duchovny, is forced to spend all his time resisting the temptation that still abounds.

An article in some editions on Thursday about a Brooklyn man who fell to his death from a building ledge after a police officer shot him with a Taser stun gun included an erroneous spelling from the police for his given name. He was Iman Morales, not Inman.

A picture on Saturday with an article about a meeting of top government officials and the executives of the biggest United States banks the previous weekend to seek a solution to the financial crisis was published in error. It depicted J. P. Morgan Jr. — not his father, J. P. Morgan Sr., who convened a similar meeting more than a century ago to halt the Panic of 1907.

An article on Sept. 15 about the expense that hotels are incurring by adding high-definition television service misstated the number of additional hotel rooms that one HDTV provider, LodgeNet Interactive, expects to serve this year. LodgeNet has placed service in 130,000 rooms and expects to add 110,000 rooms this year — not 500,000, which is the number of rooms the entire industry expects to serve this year.

An article on Tuesday about the departure of Sallie Krawcheck, who led the global wealth management division at Citigroup, gave an erroneous attribution for a quotation about the difficulties women have surviving on Wall Street when there is an economic downturn. It was Jonathan Knee, a senior managing director at Evercore Partners, who said, “Whoever is comfortable with each other survives so that women, who have only been in the top ranks for a short time, are very vulnerable.” The comment was not by Lauren Rich Fine, who quit Merrill Lynch as a research analyst and is teaching at Kent State.

An article on Aug. 27 about top fund-raisers for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton who were not committing to Senator Barack Obama’s campaign misstated the amount of money Clinton donors contributed to Mr. Obama in July. It was about $2.8 million, not $2 million.

An article on Tuesday about retailers’ trepidation as the holiday season approaches misstated a statistic for the department store chain Bon-Ton in August. It had a 10.3 percent decrease in sales at stores open at least a year; the number of stores open at least a year did not decrease by 10.3 percent.

NATIONAL.
Four groups submitted their final offers for the sprawling Starrett City housing complex on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn on Thursday.

A capsule summary on Tuesday of an article about the only major league game ever decided by an umpire alone in his hotel room misidentified the role played by Fred Merkle in the 1908 game. He was the New York Giants player who made the blunder that led to the umpire’s decision; he was not the umpire. (That was Hank O’Day.).

Doris Lessing had to wait until she was 87 to receive her Nobel Prize in literature last year; five young authors are being saluted a bit sooner. The National Book Foundation is paying tribute to these fiction writers younger than 35, chosen by previous National Book Award winners and finalists. They’re being honored for producing work that is “particularly promising and exciting and is among the best of a new generation of writers,” the foundation said. The “5 Under 35” are Matthew Eck, author of “The Farther Shore”; Keith Gessen, author of “All the Sad Young Literary Men”; Sana Krasikov, author of “One More Year: Stories”; Nam Le, author of “The Boat”; and Fiona Maazel, author of “Last Last Chance.” They will be honored at a celebration at Tribeca Cinemas on Nov. 17.

SCHMUKLER--Dorothy H. , of Queens, New York, beloved wife of Professor Nathan Schmukler, died peacefully at home on September 25, 2008. She was a wonderful wife of 61 years, beloved mother and grandmother. She was a graduate of Brooklyn College and earned a Masters degree from Columbia University. In addition to her husband, she is survived by her three children, Joan Posner, Jeffrey Elliot, and Judith Pearl, her eight grandchildren whom she adored, her sons-in-law David Posner and Rabbi Jonathan Pearl, and her daughter-in-law, Lynnea Elliot. She will be truly missed.

LYNCH--Dick , on September 24, 2008. Former NFL Great and the voice of the New York Giants. Devoted and Loving husband of Roz (Former Miss Pennsylvania). Beloved father of Jennifer Lynch, Nancy Lord, Rosalie Nester, Cynthia Lynch, John Liam Lynch and the late Richard Lynch II. Cherished Pop Pop to 11 grandchildren. Dear brother of Myrna Caruso, F. Kevin Lynch and Dennis Lynch. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. on Saturday and Sunday 24pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Monday 10am at The Cathedral of St. Patricks 5th Ave. at 51 St. In lieu of flowers, the family request donations to be made in Dick's name to the New York Chapter of the NFL Alumni Association or the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society (LLS). Written condolences can be made to www.Mem.com

ROMANOFF--H.H. Prince Michael , Prince of Russia passed away on Monday, September 22, 2008, in Sydney, Australia. He was 88 years old. He was the Grand Prior and Imperial Protector of The Sovereign Order of the Orthodox Knights Hospitaller of St. John of Jerusalem. He was the eldest grandson of HIH Grand Duke Alexander Mikhailovich and Grand Duchess Xenia, sister of Emperor Nicholas II of Russia. Born in England where King George V gave them refuge, he spent his childhood in Windsor and served in World War II as a volunteer in the Royal Navy. After the war, he remained in Australia where he worked as an engineer. He became Imperial Protector of OSJ in 1980 and was elected Grand Prior in 2006, after the death of Grand Prior Count Nicholas Bobrinskoy. He had great interest in the humanitarian work of the order and officiated at all its services, also attending several historical Romanoff events. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that contributions be sent to OSJ headquarters, 39 Parkway East, Mt. Vernon, NY 10552. USA. Lt Grand Prior, Count Alexander Woronzoft-Dashkoff Grand Chancellor, C-ess Nicholas Bobrinskoy Prior of New York, Prince Ivan Obolensky Grand Herald Dr. Paul J Cardile

WEISS--Emil R. , died Tuesday, September 16, 2008 at age 76 in New York City. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, and brother. He is survived by his wife of 54 years (Tamar), daughter Diana Weiss Widman (Stuart), son Jeffrey, two grandchildren, Evan and Sonia, brother Larry (Joyce) of Florida and many nieces and nephews. Currently a resident of both New York and Arizona, he was born in Newark, NJ on May 10, 1932. He was a graduate of Dickinson College (PA) and Harvard University where he earned a Master's in Business Administration. With a distinguished career in finance, he was associated with Neuberger and Berman for over 30 years and became a partner during that time. He was chairman of his own investment firm, Weiss Pollack Capital Management from 1989 to 1994, when he retired. He served on the board of Dickinson College from 1971 to 2002, as well as on the boards of the Montclair (NJ) Art Museum, Bloomfield (NJ) College, and was founding President of Temple Ner Tamid (Bloomfield, NJ) in 1979. His charitable activities involved all of the previously mentioned boards as well as the Scottsdale (AZ) Center for the Arts and the Phoenix Art Museum. His warm and generous spirit provided inspiration to many whom he helped in developing successful careers. He funded programs in the educational and religious institutions in which he was active to encourage independent study and provide opportunities for enhanced learning experiences for students and children, including prizes in the arts at Dickinson College and Bloomfield College, and summer camp and travel programs at Temple Ner Tamid. He will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved him

8 P.M. (TCM) PRIME TIME FEATURES: CLINT EASTWOOD This double bill begins with ''Kelly's Heroes'' (1970), in which Mr. Eastwood (above left, with Don Rickles) stars as an unconventional Army officer who captures a German colonel and brings him back to headquarters for questioning. When he learns that 14,000 gold ingots worth $16 million are being held in a nearby German bank, he decides to go get them. Telly Savalas, Donald Sutherland and Carroll O'Connor also star. In ''Where Eagles Dare'' (1969), at 10:30, Mr. Eastwood and Richard Burton play allied agents who pretend to be Nazis and stage a raid on a castle where an American general is being held prisoner. 7 A.M. KIRSCH--Maureen , died at home on September 24, 2008 following an extended illness. During her life, Maureen was a successful sales executive, a Life Master at bridge, independent film producer, patron of the visual arts and generous champion of innercity education and female empowerment through micro-finance. Maureen served on the Board of Trustees of Opportunity International and the Alumni Association of Baruch College. Mo is survived and will be missed by her husband, Geof, and her step kids Geof, Kate and Jake. Her father Gordon Daly, sister Marleen Karns and brother, Gordon Daly, will all miss her deeply. The many people who considered her a best friend will remember Maureen in high regard. Visitation at Frank Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday, September 30 and October 1 from 2-5 and 7-9. A funeral Mass will be said by Monsignor Thomas Leonard at Holy Trinity R.C. Church located at 213 West 82nd Street on Thursday, October 2 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Maureen Kirsch Memorial Fund at Baruch College in New York.

His birth certificate says John Cornelius Foley, but on the Bowery he was more widely known for his bizarre home: He was the Man in the Box. Mr. Foley, a tall and broad 57, is a walking, talking relic from the old Bowery, a graduate of countless flophouses and men's shelters and overnight jail cells to the home where I met him at the beginning of the year: a long, wooden box chained to a street sign on Broome Street.

DRAGO--Frances , died after a brief illness on August 6th, 2008. Devoted daughter of the late Ellen and Hugh G. Smith, New York Times' Dublin correspondent. Beloved mother of Maria. She is sadly missed by her loving family and friends. A funeral service was held in Dublin, Ireland on August 16th. Born in the Dublin suburb of Clontarf, as a young woman Frances emigrated to New York, working briefly with American Airlines and Alitalia, followed by a decades-long career at Sabena Belgian World Airlines. She loved to travel and did so extensively with her daughter, visiting Europe, South America and Asia. Frances' other great love were animals: the cats and dogs that were her faithful companions over the years, and animals that she would see on trips to Buenos Aires, San Diego and Rio de Janeiro. Contributions in her memory can be sent to the Animal Lovers' League, 40 Shore Road, Glen Cove, NY 11542. A memorial Mass will take place Saturday, September 27th, 9:45am at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church, Glen Cove, New York, followed by a reception at Glen Cove Mansion.

HOPKINS--Paul . Clifford Chance records with profound sorrow the death of partner Paul M. Hopkins. For over 30 years Paul was a colleague, mentor and friend to countless members of the firm, and trusted advisor to our clients. He will truly be missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife and family.

''Celebrating John Milton's 400th Birthday,'' a festival including music, drama, art exhibitions and special events, will open on Saturday at 8 p.m. with a costume ball at the Williamsburg Art and Historical Center, 135 Broadway, at Bedford Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; tickets, $40, $20 for students and 65+. On Sunday at 2 p.m. a reading and a tour of the art exhibition will be given by the poet S. David; suggested admission, $5. The festival will run through Nov. 2. (718) 486-6012; wahcenter.net. Gallery hours: Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Suggested admission, $7, free for those under 13.

A year ago, Myanmar's police and military stormed the streets of this moldy, crumbling city and began a deadly crackdown on thousands of Buddhist monks protesting sharp rises in the price of food and fuel. Now the country's ruling generals are steeling themselves for a reprise. As the anniversary approached, the police erected checkpoints on the outskirts of Yangon, formerly Rangoon, and conducted nightly house-to-house searches just after midnight, hunting for dissidents or critics of their rule -- anyone who might want to commemorate the protests.

ROTH--Alan , passed from us in the early morning of September 22 in his home in Rancho Santa Fe, CA. Alan was surrounded by his loving family -wife Ingrid of 38 years and his son Andrew. Alan Roth was born in New York City to Mollie and Philip Roth on June 2, 1934, attended Mid-town Ethical Culture School and the Fieldston School in Riverdale, NY from 1946-1952. At Brown University he developed a lifelong passion for history and music, was a member of Pi Lambda Phi fraternity and served as the captain of the Brown soccer team. Alan graduated from Brown in 1956 as a junior Phi Beta Kappa scholar and an honor student. Alan went on to start his career at Lehman Brothers as a junior analyst in 1957 and in 1961 Alan left Lehman Brothers to start his own investment advisory firm, and, at the age of 27, he became one of the youngest to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. Alan specialized in entertainment and railroad stocks, and with his meticulous attention to details and strict adherence to honesty in his analyses, he quickly became one of the new young turks on Wall Street. We admire his outstanding achievements in life and his strong character of integrity and morals. He was very much dedicated to his family, and we are so very thankful for the many years we shared together. We love you and we miss you, and we wish you a safe journey until we see you again.
DAMIAN LOEB Synesthesia, Parataxic

SALOMON--Virginia Foster , age 91, died at her New York City apartment September 24, 2008. Beloved wife of William R. Salomon for over seventy-one wonderful years. Devoted mother of Peter F. Salomon, M.D. and Susan Neiman. Loving grandmother of Wendy Salomon, Liza Byrne, Jillian Whelan and Heather Shapiro. Devoted great-grandmother of three. Her remains were donated to Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons according to her wishes. Contributions can be made to Hospital for Special Surgery, 535 East 70th Street, New York, NY 10021 or the charity of your choice.

My Sunday column is about John McCain and foreign policy. The back story is that it's increasingly obvious that the McCain campaign strategy is to portray Obama as a "risky choice" at a time of international upheavals, given his relative lack of experience. And it's certainly true that Obama doesn't have the broad familiarity with the world that McCain has; Obama is particularly weak on China, Japan and India.

The first pitch for today's game between the Mets and the Marlins has been pushed back a second time. Now the Mets are saying it will start at 1:45 P.M. When the announcement was made at Shea Stadium, the smattering of fans booed.

The first question Jerry Manuel faced when he walked into the interview room here at Shea Stadium came from a reporter asking if the lineup in the clubhouse was real. After all, with your team two games from the end of the season and clinging desperately to playoff hopes, this is not usually a natural time to revamp the batting order. At this rate, the kitchen sink will be pinch-hitting later.

The Mets just announced that the first pitch of their game against the Florida Marlins has been pushed back to 1:25 from 1:10. The tarpaulin was put on the field about 10 minutes ago. It is raining lightly. With Johan Santana pitching on three days' rest in an attempt to keep the Mets' season alive, the Mets do not need any interruptions once the game starts.

Re "Make It Airtight" (Sept. 21): I was gratified to read that Richard Stevenson, the editor who directs The Times's coverage of the election, said that "we don't want to fall into the trap of false equivalency" when accurately reporting the false and misleading advertising, speeches and statements employed by Senator John McCain and his running mate, Gov. Sarah Palin.I might have termed it "artificial balance," but "false equivalency" works for me, too.For far too long we've heard "fair and balanced" when it could just as well have been termed "irrelevant falsehoods mouthed by a spinmeister" running in the same article or airing in the same broadcast as "factual information from a candidate."Frankly, I'd welcome regulations requiring ads, speeches and press releases to present facts that can be verified from all political candidates, elected or appointed officeholders or chief executives.If we'd had them all along, our political landscape, our financial fortunes and our present world persona would be very different.Rita L. McKeeNew York, Sept. 21, 2008 ● Reporters are not restricted to second-person reporting. Reporters are allowed to speak with their own voice. A reporter has a higher duty than a person being quoted by the reporter.People being quoted can indulge themselves in partiality. But a reporter, to maintain credibility, must attempt to report "truthfully."The writer of an editorial is making a statement, which is understood to have some partiality to it. An editorial speaks with an editor's or a publisher's voice. And that voice does not have to present itself as impartial, as a reporter of facts, although it can.Jackie AldridgeAlameda, Calif., Sept. 21, 2008 ● The quote attributed to The Times's executive editor, Bill Keller - "We had to fit it into a manageable space" - is just a defense mechanism in selective reporting to support a preconceived conclusion. Crossing the line between reporting and editorial comments in a news article leads to strengthening the decline of news reporting credibility and use of obvious distortions.Don TenerowiczEllington, Conn., Sept. 21, 2008●●Re "Getting Past the Formalities" (Sept. 14): It's very nice of you to admit that using Barack Obama's middle name, Hussein, three times on the front page on Aug. 28 was an "overkill" and that by not using John McCain's full name, John Sidney McCain III, in exactly the same situation, The Times was a tad inconsistent in its treatment of the two candidates.But are you certain of the reasons Mr. McCain's name was abbreviated where Mr. Obama's was not? Are you sure that it wasn't because Mr. McCain "prefers" to forget both Sidney and (even more) the fact that he's the third of the line? Or that by omitting it, The Times wasn't bowing to Mr. McCain's preferences?The Times has seemed to be heavily invested in the earth-moving business: make every molehill about Mr. Obama into a mountain and vice versa.Tamara P. DuvallLexington, Va., Sept. 14, 2008 ● It's funny, a few months ago I had been reading The Times and had noticed, somewhat irritably, the use of "Mrs." when referring to Hillary Clinton. I love the newspaper and trust it implicitly (this might not exactly be a good thing), but I was put off by the decision not to use the more P.C. "Ms."Then I was annoyed when I noticed "Ms. Palin," feeling that such considerations were wasted on someone so terrifying and - well, all those adjectives you want to use on her.I'm glad you answered this for me. If you hadn't addressed it, I doubt I would ever have had any clarification on this issue and maybe unfairly judged the paper's editors.Brianna SnyderSpringfield, Mass., Sept. 15, 2008●●Re "The Scrutiny of Sarah Palin" (Sept. 7): The Times has been absolutely correct in its scrutiny of Gov. Sarah Palin.After inflating Ms. Palin's family leadership role and small-town values into legitimate qualifications for the vice presidency, the McCain camp is now claiming that anyone who examines these areas has violated her family's privacy.The Times needs to look even deeper into Ms. Palin's scant record. The possibility that this woman might wield power over the entire country is terrifying.Thea AndersonLincoln, Mass., Sept. 8, 2008 ● I don't buy your column.The coverage The Times has provided of Gov. Sarah Palin has been biased.It's O.K. to be biased. We all are, to some degree.What is not O.K. is when The Times refuses to admit it, or recognize it.Phil GrimmRogue River, Ore., Sept. 8, 2008 ● The Times's coverage of Gov. Sarah Palin has been absolutely fair and totally needed.We are not living in the Joe McCarthy era of fear or the George W. Bush era of lies anymore. After The Times was initially hoodwinked by President Bush's invasion of Iraq, it vowed it would never shy away from investigating issues and getting to the truth of the matter.The Times vetted Barack Obama and now it is vetting Ms. Palin.This is a crucial election, so please, Times, continue to dig deep and report your findings accurately. We voters can handle the truth.Kathy BergerSan Anselmo, Calif., Sept. 8, 2008 ● I concur with your take on unjustified Republican complaints about the scrutiny of Gov. Sarah Palin. Vice-presidential candidates are not vetted by the voters, so unless these candidates have visible public records, such as that of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., we are left to rely on what is released by campaign operatives - not the most reliable sources.Thus it is left to mainstream journalists to pose the serious questions about the candidates. In this case, the G.O.P. is merely seeking to embellish a paper-thin public record and head off potentially embarrassing questions.Had the McCain campaign properly investigated Ms. Palin, it would not be playing catch-up on this matter.Vaughn A. CarneyStowe, Vt., Sept. 8, 2008 ● It is clear that the press must be even more vigilant in its job this political season.With Steve Schmidt in charge of the McCain campaign and his mentor, Karl Rove, manning a commentator's desk at Fox News, the people of American need to know more than ever who is spinning out the information contained in news stories.More often then not we see campaign and commentator remarks cut and pasted into news stories without attribution (such as Sarah Palin's claim that she said, "Thanks but no thanks on that Bridge to Nowhere") without providing the evidence to prove their veracity.Now more than ever, it is up to the press in our free and democratic society to root out the use of the press for political gain (propaganda). Don't let Mr. Rove and his disciples use the press to sell Ms. Palin and John McCain the same way they used the press to sell the Iraq war.Debra HollowayRye, N.H., Sept. 8, 2008 ● Thank you to The Times for its continued efforts to give a whole picture of who Gov. Sarah Palin is. I hadn't realized how much the paper had already done.I appreciate your straightforward response about all of the recent criticism of The Times. At the moment there is nothing more important than informing the public before the election.In Ms. Palin we seem to have a hard-working, hard-hitting lady with some decent accomplishments and with exceptional looks (this is worthy of mention, as it seems to capture the imagination of the electorate). But there has been considerable stretching of the truth. She is in absolutely no way prepared to move into a position of power any greater than she presently has.I see many danger signs and can only hope (and expect) that The Times will continue the journalism we're seeing in regard to the vetting process.D. MandellSeattle, Sept. 7, 2008 ● The Times is investigating Sarah Palin in order to analyze her judgment, understanding, persuasiveness to skeptics, contacts and other attributes necessary for success in the vice presidency and, potentially, the presidency.Attempting to undermine this investigation creates a reasonable inference of a motive to conceal.The honor of the investigative reporters of The Times needs no defending. At times, it is the judgment of editors that has come into question. There is no journalistic need to defend the reports of the investigation - its accuracy speaks for itself.But as a letter writer has asked, where is The Times in reporting whether the stated goals of the people running for the presidency and the vice presidency would allow them faithfully to carry out the oath of office to "take care that the laws be faithfully executed"?Robert LiebrossWestbury, N.Y., Sept. 7, 2008 ● The response to the bashing of Gov. Sarah Palin in the news media always seems to be, "We have a duty to ask questions," and then to add that Republicans don't like to be questioned.Reports on FactCheck.org, a University of Pennsylvania program, show that many of the "questions" the media are asking are lightly veiled attacks, often containing false accusations. There are hundreds of reporters asking similar "questions." This is why people see such a powerful bias in much of the media.For example, CNN, in an interview on Sept. 4 with a senior adviser to the McCain campaign, asked how much of a problem it would be that Ms. Palin had significantly cut the budget in Alaska for special needs children. The reporter said she had been getting "a lot of e-mails about the subject." But in fact, as FactCheck.org notes, Ms. Palin increased funding for special education dramatically.CNN could have spent less than five minutes in a Google search to know that the "question" was a false accusation.The news media does not start questions to Barack Obama with "How does a radical Muslim terrorist like you expect to be able to attract American voters?" But reporters don't hesitate to ask such questions of Republicans.Joe DennyWayne, Pa., Sept. 9, 2008 ● Thank you to The Times for printing stories about Gov. Sarah Palin and for continuing to look into her record and positions. I want to know as much as possible before Election Day! I don't really get the people who think this should be off limits.Please don't let up. I especially appreciated the extremely informative article about the vetting process.Jen BinghamIndianapolis, Sept. 8, 2008 ●You provide an excellent defense of what should not have to be defended - journalists digging into the reality behind a campaign's spin.It's a shame that the McCain team has forced the news media to work overtime to compensate for its clearly sloppy vetting of its vice-presidential pick.I commend The Times for writing anything newsworthy that it finds out about a woman who is unknown to the American public but who has vaulted to celebrity status for the most superficial of reasons - her image.The woman could well be making executive decisions affecting all our lives. She has so far shown herself to be completely ill equipped to do so. It's the responsibility of all media to ignore appearances and get to the facts that will reveal the substance of this woman.Patty GrossmanBrooklyn, Sept. 7, 2008

Nouriel Roubini has a characteristically scathing takedown of the Paulson plan, and here's the thing: language aside, his economic analysis is similar to mine. The fundamental problem in the financial system is too little capital; bizarrely, the Treasury chose not to address that problem directly, by (say) purchasing preferred shares in financial institutions. Instead, the plan is premised on the belief that toxic mortgage-related waste is underpriced, and that the Treasury can recapitalize banks on the cheap by fixing the markets' error.

SOPANEN--Jeri Rainer , 79 born in Helsinki, Finland, died peacefully September 21 after a battle with cancer. He lived a long and enviable life--his career as a cinematographer taking him around the world eight times. He is best known for his work on such films and documentaries as My Dinner with Andre, Gardens of the World with Audrey Hepburn, The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau, The Gig, A Midsummer Nights Sex Comedy, The Plimpton! Series, and numerous Nova and National Geographic specials. He was loved by his family for his kind, gentle, generous, humble (yet proud), brilliant ways. He asked little of this world and genuinely appreciated everything he received. He was a man of few words (even though he spoke 7 languages), but His subtle, mischievous smile spoke for him. He will be profoundly missed by his wife, Marja, his three children, Mark Huneke, Anya Huneke, and Eric Sopanen, and his step-family, Mark, Petra, and Rebecca Roth. A Memorial service will be held at St. John's Lutheran Church, 83 Christopher Street, New York, NY 10014 on Saturday, October 4 at 2:00pm.

(SportsNet New York) SHEA GOODBYE: FROM THE 92ND STREET Y The former Mets All-Stars Keith Hernandez (above), Darryl Strawberry and Ron Darling reminisce about the stadium, the 1986 championship season and other high points of their careers in this discussion filmed at the 92nd Street Y on Sept. 7. Excerpts from the presidential debate on Friday night in Oxford, Miss., between Senators John McCain and Barack Obama, as recorded by Federal News Service. The moderator was Jim Lehrer of PBS. A full transcript and video: nytimes.com. MR. OBAMA You know, we are at a defining moment in our history. Our nation is involved in two wars, and we are going through the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And although we've heard a lot about Wall Street, those of you on Main Street, I think, have been struggling for a while, and you recognize that this could have an impact on all sectors of the economy. And you're wondering: How's it going to affect me? How's it going to affect my job? How's it going to affect my house? How's it going to affect my retirement savings or my ability to send my children to college?

HABER--Emanuel Hon. , 89. Beloved husband of his cherished Millicent, loving father of Bruce Haber and Jody Salzinger, adoring grandfather of Sarah, Amy, Jonathan and Julie, dear brother of Rosalind Halper, brother-in-law Norman Halper, daughter-inlaw Susan Haber and son-inlaw Eric Salzinger. Fernando Alonso on Saturday threw a fit after his car broke down in qualifying. After setting the fastest time in practice he had good reason to think he would be able to do well in qualifying, then the car broke down. I'd never seen him so demonstratively angry. On race day, it all came together and Alonso showed why he is so good, taking advantage of everything, he and his Renault team pulled off a nearly impossible to imagine victory. It was justice of a kind.

Internet | Meet "Pyr0," a reformed computer hacker now paid handsomely "to put his knowledge of the dark arts to use in capers that wouldn't look out of place in a 'Mission Impossible' movie." Such "white hats" spot security breaches and are "a force for good." [Times of London]

Brad DeLong says that Swedish-style temporary nationalization is the right answer to a financial crisis; he's right. I haven't been clear enough about this, it seems, but it's where my basic diagnosis leads: the problem is insufficient capital, you want to inject capital, but you don't want it to be a windfall to existing stockholders -- hence, take over and recapitalize the failing firms. By the way, that's what we did with AIG 10 years days ago.

Lexicon | Deleveraging is "the word of the moment." In the present crisis, it's when financial institutions, infected with mortgage-related cooties, sell assets to avoid default. That pushes down the prices of other assets, "worsening the balance-sheets of other investors, forcing more asset sales, and so on." It's the vicious cycle freezing credit -- and what the government's trying to stop. "A fate worse than debt." [Economist, Investopedia]

Lance Armstrong may not be able to start his comeback in January because of doping rules that apply to riders coming out of retirement. Those riders need to be in the sport’s antidoping program for six months before they can race, the international cycling union said Saturday. The federation said it would discuss whether Armstrong had met that requirement with the United States Anti-Doping Agency.

Savoir-faire meets moxie, and a fine romance begins. Flirtatious overtures and tender embraces, envious glances and cold shoulders all play a role in making the exhibition “Paris/New York: Design Fashion Culture 1925-1940” (at the Museum of the City of New York from Oct. 3) as provocative and entertaining as the glamorously staged revues that once regaled the smart set on both sides of the pond. The museum’s curtain goes up on the 1925 Paris Exposition Internationale des Arts Décoratifs et Industriels Modernes (enter sophisticated, French-accented Art Deco, trailed by an adoring chorus of Yanks) and falls shortly after the 1939-40 New York World’s Fair (Gotham’s hometown modernism — plucky ingénue turned diva — belts out her own triumphant anthem to liberty and the pursuit of progress). But because this production combines déjà vu with 21st-century double takes and uncensored city-to-city dialogue, it’s far from the straight revival the title may suggest.

Yves Klein made a big splash in the 1950s when he introduced a pure ultramarine pigment, International Klein Blue, in a series of identical monochrome canvases. Now that same pigment comes in a house paint from the Swiss brand KT Color. The company, which also offers the full range of Le Corbusier’s signature architectural colors, makes all of its paints with environmentally safe binders and pure pigments, so you can paint your hallway pure blue — or ultramarine pink or gold bronze flake, two other Klein hues — while staying green. Available in the United States at Aronson’s Floor Covering (212-243-4993) or go to ktcolorusa.com. [?][?][?]ANDREAS KOKKINO.

Three years ago, the New York designer Stephen Burks traveled to South Africa to work with a group of artisans known for their mosaic-tiled portraits of Nelson Mandela. His goal was to help them make vases and bowls for a new eco-conscious line by Cappellini. Next he headed to Australia to work with Aborigine artists for a Nature Conservancy project, which has enlisted designers, including Hella Jongerius and Ted Muehling, to scout indigenous materials and processes from preserves in countries like Bolivia and Micronesia. Carbon impact notwithstanding, such far-flung collaborations have become increasingly popular among designers who are wary of the perils of mass-market globalism, and who see both ecological and economic benefits in handcrafted goods. Here are six designers who are finding inspiration outside the borders of industrial production. [?][?][?]MONICA KHEMSUROV.

Heath Ceramics, the Sausalito, Calif., dinnerware and tile manufacturer, is such a good example of a modern-day company with a conscience (and a cult following) that it’s easy to forget Heath has been at it, with very few changes to its methods, for more than 50 years. Throughout Northern California, devotees talk about the dinnerware as if the pieces were heirlooms — and certainly they’re durable enough to span generations — while dozens of area restaurants serve their locally grown sunchokes on Heath plates. (There is even a Heath Chez Panisse collection.) And in the last few years, under energetic new ownership, Heath has not only expanded and updated its product lines but also begun to invite other, like-minded companies to its table, all of which are committed to making products in an environmentally sound, aesthetically glorious way.

In this economy, the idea of an artist being able to afford work space in central London is basically a joke. Unless you’re lucky enough to know the Foxcrofts, that is. About a year ago, Auro Foxcroft, a furniture designer, and his brother, Jack, a photographer, had four retired subway cars hoisted onto the roof of a warehouse in the über-hip Shoreditch neighborhood in London and rented them out as offices for creative types for a mere £33 (about $60) a week. The Foxcrofts, who call their enterprise Village Underground, bought the Tube cars for about £100 ($180) from London transport authorities, then gutted and renovated them with the help of several friends and local engineers and architects. Two of the cars now sit atop open-sided steel shipping containers, which also serve as offices. The brothers also opened a multimedia cultural space inside the warehouse, which they rent out to corporate clients like Sony. Tenants — who love the views, not to mention the cachet — include fashion designers, painters and filmmakers as well as graffiti artists who regularly redecorate the cars in zebra stripes, camouflage and pixelated patterns. The Foxcrofts are planning a similar project in Berlin and are even looking into sites in the United States. Who else, they ask, is going to look out for artists in this money-hungry world? [?][?][?]SAM LUBELL.

It used to be said that you’re never really rich unless you owe a million dollars, which seems like such a quaint figure today, but by that measure Michael Taylor was very rich indeed. Despite his immense success as the quintessential California decorator of the ’70s and ’80s, Taylor died (of AIDS, in 1986, at the age of 59) more than $3 million in debt. Translated to today, the amount doubles. An 18th-century 32-tread marble staircase, gathering dust in a warehouse for almost 20 years, may have had something to do with it. So might Taylor’s habit, when in Paris, of sending his clothes round-trip to a Chicago dry cleaner. Then there were the monthlong stays every Christmas with his mother in a corner suite at the Royal Hawaiian hotel in Honolulu. Not to mention the 18 Claude Montana leather jackets, most in black but a few in red and yellow.
From rat fur to broomsticks, Wieki Somers makes the everyday extraordinary.

I have a friend who is a film editor. When you go to the movies with him, he doesn’t watch the film but its composition. While you’re enjoying the acting, the plot and the dialogue, he will talk to you with a precise passion about a sequence of jump-cuts that barely registered with you. He sees things that you don’t. Similarly, perfumers smell things that you don’t. One whiff and they are deconstructing a perfume and staring down its interior architecture.

I don’t need to know what my B.F.F. means when she texts “lqtm.” (“Laughing quietly to myself.”) I don’t need music, and I don’t need to take blurry pictures, which I will then e-mail to my friends, who are bored to death with me and my boring blurry pictures.

For the inhabitantsof the New Yorkart world, living in a spare white loft with just a few carefully curated things is not a new idea. But Olivier Renaud-Clément, a private art dealer, has taken the concept to a new frontier. His 1,500-square-foot Long Island City loft is white from floor to ceiling — “I look at pictures all day long,” he said by way of explanation — and it is so streamlined that there are no doors, save for the front door and one to the storage room. (Not only is there no bathroom door, but there’s no bathroom wall, either; a pane of glass and a sheer curtain are all that separates it from view, so when Renaud-Clément has a party, he advises female guests to use the restroom off the lobby downstairs.) The tiny kitchen has mirrored glass cabinets; make a cup of tea and you’re Windexing for 20 minutes.

The Samurai Shopper, though steeped in ineffable ancient wisdom, sometimes falls asleep at the wheel. (The invention of the wheel? Totally missed that.) I wasn’t around when Paleolithic mamas and papas created stunning polychromatic paintings in the Altamira caves. But I’d bet the farm that those Stone Agers burned mossy wicks in animal fat to light their way into prehistoric rock stardom. Since then, civilization has spent more time bathed in the haze of candlelight than not.

We have seen the future, and it looks bright as advertised. And that is because the future will be lit by OLED’s (shorthand for organic light-emitting diodes). These paper-thin, superflexible panels are already being used in things like television and cellphone screens, but the lighting designer Ingo Maurer, known for his angelic flying light bulbs and chandeliers festooned with either broken plates or love notes, is the first to apply the technology to domestic lighting. Maurer was recently commissioned by the German company Osram Opto Semiconductors to play around with the possibilities of this new light source. His sleek table lamp, Early Future (above), which looks like an old-fashioned television antenna fitted with solar panels, is being produced by Osram in a limited edition. (A larger, suspended light, called Flying Future, which looks like a flying carpet circa 2099, is for the time being only a one-off.) OLED’s give off a white light that is less harsh, more uniform and more energy efficient than fluorescent light, and is said to be the closest simulation of actual sunlight. The panels can be made in large transparent sheets, so the next step, according to sources at Osram, would be to develop entire windows or skylights that let in the natural light by day and light up at night. Better wear shades. [?][?][?]ALIX BROWNE.
