The phrase “20th-century American design” brings to mind mass-produced modernist furnishings. But while off-the-rack furniture was having its heyday, a couture movement was flowering as well. “Modern Americana: Studio Furniture From High Craft to High Glam” (Rizzoli, $75) — by Todd Merrill, an antiques and decorative-arts dealer, and Julie V. Iovine, the executive editor of The Architect’s Newspaper — surveys the diverse directions studio designers and craftsmen took with high-end artisanal pieces. The organic wood designs of people like Wharton Esherick and Sam Maloof are shown, as is the glamorous, decorative modernism of Tommi Parzinger and James Mont and the bold opulence of Paul Evans and Karl Springer, to name a few of the 27 designers featured in the book. [?][?][?]PILAR VILADAS.
Cactus by Guido Drocco and Franco Mello for Gufram, price on request. Go to luminaire.com.

There are plenty of nonelectric coffee makers out there, but for a blend of simplicity and beauty, nothing beats the Chemex. This drip pot, with its hourglass flask — made of heatproof, laboratory-grade borosilicate glass — and corsetlike wooden grip, tied with a leather cord and a wooden bead, has an elegant sobriety that appeals to my low-tech, Birkenstock-wearing, inconspicuous-consumption side. All you do is pop in a filter, add ground coffee, then water, and voilà: a perfect cup (or 10) of java. The Chemex, which was designed in 1941 by Peter J. Schlumbohm, an inventor with a Ph.D. in chemistry and over 3,000 patents to his name, is in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art, and even though I have way too many coffee makers for my pint-size pantry, it’s going to stay in my permanent collection, too. [?][?][?]PILAR VILADAS.

The Americana at Brand rises from its 15.5-acre lot in downtown Glendale, Calif., like the setting for a short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald. From my seat aboard the vintage-style trolley that makes a circuit around this $400 million outdoor shopping mall and residential community, I glide down what reminds me of Rodeo Drive to Rush Street in Chicago, skirt the dancing fountain in Vegas, turn onto Newbury Street in Boston and end up in New Orleans, each stop announced by the cheerful ringing of the conductor’s bell. The Americana, where I’m spending a weekend, is the newly minted brainchild of the California megadeveloper Rick Caruso, the force behind the Grove in Los Angeles and a family of other open-air retail developments that turn up the design volume on the dreary shopping mall experience, past theme-park kitsch, all the way to something sublime, say, a Diamond as Big as the Ritz.

The leather-clad architect and interior designer Peter Marino has created spaces for the A-list of the airbrush set. (He’s currently working on a new Louis Vuitton “tower” boutique in Tokyo and an Ermenegildo Zegna flagship in Hong Kong, to name but two.) Having applied his modern, muscular touch to everything from Andy Warhol’s town house to a yacht for Valentino, Marino has become something of a front-row regular. “I am very much a part of the fashion community,” he admits. “I follow trends.” Of his own Tom of Finland-meets-“Easy Rider” get-ups, Marino prefers a different sort of label: “Most are traditional motorcycle police regulation clothes available for purchase on the Internet.” [?][?][?]ALEX HAWGOOD.

India Mahdavi isn’t afraid to use her feminine wiles. The Paris-based architect/designer’s sexy, chic interiors and furniture combine and contrast round, sensual shapes with masculine materials and warm colors with cold ones. Her signature lighthearted tables and stools — in shapes like chess pieces and flowers — act as playful punctuation marks. She’s shown here in her Left Bank showroom next to the Superstarr table, which is also available at ralphpucci.net. Or go to india-mahdavi.com for more details.

Not every biographer has access to the books his subject read in his youth, complete with underlines and adolescent aperçus scribbled in the margins. In “Le Corbusier: A Life” (Knopf), Nicholas Fox Weber examines the architect’s copy of Ernest Renan’s “Life of Jesus,” in which the following passage is marked: “Jesus is not a spiritualist; for him everything has a palpable realization. But he is a fulfilled idealist, for him matter is only the sign of the idea.” Written alongside is this ecstatic proclamation: “And I herewith create everything anew! This is the feature all reformers share.” Indeed, the young reader went on to remodel the world.

Liz Larkin was up early on a recent Saturday morning, wielding oven mitts and a big flashlight, punching a timer to stop its pinging. Shining a beam horizontally through the window of her three-rack Kenmore oven, she checked the progress on three trays of puffy, triangular scones — cranberry-orange, pumpkin and chocolate chip. More scones cooled on tiered racks, and a few dozen stood ready for baking. On the other end of the century-old shingled house in Pound Ridge, her two children laughed uproariously but kept their distance.

Bravo to Jennifer Egan for a compelling narrative of three families living with pediatric bipolar disorder. Her article plumbs the depths of the disorder’s consequences — on the child living with bipolar disorder and their siblings and parents. The subjects of “The Bipolar Puzzle” (Sept. 14) are the lucky ones. The severe shortage of child and adolescent psychiatrists, the lack of health-insurance parity for mental illnesses and a lack of understanding about what is and what is not bipolar disorder have caused many to slip through the cracks. Hopefully, this article will enlighten readers of bipolar disorder’s devastation and the urgency of supporting research to find better treatments and ultimately a cure.

Next month, boys will reluctantly don coat and tie, as parents spruce up their sons for the Jewish holidays and for winter holiday card photos. ''People don't realize that the real rush for kids' holiday clothes is now, '' said Andrea Harmon, the trend director at the Children's Place. ''The stores are mobbed with parents.'' Since girls often already own dress-up clothes, the boys require the extra attention. This year's look: classic with a tweak, like a comfy sweatshirt-jersey blazer or '70s-style pullovers to buffer the ignominy of neckties and -- oh, the horror -- real shoes.

HOLZBOG--Thomas Jerald, Architect and Planner Thomas Jerald Holzbog of Los Angeles, California recently passed away unexpectedly in Madrid, Spain on September 24, 2008 while traveling with his beloved partner, Janet Dreisen. He was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin on October 25, 1933 and will be missed greatly by many especially those in the architectural community where he was noted for his contemporary style, and recognized as a spokesman and educator in the environmental design community. In four decades of practice, he established a reputation for design excellence with work that was award-winning and widely published. He was known for bridging the realms of architecture, planning and landscape. He was a recognized authority in prefabricated housing and industrialized building and will always be remembered as a pioneer in that field. His large-scale projects included master planning of new towns, campuses and theme parks around the world. In addition, he sustained an involvement with local commissions and advisory boards while continuing to serve ad-hoc as a teacher, critic, and speaker. He received a degree in architecture from Yale University and a graduate degree in urban planning from Harvard University. He was a Fulbright scholar and served in the US Armed Forces. He leaves behind his former wife Wendy Wilson, his two beloved daughters, Jessica Jayne and Arabella Ezralow, son-in-law Daniel Ezralow, grandson Elijah Ezralow, brother Charles Holzbog and sister-in-law Margaret Holzbog and other family and friends. He was a devoted father, grandfather and brother. He was an active sportsman who loved his weekly tennis matches with his friends and loved swimming, especially with his grandson. He will be dearly missed by his family, friends and all of the hearts he touched. Memorial services pending.

GETTING away from the trappings of civilization has always been one of hiking's great allures, along with the possibility of a dramatic payoff in wildlife sightings and sweeping views. But keeping the region's hiking areas away from those trappings is often complicated. The one major requirement of hiking is open space, and lots of it, a commodity in ever-decreasing supply across the suburbs. Throughout the region, residents have either donated undeveloped land to a public trust or joined together to convince local governments that sometimes a parcel of natural beauty is worth saving for its own sake. What follow are suburban hiking areas that were created through the past and present efforts of these preservationists.

To the Editor: I was a member of the Norwalk High Marching Bears from 1985 to 1989, the beginning of Jeff Smith's tenure at Norwalk High School. During those four years, the band made huge leaps in becoming the dominant program that Mr. Smith has maintained for 20 years. While it's great to see the recovery of the band profiled (''A Lot Like Boot Camp, but With Horns and Drums,'' Sept. 14), the real story is Jeff Smith. His dedication, as well as his high and unyielding expectations remain an important and inspirational lesson in my life. We all could use more teachers like him. Thank you for the article.

THE NEWS China launched the Shenzhou VII spacecraft into a low orbit of Earth with a crew of three expected to carry out the nation's first spacewalk. BEHIND THE NEWS China got a late start at space exploration -- Russia and the United States conducted their first spacewalks in 1965 -- but the country has been building its program rapidly and its ''taikonauts'' are gaining fast on the cosmonauts and astronauts of Russia and the West. China plans a space station by 2020 and, eventually, a Moon landing. While the 1960s space race was driven mainly by cold war competition, China's effort now is aimed more at building national prestige and technical skill.

KAYE--Dr. Carol. The community of Analysts and Candidates at the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research (IPTAR) expresses its deep sadness at the death of Dr. Carol Kaye. Dr. Kaye's involvement at IPTAR spanned almost 40 years as a Fellow, supervisor, teacher, mentor and member of the Board of Directors and the Training Institute. As Chair of Education and Research she shaped the Third Avenue Series, a venue for members to present their work. She was a moving force in our admission to IPA. ROBERTSON--Nancy Coleman. Nancy Robertson of Naples, FL and Freeport, ME, formerly of Baltimore, MD and NYC, NY, died on Friday September 19th at the Gosnell Hospice House in Scarborough, ME after a battle with cancer. Nancy was born in Boston, MA on August 16, 1944, the daughter of John J. and Mary (Moran) Coleman. She attended Manhattanville College graduating in 1966. She married her first husband, A. Heaton Robertson, just out of college and had two children. Nancy then went on to have a successful career as a senior executive in commercial banking in Boston, NY and Baltimore. After retiring from banking, she enjoyed a second career in venture philanthropy, where she used her business expertise to advise and guide non - profit organizations. Nancy married Carl Stearn in the spring of 2005, but lost him to cancer less than a year later. Nancy was a beloved mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, wife and friend. She was a strong, independent and remarkably generous woman who will be much missed. She is survived by her children Emily Smith (Greg) Freeport, ME and Noah Robertson (Amanda), Jackson Hole, WY her grandchildren Nate and Elias Smith, Addie and Rufus Robertson, her sister Patricia Frechette (John), Mashpee, MA and Naples, FL, her niece Jule Frechette, Boston, MA, her nephews Josh Frechette (Trixie), San Rafael, CA and Sean Frechette (Innbo Shim) Brooklyn, NY. A memorial service will be held at the South Freeport Church, 98 South Freeport Road, Freeport, ME on Friday October 10th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: Common Good Ventures, 14 Main Street, Brunswick, ME 04011; National Downs Syndrome Society, 666 Broadway, New York, NY 10012; or a charity of your choice.

RUTHERFORD--G. Williams, October 5, 1920 August 31, 2008. Born October 5, 1920, to Greta and Williams Rutherford in Deming, New Mexico, Mr. Rutherford spent his younger years moving throughout the West, attending high school at New Mexico Military Institute. He moved to San Diego in 1941, having completed training at Art Center in Pasadena as a photographer. During World War II, he worked for Consairways as a celestial navigator delivering planes from San Diego to the troops in the South Pacific. In 1943 he married Anna Gwyn Foster Dearing of Coronado, California. After the War, Mr. Rutherford attended Stanford University, completing an AB in Economics and Accounting (Phi Beta Kappa) and a JD from the Stanford Law School. He joined Ryan Aeronautical, San Diego, in the legal department, but was almost immediately promoted to Assistant Controller, and then Manager of the newly formed Electronics Division. Over the next 20 years, Mr. Rutherford took on increasingly complex management responsibility. By 1969, when Teledyne acquired Ryan Aeronautical, Mr. Rutherford was appointed Vice President and Group Executive of Teledyne Inc., responsible for up to 25 companies of the Teledyne Pacific Group. At his retirement in 1989, this sector of Teledyne produced sales of $1.4 billion from its aerospace, electronics and heavy manufacturing companies. Those who worked with him believed Mr. Rutherford to be a pioneer in the art of group management a brilliant, creative and imaginative businessman who could coordinate disparate companies and produce profitable results year after year. He was wellknown for his commitment to the people who worked for him, and was admired as a leader, a teacher, and an innovator. Many businessmen and women around the world considered Bill Rutherford their mentor and friend. His creative approach to problem solving, and his vision of excellence inspired all who had the privilege of his company. As a lifelong Episcopalian, Mr. Rutherford brought his considerable management talent and passion to the Church. He served on boards of schools and vestries of churches, always encouraging those in leadership positions to step out in faith. Mr. Rutherford is survived by his son, Dr. George Williams Rutherford III of Piedmont, CA, his daughter, the Rev. Amanda Rutherford May of San Diego, his step-daughter, Mrs. Alexandra Waits of El Cajon, his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. His wife of 60 years, Anna Gwyn Rutherford died in 2004, and his son Timothy Christopher Rutherford died in 2007. A Celebration of Mr. Rutherfords Life will be held at 3pm on Sunday, October 5, 2008, at All Souls Episcopal Church in San Diego. WOOD--William Hiram Jr., 87, of Watertown, MA, died Friday, September 26 at Mt. Auburn Hospital, Cambridge MA. He was born July 6, 1921 in Boston to William Hiram Wood, Sr., born in Lawrence MA in 1895, and Dorothy Pushee, born in Antigonish, Nova Scotia in 1892. He was the grandson of John Thomas Wood, born in 1864 in Saddleworth, Yorkshire, who immigrated to Lawrence as a young boy with his adoptive father Samuel Butterworth. He was the great-great grandson of Nathan Pushee, born 1758 in Lunenburg, MA, trumpet-major of General Washington's staff in the Revolutionary War. He grew up in Canton MA and graduated from Phillips Academy in 1938; he received his SB in American History from Harvard College in 1942; he served in the US Army Signal Corps in the Pacific on Saipan and Guam; he continued his education after the war on the GI Bill; he received an MA from Boston University in 1947 and spent the next four years at Yale University pursuing an uncompleted Ph.D. He worked for the Air Force, the Institute for Naval Studies, the Sperry Rand Research Center, and the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics. From 1980 until his retirement in 1996, he was a technical writer with Intermetrics in Cambridge. He spent almost his entire life in Massachusetts, including many years in Framingham and Duxbury prior to finally settling in Watertown over 25 years ago. In 1942 he married the late Patricia Stevens, born in Newburyport, MA in 1922, and in 1997 he married the late Julie Owen, born in Concord, NH in 1926. He is survived by a son, William Hiram Wood of Watertown and a sister, Barbara Denton Wood Barnard, of Marstons Mills, MA and Melbourne, Florida. He was a lifelong lover of his country and the Democratic party; he was a passionate believer in equality of opportunity and economic justice. Gifts in his memory may be made to the Democratic National Committee. His cremated remains will be interred at the municipal cemetery in Canton. Atque in perpetuum pater, ave atque vale.

COMMUNING WITH UNION PACIFIC NO. 844,DENVER, JULY 20, 2008 Barbara Moran, 57, from Topeka, Kan. ''I have autism and I draw pictures and I sell them at galleries and disability conferences. I decided early last year that I wanted to draw something new. And because I liked Thomas the Tank Engine, I thought, 'Why don't I start drawing choo-choos?' So I went and got all kinds of steam engine books. I hadn't really paid too much attention to steam engines before, but I went and saw those pictures, and now the iron horse is my favorite animal, and I'm glad they're not extinct yet. Union Pacific has two steam engines that they take out on the road. This is No. 844 -- I met him last year, and I went to Denver this year just so I could hang out with him. I've gotten very fond of 844, and I did spend a lot of time talking to him. He loves to get his picture taken. I was holding my arms up like that, sort of like saying 'I love you this much.' We have one steam engine in Topeka, but it's a dead one and it looks like roadkill. I wish that engine was alive like 844 is.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

Bernard Shanik and his sister Shirley Fleischer. Leo Shanik will be forever in our hearts, always in our thoughts and never forgotten.

WAEHLER--Frank, 88, Architect and former Managing Partner of HLW Architects/ Engineers--died Saturday, September 20th, at Sarasota Memorial Hospital of complications from cancer and heart disease. Mr. Waehler served in the Army Air Corps in WWII as a Navigator/Bombardier, flying B-26's in the European Theatre. After the war, he joined the firm of Voorhees Walker Foley & Smith, at the time the largest Architectural/Engineering firm in the country. In 1962 he became a partner in the firm. The firm eventually became Haines Lundberg Waehler (HLW today) and is currently providing Architectural and Engineering services for its clients worldwide. He is a graduate and former Trustee of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art. Mr. Waehler's notable projects include The National Bureau of Standards Research and Test Center in Maryland; The International Institute of Tropical Agriculture in Nigeria; The Centro Sperimentale Metallugico in Rome; and the American University in Beirut. He was married to Catherine Patricia Waehler for 57 years and is survived by three children, James Waehler (Ocean View, Delaware), Kathy Waehler (Sparta, NJ) and Steven Waehler (Sparta, NJ) as well as seven grandchildren: Marcus, Russell, Katie and Georgia Waehler, Sarah and Victoria Nosal, and Franny Bittman. A private memorial service is planned in Sparta, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 225 N. Michigan Ave., Chicago, IL 60601-7633.

SOPANEN--Jeri Rainer, 79 born in Helsinki, Finland, died peacefully September 21 after a battle with cancer. He lived a long and enviable life--his career as a cinematographer taking him around the world eight times. He is best known for his work on such films and documentaries as My Dinner with Andre, Gardens of the World with Audrey Hepburn, The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau, The Gig, A Midsummer Nights Sex Comedy, The Plimpton! Series, and numerous Nova and National Geographic specials. He was loved by his family for his kind, gentle, generous, humble (yet proud), brilliant ways. He asked little of this world and genuinely appreciated everything he received. He was a man of few words (even though he spoke 7 languages), but His subtle, mischievous smile spoke for him. He will be profoundly missed by his wife, Marja, his three children, Mark Huneke, Anya Huneke, and Eric Sopanen, and his step-family, Mark, Petra, and Rebecca Roth. A Memorial service will be held at St. John's Lutheran Church, 83 Christopher Street, New York, NY 10014 on Saturday, October 4 at 2:00pm.

LAMPTON--Dinwiddie, Jr. lived life with a flourish, particularly when driving his own coach, lines of four horses in hand. His hard work at American Life, the company his father started in 1906, lasted consistently for 40 years. Many of his employees stayed with the company forty years or more. His longterm thinking has been a benefit to the company. The motto he created, ''Be wise, be insured'' announced by coaching horn, proved beneficial to company identity. His personal motto was ''whip and kick and don't give up, you've got an eternity to rest.'' He graduated from Culver Military Academy, attended St. John's College in Annapolis, MD. In 1935, his father recalled him to Louisville to work at the company because Dinwiddie Sr. was very ill. He was the first to say he learned on the job. As a boy, he showed saddlebreds, as a young man competed in polo, then raced over jumps in steeplechases, raced on the flat in the original ''Gentlemen'' races at Churchill Downs, and ended with 30 years of driving horses to an array of vehicles, mostly 19th century rolling stock. He was a member of the American Carriage Association, The Coaching Club, and the Metropolitan Club in NYC. It was there he swung four horses and a carriage through the original coaching turnaround at 60th and Fifth Avenue. Club staff came out protesting, ''You can't do that!'' answered by ''But I just did!'' For 39 years he was married to Nancy Houghland from Nashville, TN. He and his family helped make the Hardscuffle Steeplechase a noteworthy race meet. His second marriage was to Elizabeth Whitcomb Brown who also drove horses to carriages. She was killed in March 2008 in a driving accident with carriage and four horses. As a young man, he was initiated into Masonry, and is a 33rd degree member of the Scottish Rite, The Royal Order of Scotland, the Red Cross of Constantine, Kosair Shrine, York Rite Commandery and the Military Order of World Wars. He served on the Regional Board of the Salvation Army and as Director of Citizens Fidelity Bank from 1965-1975. As a believer in saving land, he bought several farms for the company in perpetuity, including ''Elmendorf' in Lexington, KY, ''Beechdale'' in Pennsylvania, and ''Hardscuffle'' in Kentucky. He is survived by his sons, Dinwiddie Lampton, III, married to Irene de Boor; Mason H. Lampton married to Mary Lucile Hardaway; and a daughter, Nana Lampton; his sister Mary Jane Lampton Peabody married to Royden Peabody, II; grandchildren, Mary Wendell Lampton of Virginia Beach, VA; Mason Hardaway Lampton, married to Suzanna Lott, of Columbus, GA; and Lucile Lampton Cogswell, married to William Cogswell of Charleston, SC; as well as five great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at 1:00pm on Monday, September 29 at The Olmsted at the Masonic Home, 3701 Frankfort Avenue, Louisville, KY with burial to follow in Cave Hill Cemetery. Visitation will be on Monday from 11:30am until time of service. Pearsons, 149 Breckenridge Lane, in charge of services. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Salvation Army, Culver Military Academy, The Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation, or the, Carriage Museum of America at the KY Horse Park.

BYLINSKY--Gene Michael, 77, died Thursday, September 18 in Loveland, CO. Born in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, the son of the late Rev. Michael Bylinsky and Dora Shadan, he was an award-winning writer for Fortune Magazine, covering science and technology. Prior to Fortune Magazine, Mr. Bylinsky was a member of the White House press corps and was a staff reporter for the Wall Street Journal. He won numerous journalism awards, including the Albert Lasker Medical Journalism Award and the American Chemical Society's James T. Grady medal. He was the author of four books: The Innovation Millionaires, Mood Control, Life in Darwin's Universe, and Silicon Valley: High-Tech Window to the Future. Mr. Bylinsky earned a B.A. in journalism from Louisiana State University. He is survived by his wife, Gwen; his daughter Tanya Fabian, son Gregory Bylinsky and six grandchildren. He is also survived by his niece, Inna Rodzianko and nephew Victor Rydlizky. He was preceded in death by his sister, Ia Rydlizky. Donations in his memory may be made to Father Woody's Haven of Hope (a homeless shelter), 1101 West 7th Avenue, Denver, CO 80204.

HABER--Emanuel Hon., 89. Beloved husband of his cherished Millicent, loving father of Bruce Haber and Jody Salzinger, adoring grandfather of Sarah, Amy, Jonathan and Julie, dear brother of Rosalind Halper, brother-in-law Norman Halper, daughter-inlaw Susan Haber and son-inlaw Eric Salzinger. Alumnus of Harvard Law School, trial lawyer and partner in the firm of Weisman, Celler, Allen, Spett and Sheinberg, longtime Judge of New York Civil and Housing Courts, six term President of the Association of Housing Court Judges, and decorated World War II Combat Air Force Veteran. He was an enthusiastic sports fan, enjoyed the theatre, and was an avid reader. Above all, he was devoted to his family. Services Sunday, September 28th at 10am at ''Schwartz Bros.'', Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

KETTERER--Judith Evelyn Frank, M.D. Judith Evelyn Frank Ketterer, M.D., 72, died at home on September 24, 2008 in Hanover, NH. She was born in 1935 in Brooklyn, NY, the daughter of Walter Nils and Ruth (Carlson) Frank. She grew up in Ridgewood, NJ. She graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1957 and New York Medical College in 1961 where she was one of five women in a class of 125. She was married to John G. Ketterer Jr. M.D. in 1960, but professionally she remained Dr. Frank. Dr. Frank trained at the Cleveland Clinic and completed her residency in pediatrics at St. Luke's Hospital in New York, NY. Dr. Frank joined Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center in 1974, where she was a Professor of Pediatrics specializing in neonatology, newborn intensive care. She was the second neonatologist to practice in the state of New Hampshire and the first woman faculty member in the Department of Pediatrics. She served as the Associate Medical Director of the Children's Hospital at Dartmouth (CHaD), as well as the medical director for the CHaD Regional Outreach Program. She was on the faculty of Dartmouth Medical School. Dr. Frank was also a researcher and was invited to Washington, DC in 1995 to testify before Congress on the long term risks of discharging newborns and their mothers too quickly. She was a lifetime champion of children's causes. In 2006, when Dr. Frank transitioned to parttime, the DHMC pediatrics library became the Frank Pediatric Library. She is survived by her husband John; children John G. Ketterer III of Rumson, NJ; Lyn Ketterer of Cambridge, MA; and Kristin Ketterer Oden of Bedford, NY; and four grandchildren. She was predeceased by her brother Walter N. Frank Jr., her mother Ruth C. Frank and her father Walter N. Frank Sr., a former Chairman of the Board of the New York Stock Exchange. Funeral service 1pm, Saturday, October 4th, Church of Christ Hanover, NH. Burial at Pine Knoll Cemetery, Hanover. Contributions in her memory may be made to ChaD (Children's Hospital at Dartmouth), 1 Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, NH 03756.

GEORGES ROUSSE Equal parts illusion, installation and graffiti, the work of the Paris-based artist Georges Rousse is never quite what it seems. Rousse painted this issue's T (Page 117; another version appears above) in pieces on the floor, staircase, window and walls of an abandoned building, his canvas du jour. (It comes together as a ''T'' when you look at it dead-on.) For a man who exhibits his work all over the globe -- he currently has a show up at the Johyun Gallery in Seoul; an exhibition at the Museo de Arte Contemporáneo de Rosario in Argentina goes up in November -- it's no surprise that his ideas come from scattered sources. (Two examples of his work are shown at left.) ''I am inspired by my travels all around the world and the contact with different countries and their cultures,'' he says. But for Rousse, fragmentation is paradoxically a great catalyst for unity. ''I am looking for something like a universal language.''

GETTING away from the trappings of civilization has always been one of hiking's great allures, along with the possibility of a dramatic payoff in wildlife sightings and sweeping views. But keeping the region's hiking areas away from those trappings is often complicated. The one major requirement of hiking is open space, and lots of it, a commodity in ever-decreasing supply across the suburbs. Throughout the region, residents have either donated undeveloped land to a public trust or joined together to convince local governments that sometimes a parcel of natural beauty is worth saving for its own sake. What follow are suburban hiking areas that were created through the past and present efforts of these preservationists.
Address: 50 Hitching Post Lane The Property: A five-

HERZ--Cary, photographer, born June 15, 1947 in New York City, died of ovarian cancer on September 1, 2008 in Albuquerque. Her career as a photojournalist began in New York in the 1970s as she documented the women's movement and women's sports. For the last 24 years Cary worked in New Mexico as a free-lance photographer. In 2007, she published the book, ''New Mexico's CryptoJews: Image and Memory.'' She was a 2008 co-winner of the National Federation of Press Women's Communicator of Achievement Award. Cary is survived by her partner, Sue LeGrand; children, Davielle and Alexandra Lakind; Sue's children, Paul, Elena, and Simon; and a large extended family of cousins and friends. She was preceded in death by her parents, Fred and Gert Herz, and her brother, Leonard Alan. Access Cary's work at: www.caryherz.com

One day they're up; the next they're down. No one can predict where oil prices are going, but millions of people are willing to make a bet on them every day. That makes it an exciting, if exhausting, time to be an energy trader. In the crude oil futures pit at the New York Mercantile Exchange, most trades are conducted electronically, but some orders are still taken by phone. In the nearby energy options pit, traders still work the old-fashioned way, jostling one another as they point, twist and shout to make transactions. It's a raucous world, where every gesture and sound mean dollars lost or gained.

MEASURE FOR MEASURE I got the idea for ''Tom's Diner'' in 1981, but I wrote it in the spring of 1982. When I was at Barnard College in Manhattan, I used to go to Tom's Restaurant for coffee, and after I graduated I also ate there before going to work. It was then a cheap, greasy place on 112th Street and Broadway, and it still is, in spite of its celebrity. And yes, it is the same one they use in the ''Seinfeld'' credits -- the neon sign that says ''Restaurant.'' I actually once saw Jerry Seinfeld right near there! The melody hit me as I was walking down Broadway, fast. I wanted something jaunty. I remember liking the near-rhymes of ''diner'' and ''corner,'' ''sitting'' and ''waiting.'' Although it is actually Tom's Restaurant I changed it to ''diner'' as it sings better.

LEBWORTH--Caral Gimbel, died peacefully in her home on September 25, 2008. after a short illness. Caral was born on November 29, 1914 to Bernard F. and Alva B. Gimbel. The two great passions of Caral's long Iife were horses and the arts. At the age of 17, she dropped out of high school and went to Paris to study art for two years. There, she met and befriended many of the great painters of the day. She returned to New York and married Edward Lasker on February 1, 1935. They divorced ten years later. In 1946 Caral married Hall of Fame baseball player Hank Greenberg with whom she had three children --Glenn, Stephen and Alva Greenberg. Caral and Hank spent most of their marriage in Cleveland, Ohio where Caral pursued her passion for equestrian sports and Hank served as part owner and general manager of the Cleveland Indians baseball team. They divorced in 1959 and both moved back to New York, where Caral lived for the remainder of her life. In 1962, Caral married Joseph Lebworth with whom she spent the next 46 years in New York City, up until his death in May of this year. Caral began her equestrian career early and was riding competitively by the age of 14. She competed in hunting and jumping, both in the U.S. and abroad. She rode several times in Madison Square Garden at the National Horse Show and won numerous ribbons and trophies. Caral often rode in a hunt team with her mother and twin sister, Hope Solinger. While an accomplished painter in her youth, she gave up making art in favor of collecting it. She was a strong patron of the arts and supported many organizations such as Plays for Living, the Museum of Modern Art and Independent Curators International. Caral is survived by her sister, her three children, ten grandchildren and one great-grandson. A private service will be held in October. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Independent Curators International, 799 Broadway, New York, NY 10003.

FERRARA--Isabel, of Oyster Bay, died on September 25, 2008. She was a graduate of the college of Mt. Saint Vincent; a Lady of Charity; and retired Deputy Director of the then Navy Resale and Services Support Office. She is survived by her brother Thomas Ferrara, her sisterin-law Nora Ferrara, and numerous nieces and nephews. She was preceded in death by her brother, Robert Ferrara and her sister, Virginia Valinoti. A memorial Mass will be held at 10:15am, Monday, September 29, 2008 at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bay Ridge, NY. Services are by James Romanelli-Stephen Funeral Home, 89-01 Rockaway Boulevard, Ozone Park, NY with viewing on Sunday, September 28th, 2008 between 2-5pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Salelsian Missions, 2 Lefevre Lane, P.O. Box 30, 10802.
MAYNARD--Nancy Hicks, service Friday, Oct. 3, 10:30am Fourth Universalist Society, 160 CPW at 76th St.

ROTH--Alan, passed from us in the early morning of September 22 in his home in Rancho Santa Fe, CA. Alan was surrounded by his loving family -wife Ingrid of 38 years and his son Andrew. Alan Roth was born in New York City to Mollie and Philip Roth on June 2, 1934, attended Mid-town Ethical Culture School and the Fieldston School in Riverdale, NY from 1946-1952. At Brown University he developed a lifelong passion for history and music, was a member of Pi Lambda Phi fraternity and served as the captain of the Brown soccer team. Alan graduated from Brown in 1956 as a junior Phi Beta Kappa scholar and an honor student. Alan went on to start his career at Lehman Brothers as a junior analyst in 1957 and in 1961 Alan left Lehman Brothers to start his own investment advisory firm, and, at the age of 27, he became one of the youngest to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. Alan specialized in entertainment and railroad stocks, and with his meticulous attention to details and strict adherence to honesty in his analyses, he quickly became one of the new young turks on Wall Street. We admire his outstanding achievements in life and his strong character of integrity and morals. He was very much dedicated to his family, and we are so very thankful for the many years we shared together. We love you and we miss you, and we wish you a safe journey until we see you again.

KAPNICK--Dr. George. The Officers and Board of Governors of the Jewish Lawyers Guild mourn the passing of Dr. George Kapnick, beloved father of our Past President, Hon. Barbara R. Kapnick. We extend our deepest sympathies to Dr. Kapnick's cherished wife, Betty Diamond Kapnick, his sons, Eric (Debbie) and Jeff (Beth) Kapnick, his grandchildren, and Justice Kapnick. Bruce N. Lederman, President Michael L. Katz, Chairperson

BARROW--Morton, 88, died on September 24, 2008 at The Arbor at Galloway Ridge, Pittsboro, NC of pancreatic cancer. Mort grew up in Brooklyn, NY, graduated from Brooklyn College in 1940, and received a JD from Columbia Law School in 1947. Serving as a captain in military intelligence during World War II, Mort was recalled to service during the Korean conflict. A 40-year resident of Roslyn Heights, NY, and Litchfield, CT, Mort built Weiner & Bauer, Inc. into a major textile converting operation. He had a passion for golf, tennis and community service, including co-founding the Shelter Rock Public Library in Albertson, New York. Mort and his wife, Evy, moved to Fearrington Village, NC in 1993, where Mort was active in local causes and served as a trustee of the Chatham Education Foundation. Mort will be remembered for his enjoyment of a good story, Paul Stuart and steak at Peter Luger's. Those lucky enough to have learned from him will remember his integrity and ethical principles. He was supportive especially of his grandchildren, delighting in their growth and accomplishments. Mort cared deeply about his family; his wife of 60 years, Evelyn Weiner Barrow; a son, Peter and wife, Amy of Wilmette, IL and their children Laura Geiger and husband Phil, Jeff and Julia; a daughter, Nancy Serrurier and husband, Greg of Menlo Park, CA and their children Kate and Ben; and a brother Alfred (deceased) and a sister, Ruth Resnick of Floral Park, NY. A celebration of Mort's life will be held at Galloway Ridge, NC on October 25, 2008 at 3:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Eastside College Prep School College Scholarship Fund, 1041 Myrtle Street, East Palo Alto, CA 94303.

BERN -- The Victoria Cup game between the Rangers and Metallurg will use a blend of N.H.L. and I.I.H.F. rules, and it will also use a mix of on-ice officials (one referee and linesman each from North America and Europe). Since my last update on Thursday, the disturbance that was near Hispaniola was upgraded to TS Kyle, then Hurricane Kyle and recently transitioned to an extratropical cyclone. It was around as a named storm for just 3.5 days, and as a hurricane for 1.25 days. It ended up following the forecast tracks very well, traveling straight north into Nova Scotia as a potent tropical storm.

He once dreamed of being a doctor and hates Botox, so it makes sense that the Lanvin designer Alber Elbaz has a more clinical approach to fashion. "I don't know if I'm making sexy clothes or not making sexy clothes," Elbaz tells Lynn Hirschberg in our latest exclusive Screen Test video. "I don't know what is the definition of sexy." But give the bespectacled Elbaz a moment to offer a diagnosis on his designs -- he'll tell you all about the ability of fashion to make the surreal real and the inherent emotionality of color, for example -- and you'll see why we (politely) beg to differ. In fact, it seems that Elbaz might have realized his childhood ambitions after all. "I don't have to give you a Tylenol to feel good. I'll give you, maybe, a red dress, and you'll feel marvelous," he confides. Paging Doctor Elbaz. . .

Elie Wiesel turns 80 on Tuesday, which by some coincidence of the calendar that might raise speculation about divine tinkering, turns out to be the first day of the Jewish New Year. There will be no public ceremony marking the milestone that day, though there will be one on Thursday, when the 92nd Street Y in Manhattan honors him with tributes and songs and questions tossed at Mr. Wiesel. Barbara Walters, Theodore Bikel and Arthur Gelb, the former managing editor of The New York Times, will be among those taking part.

Literature | A new English translation of Hugo's sprawling and digressive "Les Misérables" is 100,000 words longer than its best-known predecessor. So it draws attention to the translator's mission of sticking to an author's intent. Or in some cases not? In America, the 1863 "Confederate" edition, unlike a rival "Yankee" edition, "struck out all references to slavery." [TLS]

WOOD--William Hiram Jr., 87, of Watertown, MA, died Friday, September 26 at Mt. Auburn Hospital, Cambridge MA. He was born July 6, 1921 in Boston to William Hiram Wood, Sr., born in Lawrence MA in 1895, and Dorothy Pushee, born in Antigonish, Nova Scotia in 1892. He was the grandson of John Thomas Wood, born in 1864 in Saddleworth, Yorkshire, who immigrated to Lawrence as a young boy with his adoptive father Samuel Butterworth. He was the great-great grandson of Nathan Pushee, born 1758 in Lunenburg, MA, trumpet-major of General Washington's staff in the Revolutionary War. He grew up in Canton MA and graduated from Phillips Academy in 1938; he received his SB in American History from Harvard College in 1942; he served in the US Army Signal Corps in the Pacific on Saipan and Guam; he continued his education after the war on the GI Bill; he received an MA from Boston University in 1947 and spent the next four years at Yale University pursuing an uncompleted Ph.D. He worked for the Air Force, the Institute for Naval Studies, the Sperry Rand Research Center, and the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics. From 1980 until his retirement in 1996, he was a technical writer with Intermetrics in Cambridge. He spent almost his entire life in Massachusetts, including many years in Framingham and Duxbury prior to finally settling in Watertown over 25 years ago. In 1942 he married the late Patricia Stevens, born in Newburyport, MA in 1922, and in 1997 he married the late Julie Owen, born in Concord, NH in 1926. He is survived by a son, William Hiram Wood of Watertown and a sister, Barbara Denton Wood Barnard, of Marstons Mills, MA and Melbourne, Florida. He was a lifelong lover of his country and the Democratic party; he was a passionate believer in equality of opportunity and economic justice. Gifts in his memory may be made to the Democratic National Committee. His cremated remains will be interred at the municipal cemetery in Canton. Atque in perpetuum pater, ave atque vale.

BEN-AVI--Avrum. Born in New York City, November 8, 1916, died peacefully at home in Sarasota, Florida, on September 27, 2008. Esteemed psychologist/psychoanalyst. He was, for some 50 years, in private practice; professor and supervisor in both The Doctoral Program and The Post Doctoral Program in Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy at New York University. He started the Postdoctoral program. Handsome beyond reason, brilliant and curious, witty, charming, elegant, beloved, respected and admired by all who knew him, he was the analysts' analyst. A Jew, an atheist, he studied at Yale Divinity School for eight years after he retired. An officer in World War II, he designed tests to determine who was best fit to fly bombing missions. He leaves Rachel, his wife of 26 years; Joan, his first wife, of 34 years; and their three children, Sigrid, Jason, and Nina; as well as four grandchildren, Julia and Emma, Alice and Sarah, and sons-in-law, Reg Balmer and Marc Schreiber. Sitting Shiva 4 - 9pm, Wednesday and Thursday.

BYLINSKY--Gene Michael, 77, died Thursday, September 18 in Loveland, CO. Born in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, the son of the late Rev. Michael Bylinsky and Dora Shadan, he was an award-winning writer for Fortune Magazine, covering science and technology. Prior to Fortune Magazine, Mr. Bylinsky was a member of the White House press corps and was a staff reporter for the Wall Street Journal. He won numerous journalism awards, including the Albert Lasker Medical Journalism Award and the American Chemical Society's James T. Grady medal. He was the author of four books: The Innovation Millionaires, Mood Control, Life in Darwin's Universe, and Silicon Valley: High-Tech Window to the Future. Mr. Bylinsky earned a B.A. in journalism from Louisiana State University. He is survived by his wife, Gwen; his daughter Tanya Fabian, son Gregory Bylinsky and six grandchildren. He is also survived by his niece, Inna Rodzianko and nephew Victor Rydlizky. He was preceded in death by his sister, Ia Rydlizky. BARROW--Morton, 88, died on September 24, 2008 at The Arbor at Galloway Ridge, Pittsboro, NC of pancreatic cancer. Mort grew up in Brooklyn, NY, graduated from Brooklyn College in 1940, and received a JD from Columbia Law School in 1947. Serving as a captain in military intelligence during World War II, Mort was recalled to service during the Korean conflict. A 40-year resident of Roslyn Heights, NY, and Litchfield, CT, Mort built Weiner & Bauer, Inc. into a major textile converting operation. He had a passion for golf, tennis and community service, including co-founding the Shelter Rock Public Library in Albertson, New York. Mort and his wife, Evy, moved to Fearrington Village, NC in 1993, where Mort was active in local causes and served as a trustee of the Chatham Education Foundation. Mort will be remembered for his enjoyment of a good story, Paul Stuart and steak at Peter Luger's. Those lucky enough to have learned from him will remember his integrity and ethical principles. He was supportive especially of his grandchildren, delighting in their growth and accomplishments. Mort cared deeply about his family; his wife of 60 years, Evelyn Weiner Barrow; a son, Peter and wife, Amy of Wilmette, IL and their children Laura Geiger and husband Phil, Jeff and Julia; a daughter, Nancy Serrurier and husband, Greg of Menlo Park, CA and their children Kate and Ben; and a brother Alfred (deceased) and a sister, Ruth Resnick of Floral Park, NY. A celebration of Mort's life will be held at Galloway Ridge, NC on October 25, 2008 at 3:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Eastside College Prep School College Scholarship Fund, 1041 Myrtle Street, East Palo Alto, CA 94303.

KELLIE PICKLER ''Kellie Pickler'' (19/BNA) Whether they were honest tears or the crocodile kind, the waterworks on Kellie Pickler's face at the Country Music Association awards in November as she performed ''I Wonder,'' about the mother who abandoned her at age 2, were an instant career-maker. For this singer -- who that same month announced, ''I thought Europe was a country,'' on the game show ''Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?'' -- it was a rare, and needed, flash of seriousness, proof that there was more to the former ''American Idol'' contestant than doe eyes and blank sweetness.

The Ravens and the Steelers probably had no intention of relying on their first-round picks so early, but circumstances changed the thinking on each side. Baltimore turned to quarterback Joe Flacco when Kyle Boller (shoulder) and Troy Smith (infection) were not ready to start the season. The Steelers' top pick, running back Rashard Mendenhall, will start in place of Willie Parker (sprained knee). So Mendenhall and Flacco each has an opportunity, but it is hard to call it an enviable one. Mendenhall will be facing Baltimore's top-ranked defense. Flacco will be staring at the league's second-ranked unit insecure in the knowledge that the Steelers' ability to stop the run (64.3 yards a game) will put even more pressure on his passing. He has produced two wins but below-average numbers (258 yards passing and a 55.7 rating).

JENNY LEWIS ''Acid Tongue'' (Warner Brothers) The Jenny Lewis of ''Rabbit Fur Coat,'' her 2006 solo debut album, was restrained and polished and sweet. The soft and breathy vocals, the clean country-rock arrangements, the slightly-too-warm emotions: it all felt a bit prosaic, as if the former child actress wasn't quite yet ready to unburden herself. She was joined throughout by the Watson Twins, whose prim, wistful harmonies were lovely, but only thickened the haze surrounding her.

LEBWORTH--Caral Gimbel, died peacefully in her home on September 25, 2008. after a short illness. Caral was born on November 29, 1914 to Bernard F. and Alva B. Gimbel. The two great passions of Caral's long Iife were horses and the arts. At the age of 17, she dropped out of high school and went to Paris to study art for two years. There, she met and befriended many of the great painters of the day. She returned to New York and married Edward Lasker on February 1, 1935. They divorced ten years later. In 1946 Caral married Hall of Fame baseball player Hank Greenberg with whom she had three children --Glenn, Stephen and Alva Greenberg. Caral and Hank spent most of their marriage in Cleveland, Ohio where Caral pursued her passion for equestrian sports and Hank served as part owner and general manager of the Cleveland Indians baseball team. They divorced in 1959 and both moved back to New York, where Caral lived for the remainder of her life. In 1962, Caral married Joseph Lebworth with whom she spent the next 46 years in New York City, up until his death in May of this year. Caral began her equestrian career early and was riding competitively by the age of 14. She competed in hunting and jumping, both in the U.S. and abroad. She rode several times in Madison Square Garden at the National Horse Show and won numerous ribbons and trophies. Caral often rode in a hunt team with her mother and twin sister, Hope Solinger. While an accomplished painter in her youth, she gave up making art in favor of collecting it. She was a strong patron of the arts and supported many organizations such as Plays for Living, the Museum of Modern Art and Independent Curators International. Caral is survived by her sister, her three children, ten grandchildren and one great-grandson. A private service will be held in October. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Independent Curators International, 799 Broadway, New York, NY 10003.

The human species is now a mainly urban animal for the first time in history, according to the United Nations, and in at least some regions of the United States, black bears appear to be following suit. One new study tracking bear patterns for a decade around Lake Tahoe, Nev., finds that urbanized human settlements are a lure and a threat to the opportunistic omnivores -- attracting bears with abundant garbage, but killing many in collisions with vehicles. The study tracked 12 female bears frequenting the town since 1997 and compared their condition and fate to 10 females in undeveloped wooded areas.

Brookie Maxwell, 51, an artist, says she would go crazy if she did not have the night to do her work, when her 11-year-old son is sleeping and her phone is not ringing. "In the middle of the night, everything opens up," she says. "Sometimes I wake up hearing characters or subjects talking to each other."This work, "Exodus," is an 8-by-11-foot drawing on birch panels using Caran d'Ache crayons, gouache and acrylic wash. It is part of a trilogy, along with "The Pieta" and "The Annunciation." "Exodus" revisits the biblical Exodus by describing the effects of Hurricane Katrina through the eyes of a doctor who stayed behind to help.

Media | The recorded political sound bite is 100 years old, a science blog says. The 1908 election between William Howard Taft and William Jennings Bryan "was the first in which presidential candidates recorded their own voices for the mass market." A historian says, "You could draw a genealogy from the televised presidential debates of today straight back to these" -- played at rallies and concert halls. [Science News, with audio]

Like most book hoarders, I sometimes find my careful stacks vaguely threatening - even if they don't topple and crush me, as I half fear they will, they taunt me with the reading I haven't done. So every now and then, when the piles grow tall enough to block sunlight from the windows, I harden my heart and start to cull, as mercilessly as someone chucking moldy takeout from the fridge. (My book-hoarding colleagues have their own approaches to this problem, by the way. One is married to a man who packs all their extra books into boxes and sends them to a rented storage unit. Another tries to limit her keepers to cool photography books.) What I'm left with amounts to a personal canon of sorts, an idiosyncratic collection of the books I turn to again and again and that have formed the foundation for my reading life. It is - to continue the food analogy - a pantry of literary staples: Bellow, Cheever, DeLillo, Nabokov, Robinson, Roth. Predictable, sure, but so are flour and sugar, and you wouldn't want to bake without them.

Sept. 29 - President Dmitry Medvedev says that if the Russian government does not take immediate steps, Moscow could lose the Russian Far East, a declaration that one Russian news agency called "unprecedented" and at the very least suggests Russia faces far more serious problems there than the Kremlin has acknowledged up to now.

The city has signed a five-year contract to lease vacant land at the Brooklyn Army Terminal for a school bus parking lot. The contract, which was signed with Atlantic Express Bus, will bring in about $500,000 a year in rent to the city for 85,000 square feet of space. Previously, the space had been used as an impound lot."We have never gotten so much for land," said Lee Winter, director of leasing at New York City's Economic Development Corporation, which runs an asset management service for the city's properties, including Staten Island Stadium and Essex Street Market. About 100 buses will fit in the space.
Lehman Brothers Venture Partners, the venture-capital arm of the bankrupt investment bank, is in late-stage talks to spin off as an independent firm, VentureWire's Tomio Geron reported Tuesday.

A far-flung restaurant empire and television commitments have kept the chef Tom Colicchio away from the stove in recent years. "I needed an antidote to all this; I miss the kitchen," he told Florence Fabricant. So he plans to be in his kitchen and cook, a grand total of 24 times a year, in what is the private dining room of Craft, the original Craftbar. Starting Oct. 14, he will offer a set, multi-course dinner for $150 or more, depending on the menu, on alternate Tuesday evenings. Reservations, starting at 6 p.m., will be accepted two weeks in advance. He said he named this new venture Tom: Tuesday Dinner; 47 East 19th Street, (212) 400-6495.[UPDATE, 4:15 P.M.: Tom Colicchio just called to make a subtle but important point here. He said, "It's not the fact that I have this far-flung restaurant empire that keeps me from cooking. It's the fact that I'm a chef that keeps me from the stove." He points out that he does spend a lot of time in his kitchens, particularly Craft, but when he's there he is expediting, supervising, and doing all the other managerial tasks that chefs have to do.]

Although there were no games in the junior ranks last night, there are a few things to take note of this week, as the United States Hockey League prepares to begin its regular season on Friday night. The standings, league statistics, notes and the schedule for the week ahead begin after the jump.

Week 5 already yielded one coaching casualty and is close to having another. Early yesterday morning, the brain trust of the St. Louis Rams decided to no longer delay the inevitable and fired Coach Scott Linehan, who had lost 25 of 36 games and the respect of his team. Various reports say the Raiders' Lane Kiffin is expected to be fired today.

Sugule Ali, the spokesman for the Somali pirates holding hostage the Faina, a Ukrainian freighter loaded with weapons, spoke to me by satellite telephone today from the bridge of the seized ship. In the holds of the Faina, which the pirates seized on Thursday, are 33 Russian-built battle tanks and crates of grenade launchers, anti-aircraft guns, ammunition and other explosives. American officials fear that the weapons could fall into the hands of radical Islamist insurgents who are battling Somalia's weak government. My questions were translated into Somali, and Mr. Ali's responses into English, by a translator employed by The New York Times.
Losing money consistently after six years of publication, The New York Sun announced that today's issue will be its last.

For more than a decade, marine scientists and communicators have been trying to convey just how profoundly the biological bounty of the seas has been stripped away in the last half century. Some have done so through field research showing extraordinary declines in fish populations and the way boats have had to venture ever farther from port to fill holds. Some, like Carl Safina and Richard Ellis, have written compelling books on the vanished and vanishing.

Updated After Monday's failure of the government's massive bailout package in the House of Representatives - and the ensuing plunge in the market - lawmakers are going back to the drawing board to work on a new proposal that they are likely to take up later this week.
More of your "late night" humor (use the comment link below):

Literature | "The Odyssey" and "Iliad" are "in the middle of a massive reappraisal," an article says. Advances in archeology and linguistics "offer the strongest support yet that the Trojan War did take place." And comparative anthropology finds: "Patterns of violence in Homer are intriguingly consistent with societies on the anthropological record known to have suffered from acute shortages of women." [Boston Globe]
Among the casualties of the House of Representatives' rejection of the proposed $700 billion rescue package: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's $9 billion investment in Morgan Stanley.

Media | How did a vague idea at Fox and NBC, derided by bloggers, become Hulu, the "easiest-to-use, most professional video site on the Internet"? Like many stories, this one begins at childhood. Hulu's boss remembers rushing home from school so as not to miss "Speed Racer" at 3:30. That problem's now solved, soon with a widget embeddable on anyone's site. [Wired]
The great panic has subsided, at least for the moment. Dow futures are up 190 points this morning, and the declines in Europe are relatively mild.

Curious Office, a start-up incubator, has landed $1.7 million in first-round financing for its latest venture, Pressplane, led by Second Avenue Partners and angel investors, including the former Expedia chief, Erik Blachford.
A judge has ruled that private equity firm Apollo Management and its portfolio company Hexion Specialty Chemicals must honor a $6.5 billion buyout deal for rival chemical maker Huntsman.

A super-thoughtful and technically interesting Balenciaga show this morning from Nicolas Ghesquière: very light, luminous and leaning again toward the futuristic. He opened with beige-pink jersey stretched and gathered over a kind of heart-shaped form on the bodices of mini dresses, followed by a more complex use of second-skin tops and matching tights for under many of the looks. Slim pants and tunic tops - in pink shades of beige and light gray - had quilting, almost like a moto-cross detail but more polished and delicate like couture.

Shares of National City dropped more than half on Monday as investors wondered which regional bank might need a merger partner as the sector suffered what analysts called a deepening crisis of confidence.

The drop in Wall Street's bonuses "could rival" the 50 percent fall seen in 2003, with the current market crisis cutting the total amount paid by banks and brokerages to $16 billion, the New York State comptroller said on Monday.

Dexia, a French-Belgian lender, received a capital injection of more than $9 billion from public shareholders on Tuesday as a deepening global credit crisis continued to shake European banks, while Irish authorities moved to back all deposits in the country's banks.
Even before the opening bell, Monday looked ugly.
Private equity firms Bain Capital and Silver Lake have submitted formal bids for a piece of Huawei Technologies' mobile handset unit, Reuters reported.

After inking a deal to invest in Steven Spielberg's DreamWorks studio, India's Reliance ADA Group is now in talks with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer about a potential buyout or equity investment, The New York Post reported.
The crisis gripping the nation's banks took a troubling turn on Monday, The New York Times's Eric Dash writes, as investors' confidence in even the largest and strongest institutions spiraled lower.
The New York Sun, the six-year-old newspaper with a conservative mind-set, announced on Monday that it would close after publishing Tuesday's issue.
To the list of big losers in the turmoil on Wall Street, add these: some big foundations.

Facing his worst-ever slide due to catastrophic bets on financials, Legg Mason fund manager Bill Miller is toning down his characteristic bold investment style in an attempt to recapture his past glory, Reuters reported.

Defying President Bush and the leaders of both parties, rank-and-file lawmakers in the House on Monday rejected a $700 billion economic rescue plan in a revolt that rocked the Capitol, sent markets plunging and left top lawmakers groping for a resolution, The New York Times's Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn write.

With a bank rescue package stalled in Congress, many economists and bank executives said Monday that lawmakers should consider new, and perhaps more palatable, alternatives to prevent the financial crisis from spreading, The New York Times's Alex Berenson and Louise Story reported.
For the Federal Reserve and the Treasury Department, the crisis continues.
Private equity firms surveying the wreckage of America's financial system have a crucial question -- when will credit return?

Ivory Tower | A banking analyst has an explanation for the financial mess: Blame Harvard! He's found that when more than 3 in 10 Harvard M.B.A.'s pursue careers in finance -- a record 4 in 10 did so in 2007 -- it's time for investors to sell. But take heart: Ivy Leaguers may be souring on financial careers, a blog suggests. Oh, the indignity of working for a commercial bank! Law or medical school looks like a better move. [Valley Wag, Brainiac, IvyGate]

The collapse of the proposed rescue plan for the teetering financial system was the product of a larger failure - of political leadership in Washington - at a moment when the world was looking to the United States to contain the cascading economic crisis, The New York Times's Jackie Calmes writes.

European shares opened lower Tuesday, following falls in Asia, but they were spared the rout seen overnight on Wall Street as investors expressed hoped that a new U.S. bailout agreement would emerge this week, The New York Time's Matthew Saltmarsh and Martin Fackler reported.

It is easy to see why investors freaked out when the House of Representatives drove a stake through the Bush administration's $700 billion plan to re-animate the banking industry, Breakingviews says. The demise, it says, of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's Troubled Asset Relief Program is certain to cause more pain - and not just for Wall Street fat cats.

An article on Saturday about a decrease in confidence in the Pakistani government among Pakistanis, diplomats and investors after a bomb attack at the Marriott Hotel in Islamabad paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by a spokesman for the American Embassy there about the status of one of three Americans. The spokesman said the whereabouts of the man, described as a contractor for the State Department, were unknown; the spokesman did not say that the American was dead. (On Sunday, the spokesman said the remains of the contractor had since been identified, but he did not release additional information.).

Letters from public figures are an important component of the news in 1908, and at the top of today's front page are reports introducing the transcripts of two letters. One is an open letter to President Theodore Roosevelt from the Democratic candidate for president, William Jennings Bryan, who denounces assertions Roosevelt made in another letter recently published, connecting "the Democratic Party, and me as its candidate, with the trusts." Bryan continues: "My record is sufficient answer to your insinuations. I have lived in vain if your accusations lose me a single friend." Bryan to President on Election Funds
Apple's push to make the iPhone a desired device among the world's largest companies should receive a boost this week thanks to I.B.M.
Times columnist Jim Dwyer talks to South Bronx residents about the $700 billion economic bailout package.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the financial problems of American International Group referred incorrectly to the timing and participants at meetings at the New York Federal Reserve between Saturday, Sept. 13, and Monday, Sept. 15. Although there were indeed meetings that weekend, there was also a separate meeting on Monday to discuss financial aid for A.I.G. Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, was the only Wall Street chief executive who attended the Monday meeting, not the only chief executive who attended weekend meetings. Also, Henry M. Paulson Jr., the Treasury secretary, did not lead or attend the Monday meeting. (Both Mr. Blankfein and Mr. Paulson did attend the weekend meetings.).
A CD review on Sept. 22 about “Only by the Night,” by Kings of Leon, misspelled the surname of the band’s lead singer. He is Caleb Followill, not Followhill.

An article last Tuesday about Senator Barack Obama’s record as a debater gave an incorrect example of his forcefully responding to accusations. At a debate in January, Mr. Obama initiated a sharp exchange with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, criticizing her for sitting on Wal-Mart’s board; she then accused him of receiving favors from a Chicago “slumlord.” The exchange was not a case in which Mr. Obama “shot back” when attacked, an approach some people had encouraged him to take to improve his debate performances.

An article on Saturday about an injunction granted to NBC Universal, the owner of the Bravo cable network, blocking a deal to move the hit Bravo show “Project Runway” to the Lifetime network misstated the month the finale of the show is to be broadcast. It is October, not November.

An article on Wednesday about Barney Rosset and his career as publisher of Grove Press misstated his role in the creation of the documentary film “Strange Victory” after he served as an Army photographer in World War II. The film was made by Leo Hurwitz — not by Mr. Rosset, who was a producer.
An obituary on Saturday about Marpessa Dawn, who played Eurydice in the classic 1959 movie “Black Orpheus,” misspelled the given name of her co-star in the film. He was Breno Mello, not Bruno.
They are usually extremely good at their jobs, but sometimes ignore rules and procedures. They are known as office prima donnas and dealing with them is tricky.

The trial of Alberto W. Vilar, the opera lover and disgraced patron of the arts, opened with a prosecutor describing him as a lying fraudster who finagled money out of clients.

The backup point guard Sam Cassell is back to help the Boston Celtics try to repeat as the N.B.A. champions. Cassell had been in touch with Coach Doc Rivers during the summer, but Rivers did not know if Cassell had decided to come back for another season. Cassell, 38, who joined the team in March for the playoff run, showed up Monday for media day to sign a contract for his 16th N.B.A. season. ¶Dallas Mavericks forward Josh Howard apologized for a summer’s worth of troublesome behavior. Howard, the team’s second-leading scorer behind Dirk Nowitzki, focused mostly on expressing remorse for a YouTube video that showed him disrespecting the national anthem. But he also apologized for his July arrest after police said he was drag racing at 94 miles per hour in a 55 m.p.h. zone and his admission in a radio interview during the playoffs that he smoked marijuana. howard ¶Miami General Manager Randy Pfund, who helped the Heat win the 2006 N.B.A. championship, resigned after 13 years with the franchise. Pat Riley, the team president, will assume Pfund’s duties. heat.

Iraq lost its bid for reinstatement in 2010 World Cup qualifying after the sport’s highest court refused to punish Qatar for using an ineligible player. The Court of Arbitration for Sport agreed with soccer’s governing body, FIFA, that Iraq had no right to make an appeal because it was late in paying a $2,800 fee. The Iraqi Football Association missed the deadline by 11 days. The dispute stemmed from a March 26 Asian qualifier between Qatar and Iraq in Doha. The Brazilian-born Emerson was a Qatar citizen when he helped Qatar beat Iraq, 2-0. But earlier in his career, he had also played for Brazil’s under-20 team under the name of Marcio Passos De Albuquerque. FIFA lets players change nationality but not play for two countries.

Chicago Blackhawks goaltender Nikolai Khabibulin has been put on waivers. Khabibulin is entering the final season of a four-year, $27 million contract. He joined the Blackhawks as a free agent after leading Tampa Bay to the 2004 Stanley Cup. The Blackhawks signed the free agent Cristobal Huet to a four-year, $22.5 million deal in July, giving them two top goalies. Khabibulin has been inconsistent and injured over the past three seasons. ¶Michael Nylander set up two second-period goals and Alex Ovechkin, the N.H.L. most valuable player last season, added a what proved to be a game-winning short-handed goal early in the third as the visiting Washington Capitals held beat the Devils, 3-2, for their fourth straight preseason victory. Zach Parise scored midway through the third period and Petr Vrana added a goal with 1 minute 52 seconds left for the Devils (2-2), who had won two games in a row. devils (AP).

Lance Armstrong wants to return to elite racing in January’s Tour Down Under in Australia even though he is not eligible to return until Feb. 1, 2009. The race runs Jan. 20-25. Armstrong said he hoped authorities would grant him an exemption. The International Cycling Union (U.C.I.) requires riders coming out of retirement to be in the sport’s antidoping program for six months before racing. Armstrong filed paperwork Aug. 1 with the United States Anti-Doping Agency and said he was tested in late August. The U.C.I. has said it will make a decision this week.

Tiger Woods said his surgically repaired knee would probably be no more than 85 percent when he returned, but he saw no reason why he could not get back to the level of play that brought him nine victories in 12 official events this year, no finish worse than a tie for fifth. Woods, during a video conference to announce the 16-man field for his Chevron World Challenge in December, said his goal was getting his body healthy for 2009 to compete at a high level.
Everything is in place in Utah, where Real Salt Lake will open the newest playground in the M.L.S., Rio Tinto Stadium, with a game against the Red Bulls on Oct. 9.
The police discovered a dozen partly clothed bodies on Monday, most of which had been bound and tortured, dumped next to an elementary school in Tijuana.
This week four N.H.L. teams will play exhibition games in Europe, and Saturday’s regular-season openers in Prague and Stockholm are sold out.
On Sunday, Laveranues Coles turned in his most productive game since last October and silenced critics who felt he had not fully embraced Brett Favre.
An Afghan police officer opened fire on on U.S. soldiers in a police station south of Kabul, killing one. The American troops fired back, killing the police officer.
The possibility that President Omar Hassan al-Bashir might be indicted on charges of genocide and war crimes prompted an intense tug of war at the United Nations General Assembly.
The Nikkei dropped almost 5 percent in the first hour of trading, following the rejection in Washington of a $700 billion financial bailout package and a plunge in U.S. markets.

The Bloomberg administration accused eight stores on the reservation in Suffolk County of breaking state and federal law by selling cigarettes in bulk to bootleggers.
Andy Pettitte who finished the season 14-14 with a 4.54 earned run average and led the Yankees with 204 innings, is flirting with retirement again.

Needing to win Monday’s makeup game with Detroit to tie Minnesota for the American League Central title, the White Sox prevailed.
General Manager Omar Minaya acknowledged the challenges inherent in strengthening a team that failed miserably in the final weeks for the second consecutive year.

LEFKOW--Peter A . It is with tremendous sadness that we note the passing of Peter A. Lefkow, M.D. Peter was the Director of Cardiology Programs at the Joan and Joel Smilow Cardiac and Pulmonary Rehabilitation and Prevention Center, Rusk Institute, NYU Langone Medical Center. Astute clinician, remarkable teacher, and innovative thinker were a few of the enduring qualities that defined Peter as the consummate professional. Both in his professional and private lives, he was a loyal and dedicated friend, and had the tenacity to pursue the righteous path for those who needed his help. His overriding spirit was of caring and the desire to see those around him thrive. Peter is desperately missed. His spirit and philosophy will forever light our work here at the Cardiac Rehabilitation Center. Our sincerest condolences are offered to his mother Charlotte Lefkow, daughters Danielle, Lindsey and Christie, and his sister Susan Lefkow and his myriad of friends and colleagues. Jonathan Whiteson M.D. Ana Mola, ANP Mariano Rey, M.D. The staff of the Joan and Joel Smilow Cardiac Rehabilitation Center Rusk Institute, NYU Langone Medical Center LEFKOW--Peter. The Department of Medicine of the NYU Langone Medical Center is saddened by the passing of our longtime colleague, Peter Lefkow. Dr. Lefkow was a friend to all and a great presence at NYU for more than 40 years. He taught countless students, housestaff, and fellows in Cardiology. To all who knew him, he was a unique physician who cared deeply; he will be missed by many. We extend our deep condolences to his entire family. Martin J. Blaser, M.D. Chair, Department of Medicine NYU Langone Medical Center LEFKOW--Peter. The faculty, fellows and staff of the Division of Cardiology of NYU School of Medicine express great sadness at the passing of Peter A. Lefkow, M.D. A commanding presence at NYU for more than three decades, Peter was the consummate clinical cardiologist. He was fiercely devoted to his patients and passionate about teaching cardiology to generations of physicians-intraining. We extend our sympathies to the entire Lefkow family. Glenn I. Fishman, Division of Cardiology, NYU School of Medicine.

KELMAN--Kurt . The lawyers and staff of Collard & Roe, PC mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Kurt Kelman. Mr. Kelman was the oldest practicing patent agent in this country. He practiced for over 61 years until his death. After being accepted at the Technical University of Vienna, Mr. Kelman escaped the Nazis and came over to the United States as a young man in 1939. Fluent in French, German and English, Mr. Kelman joined Collard & Roe in 1982 and obtained for many European companies thousands of patents. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Sylvia, children Steve, Mark, and Ellen, and seven grandchildren. Collard & Roe, PC

A vast majority of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's top fund-raisers had still not contributed to Senator Barack Obama's presidential campaign by the end of August, according to a New York Times analysis of Federal Election Commission records. Only about 20 of the more than 300 Hillraisers, the fund-raisers who have bundled together $100,000 or more in campaign contributions for Mrs. Clinton, gave to Mr. Obama for the first time in August, down from about 40 in July. In all, fewer than a third of Hillraisers have given to Mr. Obama, according to the most recent campaign finance filings.

LEBWORTH--Caral Gimbel , died peacefully in her home on September 25, 2008. after a short illness. Caral was born on November 29, 1914 to Bernard F. and Alva B. Gimbel. The two great passions of Caral's long Iife were horses and the arts. At the age of 17, she dropped out of high school and went to Paris to study art for two years. There, she met and befriended many of the great painters of the day. She returned to New York and married Edward Lasker on February 1, 1935. They divorced ten years later. In 1946 Caral married Hall of Fame baseball player Hank Greenberg with whom she had three children --Glenn, Stephen and Alva Greenberg. Caral and Hank spent most of their marriage in Cleveland, Ohio where Caral pursued her passion for equestrian sports and Hank served as part owner and general manager of the Cleveland Indians baseball team. They divorced in 1959 and both moved back to New York, where Caral lived for the remainder of her life. In 1962, Caral married Joseph Lebworth with whom she spent the next 46 years in New York City, up until his death in May of this year. Caral began her equestrian career early and was riding competitively by the age of 14. She competed in hunting and jumping, both in the U.S. and abroad. She rode several times in Madison Square Garden at the National Horse Show and won numerous ribbons and trophies. Caral often rode in a hunt team with her mother and twin sister, Hope Solinger. While an accomplished painter in her youth, she gave up making art in favor of collecting it. She was a strong patron of the arts and supported many organizations such as Plays for Living, the Museum of Modern Art and Independent Curators International. Caral is survived by her sister, her three children, ten grandchildren and one great-grandson. A private service will be held in October. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Independent Curators International, 799 Broadway, New York, NY 10003.
