GAYLE--Margot . The Metropolitan Chapter of the Victorian Society in America mourns the death of our friend and founder, Margot Gayle, and extends condolences to her daughters, Carol Gayle and Gretchen Gayle Ellsworth, and their families. She was a preservationist, authority on cast-iron architecture and author of books on architecture and public sculpture who was relentless in protecting New York's 19th century architectural heritage. In 1966 she and two others established the Victorian Society in America to increase appreciation of the era's architecture and culture. The Chapter continues her work with lectures, tours and advocacy, including current efforts to expand the SoHo-Cast Iron Historic District. In 2003 the Chapter set up the Margot Gayle Fund for Preservation of Victorian Heritage to finance preservation and conservation projects.

ELLIOTT--Osborn , 83, died peacefully at home on September 28, 2008. Husband of Inger Elliott, father to three daughters, two stepdaughters and a stepson, and two foster sons, grandfather to 17 and great-grandfather to one, Oz was the legendary Newsweek editor, dean of the Columbia Journalism School and a stalwart defender of civic values as founder of the Citizens Committee for New York City. He inspired thousands in shaping not just the city we love but our society as well. Services will be held at All Souls Church in Manhattan on October 2 and in Stonington, CT on October 4. Gifts in his memory may be made to Citizens Committee for New York City, 305 Seventh Ave., NYC, NY 10001. ELLIOTT--Osborn. The Board of Trustees and staff of Asia Society express great sadness at the passing of long-time friend and supporter Osborn ''Oz'' Elliott. Elected a Trustee in 1966 and an Honorary Life Trustee in 2003, the Society endowed a prize for excellence in journalism on Asia in recognition of his important contributions to the field. His magnanimous spirit touched everyone around him and he will be missed enormously. We extend our deepest condolences to the Elliott family. Richard C. Holbrooke, Chairman Vishakha N. Desai, President, Asia Society ELLIOTT--Osborn. The Board of Directors and staff of Citizens Committee for New York City are deeply saddened at the loss of our beloved founder. Born and raised in the city he cherished, Oz spent his professional life as a crusading journalist and in public service. With Senator Javits he founded Citizens Committee for New York City in 1975, which has provided millions of dollars in grants to thousands of neighborhood and community groups throughout the nation's largest city. As editorin-chief of Newsweek from 1961-1976, he was responsible for raising the most crucial social issues of our time, including the role of women and of African-Americans in American society. He served as Dean of the School of Journalism at Columbia, and as Deputy Mayor under Mayor Beame. The board and the staff revered him and will miss him terribly. In addition, he will be remembered by the many New Yorkers, most of them in the city's poorest neighborhoods, whose community groups and organizations were supported by Citizens Committee for New York City. Our deepest condolences to his wife Inger, his children, and grandchildren. Henry Cornell, Chairman Peter Kostmayer, President ELLIOTT--Osborn. Ah Ozzie All New Yorkers are worse for your loss but better for your love affair with our town. It was mutual. Deepest sympathy to Inger and your loving family. Michael Clark and Marcia Isman ELLIOTT--Sloane, in Kifissia, Greece, on September 26 at 78 of cancer. For 21 years publisher and editor of the English language monthly magazine, ''The Athenian''. Novelist, playwright, essayist and wit. Born in New York City the son of Clinton Elliott and Margaret Sloane deFreygang. Survived by his wife Drossoula, eldest daughter of the painter Spyros Vassiliou, four children Anghelika (David Maddalena), Margaret Sloane (James Corsi), Stephen, Lucy (Andreas Kambanis), three grandchildren Zoe and Timothy Maddalena and Ondine Corsi, and a brother Clinton Elliott of Tyringham, Massachusetts.
FERRI--Ernest . The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ernest Ferri, associated with The New York Times from October 1, 1950 until retiring on August 16, 2008.

Cash America International, the world's largest pawnshop operator, said it would spend $90 million for an 80 percent interest in the owner of 100 similar stores in Mexico. The company will also pay an amount tied to future performance for the stake in the owner of Prenda Fácil pawnshops in 16 Mexican states, Cash America said. Fewer people in Mexico use banks than in the United States, making it an attractive market for pawn-shop owners like Cash America and a competitor, First Cash Financial Services, said Elizabeth Pierce, an analyst for Roth Capital Partners. Prenda Fácil's receivables were $21.5 million on June 30, Cash America said. The company expects the purchase to add to 2009 earnings.

KATZ--Aaron , age 92, passed away peacefully at TideWell Hospice & Palliative Care in Venice on September 28, 2008 with his beloved wife, Cema, at his side. The couple had relocated from Brooklyn, NY, Aaron's birthplace, upon his retirement in 2005. Born October 22, 1915, Aaron became an educator, philosopher, writer, actuary and idealist. A passionate believer in the dual concepts of justice for all and equality of opportunity without regard to race or gender, he was active in the early civil rights movement. Long before Dr. King put beautiful words to his dream, Aaron was communicating a vision of our country as a living example to the world; a nation where each citizen's potential would be valued and fulfilled. A Purser in the Merchant Marine during World War II and its aftermath, Aaron served with honor. That exposure to other cultures and attitudes helped shape the direction of his life. While his facility for language did not extend to expertise in accent or syntax, he made himself understood; the many friendships forged in his travels endured for decades. Blessed with humor and a quick wit, he delighted in challenging young people with word puzzles involving logic and math. Many now credit Aaron for inspiring them to career paths in science and law. Non-violent by nature, Aaron was deeply troubled by the disposition of cases such as Sacco-Vanzetti. He later became an expert on the trail and conviction of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, offended by the unprecedented peacetime death sentence he believed to be a politicallymotivated assault on the freedoms guaranteed by our Constitution and Bill of Rights. Aaron served as Director of the National committee to reopen the Rosenberg Case for over 30 years. His lectures and discussion groups at Brooklyn College were popular and he continued the presentations well into his 80s. Aaron will be greatly missed by his wife, daughter, grand and greatgrandchildren, uncle/aunt, cousins, in-laws, nieces/nephews and others whose lives he touched. Services and burial will be private. Farley Funeral Home in Venice, Florida is handling the services. To send condolences visit www.farleyfuneralhome .com

If you learned you had a life-changing illness, broadcasting it on the Internet might be the last thing on your mind. But PatientsLikeMe encourages people to do just that. Founded by Ben and James Heywood after their brother Stephen received a diagnosis of Lou Gehrig's disease, the site is a kind of Facebook for the chronically ill. It holds thousands of profiles of patients living with diseases as diverse as multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's and H.I.V., with a special section for mood disorders like depression and anxiety. Patients can use slick visual tools to chart their symptoms over time, rate their drugs and treatments, and track their progress against fellow patients with a degree of transparency that borders on the voyeuristic. Users should be aware that the site shares data, stripped of names and other identifying material, with nonprofit groups, research hospitals and pharmaceutical companies.

Terms of his fine were still being negotiated Monday between the National Football League Players Association and the N.F.L. Management Council.

When clinical trials contradict all the evidence that precedes them, what do you believe? By the early 1990s, several studies seemed to show that beta carotene, an antioxidant found in fruit and vegetables, lowered the risk of cancer. But then came randomized clinical trials, which concluded that beta carotene failed to protect against either cancer or heart disease.

Looking for experimental treatment? With more than 25,000 open trials testing a dizzying variety of new drugs, surgeries and vaccines, this site may have something for everyone. The upside is bargain-priced treatment; inpatient volunteers can be well compensated. The downside is that you may be pumped full of an untested drug with serious effects. (You may get a placebo.) By and large, the trials sponsored by universities and the National Institutes of Health are more likely to be monitored for safety than those offered by private companies.

You have probably seen a document that looks very much like this. A blood test is a routine part of a physical exam, and you may even have a copy of your report in a file somewhere. But deciphering the numbers is anything but routine. ''The simplest of the tests, the most routine blood tests, are fraught with complexity in their interpretation,'' said Dr. Conrad Blum, a professor of clinical medicine at Columbia. If you know everything in this graphic, and nothing else, he added, ''you know very little of the subtlety involved in lab test interpretation,'' which is strictly the province of a medical professional.

For all of you on Main Street who have been watching the turmoil on Wall Street for the last few weeks, Monday's shockwaves rattled even the most steadfast. The day began with the announcement that another big bank -- Wachovia -- had been taken over, just days after Washington Mutual collapsed and was sold. In early afternoon, the House rejected the bailout package for the financial industry. Stocks plunged, with the Dow ending the day down nearly 778 points in the worst single-day drop in two decades.

It may be tough to get an appointment at the Mayo Clinic, which for over a century has set the standard for medical care in America. But it's much easier to consult its encyclopedic site, which may be the most concise source of medical information on the Web. Unlike many other health sites, Mayo writes its own material, with a tone that manages to be both conversational and precise, straightforward and sympathetic. (''Suicide is the act of taking your own life. ... You may think suicide is a solution when, in fact, it's not.'') The no-nonsense symptom checker, while remarkably simple to use, should probably be kept away from hypochondriacs. (Wheezing and drooling? You may have epiglottitis. Dizzy and stumbling? Might be ataxia.) The site could be easier to navigate, but the guide to ailments is so terse and authoritative that you may find yourself reading it for pleasure.

It is easy to see why investors freaked out when the House of Representatives drove a stake through the Bush administration's $700 billion plan to re-animate the banking industry. The demise, at least for now, of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's Troubled Asset Relief Program is certain to cause more pain -- and not just for Wall Street fat cats. The failure of the United States government to emerge as a willing buyer for hundreds of billions of dollars of toxic assets will accelerate the painful process of deleveraging, bringing with it more bank failures. That, in turn, will shrink the size of the private sector balance sheet that consumers and companies have come to rely upon.

Elly was a visionary who recognized the need for a unified voice that would speak on behalf of the seniors of New York City. Thus, CSCS came into being 30 years ago. Over the years, Elly was a source of advice and counsel to the organization, for which we will be ever grateful. Dionne, President Igal Jellinek, Executive Director GUGGENHEIMER--Elinor C., age 96, on September 29, 2008. Wife of the late Randolph. Mother of Charles and Randolph, mother-in-law of Jane. Grandmother of Randolph III, Steven and Lynn and greatgrandmother of seven. Attended Vassar and graduated from Barnard in 1933. Recipient of honorary degrees from Marymount Manhattan College, the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and other institutions. She was the first woman member of the NYC Planning Commission in 1961. In the 1970s, she was the Commissioner of the NYC Department of Consumer Affairs. She was the founder of the Council of Senior Center & Services in NYC in 1979. She founded the NY Women's Forum in 1973, the National Women's Forum in 1981, the International Women's Forum in 1983 and the NY Women's Agenda in 1992. She founded the Day Care Council of NY in 1948 and the Day Care & Child Development Council in 1958. She is also the founder of the Child Care Action Campaign. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell --The Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Wednesday and Thursday 5-7pm. The first presidential debate garnered an average of 52.4 million television viewers on Friday, Nielsen Media Research said on Monday. The relatively low audience estimate puzzled some television executives who expected a wider audience for the commercial-free forum between Senators John McCain and Barack Obama. The debate drew eight million fewer viewers than the first debate between President Bush and Senator John Kerry in 2004, but attracted six million more viewers than the second debate that year, which was also held on a Friday.

YEAGER--Paul S . The Trustees of the Columbia University Club Foundation mourn the loss of their Secretary and fellow Trustee, Paul S. Yeager. We will miss his longtime friendship and wise counsel. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Joann, and his family. YEAGER--Phillip C., 80, the founder and Chairman of one of the nation's largest freight transportation companies, died on September 29, 2008 from complications from a heart attack. Mr. Yeager, an intermodal industry pioneer, founded Hub Group with his late wife Joyce in 1971. Working together as a team, the two built a company that started in a windowless one room office above a flower shop and is today a publicly traded Fortune 1000 corporation with over $1.8 billion in annual sales. Mr. Yeager was born in Bellevue, Kentucky in 1927 and grew up in a working class family during the Great Depression. He worked in his family's butcher shop at a young age, earning a nickel or a doughnut for each delivery. Mr. Yeager learned the value of hard work and thrift during these formative years, character traits that would define his life. After excelling at sports in high school, Mr. Yeager attended the University of Cincinnati on an athletic scholarship, playing both football and tennis at the collegiate level. He was drafted in the Army in 1946 and served at Camp Carson in Colorado for 18 months. After a brief stint managing an ice house, Mr. Yeager began working for the Pennsylvania Railroad in 1952. He worked for the railroad for 19 years, witnessing the introduction of intermodal transportation in 1954. At that time, intermodal service, which combines the use of truck and rail transportation, was in its infancy. Realizing the potential of this new and more fuel efficient form of transportation, Mr. Yeager started Hub Group with his wife Joyce by his side and $500 in cash. With his strong relationships at the railroads and his reputation for honesty, customers began shipping with Hub Group in impressive numbers. The Company began a geographic expansion and had locations in over 25 important rail cities by 1985. Hub Group went public in 1996 and is currently traded on NASDAQ under the symbol HUBG. Mr. Yeager remained an active Chairman, company spokesman and industry advocate up to the time of his death. During his career Mr. Yeager received numerous awards recognizing his contributions to the transportation industry, including the Intermodal Transportation Association's Man of the Year, the Salzburg Practitioners Award from Syracuse University, the Presidential Medal from Dowling College, induction into the Chicago Area Entrepreneurship Hall of Fame, the Silver Kingpin award from the Intermodal Association of North America, the New York Traffic Club's Transportation Person of the Year, Target's Vice President's Life Time Achievement Award and the Connie Award from the Containerization and Intermodal Institute. Mr. Yeager also received an honorary Doctor of Public Service degree from the University of Denver in recognition of his achievements in the intermodal industry. Despite his tremendous accomplishments, he was a down to earth person who never lost the common touch. Mr. Yeager is survived by his wife Anne, daughter Debra (Bob) Jensen and his two sons David (Julia) and Mark (Heather), grandchildren Patrick Jensen, Elizabeth (Jim) Cassaro, Matthew, Phillip, Laura, Alexander, Samantha Yeager and two great grandchildren, Mia and Tyler Cassaro. Visitation for Mr. Yeager will take place Wednesday, October 1, from 5:008:00pm at Gibbons Elliston Funeral Home located at First and Grant Street, Hinsdale, IL 60521. Family and friends will meet Thursday, October 2 at St. John of the Cross, 5005 S. Wolf Road, Western Springs, IL 60558 for a 10:00am memorial service. In lieu of flowers, memorials made to Childrens Memorial Hospital, 2300 Childrens Plaza, Box 4 Chicago, IL 60614-3363 directed to ''The Yeager Professorship in Pediatric Neurosurgery'' would be appreciated.

San Francisco City Clinic, which offers low-cost testing and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases, is also a bracing and realistic source of information. Its front page comes on gently with a little box marked ''About You.'' This leads to a customized list of diseases one can get as, say, a middle-age transsexual who sleeps with both men and women. For those who would rather see all the risks at once, a handy chart of ''S.T.D. basics'' catalogs the infections that can be transmitted by nine kinds of sexual activity. Bay Area residents can consult an exhaustive catalog of local resources. For the rest of us there is the clinic's ''Dr. K,'' whose advice columns reveal, for example, that two condoms are not better protection than one.

The vote count during parliamentary elections in Belarus on Sunday was not as open as promised, and the election generally failed to meet European democratic standards, said the election monitoring agency of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. In a statement released Monday, the agency said independent observers were often denied access to polling stations. When access was provided, it said, observers reported cases of deliberate falsification of results. The agency said opposition candidates did have less difficulty holding demonstrations and greater access to television than in previous elections in Belarus, a country often described as Europe's last dictatorship.

Anyone who accuses Hong Kongers of being unpatriotic has obviously not asked any of us about our airport. There's city-wide pride in a facility that's not only big, shiny and designed by a big-named architect, but also runs like clockwork. It's orderly and quick, partly because of reasonably relaxed immigration and customs restrictions. (Unlike mainland China, Hong Kong lets most Westerners in without a visa). The major problems I've heard about have been because of typhoons.

The fallout from the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy continues to trip up the markets. Dozens of hedge funds and money management firms that depended on Lehman's prime brokerage unit to clear trades, provides loans and handle administrative chores are starting to collapse, Bloomberg News reports.

I love it when I can apply a simple formula to a broad range of dishes, and it seldom works as well as it does with creamy vegetable soups. These soups have three basic ingredients, and their proportions form a pyramid: three parts liquid, two parts vegetable, one part dairy. The foundation is chicken stock; the middle section is any vegetable, or combination of vegetables, that will puree nicely; the peak is cream, milk, yogurt or sour cream. Take a look at the Minimalist column in which this recipe was originally published for more about that.

The Blackstone Group and JPMorgan Chase are teaming to raise over $1 billion to help fund the conversion of 20,000 U.S. cinema screens to digital technology, in a deal due to be announced later on Wednesday, The Financial Times reported.
The Reserve Primary Fund, the money-market fund that "broke the buck" two weeks ago, said it will return at least one-third of investors' money, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Politics | A libertarian reviewer disputes the "libertarian paternalism" of the book "Nudge." The book says government can "nudge" people into making good choices, using "real world" behavioral economics. British Prime Minister Grodon Brown on Wednesday expressed confidence in the rescue takeover of HBOS by British rival Lloyds, seeking to calm fears that the deal may be in trouble.

Cities, states and other local governments have been effectively shut out of the bond markets for the last two weeks, raising the cost of day-to-day operations, threatening longer-term projects and dampening a broad source of jobs and stability at a time when other parts of the economy are weakening, The New York Times reported.

European stocks were moving higher Wednesday, following similar gains in Asia, helped by hope that American lawmakers will be able to revive the $700 billion rescue plan for the financial system, The New York Times's Matthew Saltmarsh reported.

Under pressure from banks and legislators, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued an interpretation of an accounting standard that could make it easier for banks to report smaller losses, or perhaps even profits, when they announce results for the third quarter, The New York Times's Floyd Norris reported.

Lee S. Ainslie, Louis M. Bacon and Daniel Loeb are some of the most successful hedge fund managers around. But even they lost big lately as the markets turned chaotic, The New York Times's Louise Story reports.

The governor of the Bank of England, Mervyn King, gave a speech last spring denouncing the hubris of bankers. Senate leaders scheduled a Wednesday vote on a $700 billion financial bailout package after accepting tax breaks and a higher limit for insured bank deposits in a bid to win House approval and send legislation to President Bush by the end of the week.

Wells Fargo Chairman Richard Kovacevich says he feels like a kid in a candy store. But he's taking his time to decide what to buy, according to Reuters.

Abertis Infraestructuras and Citigroup withdrew their $12.8 billion bid to lease the Pennsylvania Turnpike on Tuesday, after Pennsylvania lawmakers made it clear the proposal was unlikely to come to a vote in the current session.

Midway Airport is poised to become the first large privately run hub airport in the country, officials said Tuesday, after an investment group bid $2.52 billion to win rights to a long-term lease, The New York Times's Susan Saulny writes.

When the Bush administration announced its $700 billion plan to shore up the nation's shaky financial system, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. called it the Troubled Asset Relief Program. Everyone else called it the bailout. And from that point on, its fate may have been set, says The New York Times's Peter Baker.

Politics | A podcast compares today with the three-way 1912 campaign. Teddy Roosevelt (McCain's idol) runs against his party (Taft) and touts reform with "wild eruptions" on the stump. A calmer Woodrow Wilson reassures voters leery of T.R., and wins. (Wilson was an ex-academic with two years as governor, by the way.) [My History Can Beat Up Your Politics]
Sovereign Bancorp, the largest remaining U.S. savings and loan, has hired Paul Perrault as chief executive, replacing Joseph Campanelli, who had held the job less than two years.

Arts | An essay on why art is so bad today. Pursuit of divine beauty? No. "By universalizing the spirit of opposition," the avant-garde has made art "a purely negative enterprise." And most "novelty" is "a tired repetition of gestures inaugurated by the likes of Marcel Duchamp, creator of the first bottle-rack ­masterpiece and the first urinal fountain." [First Things]

New York | Are the Hamptons a good idea? Ask Woody Allen: "Many years ago, when everyone I know had houses in the Hamptons, I thought maybe it was for me too. I bought a very, very beautiful house in Southampton, and I spent over a year fixing it up ... I mean, I did an incredible job. Then I went out there one night and I slept in it, and I never came back." [New York]

The Republican presidential candidate, William Howard Taft, campaigned in Lincoln, Neb., the hometown of the Democratic candidate, William Jennings Bryan. Bryan recently dared Taft to agree with Theodore Roosevelt, the incumbent president, that the names of campaign contributors should not be reported until after the election. Taft took the dare, saying, "It is not good policy to discourage those who desire to contribute to the legitimate purposes of the campaign from so contributing by exposing them to bitter diatribes or unfair attacks or slanderous condemnation of partisans in an electoral fight." Taft in Bryan's City Accepts Challenge

Almost everything I thought parenting would be back before I had children has turned out to be wrong. I thought all those people were exaggerating when they said you can't understand what it means to be a parent until you are one. I was wrong about that. I thought I could compartmentalize my life and my work instead having it all tangled and entwined. Wrong again. I thought I would never lose the baby weight. Sort of wrong. I did; it came back. I thought I would never be the kind of parent who let her child cry himself to sleep or play with toy guns or watch PG-13 movies before turning 13. Very wrong.

An obituary on Sept. 19 about Robert Steinberg, co-founder of Scharffen Berger Chocolate Maker, misidentified the location of the brand’s first retail shop and misstated the timing of the opening. It opened in a factory in Berkeley, Calif., some time after the brand’s founding in 1996; it was not in the company’s original factory in San Francisco, which opened earlier that year.

GAYLE--Margot. For 61 years Margot Gayle was an active member. She never understood inactive. As newsletter editor, trustee, chair of dozens of committees (several, now venerable organizations) and finally recipient of the Society's Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis medal, Margot earned the right to relax. But the energy and spirit that saved threatened treasures from the Alice Austen House in Staten Island to the Old Sun Clock to the Bogardus Fire Tower in Harlem kept her advocacy going right to the end. Before we had mayors who cared, she practically swept up City Hall, saved the Art Commission from extinction and helped the Landmarks Preservation Commission become independent. It is hard to imagine what New York might have become without her. The Municipal Art Society of New York

''Round up the usual suspects,'' Captain Renault says in ''Casablanca.'' You could say the same of an Oktoberfest menu. Sausages, roast chicken, pigs' knuckles and headcheese are usually washed down with copious quantities of beer. But Oktoberfest beers, from Germany and the United States, are more versatile. These often subtle and food-friendly brews pair nicely with a wider array of meats, poultry and even seafood. Fresh clams go well, as does meaty grilled fish like striped bass.

GUGGENHEIMER--Elinor C., age 96, on September 29, 2008. Wife of the late Randolph. Mother of Charles and Randolph, mother-in-law of Jane. Grandmother of Randolph III, Steven and Lynn and greatgrandmother of seven. Attended Vassar and graduated from Barnard in 1933. Recipient of honorary degrees from Marymount Manhattan College, the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and other institutions. She was the first woman member of the NYC Planning Commission in 1961. In the 1970s, she was the Commissioner of the NYC Department of Consumer Affairs. She was the founder of the Council of Senior Center & Services in NYC in 1979. She founded the NY Women's Forum in 1973, the National Women's Forum in 1981, the International Women's Forum in 1983 and the NY Women's Agenda in 1992. She founded the Day Care Council of NY in 1948 and the Day Care & Child Development Council in 1958. She is also the founder of the Child Care Action Campaign. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell --The Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Wednesday and Thursday 5-7pm. Services Friday, October 3rd, 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th St. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Women's Forum Education Fund, 6 E. 39th St. New York, NY 10016 or Council of Senior Centers and Services, 49 W. 45th St. 7th Floor, New York, NY 10036. GUGGENHEIMER--Elinor. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of Jewish Home Lifecare extend their heartfelt condolences to trustee Randolph Guggenheimer on the passing of his mother Elinor, one of New York City's preeminent civic leaders. As was his mother, Randy is dedicated to the principle that elders should live their lives with dignity and meaning. He has been a strong supporter and advocate for Jewish Home Lifecare since joining the Board and, among other roles, has served as the chair of the Manhattan Divisional Board. Our thoughts will be with Randy, his wife Jane and the entire family during their time of loss. Gene D. Resnick, MD Chairman of the Board Audrey S. Weiner, DSW President/CEO

McCARTHY--Daniel J. Famous in Actuarial Circles, Dead at 70. Daniel J. McCarthy, Jr., noted actuary and former President of the American Academy of Actuaries, died Friday in Manhattan after a very brief illness. He was 70. The cause was stomach cancer. For years, Dan had a New Yorker cartoon in his office that showed a man at a cocktail party trying to impress someone by claiming to be famous if one happened to travel in actuarial circles. Dan was, in fact, famous in actuarial circles as a leader in the field who did much to advance the profession and to serve the insurance industry as a whole. Dan started his career at Equitable Life, where he was asked to try his hand at becoming an actuary. He at first had no idea what an actuary was, but agreed to give it a try. Years later, he taught his children that actuaries ''predict the present financial implications of future contingent events.'' It's no surprise that his six children all went on to professions that were easier to describe. After the Equitable, Dan joined Milliman & Robertson, now Milliman, Inc., which is among the worlds largest independent actuarial and consulting firms with 48 offices around the world. He served as Chairman of the firm for seven years, was President of the American Academy of Actuaries, spent six years as a member of the Actuarial Standards Board, was on the board of the Society of Actuaries, and served as the first International Secretary of the American Academy of Actuaries, traveling all over the world to represent the U.S. actuarial profession at many international organizations. In recent years, he served as Chairman of The Actuarial Foundation, a philanthropic group whose mission is to serve the public by developing education and research programs that harness the talents of actuaries. Dan was also known for advising countless other actuaries, generously sharing his experience with them one-on-one and through his public speaking. In trying to get a handle on what her dad did, one of his daughters once asked Dan what it looked like when he was done with a job. ''It's generally a report that presents an idea,'' he told her. She asked, ''What happens if an idea doesnt come to you?'' He was amused and answered, ''So far, one always has.'' He developed a specialty in demutualization, a term that refers to companies that are customer-owned mutual organizations becoming shareholder - owned stock companies. Dan was involved at various levels in demutualizing over 20 companies. He was referred to by The Life Insurance Council of New York as a ''giant in the insurance industry'' and as an ''extraordinary champion of the actuarial profession'' by the current President of the Academy of Actuaries, Bill Bluhm, who also wrote, ''He was an amazing individual, blessed with a first-rate mind, a great heart, and a vibrant personality. Anyone who ever worked with Dan understood what a pleasure it was to be part of whatever team he was leading. He was a consummate leader, one whose enthusiasm for his profession for life in general was infectious and inspiring.'' Dan never did run out of ideas. Even a brilliant actuary could not have predicted exactly when his own life would end, but he and his family spent a wonderful August together at their vacation home on Lake Winnepesaukee, where he played tennis and golf, went swimming and kayaking, and, probably his favorite activity, took his grandchildren for motorboat rides to get ice cream cones. Dan is survived by his wife of 49 years, the former Virginia Miller, of Aberdeen, NJ and Moultonborough, NH, his children, Deirdre Gelinne of Westfield, NJ, Daniel III of Laconia, NH, Justin of Farmingdale, NJ, Anne Knight of Hopkinton, NH, Judith of Summit, NJ, and Elizabeth of Manhattan, 15 grandchildren, and his sister, Elizabeth Daly, of DeWitt, NY. A funeral mass will be held today at 10am at St. Benedict Roman Catholic Church in Holmdel. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Dans memory at http:// mercyfirst.org/. For more information, see the memoriam on the website of the American Academy of Actuaries: actuary.org / mccarthy.asp.

LEBWORTH--Caral G. It is with deep sadness that The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art has learned of the passing of Caral G. Lebworth. Caral was a beloved member of the International Council since 1971. She and her late husband, M. Joseph Lebworth, traveled with us all over the world; their curiosity, intelligence, and warmth made them an integral part of the Council, and of The Museum of Modern Art. Caral's mother, Alva Gimbel, was a patron of the Museum in the early days, and Caral carried on that friendship and tradition. She will be very deeply missed by her many friends. We send our heartfelt condolences to her beloved twin sister Hope G. Solinger, and to her three children, Glenn, Stephen, and Alva Greenberg. Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

The Firing Line Scott Linehan became the first coaching casualty of the season when he was fired by the St. Louis Rams on Monday morning. Raiders Coach Lane Kiffin was next out the door Tuesday. Theirs were among the earliest in-season coaching changes in the last 20 years. ROSENTHAL--John B. , Founder and Chairman Emeritus of Pennrose Properties, Inc., along with its affiliates Pennrose Management Company and Pennrose Service Company. Acting on his sweeping vision to promote a better quality of living for the residents of affordable housing communities, Mr. Rosenthal launched Pennrose Properties in 1981. It was Mr. Rosenthal's innovative approach, and the belief in power of private initiative partnering with non-profit and community organizations that set Pennrose apart. As one of the first developers in Pennsylvania to effectively utilize the Low-Income Housing Tax Credit program (LIHTC), Pennrose is widely considered to have set the industry standards and become one of the MidAtlantic region's premier affordable housing developers. For more than thirty years, Mr. Rosenthal has championed the goal of making a profound impact on the lives of lower income families by working to provide meaningful supportive services in a quality, secure and affordable living environment. To date, Pennrose has developed more than 10,000 affordable apartments. Mr. Rosenthal's achievements in rebuilding communities and his sensitive approach to historic building conversions earned him the F. Otto Haas Lifetime Achievement Award from Preservation Pennsylvania, the Commonwealth's only private, nonprofit organization dedicated to the protection of historically and architecturally significant properties. Mr. Rosenthal was also the recipient of Ernst & Young's Greater Philadelphia Entrepreneur of the Year Award in 2002. In addition, he served as Vice Chairman of the Urban Land Institute, Delaware Valley Chapter, and was an active participant and member of the Urban Land Institute, Executive Committee. A native New Yorker, Mr. Rosenthal was educated at Williams College, where he received his Bachelor of Arts degree. He earned his MBA and Juris Doctor degrees from Cornell University. An ardent supporter of community programs, Mr. Rosenthal served on the boards of many civic organizations and commissions, including the Tri-County Commission, Universal Community Homes, and the Philadelphia Child Guidance Center. He currently had been on the Board of Youth Build Philadelphia, and the Mayor's Office of Community Services, and was Vice Chairman of the Urban Land Institute, Philadelphia District Council. Mr. Rosenthal is survived by his wife, Linda; a brother, Richard and his wife, Julia; a sister, Susan; and nephews-Daniel, Matthew, Andrew, and Peter; and a niece, Sandra. Services will be held on Friday, October 3, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, located at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Friends of Youth Build Philadelphia, 1231 North Broad Street, 3rd Floor, Philadelphia, PA 19122, phone 215-6278671.

When Michael Lewis's book ''The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game'' came out in 2006, it brought a lot of attention to the position of left tackle and gave fans a glimpse of how important offensive line play is to success in the N.F.L. This season, it seems a few quarterbacks are determined to prove that they can be successful even if they spend most of the game picking mud out of their face masks. Of the six quarterbacks who have been sacked 11 or more times, four have quarterback ratings of 90 or above. J. T. O'Sullivan, right, the first-year starter of the 49ers, has been put down a league-high 19 times for a combined loss of 98 yards and is on pace to tie David Carr's season record of 76 sacks set in 2002. Despite that, he has a respectable rating of 90, and his team is off to a somewhat surprising 2-2 start.

People with pancreatic cancer are more likely than those without the disease to have been infected with the hepatitis B virus, a study has shown for the first time. The finding suggests that hepatitis B -- already known to cause liver cancer in some patients -- may also increase the risk of pancreatic cancer, one of the deadliest types of tumor. But while the study showed an association, it did not prove cause and effect, the researchers said. More work is needed to determine whether the virus really can cause pancreatic cancer.

She married Bert Greenberg of New York City in 1950. They had four children and the family lived in Great Neck, New York for 25 years where Betsy taught the harp and piano. Her first marriage ended in divorce. In 1997, Betsy married John Bruce Stevenson and relocated to Sagaponack, New York. Rice cookers are usually sold with a plastic measuring cup that holds about three-quarters of an American cup. It is the size of the traditional Japanese tool for measuring rice: the masu, a wooden box sometimes used for drinking cold sake. ''Measuring seems to be the most difficult part for our American buyers,'' said Marilyn Matsuba, the American marketing manager for Zojirushi, the company that sells the most rice cookers in Japan. She said cooks can use the same proportions as when cooking rice in a pot. A ratio of two cups liquid to one cup long-grain rice will work; for short-grain rice, the ratio of water to rice is about one and a quarter cup to one cup. An Asian measuring method is surprisingly reliable: with the tip of the index finger resting on the top of the rice, add water until it rises just above the first knuckle. A rice cooker can accommodate easygoing approaches to measurement, because its long steam bath evens the texture of the rice. JULIA MOSKIN

This two-minute advertisement by Senator Barack Obama's media team features him speaking directly into the camera. THE SCRIPT Mr. Obama says: ''For eight years, we've been told that the way to a stronger economy was to give huge tax breaks to corporations and the wealthiest Americans, and somehow prosperity would trickle down. Well, now we know the truth. It didn't work. Instead of prosperity trickling down, pain has trickled up. Working-family incomes have fallen by $2,000 a year. We're losing jobs. Deficits are exploding. Our economy's in turmoil. I know that we can steer ourselves out of this crisis. But not by driving down the very same path. And that's what this election's all about. On taxes, John McCain and I have very different ideas. Instead of giving hundreds of billions in new tax breaks to big corporations and oil companies, I'll cut taxes for small and startup businesses that are the backbone of our economy. Instead of more tax breaks for corporations that outsource American jobs, I'll give them to companies who create jobs here. Instead of extending the Bush tax cuts for the wealthiest, I'll focus on you. My plan offers three times as much tax relief to the middle class as Senator McCain's. If you make less than a quarter- million a year, you won't see your taxes raised one penny under my plan. And seniors making less than 50,000, who are struggling with the rising costs of food and drugs on fixed incomes, won't pay income taxes at all. The tax code we have today is over 10,000 pages long. Almost every bit of it was shaped by some lobbyist taking care of some special interest. Well, it's time we had a president who puts you first. I hope you'll log on to BarackObama.com and read my full plan. It will help jump-start our economy, create millions of jobs and bring back our Main Streets all across America. The old trickle-down theory has failed us. We can't afford four more years like the last eight. I'm Barack Obama, and I approved this message because I know that with a new direction and new policies focused on jobs and the middle class, we can lift our economy and our country.''

KELMAN--Kurt. The lawyers and staff of Collard & Roe, PC mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Kurt Kelman. Mr. Kelman was the oldest practicing patent agent in this country. He practiced for over 61 years until his death. After being accepted at the Technical University of Vienna, Mr. Kelman escaped the Nazis and came over to the United States as a young man in 1939. Fluent in French, German and English, Mr. Kelman joined Collard & Roe in 1982 and obtained for many European companies thousands of patents. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Sylvia, children Steve, Mark, and Ellen, and seven grandchildren. Collard & Roe, PC

It's hardly surprising that the incendiary, banked-coal marriage between Ted Hughes and Sylvia Plath has been revealed to us over the years partly through the intensely personal form of "letters." I use scare quotes because as often as not these are letters as metaphor or literary device. In 1979, Plath's mother, Aurelia, contributed to a play, "Letters Home," based on an annotated volume of Sylvia's letters she'd published four years earlier; in 1998, Hughes published "Birthday Letters," a collection of 88 poems explicitly addressing their disastrous relationship.

So what is not for sale to advertisers in the subway system these days? The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has unveiled, for the first time, an advertisement that would cover an entire subway train, every single car, inside and out.The campaign, for the History Channel's series "Cities of the Underworld," will run the month of October.

During the last weeks of my mother's life, I was with her on a routine doctor visit when she began experiencing excruciating pain. She was rushed to the emergency room, where she was quickly given some sort of scan. Minutes later, a nurse administering pain medicine didn't talk or look at me or my father. Her effort to avoid eye contact told me all I needed to know. My mother's cancer had returned with a vengeance.
BET's "Rap City," the long-running hip-hop video show, will broadcast its final episode by the end of the month, the cable channel confirmed.

It's probably too much to hope that tonight's vice presidential smackdown in St. Louis will turn into a poetry slam. But some people are already finding poetic potential in the contest between Sarah Palin and Joe Biden.

Stefano Pilati tonight advanced the spirit and graphic modernity of his fall collection, though without extracting the same degree of awe that he did six months ago in the Grand Palais. The cutting of the clothes evoked an Eastern influence-and in a sense the imaginative ground for the late Yves Saint Laurent. The opening jackets, in a black or a French blue cotton/silk jacquard, were drawn from kimonos, and were paired with loose wool crepe trousers with a dropped crotch. There are so many versions of those pants around, so many adaptations, that I cannot think of an adequate word to describe them. But suffice to say that Pilati's versions-in three lengths-were well-conceived and flattering, with a slim cut through the waist.

After a school bus ferrying kindergartners and first graders rambled through Brooklyn for four and a half hours one day last month, with the driver out of touch for part of the time, the Department of Education said that a pilot program to install global positioning system devices in some school buses was under way. But some City Council members are saying that the department's pilot program is too little, too late ­and that it unnecessarily duplicates a service that other city agencies already use.In a letter sent Thursday to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, [pdf] six council members wrote that the school system should scrap its pilot program and instead tap into a $500 million wireless communication network and vehicle tracking system developed by the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, which is already being used by the police, sanitation, transportation and social services departments.

It turns out it is not a five-hour flight to San Francisco, as I thought it would be in my last post. It is more than seven if A) it is raining at JFK when you take off and B) you spend an hour taxiing toward the runway.

In response to my post Wednesday about whether Americans are too young to remember the Great Depression, a reader Lance L. said that "For those who read, the Great Depression would seem as vivid today as it probably was back then." He recommended "The Grapes of Wrath" and a few other classics about the era as resources for understanding what happened then, and presumably what might happen now if the United States sank into another deep recession.

As we mentioned on Wednesday, there is a fight in Washington right now over something called the mark-to-market accounting rule. The rule requires companies to value assets at the price they currently could be sold for.

Tenants, including the governor of New York, began moving in last year, so this diaphanous skyscraper is bustling. You're looking forward to ending your visit downtown with a trip to its observatory.

Updated with more answers, Oct. 3 | The news that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to seek a third term by having the city's term limits law altered has prompted intense interest in term limits, which were imposed by an amendment to the City Charter that voters approved in 1993 and ratified again in 1996. Chris Mayer, the senior vice dean of Columbia Business School, wrote an op-ed for The Times last week arguing that the federal government "needs to directly stabilize the housing market." Now, Mayer has co-written an article for the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal with Glenn Hubbard (President Bush's former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers) with a similar argument: "We propose that the Bush administration and Congress allow all residential mortgages on primary residences to be refinanced into 30-year fixed-rate mortgages at 5.25 percent (matching the lowest mortgage rate in the past 30 years), and place those mortgages with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Investors and speculators should not be allowed to qualify."

Institutional investors and the accounting industry on Wednesday lashed out against potential plans to suspend rules used to account for banks' hard-to-price assets, saying it would deprive investors of critical information, Reuters reported.
Efforts by Embarq to sell itself have stalled, as current market conditions have made it difficult for potential suitors to raise cash to finance a deal, The Wall Street Journal reported.

I don't think the explanation for last night's rambling Givenchy show is that Riccardo Tisci just has too many ideas and doesn't know how to "focus." I'm beginning to wonder if he has any ideas at least that are original. It was easier in his first seasons At Givenchy to detect a point of view, for strong tailoring, romance and some great knitwear. I remember a rtw show he did on a square stage at Bercy that had those terrific jackets and trousers with heavy gold buttons. But last night's show seemed to be five or six collections crammed into one, with the Givenchy blouse story (frilly or bib-front), the cut-out shifts over contrasting lady-bright lace, the tough tailoring with a girdled waist, the bondage bits (done in a prosaic way, too), the white club dresses doused with crystals, and the denim outfits mixed with black leather and even embellished with flame patterns.

For those of you who missed it, the Senate passed its version of the financial bailout plan, which was embroidered with unrelated tax credit extensions for the renewable energy industry. As Bloomberg has it today, "the tax package would spare 24 million American households from a scheduled alternative minimum tax increase this year, renew credits for business research, and extend $17 billion in energy incentives."

Technology mergers and acquisitions volume dropped by one-third in the third quarter, as many big-name buyers went missing, The 451 Group wrote. Both the spending and rate of deals make 2008 look a lot like 2005, the report said.

My Thursday column is about the economic crisis and is very much shape by my experience in Japan watching Japanese politicians refuse to act decisively to respond to the banking crisis there. I argue that the lesson from Japan is that the House should immediately follow the Senate's lead and pass the bailout -- but then come back in January and pass a series of measures to inject more fairness into the system. Step one would be an end to subsidies for executive pay. Any suggestions for steps two and three?

World | The world has a water shortage, not a food shortage, an article says. You may drink only two liters of water a day, but you consume about 3,000 if you count the water that goes into your food (even more if you're a meat-eater). Experts are working on "more crop per drop" efficiency in farming, which now wastes veritable deluges of water. [Economist]

China | The writer Ha Jin describes how the authorities in his native country muffle dissent: "On the whole, the party has succeeded in buying off the intellectuals, who live much better than the people in the lower social strata." Thus, "as long as China's brains do not join forces with the rebellious masses, the country will be easier to control." [American Scholar]

History | The European Union is the Hapsburg Empire reincarnated, a colorful new biography suggests. The biography is of a minor Hapsburg royal, but a review says its "real subject matter" is "the volatile chemistry of nation-building in modern Europe." Bloody ultranationalism has been replaced by a Hapsburgian "multi-ethnic commonwealth." [TLS]

Technology | One of the last typewriter repairmen stays in business by fixing laser printers. But he insists the typewriter isn't dead; it's newly popular with the young, "who have found their parents and grandparents' old typewriters in basements and attics." Maybe the typewriters can click out the beat next to the hip-hop turntables. [Business Week]

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Brook Lopez fell somewhat in the N.B.A.’s draft. Ryan Anderson rose somewhat. Together, they landed with the Nets, the organization’s big-man bounty of first-round selections. From competitors to collaborators, they now confront a jarring transitional period otherwise known as the rookie season.

Jason Bay ripped a two-run homer against John Lackey that helped propel the Red Sox to a victory against the Angels in Game 1 of their division series.

Because of Id al-Fitr, the festival marking the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.
Highlights from this year’s show at the Porte de Versailles convention center, which is open to the public through Oct. 19.
Why do I believe term limits should be lifted temporarily to allow Michael Bloomberg to run for a third term? The answer is simple. I don’t want this city to repeat the early 1970s.
Journalists were given an extended look at the movie, about the tawdry life of superheroes who have fallen from grace.

A 1906 letter from Grover Cleveland, the former president, who died June 24, has come to light, and in it he said he was "dumbfounded by the return of Democracy to Bryanism," a trend that has again given William Jennings Bryan the Democratic presidential nomination. "Mr. Cleveland did not hesitate to express his belief that the party was going down to defeat again in 1908," the front-page article says. Cleveland in 1906 Condemned Bryan

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that he would support changing New York’s term limit law and that he would run again if it is lifted.

As Gina Kolata reports in The Times today, relaxation is a “trait that is often underappreciated, coaches and athletic trainers say. Yet it can make the difference between doing your best and not doing well, between feeling dragged down or soaring. Coaches search for better ways to teach it. And many athletes, including some of the world’s best, work on it constantly. An ability to relax while pushing hard, exercise researchers say, is one reason why winners win.” Relaxation also is a mysterious state and hard to describe, and perhaps even harder to coach, going against an athlete’s instincts. Here’s one piece of advice: try relaxing your eyes.

Al Davis and the Oakland Raiders were at it again this week, putting their organizational dysfunction on public display Tuesday with a lengthy, bizarre news conference in which Davis fired Coach Lane Kiffin and replaced him with offensive coordinator Tom Cable, the team’s sixth coach in seven years. Figuring out the Raiders means deciphering their 79-year-old owner; that’s no easy assignment, but it’s one Play’s Bryan Curtis took on last year when he profiled Davis and his organization for our September 2007 issue.

You can’t be a 40-something runner (like me) without hearing constant warnings from people that running will ruin your knees. The threat seemed to become more credible last month, when researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the University of North Carolina published a major epidemiological study predicting that nearly 45 percent of all Americans will develop arthritic knees during their lifetime. The risk rises to 56.8 percent for anyone who’s ever suffered a knee injury, a harsh reminder of hard hits and awkward landings past. The study employed medical data from more than 3,000 middle-aged North Carolinians.

The N.F.C. East has been the ascendant division in pro football for the past two years. And now there’s no doubt, as countless salivary analysts remind us each weekend, that we are also witnessing the return of the old "N.F.C. Beast," a cluster of talented and physical teams that terrify opponents.
An article on Saturday about the first presidential debate misstated Senator John McCain’s age in some editions. He is 72, not 71.

Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about drug violence in Mexico misspelled the name of a town where La Familia, a violent drug gang, dumped the heads of five uncooperative drug dealers in a bar in 2006. It is Uruapán, not Uruapa.

An article in some editions last Thursday about the dedication of a new library at the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y., misstated the strategic role played by the original fortifications at West Point during the Revolutionary War. They were built to prevent the British from seizing control of the Hudson River, not to halt any advance of the British toward New York City (which the British had already captured).

An article on Monday about the helmet-to-helmet hit that injured Arizona Cardinals receiver Anquan Boldin in the game against the Jets misspelled the surname of the Cardinals’ team owner and his son. They are Bill and Mike Bidwill, not Bidwell. (Mike Bidwill was among those who went to the X-ray room at Giants Stadium to check on Boldin.).

An article on Friday about the creative family rules that the N.F.L. quarterback Kurt Warner and his wife, Brenda, use with their children referred incorrectly to her military background. Although she was indeed a marine, she was not an officer in the corps.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Steve Dunleavy, a longtime New York Post columnist who is retiring after 55 years in journalism, gave an outdated name for a Turner Broadcasting channel that was inspired by his journalistic style. It is truTV — not Court TV, which was its name through 2007.

Because of an editing error, the college football top 25 chart on Monday with an analysis of the weekend’s games misstated, in some copies, the University of Southern California’s ranking by The Associated Press. It is No. 9; it is not tied with No. 1 Oklahoma.

An obituary and an Inside The Times capsule summary on Wednesday about the poet and critic Hayden Carruth misstated a word in a quotation from him. He said, “My poems, I think, exist in a state of tension between the love of natural beauty and the fear of natural meaninglessness or absurdity” — not “meaningless” or absurdity.

An obituary on Saturday about Marpessa Dawn, who played Eurydice in the classic 1959 movie “Black Orpheus,” misspelled the given name and the surname of her co-star in the film. He was Breno Mello, not Bruno Melo. (A correction in this space on Tuesday, which dealt only with the obituary’s misspelling of Breno, spelled Mello correctly.).

The Skin Deep column on Feb. 7 reported that the number of Americans traveling abroad for medical care in 2006 had increased to 500,000 from 150,000 in 2004, and that of those half a million, 200,000 were seeking dental care. The 2006 figures were attributed to the National Coalition of Health Care, an alliance of more than 70 organizations.

Martin Brodeur stopped 16 shots, and Zach Parise, Patrik Elias and Anssi Salmela each scored in the Devils’ 3-0 victory over the Islanders on Wednesday night in a preseason game in Uniondale, N.Y. The Devils improved to 3-2 in the preseason. MacDonald made 19 saves for the Islanders (2-2) in their only preseason game at home.

Joey Logano will stop driving Sprint Cup Series races this season for Hall of Fame Racing. Logano, a promising 18-year-old, is set to replace Tony Stewart in Joe Gibbs Racing’s flagship No. 20 next season. The team scheduled him for a handful of starts this year and loaned him to Hall of Fame for another five races. But his first two races in the No. 96 were a struggle. He finished 32nd in his Cup debut in New Hampshire and was 39th last week at Kansas. Logano was scheduled to make three more starts for Hall of Fame this year, but instead will turn the wheel over to Ken Schrader and focus on the Nationwide Series.

Lionel Messi scored two late goals to give F.C. Barcelona a 2-1 victory at Shakhtar Donestsk in the Champions League. A.S. Roma rallied for a 3-1 victory at Bordeaux. Things went more smoothly for Liverpool, which defeated P.S.V. Eindhoven by 3-1, and Atlético Madrid, which beat Marseille, 2-1. Chelsea played to a 0-0 draw at unheralded C.F.R. Cluj in another of the day’s eight group matches.

Oscar De La Hoya said he wanted to fight at least a few more times after taking on Manny Pacquiao on Dec. 6 in Las Vegas, in what is sure to be the biggest fight of the year. De La Hoya broke box-office and pay-per-view records with a narrow loss to Floyd Mayweather Jr. last year, and he said that fight proved he could still compete at an elite level. De La Hoya had announced he would retire after this year and focus on his many business interests.

Serena Williams made numerous errors after she swept the first set Wednesday, leading to a 0-6, 6-1, 6-4 loss to Li Na of China that will cost Williams the No. 1 world ranking. By dropping the second-round match at the Porsche Grand Prix in Stuttgart, Germany, Williams will be overtaken by Jelena Jankovic in Monday’s new rankings, the W.T.A. said. Williams gained the top spot when she beat Jankovic in the United States Open final three weeks ago for her ninth Grand Slam title. Williams was playing her first match since the Open. She rolled through the first set and appeared headed for a resounding victory. Li beat Williams’s sister Venus to reach the semifinals at the Beijing Olympics.

The Russian forward Alexander Radulov was wrong to sign with a club in his home country while under contract with the Nashville Predators, ice hockey’s world governing body ruled. But the International Ice Hockey Federation said it had no legal basis to suspend him because there was no agreement to regulate international transfers. The ruling indicated Radulov had an agreement to serve the year left on his Predators contract. The case had been at the center of a wider dispute between the N.H.L. and Russia’s new Continental Hockey League, or the K.H.L., over respecting players’ contracts.

Paula Radcliffe will defend her New York City Marathon title on Nov. 2, the New York Road Runners announced. Five months after winning the 2007 edition, Radcliffe was sidelined with a stress fracture in her left leg. That left her with little time to train for the Olympics, where she finished 23rd. Radcliffe has never lost on the New York course. Last year, she ran shoulder to shoulder with Gete Wami of Ethiopia nearly the entire race before pulling away in the last half-mile. Radcliffe’s victory came 10 months after she gave birth to her first child.

Metallica’s “Death Magnetic” (Warner Brothers) is No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a third week, despite a major slip. It sold 132,000 copies last week, a 61 percent decrease from the week before, according to Nielsen SoundScan; its three-week total is 959,000. In second place this week is Demi Lovato, Disney’s latest pop star. (She starred in “Camp Rock” with the Jonas Brothers.) Her debut, “Don’t Forget,” sold 89,000 copies. Ne-Yo dropped one spot to No. 3 with “Year of the Gentleman” (Def Jam), selling 83,000, and several new albums entered the Top 10. Pussycat Dolls’ “Doll Domination” (Interscope) is No. 4; Kings of Leon’s “Only by the Night” (RCA) is No. 5; and Jazmine Sullivan, a new R&B singer with a hit song, “Need U Bad,” opened at No. 6 with her debut album, “Fearless” (J). Theater Works, a radio theater troupe, on Oct. 26. Both performances are directed by John de Lancie (also known as Q from “Star Trek: The Next Generation”), and will feature alumni from the casts of “Star Trek: Voyager,” “Heroes” and “The X-Files.” Tickets are available from the box office, (718) 951-4500, or at BrooklynCenterOnline.org.

FANS who turned up for the Eugene Mirman Comedy Festival at the Bell House in Brooklyn last weekend paid homage to the gaslight era, dressing to complement the old-school décor of this saloon and variety club near the Gowanus Canal. Alysia Savoy (above center) tended bar in a cinched top and pencil skirt; Dave Hill, her mustachioed colleague (above right), was spruce in a vest and newsboy cap. Other members of this playfully sinister demimonde included emo boys like Brendan Sullivan (above left), wearing a hoodie and shredded jeans; and neo-goth vixens like Anna Del Gaizo (far left), wicked in dark hose and biker boots.

Elinor Guggenheimer, who was already a grandmother when she began advocating for children, women and the elderly, and went on to become a national spokeswoman for their concerns as well as a prominent member of the New York City government, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 96. The death was confirmed by her daughter-in-law Jane Guggenheimer.

BISHOP--John Patrick, 33, was born in Harrison, AR on February 28, 1975. He died on Wednesday, September 24, 2008 at Baptist Hospital in Little Rock, AR. John was a good and honest man who loved his wife and children deeply and without reservation. He is survived by his wife, Sara, whom he wed on October 13, 2001, his children Samuel James, Anna Katherine, and John Abraham. He is also survived by his parents, Linda Summers of Berryville, AR and Pat Bishop of Green Forest, AR, stepfather Paul Summers of Berryville, AR, brothers Matthew of Fayetteville, AR and Michael of Tulsa, OK, as well as numerous aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, cousins and other relatives and a multitude of friends. He was preceded in death by his maternal grandparents, Daniel and Anna Santa Cruz of Berryville, AR and Carl and Louise Bishop of Green Forest, AR. John graduated from Berryville High School in 1993 and from the University of Pennsylvania in 1998 with a B.S. in Economics. He went on to earn an M.A. in Economics from St. Annes College of Oxford University in 2000. For the next seven years he worked as a derivatives trader for various investment banks in New York City. In the spring of 2008, he moved home to Berryville, AR with his family to raise his children in the same environment he had so loved as a child. He was never happier than this past year when he was spending a day riding horses with his kids, sitting on the porch with his wife or sitting on a tractor haying for hours on end. John touched and enhanced the lives of all who knew him with his gentle strength and belief in the goodness of God. His commitment to his family, his friends, and his faith never wavered. Memorial Mass will be 11am Saturday, October 4, 2008 at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121 Street, New York City, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to two charities John strongly believed in. St. Annes Scholarship Fund at St. Annes Church, 614 South Main Street, Berryville, AR 72616, and Farm of the Child, 1616 Nottingham Knoll Drive, Jacksonville, FL 32225 or online at farmofthechild.org/ donate. Condolences can be sent to the family at nelsonfuneral.com.

The Federico family; Helen, Lisa, Gina and their kids and spouses will miss Nathan Gluck, our kind, gentle and creative friend for more than 70 years, who died over the weekend in San Diego. We'll miss his visits by train, his concern about our well-being, his holiday phone calls, and his drawings, paintings and collages, which arrived in the mail without fail for every New Year, birth and anniversary. We'll miss his kindness, his wisdom, his worldliness. Nathan was one of the last of an era. G'luck, Nathan Gluck!

ROSENTHAL--John B. Founder and Chairman Emeritus of Pennrose Properties, Inc., along with its affiliates Pennrose Management Company and Pennrose Service Company. Acting on his sweeping vision to promote a better quality of living for the residents of affordable housing communities, Mr. Rosenthal launched Pennrose Properties in 1981. It was Mr. Rosenthal's innovative approach, and the belief in power of private initiative partnering with non-profit and community organizations that set Pennrose apart. As one of the first developers in Pennsylvania to effectively utilize the Low-Income Housing Tax Credit program (LIHTC), Pennrose is widely considered to have set the industry standards and become one of the Mid-Atlantic region's premier affordable housing developers. For more than thirty years, Mr. Rosenthal has championed the goal of making a profound impact on the lives of lower income families by working to provide meaningful supportive services in a quality, secure and affordable living environment. To date, Pennrose has developed more than 10,000 affordable apartments. Mr. Rosenthal's achievements in rebuilding communities and his sensitive approach to historic building conversions earned him the F. Otto Haas Lifetime Achievement Award from Preservation Pennsylvania, the Commonwealth's only private, nonprofit organization dedicated to the protection of historically and architecturally significant properties. Mr. Rosenthal was also the recipient of Ernst & Young's Greater Philadelphia Entrepreneur of the Year Award in 2002. In addition, he served as Vice Chairman of the Urban Land Institute, Delaware Valley Chapter, and was an active participant and member of the Urban Land Institute, Executive Committee. A native New Yorker, Mr. Rosenthal was educated at Williams College, where he received his Bachelor of Arts degree. He earned his MBA and Juris Doctor degrees from Cornell University. An ardent supporter of community programs, Mr. Rosenthal served on the boards of many civic organizations and commissions, including the Tri-County Commission, Universal Community Homes, and the Philadelphia Child Guidance Center. He currently had been on the Board of Youth Build Philadelphia, and the Mayor's Office of Community Services, and was Vice Chairman of the Urban Land Institute, Philadelphia District Council. Mr. Rosenthal is survived by his wife, Linda; a brother, Richard and his wife, Julia; a sister, Susan; and nephews-Daniel, Matthew, Andrew, and Peter; and a niece, Sandra. Services will be held on Friday, October 3 at 11am, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, located at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Friends of Youth Build Philadelphia, 1231 North Broad Street, 3rd Floor, Philadelphia, PA 19122, phone 215627-8671.

RANDELMAN--Hal. Born July 13, 1938 in New York City, Hal passed away on September 27, 2008 following a long and courageous battle with cancer. He lived most of his life in New York City, relocating to Naples, FL in 2001 and then to Los Angeles in 2005. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation in his memory to The American Cancer Society.

Has the elusive British graffiti artist Banksy struck New York again? On Wednesday pedestrians and bloggers were abuzz that a new mural project going up in SoHo was the handiwork of Banksy, the pseudonymous street artist. The mural, depicting what appeared to be a rat toting an umbrella, seemed to repeat a motif seen in another mural recently painted on a wall at Grand and Wooster Streets, that of a rat in an ''I -- NY'' T-shirt. That work was believed to be a collaboration between Banksy and the outdoor advertising company Colossal Media, which put up both murals and had no comment on Banksy's involvement. David Choe, an artist represented by Lazarides Galleries, which also handles Banksy's art, identified the murals as Bansky's. A representative for Banksy did not reply to questions sent via an e-mail message.

Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska drew a blank in an interview broadcast on Wednesday when asked by Katie Couric to name any decisions by the United States Supreme Court that she disagreed with, beyond Roe v. Wade. ''Hmmm,'' Ms. Palin, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, said after a brief silence. ''Well, let's see. There's -- of course in the great history of America there have been rulings that there's never going to be absolute consensus by every American. And there are those issues, again, like Roe v. Wade, where I believe are best held on a state level and addressed there. So you know, going through the history of America, there would be others but -- -- .''

ELLIOTT--Osborn . The Board of Directors and staff of Symphony Space mourn the passing of Osborn Elliott. Oz's life was a record of dazzling achievements--as a journalist and editor at Newsweek, and as Dean of Columbia's School of Journalism. But Oz was more than an accomplished professional. Husband of Inger Elliott, father to three daughters, two stepdaughters and a stepson, and two foster sons, grandfather to 17 and great-grandfather to one, Oz was the legendary Newsweek editor, dean of the Columbia Journalism School and a stalwart defender of civic values as founder of the Citizens Committee for New York City. He inspired thousands in shaping not just the city we love but our society as well. Services will be held at All Souls Church in Manhattan on October 2 at 11am and at the Calvary Church in Stonington, CT on October 4 at 11am. Gifts in his memory may be made to Citizens Committee for New York City, 305 Seventh Ave., NYC, NY 10001.

ATHOS--William J. M.D. , age 78, at home in St. Petersburg, FL on September 30, 2008 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband of Irene (nee Koskinas) for 51 years. Loving father of Elizabeth Athos and Jean Athos-Adler. Father-inlaw to Dr. Michael A. Adler and William Figdor. Adored grandfather to Christopher and Alexandra Adler and Dmitri and Andrei Figdor. Born in Greece in 1929 to Persephone and John Athos, Dr. Athos emigrated to the U.S. at age seven and grew up in New York City. He was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School, Columbia College and SUNY Downstate Medical Center where he was elected to Alpha Omega Alpha. He completed his internship, residency and New York Fellowship at St. Lukes Hospital. Dr. Athos served as a Captain in the U.S. Army Medical Corps and was Physician to the Peace Corps Training Program at Columbia University. He enjoyed a long career practicing Internal Medicine in New York City, was devoted to his patients who adored him, and was affiliated with St. LukesRoosevelt Hospital, Lenox Hill Hospital and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons as an Assistant Clinical Professor of Medicine. He was voted one of New York Magazines Best Doctors in New York and he particularly treasured his award for Distinguished Service from the Salvation Army, having served as a consultant and volunteer for 25 years. His love, intellectual curiosity and wit will be sorely missed but his inspiration will remain. We will forever love and miss him. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Dr., Tenafly, NJ on Friday 2-4 and 79pm. Funeral Service at St. John the Theologian Greek Orthodox Cathedral, Tenafly on Saturday 10am. Interment Brookside Cemetery, Englewood, NJ. Donations may be made to the Dr. William J. Athos Endowment Fund of St. Stephanos Church, 3600 76th Street North, St. Petersburg, FL 33710 or Hospice of the Florida Suncoast, 3050 1st Avenue S., St. Petersburg, FL 33712. For directions visit www.barrettfuneralhome.net

J. L. Chestnut Jr., who after attending law school in Washington returned to his hometown, Selma, Ala., and set up shop as the city's first black lawyer, then went on to fight for voting rights for blacks, laying the groundwork for the march led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. from Selma to Montgomery in 1965, died Tuesday in Birmingham, Ala. He was 77 and lived in Selma. The cause was kidney failure after an illness of several months, his daughter Vivian said.

An article on Tuesday about the dismissal of a lawsuit that tried to stop the operation of a giant particle accelerator, built by the nuclear research organization known as CERN, erroneously attributed a quotation to one of the plaintiffs, misrepresenting his view on one point. The plaintiff, Luis Sancho, who is a science writer and professor in Barcelona, believes that the most recent safety study of the collider was inadequate. He did not say, ''The study was not perfect, but at least the safety factors on which CERN is relying are not quite as bad.'' (That quotation, contained in an e-mail message sent to the reporter by Mr. Sancho, represents the view of James Blodgett, who studies risk assessments and has been critical of how physicists determine risks.)

Senator John McCain has disputed, patiently, accusations that he has a short temper. But his sarcastic, and sometimes testy, responses to The Des Moines Register's editorial board, which the Iowa newspaper videotaped and posted online Wednesday, are not likely to help him make that case. ''Really?'' he responded to a question about possible concern from voters about Gov. Sarah Palin's level of experience. ''I haven't detected that in the polls; I haven't detected that among the base. If there's a Georgetown cocktail party person who, quote, calls himself a conservative who doesn't like her, good luck.''

JUMPING rope, long a playground favorite, is serious exercise. It builds aerobic capacity while also improving agility, coordination and endurance. Like running, jumping rope is easy to learn. But, said Carol Espel, an exercise physiologist and the national director of group fitness for Equinox, ''it has the added benefits of working the upper body and being easier on the knees.'' New jump-ropes with digital calorie counters underscore how the activity has moved beyond child's play. Improved ball bearings and heavier ropes make for a tougher workout, with faster rope rotations. Some handles are made weightier to challenge arms and shoulders. And some jump-ropes don't even have ropes.

He was 74 and lived in New York City and Rockport, having moved to this country some two decades ago.

BAGHDAD -- The dust storms that have blanketed Baghdad, making it hard to see for much of the summer, seem a metaphor for the times. The security situation is indisputably good. Violence is down. Parliament passed both a law to hold a census for the first time in more than three decades and a provincial election law that would allow the balloting to be held in all but one province by the end of January. This is clear progress.
