The former Nebraska running back Lawrence Phillips was sentenced Friday to 10 years in prison for assault with a deadly weapon. The charge stemmed from an incident several years ago when Phillips hit three teenagers with his car after he got mad at them during a pickup football game in a park.

At the back of Alexander McQueen's rather brilliant show tonight, near a modest herd of stuffed animals, was the projected image of a large roving eyeball. It had replaced an image of earth seen from outer space, so the inference was that we are being watched. Or studied under a microscope. Or through a kaleidoscope. Heavens, I don't know. It's quite late here. The show dealt with the natural world, evolution, Darwinism, the Industrial revolution, Victorian dress form shapes. Yet it felt drivingly contemporary, with the emphasis on prints based on animals, wood grains, crushed crystals, skeletons, and mechanical shapes like the Eiffel Tower. You just felt blitzed by the color and pattern, and I had the impression that no two were alike. Amazing work. And McQueen came out in the end dressed in a white bunny suit. I mean, we can only assume that it was McQueen, so transformed

Conservatives have long complained of the dangers posed by the unique status of Fannie Mae. Though it was privatized in 1968, and allowed to sell shares to the public, it was also a "government-sponsored enterprise" (or GSE), which meant it had, for example, a line of credit at the Treasury, and thus was perceived by investors to have at least an implicit government backing. A paper by Peter J. Wallison and Charles W. Calomiris of the American Enterprise Institute explains the creation, evolution and fall of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Wallison was general counsel of the Treasury Department in the Reagan administration, and played a significant role in proposals for the deregulation of the financial services industry. Each week, The Times asks the bloggers who cover opposing teams to break down the coming game for the Giants - in 100 words or less. (Give or take a few rants.) In this edition, we examine the Giants' game against the Seahawks on Sunday (1 p.m. Eastern on Fox). The night before the Chanel show I dropped by 31 Rue Cambon to visit Karl Lagerfeld, and saw Stefano Tonchi and then Carine Roitfeld swinging through the door almost at the same time. It can get a little crowded up in the studio, and I'm sure at times the staff would like to grab Lagerfeld by the ponytail and drag him back to the fittings. But somehow he manages to keep an eye on everything. He told me that for the show he was going to have a full-size façade of the house erected in the Grand Palais. Lagerfeld's sets for Chanel just get bigger and bigger.

One of the many disconcerting parts of raising a teen, is that our home phone doesn't ring. When I was that age, I now realize, my parents had a way to gauge who was a part of my life by the phone calls. No they didn't listen in. (At least I don't think they did. I'll have to go ask my mom.) But the phone rang, and they picked up, and Sheila or Chris or Jay had to tolerate a few moments of conversation before my mother handed the receiver over to me. It was attached to the wall, and I sat on the stairs near the kitchen and talked as the rest of the family walked past.

Soot brings to mind dirty chimneys and grimy air, but many New York schoolchildren encounter it daily on their school buses. For the 138,000 children who ride in the city's 6,770 diesel school buses, exhaust can damage developing lungs, and contains more than 40 toxic substances, including known cancer-causing agents. Diesel pollution inside a school bus can be five times higher than outdoor levels, according to a study released on Thursday by the Environmental Defense Fund, which proposes various ways to address the problem.The report advocates investing $30 million over three years to retrofit polluting buses and retire older buses when they're 16 years old instead of 19. (Connecticut and New Jersey generally retire theirs at 12 years old.)

Television dramas in our post-"Sopranos" age have become supersize, but are the actors now too small? Glenn Close of the FX series "Damages" won the best-actress Emmy award last month. Maybe it's not surprising: a veteran like Close can readily shoulder the demands of her role, where Hamm, the greener actor, may have to mature into his.

Education | The financial crisis looks set to hit education funding at all levels. Here's how things look: crimped tax revenues for public schools (coupled with higher food and fuel costs) thanks to rising foreclosures and plunging property values; tighter credit for college loans; tighter state budgets for higher education; a bailout-strapped federal education budget; and college endowments hit by the double whammy of declining portfolio values and poorer donors. No one seems to have pulled all this together yet, but the links here shed light. [Education Week, EZine Articles, Houston Chronicle, Chronicle of Higher Education]

There are 43 holidays this year (some overlapping) on which alternate side of the street parking is suspended in New York City -- 10 days in October alone. Some are national (Independence Day). But most are religious. There are so many that -- for the first time in anyone's memory -- four religious holiday parking days just happened in a row: the two days for Rosh Hashana on Tuesday and Wednesday and three days for Id al-Fitr, ending today. This proliferation of religious parking holidays is a result of a flare-up 40 years ago between Mayor John V. Lindsay and just about everyone else.

Ji-Yai Shin, a 20-year-old South Korean, shot a five-under-par 67 on to take the first-day lead in the Samsung World Championship in Half Moon Bay, Calif., topping Paula Creamer’s 68 that featured a birdie on No. 17.

Red Wings defenseman Chris Chelios will be sidelined three to six weeks with a fractured shin bone. Chelios, 46, is the N.H.L.’s oldest player. He is entering his 25th N.H.L. season and his 10th with Detroit. Chelios was hurt in Tuesday night’s 2-1 preseason loss to Montreal.

Operation Puerto, cycling’s biggest doping investigation, has ended without a conviction. The Spanish news media reported that a judge officially sealed Operation Puerto, which had implicated more than 50 riders. Raids in Madrid and Zaragoza in May 2006 turned up steroids, hormones and the endurance-boosting substance EPO, nearly 100 bags of frozen blood and equipment for treating blood. Judge Antonio Serrano reportedly decided to close the case after tested samples showed levels of EPO that were too low to merit a health risk — in line with Spanish doping laws then. U.C.I., cycling’s governing body, is trying to see the evidence gathered in the investigation.

Jeff Overton shot a five-under-par 67 to take the first-round lead at the Turning Stone Resort Championship, the second stop on the P.G.A. Tour’s Fall Series, in Verona, N.Y. Overton made three birdies on his back nine to take a one-shot lead over Michael Allen and Steve Allan.

The Washington Redskins were ordered to provide deaf and hard-of-hearing fans with “equal access to aural content” at FedEx Field, like music lyrics, ads and other broadcasts on the public-address broadcasts. United States District Court Judge Alexander Williams said that since the suit was filed, the Redskins had resolved the “vast majority of the issues” raised by the plaintiffs by captioning play-by-play, emergency information and other content.

Ticket sales start Friday for the 2010 Vancouver Olympics and will be available for five weeks through an online process designed to thwart scalpers. The organizing committee will accept applications for tickets between Friday and Nov. 7, submitted either online at vancouver2010.com or through a paper application available by phone. Who gets which tickets will be decided after the deadline for applications. Applicants for tickets will be notified in late November or early December if they are successful. tickets.

Ticket sales start Friday for the 2010 Vancouver Olympics and will not be offered first come first served. Instead, they will be available for five weeks through an online process designed to thwart scalpers. The organizing committee will accept applications for tickets between Friday and Nov. 7, submitted online at vancouver2010.com or through a paper application available by phone. Who gets which tickets will be decided after the deadline for applications. If there is more demand for an event than there are seats, a lottery will be held. Applicants for tickets will be notified in late November or early December if they are successful.

Operation Puerto, cycling’s biggest doping investigation, has ended without a conviction. The Spanish news media reported that a judge officially sealed Operation Puerto, which had implicated more than 50 riders. Raids in Madrid and Zaragoza in May 2006 turned up steroids, hormones, the endurance-boosting substance EPO, nearly 100 bags of frozen blood and equipment for treating blood. U.C.I., cycling’s governing body, is working with the lawyers for the World Anti-Doping Agency and the International Olympic Committee to try to see the evidence in the investigation.

Hélio Castroneves, a two-time Indianapolis 500 winner and a winner of ABC’s “Dancing With The Stars,” was indicted on tax evasion and tax fraud charges in Miami, accused of using offshore accounts to hide millions of dollars in income from the Internal Revenue Service. Castroneves, 33, is charged with conspiracy and six counts of tax evasion for failing to report about $5.5 million in income between 1999 and 2004, according to court documents. Each count carries a maximum five-year prison sentence.

Two and a half hours into a 24-hour auto race at Brighton Beach, a racing official was stuck by the lead car, a Simplex, as he attempted to dash across the track last night in front of 10,000 spectators. The official, Thomas K. Fickett, as he was later identified, was not expected to live. The driver, George Robertson, stopped at the judges' stand and left the wheel to his mechanic, who proceeded with the race. An article on Tuesday about a review of studies of psychoanalytic therapy referred incorrectly to the 23 studies included in the review. In many of the studies — but not all of them — the therapy had been given more than once a week.

An article in the Itineraries pages on Tuesday about an increase in airline service and amenities on Asian routes misidentified, in some editions, the airport used by Singapore Airlines for its all-business-class flights from North America. It is Newark Liberty International Airport, not Kennedy International Airport in New York. The article also misspelled the given name of a California management consultant who has begun flying Jet Airways, the first India-based airline to fly from San Francisco to Mumbai. He is Gunjan Bagla, not Ganjun.

A picture caption on Wednesday with a theater column about the New York Musical Theater Festival misidentified the actor shown with Celina Carvajal in a scene from “Bedbugs!!!” and the role he portrays. He is Christopher Hall playing Cimex, king of the bedbugs — not Brian Charles Rooney, who plays a singer.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about efforts by General Motors and other American carmakers to appeal to international markets misidentified the location of a Ford plant in Europe that has begun manufacturing the subcompact Fiesta. It is in Cologne, Germany — not Cologne, Italy.

The Critic’s Choice column on Tuesday, about early British films on DVD including “Sweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street” from 1936, referred imprecisely to the creation of the “Sweeney Todd” musical based on Christopher Bond’s 1973 play. While Stephen Sondheim wrote the music and lyrics, Hugh Wheeler wrote the book for the musical. It was not simply a “musical adaptation” by Mr. Sondheim.

Because of an editing error, the Advertising column on Thursday, about plans to revive infomercials for the Veg-O-Matic and other products from the Ronco Acquisition Corporation, referred incorrectly in one reference to the status of marketing films featuring Ron Popeil, the company’s founder and original pitchman. As the column noted elsewhere, infomercials featuring Mr. Popeil are still shown; he has not been “off the air for many years.”.

An article on Thursday about the debt problems of The Star Tribune of Minneapolis misstated its ownership history. Before being owned by the McClatchy Company, it was owned by the Cowles Media Company — not by Knight Ridder.

An article on Wednesday about failing real estate deals in New York following the turmoil on Wall Street referred incorrectly to the status of a plan by the law firm of Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe to lease space at Citigroup Center. The law firm is still considering the move, a partner said, and has not in fact decided to extend its lease at its current location, 666 Fifth Avenue. The article also misidentified the city where HSBC — which has canceled plans to move its American headquarters to 7 World Trade Center — is based. It is London, not Hong Kong.

An article on Tuesday about the backstage activities at Paris Fashion Week misidentified an author in describing outfits in the Rick Owens collection as looking like something futuristic nuns might wear in a novel. She is Margaret Atwood, the Canadian author whose novel “The Handmaid’s Tale” is set in a totalitarian theocracy — not Margaret Drabble, the British author.

The small city of Elko, in eastern Nevada, does not have a lot of Democrats. So when Cathy Vance and Marti DeLance, campaign volunteers there for Senator Barack Obama, go looking for sympathetic voters, they get a lot of exercise. And they have to settle for a lot of undecided voters. There are a remarkable number of them, even with just over a month to go, even as a multitude of yard signs crop up in support of Senator John McCain.

Appalachia is supposed to be one of Senator Barack Obama's biggest weak spots. But judging from a surprise work stoppage at the Blacksville No. 2 coal mine in West Virginia, Mr. Obama evidently has some pockets of support there. On Monday, more than 440 members of the United Mine Workers of America took the day off, halting production at the Blacksville mine. The union declared it a memorial day, largely to protest what union officials said was an anti-Obama advertisement that the National Rifle Association was filming at the mine.

BLEI--Andres M.D. , ''Andy'', Prof. of Medicine at Northwestern University for more than 25 years, contributed to the creation of a leading center for the care of liver disease, both in terms of patients seen and the intensity of research. A native of Buenos Aires, an educator, clinician, and editor, you will be remembered for your intellect, leadership, generosity, charisma, and compassion. Beloved husband of Estela, loving father of Daniela and Alex, adored brother of Miguel, and dear cousin to family members, you will be missed for your infectious enthusiasm and energy. With passion you lived life to the fullest, touching others with your creativity, curiosity, and affection. Dignified and determined in sickness as in health, you will always inspire us. Our warmest thoughts and favorite memories are filled with you. A memorial service will be held at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, Monday, October 6, 4pm at Hughes Auditorium, Lurie Medical Research Center, 303 East Superior St., Chicago, IL.

LEVINE--Selene , of Rye, NY and Palm Beach, FL died September 30, 2008 after a long courageous battle with cancer. She was born October 22, 1924 in New York City to Sophie and Jack Davidson. Selene began her career as an assistant to writer Dorothy Norman. She later used her creative talents to design and craft gold and silver jewelry. Active in many local organizations, including Hadassah, UJA, Beth Emeth Synagogue and PTA. Spending winters in Palm Beach, she continued her philanthropic activities at the Palm Beach Habilitation Center and as an officer of ORT. Lover of ballet, music and theater. Lifelong tennis player and fan, watching every Grand Slam televised. Loving ''Honey'' to her husband, ''Momma'' to her children and ''Granny'' to her grandchildren. Predeceased by husband, Josh. Survived by her three daughters, Judi Levine (Bernie Bornstein), Beth Levine (Henry Abarbanel) and Linda (Erie) Spellman, grandchildren, Brett, Sara, Lindsey and Matthew, brother, Harvey Davidson, and loving companion, Sonia McNab, who breathed life into her until her last breath. Funeral service Friday 11:00 am at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Services by Zion Memorial Chapel, Mamaroneck. Contributions to The Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70th Street, New York, NY 10021, and Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 95 S. Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601. LEVINE--Selene, beloved wife of our deceased partner, Josh Levine, and benevolent spirit to our firm. We extend our profound sympathies to Selene's daughters Judith, Beth and Linda and to their families. Davis & Gilbert LLP

MELEZIN--Abraham . Professor Emeritus CCNY of CUNY. Formerly a teaching assistant at the University of Stefan Batori in Vilno, Poland and after World War II, University of Marie Curie Sklodowska, Lublin, Poland. Survivor of the Vilno ghetto, a death march, and Stutthof concentration camp. He was predeceased by his first wife, Sulamith Starapolska Melezin and his son Zarek Melezin in the Holocaust. He was predeceased by his second wife, Rachela Pupko Krinsky Melezin and his daughter Sarah Wall in 2002. He is survived by his granddaughter, Alexandra Wall of Oakland, CA and his son-in-law Irwin Wall of New York. All his life an optimist, always looking for the silver lining in the clouds and always believing in progress with the living march ahead. ''Reach for the life ahead, don't crown your head in the laurel leaves that are wilted and few.'' Services will be held today at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th at 11am. Donations can be made to Sloan Kettering, Alzheimer's Association or Jewish National Fund.

ATHOS--William J. M.D. , age 78, at home in St. Petersburg, FL on September 30, 2008 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband of Irene (nee Koskinas) for 51 years. Loving father of Elizabeth Athos and Jeanne Athos-Adler. Fatherin-law to Dr. Michael A. Adler and William Figdor. Adored grandfather to Christopher and Alexandra Adler and Dmitri and Andrei Figdor. Born in Greece in 1929 to Persephone and John Athos, Dr. Athos emigrated to the U.S. at age seven and grew up in New York City. He was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School, Columbia College and SUNY Downstate Medical Center where he was elected to Alpha Omega Alpha. He completed his internship, residency and New York Fellowship at St. Lukes Hospital. Dr. Athos served as a Captain in the U.S. Army Medical Corps and was Physician to the Peace Corps Training Program at Columbia University. He enjoyed a long career practicing Internal Medicine in New York City, was devoted to his patients who adored him, and was affiliated with St. LukesRoosevelt Hospital, Lenox Hill Hospital and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons as an Assistant Clinical Professor of Medicine. He was voted one of New York Magazines Best Doctors in New York and he particularly treasured his award for Distinguished Service from the Salvation Army, having served as a consultant and volunteer for 25 years. His love, intellectual curiosity and wit will be sorely missed but his inspiration will remain. We will forever love and miss him. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Dr., Tenafly, NJ on Friday 2-4 and 79pm. Funeral Service at St. John the Theologian Greek Orthodox Cathedral, Tenafly on Saturday 10am. Interment Brookside Cemetery, Englewood, NJ. Donations may be made to the Dr. William J. Athos Endowment Fund of St. Stephanos Church, 3600 76th Street North, St. Petersburg, FL 33710 or Hospice of the Florida Suncoast, 3050 1st Avenue S., St. Petersburg, FL 33712. For directions visit www.barrettfuneralhome.net

GLUCK--Nathan . The Federico family; Helen, Lisa, Gina and their kids and spouses will miss Nathan Gluck, our kind, gentle and creative friend for more than 70 years, who died over the weekend in San Diego. We'll miss his visits by train, his concern about our well-being, his holiday phone calls, and his drawings, paintings and collages, which arrived in the mail without fail for every New Year, birth and anniversary. We'll miss his kindness, his wisdom, his worldliness. Nathan was one of the last of an era. G'luck, Nathan Gluck! TOPOL--Robert M. , age 83, passed away on September 30, 2008. My Bob-the tall handsome ex-marine I picked up in college and chased until I married him-the love of my life for over 60 years who was always there for me and our family. Willing to take on every challenge with a big smile and an open mind, whether the whims of his wife or the needs of his children. Intrepid adventurer to any exotic spots-whether wild or tamed, as much at home in the jungle as on the Boulevards. Enthusiastic sportsman both as participant or observer, connoisseur of fine wines and great foods, classy dresser, philanthropist, leader at spas, meetings, excursions, conventions. He was a brilliant financier bending every effort to share his ideas, his acumen and his intelligent analyst with those who can profit by it. He was a good and loyal friend, a person you wanted to be with and someone you would not easily forget. He gave many young people great training and a chance to grow, and enabled many to make satisfying careers for themselves. His wife, D'Vera, his children: Clifford and his wife Robin; Gail and her Tom Mandel; Martha and her husband David Kirby as well was his seven grandchildren; Matthew, Michael, Maple, Rachel, Graham, Ruby and Cooper will miss him everyday from now on. Memorial service will be held at 11am, Sunday October 5, 2008 at the Emelin Theater, Library Lane, Mamaroneck. TOPOL--Robert M. We deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Bob, whose generosity and love of life will never be forgotten. Phyllis and Howard Schwartz TOPOL--Bob. The Board and staff of Citymeals-on-Wheels mourns the passing of Bob Topol, longtime Board member and generous friend to New York's homebound elderly. We send sincere condolences to his wife Dee, his children and all who loved this wonderfully kind man. Gael Greene, Co-Founder and Chair Joseph M. Cohen, President Marcia Stein, Executive Director

There are only a handful of works of modern architecture in Rome. And, to my mind, there is only one "must see": It is Renzo Piano's Auditorium complex, a performing arts center that is essentially Rome's version of Lincoln Center or the Sydney Opera House. Unfortunately, that magnificent creation is terribly located, out of the historic center. So tourists generally miss it entirely.

After squandering an opportunity to improve their chances of qualifying for the Major League Soccer playoffs with last week's home loss to Colorado, the Red Bulls (9-10-8, 35 points) faced struggling Toronto F.C. (8-12-7, 31 points) Saturday night at Giants Stadium. But after 90 minutes, it was difficult to tell which club was struggling more. The Red Bulls, who lost by 3-1 and wasted another chance to pocket a critical 3 points, have now lost four of their last five games, including two straight at home, where they now have an 8-3-3 record. Nothing from a possible 6 points might have doomed the Red Bulls' playoff chances.

Editor's note: Mark Sunshine, president of the commercial lending institution First Capital, writes a guest post about why we may be heading into what's called a liquidity trap. This means that monetary policy, including interest-rate changes, can't prevent a deep depression, but that the Treasury's fiscal stimulus plans - including a little-noticed tax change pushed through last week - just might work.

Missouri quarterback Chase Daniel led the Tigers to a 12-2 record and the upper levels of the national rankings last year. He finished fourth in the voting for the Heisman Trophy and passed for 4,306 yards and 33 touchdowns, both team records. He will contribute a diary to The New York Times during the college football season. In this entry, which was told to Thayer Evans, he talks about the challenge of playing at Nebraska, being leapfrogged by Alabama in the polls and what he thinks about the current financial crisis.

It's not a list of the world's wealthiest people but rather a way of telling you how you fit in the global distribution of wealth. So you enter your annual income and (almost certainly if you have a computer and are on line) it'll tell you that you're in the top xx percent of humanity by wealth.

PARIS - The Chloé show just closed at the Tuileries. It was the label's first collection under the direction of Hannah MacGibbon. Moments ago, T's editor Stefano Tonchi wrote on The Fashion Telex: "Chloé: A fresh start with a new designer. PARIS - Last night's Alexander McQueen show finished too late for the critics to file reviews for the morning papers. But somehow before going to bed Cathy Horyn gathered her thoughts and wrote on her blog:"It felt drivingly contemporary, with the emphasis on prints based on animals, wood grains, crushed crystals, skeletons, and mechanical shapes like the Eiffel Tower. You just felt blitzed by the color and pattern, and I had the impression that no two were alike. Amazing work."

Chris Lee scored 2 minutes 28 seconds into overtime on his 28th birthday Friday night, lifting the Islanders to a 3-2 preseason victory against the Devils in Newark. Lee snapped a drive that beat the backup goalie Kevin Weekes on the Islanders’ 20th shot. Bruno Gervai earned an assist.

John Velazquez was hospitalized after a spill at Keeneland that also injured his fellow jockey Jamie Theriot. Velazquez was sent to the University of Kentucky trauma unit for evaluation, the track said. He was alert and moving his arms and legs.

Kelly Slater won an unprecedented ninth world surfing championship in Mundaka, Spain. He dominated five of the first eight events, earning enough points to clinch the title with two Association of Surfing Professionals Tour contests remaining.

Jeff Overton shot a three-under-par 69 to take a one-shot lead over Tag Ridings (68) in the Turning Stone Resort Championship in Verona, N.Y. Playing through wind, rain and a brief shower of hail, Overton was at eight-under 136.

The two-time Indianapolis 500 winner Hélio Castroneves, who also won an edition of “Dancing With the Stars,” pleaded not guilty to federal tax evasion charges. Castroneves, 33, was released on $10 million bail after a court appearance in which he was shackled in handcuffs and leg chains and was visibly weeping into a wad of white tissue. Outside, Castroneves said he was overwhelmed by the weight of the moment.

China | Just before becoming financial-panic fireman, Treasury Secretary Hank Paulson urged American sympathy for the Chinese, but said little of the need for sympathy coming the other way. This looks ironic in hindsight. After all, China is America's biggest creditor, stuck with a lot of the bad American debt that Paulson wants the markets to forget about. And now even China's economy is sputtering. [Foreign Affairs, Business Week]

Sport | Two accounts of one of mountaineering's worst disasters: the deaths of 11 experienced climbers on K2, the world's second-highest mountain. One article says it was not a story of "Into Thin Air" hubris, as some oversimplify it. Rather, the tale has "selflessness and even heroism, as well as heartbreaking loss and staggering overconfidence." [Men's Journal, Outside]

Canada | Bear attacks are well below bee stings as threats to life in Canada. But you wouldn't know it from the scary headlines up there. Still, the hype raises awareness about how to prevent attacks, making attacks rarer still. So pack your picnic basket. [Economist]

Food | One unintended way consumer demand hurts consumers: they pay their pet doctors more than large-animal veterinarians are paid. So, veterinary schools turn out a lot of the former and a critical dearth of the latter -- the ones crucial to protecting the food supply. [Associated Press]

An article on Sept. 13 about a ruling setting aside charges of corruption against Jacob Zuma, the leader of South Africa’s governing party, misstated the value of government arms purchases in the late 1990s that were at the heart of a related bribery case. The purchases were worth an estimated 30 billion rand, not $30 billion. (Because the rand fluctuated during those years, the cost was estimated to have been in the $3 billion to $5 billion range.).

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday listed the top sellers on the weekly Billboard album chart. After the first edition went to press, Nielsen SoundScan, which provides the data for the Billboard ranking, issued updated numbers that moved the Pussycat Dolls’ “Doll Domination” to fourth place from fifth place and dropped Kings of Leon’s “Only by the Night” to fifth from fourth. Later editions carried the updated rankings.

An obituary last Saturday about Don Ultang, who shared the 1952 Pulitzer Prize for photography with a colleague for documenting what was possibly a racially motivated assault during a college football game between Oklahoma A&M and Drake University, misstated the given name of the A&M player involved in the attack on a black player for Drake. He was Wilbanks Smith, not Milbanks. The error also appeared in a caption for a sequence of pictures documenting the incident.

TYNES IS AVAILABLE Lawrence Tynes has recovered from his left knee injury and will be available to kick for the Giants (3-0) on Sunday when they play Seattle (1-2) at Giants Stadium. John Carney, his replacement this season, remains on the roster. Coach Tom Coughlin said he would dress only one of them but would not reveal his choice. Although Tynes and Carney often express respect and admiration for each other, the situation has been awkward. Carney, a 21-year veteran who is 44 years old, has been perfect on nine field goals and eight extra points. He won the Giants' previous game, a 26-23 victory over Cincinnati on Sept. 21, with a 22-yard field goal in overtime. When asked if he had been told Sunday's plans, Carney paused briefly and replied: ''We're both ready. So we'll see what happens.''

Gordon Brown, the beleaguered prime minister, reshuffled part of his cabinet on Friday, astonishing many political analysts by rehabilitating his onetime nemesis, Peter Mandelson, who resigned twice because of accusations of conflicts of interest by the government of Tony Blair. Mr. Mandelson, now the European Union's trade commissioner, is expected to become Britain's minister for business, the BBC reported. Mr. Mandelson was viewed as a close ally of Mr. Blair's and a rival of Mr. Brown's within the Labor Party. There has been tension between Mr. Brown and Mr. Mandelson for more than a decade, since Mr. Mandelson provided crucial backing to Mr. Blair to take over the party's leadership before the 1997 election. His latest invitation to the cabinet might have been to appease the Labor Party faction that remains loyal to Mr. Blair, or at least to lessen the plotting against Mr. Brown, analysts speculated.

Senator Barack Obama ''suspended'' his campaign and returned home to Chicago on Friday night for personal reasons: to celebrate the 16th anniversary of his marriage to Michelle. ''You know what you guys could give us for our anniversary?'' Mr. Obama told reporters aboard his campaign plane late Wednesday night, pleading for some ''quiet time.'' ''Not have a camera pool outside of the restaurant, so that everybody knows that we're there.''

STRAUSS--Fred S. , on October 3, 2008 in his 94th year. Greatly adored and loved husband of Marji S., his beloved wife and most important part of his life for 53 years. Beloved father of Michael and Iris, cherished grandfather of Michelle, Ilene, Matthew, Molly, Danielle and Ian, loving greatgrandfather of Taylor and Lucas. Aside from his devoted family life, these are some of the most notable of achievements in business; President of Harte and Co., Vice-President and Board of Directors for Diamond Shamrock Oil and Gas. His charitable contributions include being the co-founder of Children's Blood Foundation and the establishment of the Max and Ida Foundation which has contributed to many hospitals over the last few decades. His dedication to his family and Jewish life has caused instrumental changes in the last 15 years with the establishment of the Zimmerman Strauss Mu Seam and monument in Nidda, Germany in the remembrance of the lives lost in World War II. Fred, you will be missed more than you could ever imagine, we will love you, love you, love you forever. Service at Frank E. Campbell ''The Funeral Chapel'', Madison Ave. at East 81st St., 212288-3500, Sunday 9:30am. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery. STRAUSS--Fred. To our esteemed Chairman and leader of The Monday Nighters for more than 40 years. Your guidance and wisdom will be sorely missed. May you rest in peace with your beloved Marji and know that you were loved by all who knew you. Our deepest sympathies and heartfelt condolences go out to your son Michael, daughter Iris, six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. The Monday Nighters STRAUSS--Frederick S. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Frederick S. Strauss, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Dr. David M. Posner Senior Rabbi Dr. Ronald B. LAS VEGAS -- A jury has reached a verdict in the O. J. Simpson armed robbery and kidnapping case. The verdict, which was to be read late Friday night, Pacific time, comes 13 years after Mr. Simpson was acquitted in the highly publicized murders of his ex-wife and her friend.

BRECK--Mr. John H., Jr. , died at the age of 90 on October 1, 2008 at his summer home in Quonochontaug, RI. He was a longtime resident of the Ocean Reef Club, Key Largo, FL and also maintained a home in Longmeadow, MA. He was born on April 12, 1918 in Springfield, MA the youngest child of John H. Breck, Sr. and Elizabeth Pratt Breck. He attended Georgetown University and was graduated from American International College, Springfield where he met his future wife, Barbara Nash. After graduation he went to the Wharton School of Finance at the University of Pennsylvania where he received an MBA in 1942. He then enlisted in the Air Force. During the Second World War he served with a bomber squadron of the Eighth Air Force in Alconbury, England. During high school and college he had worked at his father's company, John H. Breck, Inc. the makers of Breck Shampoo and other hair care products. When the war ended he joined his father, his brother Edward and sister Constance in the family firm. Together with his family and with the help of an iconic ad campaign, Breck Shampoo became the world's bestselling shampoo in the 1950s. He was executive vice-president of Breck at the time the company was sold in 1963 to American Cyanamid Company, now Wyeth. In 1965 he left Breck, purchased a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, and along with two partners, Garrett Nagle and David McNeish, started the firm of Breck, McNeish and Nagle with offices in Springfield and Boston. The firm closed in 1973 and he devoted his time to his investments, philanthropy and the improvement of his golf game. He is survived by his wife of 62 years Barbara Nash Breck; his children, John H. Breck, III of Naples, FL, and two daughters Susan Carpenter (William) of Whitefish, MT and Sandra Kelley (Cameron) of Sudbury, MA; his sister M. Constance Breck of Longmeadow, MA; and three grandchildren, William Breck Carpenter, Anna Nash Carpenter and John Travis Kelley. His daughter, Patricia; his brother Edward Breck; and sister Marian Breck Sullivan predeceased him. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to Home Hospice Care of Rhode Island, 143 Main Street, Wakefield, RI 02879 or the John H. Breck and Barbara N. Breck Charitable Foundation, c/o J.M. O'Brien & Co., 1350 Main St., 15th floor, Springfield, MA 01103.

Bruckman and Gilda L. Bruckman, loving brother of Lazar A. Bruckman. Chief Chemist at Brewster Finishing Co., Paterson, NJ for over 40 years. An enthusiastic jogger, a dedicated gardener, a gifted linguist, a devoted uncle; he was endlessly inquisitive and open to wonder. Memorial service at a date to be announced. Donations may be made to the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science, 633 Third Avenue, 20th floor, NY, NY 10017.

In all the talk about the vice-presidential debate, there was an issue that did not get much attention but kept nagging at us: Sarah Palin's description of the role and the responsibilities of the office for which she is running, vice president of the United States. In Thursday night's debate, Ms. Palin was asked about the vice president's role in government. She said she agreed with Dick Cheney that ''we have a lot of flexibility in there'' under the Constitution. And she declared that she was ''thankful that the Constitution would allow a bit more authority given to the vice president also, if that vice president so chose to exert it.''

8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: PAUL HENREID Turner Classic Movies salutes Henreid, the actor and director who fled Nazi-occupied Europe during World War II to become a leading man at Warner Brothers. The five-film tribute begins with ''Now, Voyager'' (1942), starring Bette Davis as an ugly duckling who turns into a swan after falling in love with a married man (Henreid, above with Davis), at 8. Henreid also stars in ''The Spanish Main'' (1945) as a Dutch pirate in the Caribbean who kidnaps the Spanish governor's fiancée (Maureen O'Hara), at 10:15; ''Of Human Bondage'' (1946), as a medical student who risks his future when he becomes involved with a low-class waitress (Eleanor Parker), at midnight; ''Hollow Triumph'' (1948), as a gangster on the lam who poses as a psychiatrist, at 2 a.m.; and ''Casablanca'' (1942), at 3:30, in which Henreid plays the Czech resistance leader Victor Laszlo, a role he almost refused because he worried that playing second fiddle to Humphrey Bogart would tarnish his image -- even though he got the girl, played by Ingrid Bergman. 10 A.M. (Fox Business) YOUR QUESTIONS, YOUR MONEY Dagen McDowell and Connell McShane will answer viewers' questions and cover developments in the financial crisis.

Three Japanese mountain climbers were killed while trying to reach the summit of a sacred mountain in Tibet, a mountaineering official said Friday. The climbers died Wednesday in an avalanche while scaling Mount Kulagangri, according to an official of the Tibet Mountaineering Association, Dou Changshen, The Associated Press reported. The bodies of the climbers were found by team members less than 1,000 feet from a camp at 19,300 feet. The three were part of a group of seven Japanese climbers who left Lhasa, Tibet, on Sept. 20.

LeBEAU--Norman , 78, passed peacefully in Mexico, September 22. Born in Brooklyn to Lillian and Murray Leibow, Norman studied at Columbia, NYU, The Art Students League, and in Paris and married opera singer, Ruth Antelis of the Bronx. A self made success in the jewelry trade, Norman custom designed, manufactured and sold his work for forty years on Madison Avenue at LeBeau Jewelers and Boris-LeBeau in Palm Beach, winning numerous diamond and pearl design awards. In retirement Norman focused his creative ability on sculpting at the Palm Beach Armory and in San Miguel, Mexico and supported several art and philanthropic institutions. A true Bohemian, Norman loved life and attacked every day as if it were his last, from bicycling through Europe, skiing the Swiss Alps and hot air ballooning in Africa. Norman's love of people was equal to his fascination for animals, plants and art (www.normanlebeau.com). He is survived by his son Brad Mason, partner Brooke Dale and life long friends Bill Silfin, Lucille Chayt, Nikki Cohen, and Audrey Diamond. Charitable donations in memory of Norman LeBeau may be made to the ASPCA. Special Giving. 520 8th Ave 7th Fl NYC, NY 10018 or 800628-0028. A celebration of Norman's life will be announced shortly. bmlebeau@aol.com

O'SULLIVAN VASSILIADIS-Joan , 82, past president of the Newswomen's Club of New York and a pioneer in championing the work of women journalists, died on September 29 at home on her favorite sofa with her husband, Archie Vassiliadis, holding her hand. Through months of fighting cancer, Joan didn't give illness the time of day. She laughed and told stories surrounded by her beloved daughters Darcy Flanders and Demitra Vassiliadis, her son-in-law Robert and her granddaughter Arlene age six, and close friends and family. In her career, Joan won many awards as a columnist for King Features Syndicate. Since the 1950s, Joan poured her talent and time into the Newswomen's Club, its Front Page Awards, and the club's scholarship board, the Anne O'Hare McCormick Memorial Fund Inc., of which she was president. The family requests donations be made to a McCormick Fund scholarship award created in Joan's honor by her longtime friend and fellow newswoman Roz Massow. Please make check payable to: Anne O'Hare McCormick Memorial Fund Inc., a tax-exempt charitable entity, Important: on check memo, please designate ''Joan O'Sullivan Scholarship.'' Send check to: Anne O'Hare McCormick Memorial Fund Inc., ATTN. Jan Paschal, treasurer, c/o Newswomen's Club of New York, 15 Gramercy Park South, New York, NY 10003.

Nielsen's television ratings confirm what polls and pundits are saying: the level of interest in the vice-presidential matchup this year is unprecedented. The debate Thursday between Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Gov. Sarah Palin reached at least 73 million viewers, making it the most-watched vice-presidential debate in television history. (Nielsen reported an average of 69.9 million viewers on 11 networks, and PBS estimated another 3.5 million.) The previous record was set in 1984, when 56.7 million watched the debate between Vice President George Bush and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro.

Back in the day, economists used to talk about the foreign trade multiplier -- international business cycle linkages via flows of goods and services. The basic idea was that since one country's imports are other countries' exports, a recession in one country would be transmitted to the rest of the world as slumping demand here led to an export plunge abroad.

The story goes that when he was running for re-election to the Senate in 1954, Lyndon Johnson was opposed by a couple of non-profits that urged voters to reject him and his radical communist ideas. (And you thought things were crazy today.) In response, Johnson had new language inserted into the section of the I.R.S. code, which defines a tax exempt entity. His addendum declared that an exempt organization "does not participate in or intervene in (including the publishing or distributing of statements), any political campaign on behalf of (or in opposition to) any candidate for public office."

PARIS - At last night's Galliano show in the 19th arrondissement, the runway took the form of a subway grate covering a chasm of pulsating red light. Luckily for the contingent of women arriving in stilettos, which would have slipped dangerously through the gaps, the hazard was only an illusion. A clear plastic floor sat atop the grating. Once the show started, the runway was still attention grabbing, with models wearing extreme wigs in all colors, porcelain-doll maquillage and a few humongous pirate hats. In other words, typical Galliano. To get a feeling for the theatricality of the show, watch the videos after the jump, then catch Cathy Horyn's early impression ("exceptional," "trance-making") on her blog.

History | How the board game Monopoly helped free Allied prisoners in the Second World War: the British included metal files, compasses and maps, along with the standard thimble and Scotty dog, in game boxes sent with P.O.W. care packages accepted by the Nazis. Reichstag for $500? Soon the Allies would win the larger real-estate game begun by Hitler. [Mental Floss]

Science | The finding that Coke is a spermicide has won an Ig Nobel Prize, the award from Annals of Improbable Research magazine to odd but often practical research. The ceremony at Harvard also honored the discovery that foods that sound better taste better; and that exotic dancers make more money when they are at peak fertility. [Improbable.com, Associated Press]

I had in mind two boiled eggs (four minutes) and coffee at the Café de Flore, to be devoured with the Herald Trib and two or three English papers. I had lots of like-minded company at the Flore. Arthur Abraham’s defense of his International Boxing Federation middleweight title against Raúl Márquez on Saturday in Bamberg, Germany, has been postponed because Abraham has come down with the flu. The fight has been rescheduled for Nov. 8, also in Bamberg.

The undefeated Zarkava is ready to take on the boys for the first time Sunday, with a chance to become the first filly in 15 years to win the Prix de l’Arc de Triomphe in Paris. Zarkava was impressive enough in winning the Prix Vermeille last month that it was decided she would get a chance to boost her record to 7 for 7 in Europe’s most prestigious race. The last filly to take the Arc was Urban Sea in 1993. Zarkava, a 3-year-old filly owned by the Aga Khan, is the favorite in a 16-horse field and drew the inside No. 1 post for the nearly one-and-a-half-mile race at Longchamp. The winner earns $3.2 million from a total purse of $5.5 million.

The soon-to-be-No. 1 Jelena Jankovic beat Venus Williams to reach the Porsche Grand Prix final in Stuttgart, Germany, overcoming a painful foot injury for a 6-7 (8), 7-5, 6-2 victory. Jankovic will be going for her second title in two weeks when she plays Nadia Petrova on Sunday. Jankovic won the China Open last week and will be No. 1 when the new WTA rankings come out Monday. Petrova defeated Victoria Azarenka of Belarus, 6-4, 6-4. Jankovic has a broken toenail on her left foot and received two painkilling shots to be able to play.

Chad Barrett scored two goals to lift Toronto F.C. to a 3-1 victory against the Red Bulls on Saturday night in East Rutherford, N.J. Abdus Ibrahim also scored for Toronto (8-12-7). Dane Richards had the lone goal for the Red Bulls (9-10-8), who dropped their third straight game and fourth in five matches. The goal was Richards’s third of the season.

The Carolina Hurricanes signed their first-round draft pick, Zach Boychuk, to a three-year entry contract worth more than $2.6 million at the N.H.L. level. Boychuk will make $787,500 a season in the N.H.L. or $65,000 at the minor league level. He also received a $262,500 signing bonus. The Hurricanes took Boychuk, a 19-year-old center, with the 14th overall pick in the June draft.

Magnus Carlsson (73) was a stroke behind the leaders, and Padraig Harrington (74) was two back.

The Socialist Party's candidate for president, Eugene V. Debs, was greeted by 4,000 supporters upon his arrival at Grand Central Station. At the Hippodrome, he addressed an audience of 7,000, many waving red flags, who paid admission of 15 to 50 cents each - or more to ticket speculators. He attacked President Theodore Roosevelt and, only by association, William Howard Taft: "Roosevelt is the arch enemy of the working men and women. When he graduates from the White House and goes to Africa, where he properly belongs, he will have rendered his first service to the working class." In “Those Who Write, Teach,” David Gessner (Sept. 21) structures the choices available to a writer/teacher as either sitting at a lonely desk writing or balancing that writing with all the requirements of teaching. Such a distinction is useful when he writes about Emily Dickinson but much less so when applied to Thoreau or Melville. They went to the woods and the sea, where their experiences and observations provided them with the material for their writing. Teaching does not so much deprive writers of writing time as it substitutes a significant but limited experience for one richer in the invaluable raw material needed for writing.

As a junior at Wesleyan in 1967, I and another classmate sat as the first student members of the University’s Educational Policy Committee (Mark Oppenheimer, 21 Sept.). We helped design the first student evaluation of teaching that would be formally used in considerations of promotion and tenure — by some accounts the first in the nation. It was seen as an advisory tool, not the sole determiner of any professor’s worth. Had we known that teaching evaluations at Wesleyan would be used as a club to terrorize faculty members on short-term appointments, we would have thrown up our hands in horror. A teacher might not have his or her contract renewed after several years of weak teaching performance, but not renewing a temporary faculty member for failing to achieve the near impossible mark of 85 percent “excellent” or “good” student ratings after just one year is rank abuse of the process.

Charles Murray’s statement (Deborah Solomon, Sept. 21) that only 20 percent of college students have the brains and abilities to understand their assigned readings echoes the infamous British psychologist Sir Cyril Burt. As school psychologist for the London County Council from 1913 to 1932, Burt claimed that only 20 percent of British children were intelligent enough to be routed to university. Thus he reinforced the British class system by denying higher education to all but that handful. This began to change only when the Labor Party came to power after World War II. Interestingly, although some of his other work was stellar, Burt was exposed as a fraud who manipulated findings about the relation between class and intelligence. Murray’s “Bell Curve” (1994) was exactingly critiqued by Stephen Jay Gould for its methodological and philosophical shortcomings. That our nation grievously undereducates its children may in part be traced to Murray’s ideas.

Jonathan Mahler’s article on Kelly Jolley overstates his influence on Auburn’s department of philosophy (Sept. 21). Before Professor Jolley became chairman, the department had already outpublished all others in Auburn’s College of Liberal Arts. The debates it held among its and some other professors were very popular and gradually brought in more and more students and majors.

WACHS--Nancy, ground breaking green architect, humanitarian and beloved mother and grandmother, dies at 76. Ms. Wachs, a lifelong humanitarian, was an inspiration to all who knew her. She was a strong advocate for the arts, education, women's rights, Hospice and helping those in need. Ms. Wachs was utilizing green architecture practices in the 1950s long before it became popular. She inspired her children with a strong sense of social justice, environmentalism and a love of nature. A native of Rochester, NY, Ms. Wachs graduated from Cornell University's Architecture, Art and Planning School, one of a few women at that time with a major in architecture (Class of 1954). Her architectural career featured working for the City of Rochester and others designing contemporary commercial structures and residences. She served as a longtime editor and staff member for the American Institute of Architects (AIA) of Rochester newsletter. As an expression of respect, please consider making donations in Nancy M. Wachs name to: Lifetime Care Hospice 3111 Winton Road South, Rochester, NY 14623. A memorial ceremony will be held in the future. Please contact Molly.Lavik@verizon.net for details. Ms. Wachs was married to Arthur Wachs who predeceased her in 2003 and is remembered by her son Christopher Wachs, daughter Molly Wachs Lavik and granddaughter Lindsey Megan Trauty Wachs.

ANDRÉ SARAIVA is a man of many hats: graffiti artist, hotelier, club owner (New York's Beatrice Inn is one of them) and proprietor of Black Block, a boutique at the contemporary art museum Palais de Tokyo in Paris. Now comes ''clothing designer,'' a job the stylish Frenchman (right) has taken on out of necessity. ''I would go back to the stores where I had bought things, but could never find what I wanted,'' he said of his new Black Block line, which includes well-made pieces inspired by the perennial favorites in his wardrobe: the slim-cut Japanese denim jeans; the pocketed Egyptian cotton polo shirts; the colorful, braided belts from Charvet; the leather bomber jacket he bought at the Rose Bowl flea market 15 years ago, now beautifully reproduced by Hermès craftsmen. ''They're classics you can come back to,'' he said. Catchy, non?

HUNTER--Irene Mennen, of Manchester, VT and Delray Beach, FL died October 1st after a lifetime of community volunteerism and philanthropy. She was born in Newark, NJ in 1918 to Irene and William Mennen, the founder of the Mennen Company. She graduated from the Emma Willard School in 1935, and Smith College in 1939. She was married for 57 years to the love of her life, the late James ''Bing'' Hunter; and she is survived by their four children: Elizabeth Solomon of Park City, UT; Jim Hunter of Williamstown, MA; Bonnie Trotta of Mount Kisco, NY; and Susan Hunter of Dedham, MA. She is also survived by their eleven grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren: Virginia Solomon of Los Angeles, CA, Ross Hunter of Boston, MA, Sarah Hunter of Prince Edward Island, Canada, Margaret Hunter of Williamstown, MA, Katama Eastman and her children Merrill, Jack, and Oliver Eastman of New York, NY, Peter Guernsey of Los Angeles, CA, James Trotta and Johnny Trotta, of Mount Kisco, NY, Colby Previte and her son Carter Previte of Rochester, NY, Kristin Hunter-Thomson of Monterey, CA, and Whitney HunterThomson of Chicago, IL. She is also survived by her brother William G. Mennen of Carmel, CA. From chairing financial campaigns to making wreaths for the church bazaar, both Mr. and Mrs. Hunter spent their lives improving their communities. Mrs. Hunter's philanthropic interests were directed primarily toward education and the arts. Over the years, she sat on the boards of, or financially endowed, Emma Willard School, Alumnae Association of Smith College, Bennington College, Williams College, Southern Vermont College, Paul Taylor Dance Company, Jacobs Pillow Dance Company, Williamstown Theater Festival, WGBY, American Museum of Fly Fishing, Hunter Park, Burr and Burton Academy, Long Trail School, Pine Cobble School, Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, The Vermont Symphony, Hildene, First Congregational Church of Manchester, New England Tropical Conservatory, and Northshire Day School. Together with family and friends, she shared a passion for golf, skiing, travel, and the Red Sox. Along the way, she even found time to earn her pilot's license. She earned the only Lifetime Achievement Award ever awarded by The National Association of Fundraising Professionals. From those to whom much has been given, much is expected. This is her legacy. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Monday, October 6th at the First Congregational Church in Manchester, VT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Northshire Day School, 5484 Main St., Manchester Center, VT 05255 (802) 362 - 1395. Brewster Funeral Service in Manchester has been entrusted with the care of Mrs. Hunter's funeral services. HUNTER--Irene. As a leading light of the Jacob's Pillow Board, Irene was an unfailingly generous and stalwart champion who inspired us all. She was a remarkable person, and we are forever grateful for her lasting contribution to the success of Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. Neil Chrisman, Board Chairman Ella Baff, Executive Director

KAPPEN--Bernard A., born September 30th, 1924 deceased September 30th, 2008. West Palm Beach, FL formerly of NYC. A man of uncommon warmth, generosity and love. Beloved by his wife Lenore Goldstein Kappen for 62 years. He will be sorely missed by all who had the pleasure of his company.

I want to take a trip by myself, but I have no idea where to go! I would like it to be outside the United States, relatively safe (I'm a 24-year-old female) and with enough to explore but with options for places to go and relax. I understand there are some risks in traveling alone, but it's an experience I would like to have while still young. With others, I've been to Paris, Amsterdam, Brussels, Budapest, Cyprus, Athens, Toronto, Dominican Republic and Ecuador. -- Ana Fermin, Rochester The world, or quite a bit of it, at least, is your oyster. Considering the places you've been and keeping in mind that you are traveling alone but, I assume, don't want to be isolated from locals and other travelers, I have five places for you to consider. I can vouch for each of them in terms of safety, fun, sociability and excitement, but to further your research, go to nytimes.com/travel and look at the destination pages for archived articles, venue information and other trip-planning advice.

LINDSAY--Lt. Colonel Samuel McCune II, US Army Retired , died on 14 September 2008 in Tenerife, Spain where he resided since his retirement from active duty in 1976. After attending Horace Mann School he graduated from Peekskill Military Academy and the College of William and Mary before joining the Army in 1952. He served in Germany, Korea and Vietnam where he received the Bronze Star for meritorious service. He is survived by his wife, Amy. Interment will be in Union, Connecticut. Sam was a dear friend for many years and he will be missed.

REISCH--Milton, M.D . It is with great sadness we report the death of Dr. Milton Reisch, retired Associate Clinical Professor of Medicine, Department of Dermatology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, who died September 15, 2008, at the age of 86, having practiced medicine for over 60 years. A native of Baltimore, Maryland, he received a B.S. degree, with honors, from the University of Maryland School of Pharmacy and a Doctor of Medicine degree from the University of Maryland School of Medicine, graduating first in his medical school class. After graduation, he served in the US Army, attaining the rank of Captain, first at Fort Sam Houston in Texas and then at the 361st Station Hospital in Tokyo, Japan, where, at the age of 26, he became Chief of Staff. Upon his return to the US, he completed his training in Dermatology at New York and Columbia-Presbyterian Hospitals. He maintained offices for the practice of Dermatology in Manhattan and the Bronx, until 2005. Dr. Reisch was responsible for reactivating the Dermatology clinics at Morrisania and Montefiore Hospitals, and served on the volunteer staff of Montefiore Hospital for more than 50 years. He also headed the Adverse Drug Reaction Committee at Montefiore Hospital for many years. He loved practicing medicine and he especially enjoyed training other doctors. Dr. Reisch's legacy continues in the hundreds of doctors who were fortunate enough to have learned under his tutelage to be compassionate and dedicated healers. He was adored by his family, friends, patients and colleagues. Dr. Reisch was a world traveler and loved to take his family with him on the adventures. He made friends everywhere he went. He is survived by Rashi, his wife of 62 years, his children, grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Contributions in his memory can be made to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, Att: Sheriann Namer, 2 Oakwood Boulevard, Suite 200, Hollywood, FL 33020.

NO BOWL OF CEREAL Andrea Illy, the coffee seller, and Jean-Georges Vongerichten, the restaurateur and chef, are introducing fancy breakfast offerings for Le Meridien hotels that include espresso with hot chocolate, cocoa and steamed milk; ''juice shots'' in flavors like mango-chili-lime; and custard with goat and gruyere cheeses and black olive and dill purées. But Mr. Illy and Mr. Vongerichten tend to make less elaborate choices when it comes to their own breakfasts. On a recent visit to New York, Mr. Illy, the Italian chairman of Illycaffe, said he usually starts his day with two or three biscotti, a glass of soy milk, a piece of fruit, and espresso, ''one for breakfast and one after breakfast.''

O'SULLIVAN VASSILIADIS-Joan, 82, past president of the Newswomen's Club of New York and a pioneer in championing the work of women journalists, died on September 29 at home on her favorite sofa with her husband, Archie Vassiliadis, holding her hand. Through months of fighting cancer, Joan didn't give illness the time of day. She laughed and told stories surrounded by her beloved daughters Darcy Flanders and Demitra Vassiliadis, her son-in-law Robert and her granddaughter Arlene age six, and close friends and family. In her career, Joan won many awards as a columnist for King Features Syndicate. Since the 1950s, Joan poured her talent and time into the Newswomen's Club, its Front Page Awards, and the club's scholarship board, the Anne O'Hare McCormick Memorial Fund Inc., of which she was president. The family requests donations be made to a McCormick Fund scholarship award created in Joan's honor by her longtime friend and fellow newswoman Roz Massow. Please make check payable to: Anne O'Hare McCormick Memorial Fund Inc., a tax-exempt charitable entity, Important: on check memo, please designate ''Joan O'Sullivan Scholarship.'' Send check to: Anne O'Hare McCormick Memorial Fund Inc., ATTN. Jan Paschal, treasurer, c/o Newswomen's Club of New York, 15 Gramercy Park South, New York, NY 10003.

LeBEAU--Norman, 78, passed peacefully in Mexico, September 22. Born in Brooklyn to Lillian and Murray Leibow, Norman studied at Columbia, NYU, The Art Students League, and in Paris and married opera singer, Ruth Antelis of the Bronx. A self made success in the jewelry trade, Norman custom designed, manufactured and sold his work for forty years on Madison Avenue at LeBeau Jewelers and Boris-LeBeau in Palm Beach, winning numerous diamond and pearl design awards. In retirement Norman focused his creative ability on sculpting at the Palm Beach Armory and in San Miguel, Mexico and supported several art and philanthropic institutions. A true Bohemian, Norman loved life and attacked every day as if it were his last, from bicycling through Europe, skiing the Swiss Alps and hot air ballooning in Africa. Norman's love of people was equal to his fascination for animals, plants and art (www.normanlebeau.com). He is survived by his son Brad Mason, partner Brooke Dale and life long friends Bill Silfin, Lucille Chayt, Nikki Cohen, and Audrey Diamond. Charitable donations in memory of Norman LeBeau may be made to the ASPCA. Special Giving. 520 8th Ave 7th Fl NYC, NY 10018 or 800628-0028. A celebration of Norman's life will be announced shortly. bmlebeau@aol.com

Laura Gilbert, a Manhattan-based artist, is employing her creativity to protest what she calls ''the current economic calamity.'' Ms. Gilbert plans to stand on Wall Street this Tuesday and give away signed and numbered originals of ''The Zero Dollar,'' a slightly downsized rendering of the $1 bill with zeros in place of the ones. Ms. Gilbert, who began working on the print after the fall of Bear Stearns earlier this year, sees the dollar bill as ''symbolic of America's stature in the world.'' As a reflection of the crisis in the financial markets, she has tried to lower the monetary value of the print itself to zero by creating a very large edition of 10,000.

HWANG--Michael Ling-Kwei, 82 years, died peacefully at home on October 1, 2008 surrounded by his loving family and nurse. Born February 6, 1926, in Shanghai, China. Devoted husband to Minnie Young Hwang for 58 wonderful years, proud father of Deborah (Graham) Marriott, William (Chizuko) Hwang, Jeffrey (May Chao) Hwang, Michelle (Ken) Hirschman and Loraine (Tom) DeSantis, cherished grandfather to Michael Chivas Young Hwang, Rebecca and William Marriott, Sidney, Audrey and Marcus Hirschman, Miranda and Jessica Chao Hwang, and brother to Helena Wang and Ellen Lin. Michael came to the United States in 1946, with a degree in Industrial Engineering from Chiao Tung University and earned an M.B.A. from the University of Denver. He enjoyed a long career as a successful investment banker and venture capitalist. In 2001, he retired as Senior Vice President from Oppenheimer & Co. Michael will forever be remembered for his generous and kind spirit, his relentless passion for the stock market, and incredible stoicism while battling a long illness. A memorial service in celebration of his life will be held on Tuesday, October 7 at 11am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Private interment to follow. In lieu of flowers, the family requests a donation to your favorite charity.

WEISMAN--Donald R., M.D., 84, died September 28, 2008 at Mt. Sinai Hospital, NYC. Devoted son of the late Charlotte and late A. Henry Weisman of Waterbury, CT, and adoring brother of his late sister Joan. Beloved husband to his dear Joanie, the love of his life for over 48 years, and incredible father to Doug, Lawrence, Roger, and Carla. Loving father-in-law to Katie, Nikki, and Rafael. Proud Poppy to Donny, Nicky, Alex, Teddy, Sophia, and Eric. A unique musical phenomenon with an unparalleled gift for singing and playing whatever he wanted who relished sharing his musical magic with everyone. He also had a remarkable ear for languages. Lover of a good joke or story, literature, dogs, swimming, wine, chocolate, and quality food, especially anything made by his loving wife Joan. Dedicated to family and Yale, particularly his cherished Glee Club. Donald was the consummate physician and teacher in private practice and at Mt. Sinai Hospital for over 50 years. With an unmatched talent for treating children, he cared for the poor pro bono and for everyone with the same devotion, compassion, and warmth as he did actors, musicians, and performers. A true gentleman and man of unwavering principle, intense conviction, resolute character, rare humanity, and genuine humility who also made people laugh. Donald was deeply loved and will be profoundly missed by all who knew him. A memorial will be held Friday, October 24, 11:30am at the 92nd Street Y on Lexington Ave. Contributions may be sent to Yale Glee Club Associates, PO Box 201929, New Haven, CT 06520-1929.

BEN-AVI--Avrum . Born in New York City, November 8, 1916, died peacefully at home in Sarasota, Florida, on September 27, 2008. Esteemed psychologist/psychoanalyst. He was, for some 50 years, in private practice; professor and supervisor in both The Doctoral Program and The Post Doctoral Program in Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy at New York University. He started the Postdoctoral program. Handsome beyond reason, brilliant and curious, witty, charming, elegant, beloved, respected and admired by all who knew him, he was the analysts' analyst. A Jew, an atheist, he studied at Yale Divinity School for eight years after he retired. An officer in World War II, he designed tests to determine who was best fit to fly bombing missions. He leaves Rachel, his wife of 26 years; Joan, his first wife, of 34 years; and their three children, Sigrid, Jason, and Nina; as well as four grandchildren, Julia and Emma, Alice and Sarah, and sons-in-law, Reg Balmer and Marc Schreiber. Sitting Shiva 4 - 9pm, Wednesday and Thursday.

The top teams did their part Saturday to set up several big matchups with national implications. No. 1 Oklahoma, No. 5 Texas and No. 6 Penn State remained undefeated, and No. 12 Florida bounced back from an upset loss to Mississippi to beat Arkansas. In contrast to last week, when seven top 25 teams lost, none went down in the early games Saturday. (No. 10 South Florida lost to Pittsburgh on Thursday.) That kept everything on target for next weekend, when Oklahoma faces Texas in the Red River Rivalry, Florida hosts No. 3 Louisiana State and Penn State goes to Wisconsin. On Saturday night, No. 3 Missouri routed Nebraska; the Tigers (5-0) will host No. 21 Oklahoma State on Saturday.

AT age 70, the photographer and longtime British Vogue contributor David Bailey (whose Swinging '60s persona inspired the 1966 Antonioni film ''Blowup'') admits he has never known anything about fashion. ''I've just liked the girls,'' he howled from his studio in London. His latest book, ''Is That So Kid,'' focuses on a favorite, Anjelica Huston, whom he spent all of 1973 photographing for Vogue. (''We were also having an affair,'' he noted). Indeed, those were wonderfully decadent days, as is evident by the images: Huston, riding on a motorbike behind the photographer Oliviero Toscani in Milan, her Missoni cape flying in the wind; lounging in a hotel room in Nice with Manolo Blahnik (then a fledging footwear designer), fresh orchids in her hair; posing with Yves Saint Laurent in his Paris apartment; with ornate fans at Karl Lagerfeld's house; on horseback at Jean Shrimpton's family farm; and sprawled on a hotel floor with Bailey, his head in her lap. ''I never treated these girls like models -- always people,'' he said, letting loose a hearty laugh.

It might be the closest thing northeast Florida ever had to an artists' retreat. Something was always happening at 4 Tallwood Road in Jacksonville Beach: someone painting, recording a song or cooking a vegan dinner. It began in 2000, with Jeremie Faircloth and E. J. Baker, both now 28, local kids with artistic aspirations who wanted a beach house. Over the years, a good dozen creative types cycled in and out of the ramshackle four-bedroom home. This summer, 4 Tallwood broke up. The landlord decided to sell, and the last assortment of five bohemians moved on. ''This has been a haven for us,'' Faircloth said, ''a haven for our creativity. It's really sad.'' ITINERANT ARTISTS

TOPOL--Robert M., age 83, passed away on September 30, 2008. My Bob-the tall handsome ex-marine I picked up in college and chased until I married him-the love of my life for over 60 years who was always there for me and our family. Willing to take on every challenge with a big smile and an open mind, whether the whims of his wife or the needs of his children. Intrepid adventurer to any exotic spots-whether wild or tamed, as much at home in the jungle as on the Boulevards. Enthusiastic sportsman both as participant or observer, connoisseur of fine wines and great foods, classy dresser, philanthropist, leader at spas, meetings, excursions, conventions. He was a brilliant financier bending every effort to share his ideas, his acumen and his intelligent analyst with those who can profit by it. He was a good and loyal friend, a person you wanted to be with and someone you would not easily forget. He gave many young people great training and a chance to grow, and enabled many to make satisfying careers for themselves. His wife, D'Vera, his children: Clifford and his wife Robin; Gail and her Tom Mandel; Martha and her husband David Kirby as well was his seven grandchildren; Matthew, Michael, Maple, Rachel, Graham, Ruby and Cooper will miss him everyday from now on. Memorial service will be held at 11am, Sunday October 5, 2008 at the Emelin Theater, Library Lane, Mamaroneck.

THE NEWS The House of Representatives unexpectedly rejects the $700 billion economic rescue plan negotiated by the leaders of both parties, the Treasury and the White House. BEHIND THE NEWS Efforts by central banks before the vote to loosen up straitened credit markets with big injections of cash fell flat, so when the bill's defeat becomes clear, stock markets spiral downward; the Dow industrials fall nearly 7 percent, their worst day in decades. The defeat reflects broad public anger over the rescue package, which is criticized as an undeserved bailout of Wall Street high-flyers. House Republicans, in particular, defy their leaders to vote no.

LET THEM EAT COOKIES Amid all the recent economic turmoil, you may consider it frivolous to celebrate National Cookie Month, which began last Wednesday. But the P.R. agency for Dr. Siegal's Cookie Diet has stepped in to remind us that cookies have long served as economic icons. A news release says that in the 1930s, chocolate chip cookies reportedly became popular after some chocolate accidentally fell into a bowl of sugar cookie dough, which was used anyway for reasons of Depression-era frugality. A more recent example of cookie resonance is the Cookie Monster from ''Sesame Street,'' whose voraciousness can be seen as a symbol of unchecked financial greed.

AT the last two Paris auto shows, makers of sport utility vehicles set up an off-road test track between the convention halls. This year it was replaced by two smaller tracks, one for eco driving and one for electric cars. When I went to the tracks Thursday afternoon, it was raining lightly and nearly everyone was at lunch. A Tesla Roadster, two Italian trucks and a tiny electric car were all parked quietly without their handlers. The electric Smart car was still on display inside Hall 1.

ENJOYING A BIRTHDAY DINNER IN LAHORE, PAKISTAN, JULY 2, 2008 Charlotte Smith, a veterinary student from London, shares her 23rd birthday and a view of the Badshahi Mosque with her friend John Croft, 23, a physics student from Peterborough, England, atop Cooco's Den restaurant. ''I have to say I wasn't one of those traveler people at the beginning. I'm the youngest sibling, and I was always a family, home person. For such a long time I was focusing on trying to get into vet school. But then my place got deferred, so I was given a year to do whatever I liked. I spent 10 months on the subcontinent, working with street animal charities on and off, mostly in India, so it was half play and half working. People were very welcoming in Lahore -- more friendly, actually, than in India. The first thing that really hits you in Pakistan is having to be a lot more respectful to the culture, compared to India. Almost every traveler you meet wears local dress. It wasn't a pretentious thing to do, it just meant you were more likely to be spoken to and respected a little more because you're respecting them.'' As told to Austin Considine

A ROAD TO RESILIENCE Gerald M. Levin knows something about resilience. Mr. Levin, the former C.E.O. of Time Warner, presided over its troubled merger with America Online, and retired in 2002. He subsequently moved to California and became the presiding director of Moonview Sanctuary, which was founded by his wife, Laurie Ann Levin. The center, located in Santa Monica and staffed by doctors and psychologists as well as those trained in holistic healing, initially focused on trauma, addiction and chronic pain. But the professionals also began treating athletes and executives to improve their focus and performance.

It was the worst week for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Enactment of a $700 billion government rescue plan for the financial system on Friday afternoon failed to lift the stock market. On Monday, when the House of Representatives rejected an earlier version, the market suffered its biggest one-day loss in 20 years.

DOMESTIC DISTURBANCES In the 1980s it seemed respectable, honorable and, dare I say, valuable to do things other than make a lot of money. But by the late 1990s, in New York, if you weren't in the financial industry, it was hard to survive. And so it went throughout the country, in the whole winner-take-all-era ushered in by the boom years of the late 1990s. The model for success narrowed. The goal posts marking success grew more out of reach. For all the people who did something with their lives other than doggedly, single-mindedly -- and successfully -- pursue wealth, life got harder and scarier and more confusing.

QUINN--Marjorie Mary, died at home on September 22. She was the devoted daughter of the late John and Florence Quinn of Westerly and Watch Hill, RI, and New York City. She is survived by her loving sisters, Elaine Quinn McHugh of Larchmont, NY and Jacqueline Quinn Smith of Bradenton, FL. A brother, John Quinn, III predeceased her. Marjorie was a graduate of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, Providence, RI and Manhattanville College. She retired in 1986 as the editor of the Goings on About Town department of The New Yorker magazine and was a member of the Junior League of New York. She is also survived by 10 nieces and two nephews, 22 grandnieces and nephews and 16 great-grandnieces and nephews. A memorial Mass will be held at the Church of the Holy Family, 315 E. 47th Street, New York, NY at 10:30 am on Wednesday, October 8, followed by a reception.

One point I think is really important in understanding the crisis is that there has been a huge increase in financial globalization just in the last few years -- basically since 1995. The chart above shows rest-of-world assets in the United States (red) and US assets abroad (blue) as a percentage of non-US GDP; while we talk a lot about the US as a debtor nation, what's really striking is the surge on both sides of the balance sheet. This has made the global financial system a lot more tightly linked, so that big economies are now experiencing the kind of contagion previously associated with emerging markets caught up in the 1997-1998 crisis. We're all Brazilians now.

It is once again safe to leave the house on a sunny day without an umbrella: the StreetWars tournament is over, and we have a winner.The three-week squirt-gun tournament went into sudden death mode last Monday, its dozen or so remaining players given two ways to win: by squirting the other players until no one else was left, or by squirting the man in charge of the game, Franz Aliquo, who calls himself Supreme Commander. During one especially dicey period with my mother, then in an assisted living facility, my brother and I hired a geriatric care manager, first for a consultation and then for additional help at an hourly rate. It felt like such an extravagance, given that we weren't rolling in money, but the care manager helped solve a series of complex problems that I doubt I'd have solved by myself, mostly involving brokering a compromise with the facility, whose management wouldn't let me hire a private aide for my mom but could not provide what she needed.

SINJAR, Iraq -- Sinjar is just east of nowhere, a Yezidi town in northwestern Iraq bounded on three sides by mountains, desert and the road leading to the Syrian border. It took us six days to get here, working with public affairs officers to get on flights from base to base, sleeping on tarmacs, waiting days for outgoing convoys. Marko Georgiev, a photographer for The Times, and I finally were given a ride out to the area by a convoy that was resupplying some of the little command outposts.
