JAZMINE SULLIVAN ''Fearless'' (J) Love is funny, and it makes you do funny things. Need proof? It's all over the debut album by the young R&B singer Jazmine Sullivan. Take ''Bust Your Windows,'' the opening song, in which Ms. Sullivan expresses her feelings with the appropriate tool, a crowbar. ''I bust the windows out your car/though it didn't mend my broken heart'' she sings, over Hitchcockesque strings and a buoyant hip-hop beat. ''I'll probably always have these ugly scars.'' It's a stellar revenge tune, as sassy and unexpected as Carrie Underwood's ''Before He Cheats,'' and an indicator that unlike most soul divas, Ms. Sullivan cuts her misery with a dash of whimsy.

DEERHOOF ''Offend Maggie'' (Kill Rock Stars) All the parts are in place on ''Offend Maggie,'' Deerhoof's beguiling, characteristically uproarious new album. Big, brash guitar riffs; brightly tolling dissonances; lurching dynamic shifts; oddball song constructions. And in the foreground, just barely, the deceptively sweet singing voice of Satomi Matsuzaki, bringing an uneasy calm to lyrics that court the absurd. This San Francisco indie-rock band has its formula patented.

9 P.M. (Sundance) 14 WOMEN (2007) Since 2000 the number of women serving in the United States Senate has risen to 16 from 9. In this documentary, filmed from 2004 to 2006, Mary Lambert, whose sister is Senator Blanche Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas, profiles the 14 women serving in the Senate at the time. Ms. Lambert travels from these women's offices and homes to the campaign trail and the floor of the Senate as they discuss topics like their inspirations for entering politics, the joys and hazards of campaigning and the importance of family support. Senators Barbara Boxer, Maria E. Cantwell, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Susan Collins, Elizabeth Dole, Dianne Feinstein, Kay Bailey Hutchison, Mary Landrieu, Barbara Mikulski, Lisa Murkowski, Patty Murray, Olympia Snowe, Debbie Stabenow and Ms. Lincoln (above, at the Democratic National Convention this year)are interviewed. Annette Bening narrates. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Judy Shepard discusses the 10th anniversary of the murder in Wyoming of her son, Matthew. Also on the program, a performance by Olivia Newton-John.

Col. Donald Blakeslee, one of the most decorated fighter pilots of World War II and the commander of the first American fighter squadrons to reach Berlin as the Allies ground down the German Luftwaffe, died Sept. 3 at his home in Miami. He was 90. The cause was heart failure, said his daughter and only immediate survivor, Dawn Blakeslee. Ms. Blakeslee said she did not announce her father's death last month because of his reluctance to talk about his achievements.

HWANG--Michael Ling-Kwei, 82 years, died peacefully at home on October 1, 2008 surrounded by his loving family and nurse. Born February 6, 1926, in Shanghai, China. Devoted husband to Minnie Young Hwang for 58 wonderful years, proud father of Deborah (Graham) Marriott, William (Chizuko) Hwang, Jeffrey (May Chao) Hwang, Michelle (Ken) Hirschman and Loraine (Tom) DeSantis, cherished grandfather to Michael Chivas Young Hwang, Rebecca and William Marriott, Sidney, Audrey and Marcus Hirschman, Miranda and Jessica Chao Hwang, and brother to Helena Wang and Ellen Lin. Michael came to the United States in 1946, with a degree in Industrial Engineering from Chiao Tung University and earned an M.B.A. from the University of Denver. He enjoyed a long career as a successful investment banker and venture capitalist. In 2001, he retired as Senior Vice President from Oppenheimer & Co. Michael will forever be remembered for his generous and kind spirit, his relentless passion for the stock market, and incredible stoicism while battling a long illness. A memorial service in celebration of his life will be held on Tuesday, October 7 at 11am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Private interment to follow. In lieu of flowers, the family requests a donation to your favorite charity.

Defense lawyers for Senator Ted Stevens said Sunday night that they had discovered new evidence of what they said was prosecutorial misconduct and renewed their call for a federal judge to declare a mistrial or dismiss the case. In papers filed late Sunday night, lawyers for Mr. Stevens, Republican of Alaska, said that material they received Friday at the order of the trial judge revealed what they said was ''intentional misconduct'' on the part of the Justice Department to conceal information that would have helped show Mr. Stevens was innocent. The new assertions came after Judge Emmet G. Sullivan has already admonished prosecutors on two occasions for earlier failings, although he declined on Thursday to declare a mistrial.

OASIS ''Dig Out Your Soul'' (Big Brother) Oasis's best records should be heard in bars, with lots of people talking and a game on the television. Its giant planes of guitar sound and Liam Gallagher's slow-motion nasal burr -- one of the great British sounds -- complement the petty emotions and electronic hum that surround us in public places; the songs' lyrics, trivial and social, keep time sliding along. Any bar will do, though Oasis albums since ''Standing on the Shoulder of Giants,'' from 2000, might go better in a wine bar. The songs would fit the clientele: slower, more self-conscious, less invincible.

RESNICK--Jack, died October 5 at age 85 in Florida. Devoted husband of Lila for 63 years, loving father and father-in-law of Gene, Lindsay, Susan and Suzanne, adoring grandfather of Matthew, Bradley and Nina, and brother of Lillian Farmelant, he was a gentle man who took great pride and total delight in his family. His warmth, easy smile, stories of growing up in Brooklyn and his WWII Air Force tour in England, and exploits on the golf course will be deeply missed and always remembered with great love. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his honor may be made to Jewish Home Lifecare, Research and Education Endowment Fund, 120 W. 106th St., NYC, NY 10025.

FRECHTMAN--Patricia Ann, 72 years of age, of New York City, passed away October 3, from complications of lung disease. Survived by her husband of 30 years, A. Bernard Frechtman, her children, Karen Say of Ann Arbor, MI, Edwin Hague of Tallahassee, FL, Mary D'Onofrio of Glen Rock, NJ and Nanci Browne of Indianapolis, IN; stepchildren, Janet Hoffer of West Orange, NJ and William Frechtman of Morristown, NJ and a special son, Evaldo Fontes, Jr. of Belo Horizonte, Brazil; 17 grandchildren, Mary Catherine Register, Andrea Hague, Maggie Hague, Martha Hague, Katie Mercer, Joshua Browne, Lindsey Browne, Jacob Browne, Matthew D'Onofrio, Anthony D'Onofrio, Stephen Hoffer, Andrew Hoffer, Russell Hoffer, Ariel Frechtman, Ilana Frechtman, Jordan Frechtman and Tales Fontes. She was a Trainer and Motivational Speaker, an author and publisher of books about twins; an expert knitter and avid reader. She believed in making memories for her grandchildren, promoted reading in their lives, found great enjoyment in holding tea parties and celebrating their birthdays and special events. She was her husband's severest critic, dearest love and best friend. She loved music, books, art, theatre, travel, London and New York City. She believed in the goodness of people and all who came in contact with her became her friend. She will be remembered with love.

REISCH--Milton, M.D . It is with great sadness we report the death of Dr. Milton Reisch, retired Associate Clinical Professor of Medicine, Department of Dermatology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, who died September 15, 2008, at the age of 86, having practiced medicine for over 60 years. A native of Baltimore, Maryland, he received a B.S. degree, with honors, from the University of Maryland School of Pharmacy and a Doctor of Medicine degree from the University of Maryland School of Medicine, graduating first in his medical school class. After graduation, he served in the US Army, attaining the rank of Captain, first at Fort Sam Houston in Texas and then at the 361st Station Hospital in Tokyo, Japan, where, at the age of 26, he became Chief of Staff. Upon his return to the US, he completed his training in Dermatology at New York and Columbia-Presbyterian Hospitals. He maintained offices for the practice of Dermatology in Manhattan and the Bronx, until 2005. Dr. Reisch was responsible for reactivating the Dermatology clinics at Morrisania and Montefiore Hospitals, and served on the volunteer staff of Montefiore Hospital for more than 50 years. He also headed the Adverse Drug Reaction Committee at Montefiore Hospital for many years. He loved practicing medicine and he especially enjoyed training other doctors. Dr. Reisch's legacy continues in the hundreds of doctors who were fortunate enough to have learned under his tutelage to be compassionate and dedicated healers. He was adored by his family, friends, patients and colleagues. Dr. Reisch was a world traveler and loved to take his family with him on the adventures. He made friends everywhere he went. He is survived by Rashi, his wife of 62 years, his children, grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Contributions in his memory can be made to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, Att: Sheriann Namer, 2 Oakwood Boulevard, Suite 200, Hollywood, FL 33020.

KAVEY--Leon, Esq., born 1916 in Port Chester, died October 3, 2008 in Rye, NY. Distinguished combat veteran in WWII, lawyer, and local business owner. He will be remembered for his wit, kindness, curiosity, and generosity of spirit. Remembered by Clarice Plaut Kavey, his loving wife of 68 years, his son, Richard P. Kavey, M.D., and his granddaughter, Allison B. Kavey, Ph.D.

When I recently saw an ad for a $125,000-a-year teaching job at a New York City charter school, my first thought was that it must be some sort of phishing scam. Everyone knows teachers don’t make $125,000. My second thought was, “Why shouldn’t we?” After visiting the school’s Web site and reading a New York Times article about the school, I realized it was not only legit, but potentially revolutionary in terms of education reform. So this school year, in addition to my regular special education teaching job, I’ve decided to get involved in the creation of this new school.

One thing I learned way back in grad school was that there was a big difference between the assets of first-world, mature-country central banks and those in rickety developing economies. The Fed and its peers had clean balance sheets, with basically nothing but Treasury bills on the asset side. Third world central banks, on the other hand, did a lot of direct lending to the private sector, and had all sorts of dodgy assets on their books.

This is a recreation of something I had in Istanbul, a bubbly casserole of shrimp, tomatoes and vegetables in which the dominant flavors are basil and butter. Several days ago, many moons ago, Kim-our Kim of the blog-made the comment that, despite all the videos and other coverage, she wasn't entirely seeing what those of us in Paris were seeing. I thought that was an interesting observation, if I've conveyed it correctly, and it has stayed on my mind. I can only say that a lot of us in Paris had trouble seeing things clearly, too. (I am back at home now.) It's hard to find a sense of clarity and rhythm in the constant bombardment of images, opinion, wrong information, displays of poor management (I refer to the way Facchinetti was dismissed from Valentino, though not the decision ultimately to change designers), and the gloom supplied at once by the economic crisis and the expensive orgy of the shows. Of course designers have to go on designing-that's what they do. But the excellence has to be on all levels right now, from the integrity and muscle of the design to an evident awareness of what is happening in the global marketplace. We all have our favorite collections-for me, Marc Jacobs, Jil Sander, Dries Van Noten, elements of Chanel-and I suppose what makes them standout is that they are able to cut through the noise and show us something that genuinely feels new or interesting and useful.

Enrollment in Latin classes here in the Westchester County suburb of New Rochelle, N.Y., has increased by nearly one-third since 2006, to 187 of the district's 10,500 students, and the two middle schools in town are starting an ancient-cultures club in which students will explore the lives of Romans, Greeks and others.

With the second presidential debate just hours away, the campaign's recent turn toward the negative has many wondering whether the candidates will come armed with their attacks on character and past associations when they face each other on stage at Belmont University in Nashville, Tenn. tonight.
Share prices are up a little, but London interbank lending rates are up again, an indication that the banks still do not trust each other.

The map of Wall Street has been ripped up and redrawn -- and the revamp may be far from over. DealBook's latest special section in The New York Times covers the people who are helping to reshape the Street and what the new terrain might look like.

From our colleague and fellow blogger, John Tierney, whose column appears in today's Science section:

European governments pledged Monday to safeguard bank deposits in a bid to stem financial panic, but they stopped short of a coordinated strategy to break the grip of a credit crisis that now threatens to set off a protracted recession across the Continent, sending markets tumbling on both sides of the Atlantic.

A federal inquiry has concluded that the Securities and Exchange Commission should consider disciplining its director of enforcement and two supervisors for their role in handling an insider trading investigation that led to the firing of an S.E.C. lawyer for trying to interview an influential Wall Street executive.

Vikram Pandit is playing a dangerous game with Citigroup's public image in his battle for Wachovia, Breakingviews says. The more Citi stakes its claim to Wachovia on the terms it reached a week ago, the worse it looks to shareholders, regulators, legislators and the bank's customers, the publication argues.
Bank of America, citing "recessionary conditions," halved its dividend on Monday and said it would sell at least $10 billion in new common stock to bolster its capital to offset rising loan losses.

It was a daunting task for any ad agency copywriter. In the last 10 days of the life of Washington Mutual - Sept. 15 to Sept. 25 - terrified customers withdrew $17 billion in deposits from the failing savings and loan, which federal regulators then took over and sold to JPMorgan Chase for $1.9 billion.

The Treasury Department put its $700 billion bailout on a fast track on Monday, asking companies to submit bids for running the system by Wednesday and announcing its plan to select winners on Friday, The New York Times's Edmund L. Andrews writes.

The Internal Revenue Service has taken steps to help ease the credit crisis by allowing corporations to ramp up their use of tax-free loans from overseas subsidiaries, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reports.
As pressure built in the credit markets and stocks spiraled lower around the world on Monday, the Federal Reserve was considering a radical new plan to jump-start the engine of the financial system.

When the White House brought out its $700 billion rescue plan two weeks ago, its sheer size was meant to soothe the global financial system, restoring trust and confidence. Three days after the plan was approved, it looks like a pebble tossed into a churning sea, The New York Times's Mark Landler writes.

Emerging markets took one of their biggest collective tumbles in a decade Monday as stock markets from Mexico to Indonesia to Russia were gripped by fears of a collapse of Europe's banking system and concern that a global recession could drag down the price of commodities, forcing a steep slowdown in emerging-market growth, The New York Times's Alex Barrionuevo reported.

Peter Y. Solmssen may have an important title as general counsel of the German engineering company Siemens, but he is just one of about 400,000 employees. Which is why his job as the enforcer of anticorruption rules is so difficult, The New York Times's Carter Dougherty writes.
Italian prosecutors sought a 13-year prison term for the former head of Italian food company Parmalat Monday over its 2003 collapse, one of Europe's biggest financial scandals.
Shares in Japan lost 3 percent Tuesday, but other markets in Asia resisted the selloff trend, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener reported.
Alien Technology, a provider of UHF Radio Frequency Identification products, has landed $38 million in fresh round of funding.

While global private-equity fundraising marked its weakest quarter in more than three years, Asia-focused funds managed to surpass their European counterparts for the first time in history, according to data compiled by Private Equity Intelligence, an independent research group.

Music | People fret over classical music's future because its audience is old and gray. But, a writer asks, so what? The graying is "(a) nothing new and (b) not necessarily a cause for panic, because, at least so far, there has always been 'new gray' waiting in the wings to replace the old." [Los Angeles Times]
Giga Omni Media, the parent of tech blog GigaOm, has reeled in $4.5 million in third round of funding, led by Alloy Ventures.

Updated: Hi Caucus readers -- I have been on a tour of the center of America, traveling from San Francisco to New York, more or less along I-80, interviewing voters. I'm halfway through my two-week journey, and plan to be in Des Moines, where it all began, in time for the second presidential debate.

Bill Gross, head of the world's largest bond fund, on Monday urged the U.S. Federal Reserve to take more dramatic steps to jump-start paralyzed credit markets, including direct purchases of commercial paper -- a move The New York Times reported the Fed was considering.

Eli Lilly agreed on Monday to pay $6.5 billion to acquire ImClone Systems, the biotechnology company that is controlled by Carl C. Icahn and whose stock was involved in the insider trading scandal that sent Martha Stewart to jail.

Advanced Micro Devices plans to announce Tuesday that it will split into two companies - one focused on designing microprocessors and the other on the costly business of manufacturing them - in a drastic effort to maintain its position as the only real rival to Intel, according to The New York Times's Ashlee Vance.

MGM Mirage, controlled by billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian, announced Monday that it had landed $1.8 billion of $3 billion in financing it needs for Las Vegas casino owner's biggest development, CityCenter, despite tough lending conditions.

The Federal Reserve on Monday gave its approval for Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group to acquire up to 24.9 percent of the voting shares of Morgan Stanley.

The Hartford Financial Services Group said Monday that it would receive a $2.5 billion investment from Allianz, the German financial services company.

Way back in July, Steven Earl Salmony, a frequent comment contributor and a blogger and psychologist from Chapel Hill, N.C., posted an invitation to Dot Earth visitors to meet at the New York Times office on the first Monday in October, and sure enough, a small cluster of Dot Earthers did convene yesterday. I invited them in to see the chaotic jumble called my desk, and then we went up to the cafeteria to chat about blogging, the state of the planet and nation, population growth (a passion of Steve) and other matters.

Literature | Greed is a perennial theme in literature. Shakespeare, Chaucer, Trollope, Dreiser, Wolfe -- they all dealt with it. So why haven't the novelists of today? a book editor asks. "The 21st-century Masters of the Universe have remained stubbornly absent from fiction." One explanation: this financial stuff is too complicated. Still, the excess isn't. [Guardian]

Perhaps the most technologically advanced new vehicle now on display at the 2008 Paris Motor Show is the unique Venturi Volage, which has no engine, mechanical gearbox, clutch, driveshaft, universal joint, or traditional suspension components.

Mideast | The Lebanese say Israel stole our falafel. A trade association is planning an international lawsuit claiming the loss of millions because Israel markets original Lebanese foods like tabouleh, hummus, falafel and fattoush. A frivolous action? Forget not the "feta cheese precedent" of 2002, which gave Greece rights to the name. [Ynetnews]

China | A leading China expert says people have got the country all wrong: it's becoming less capitalist, not more. His book says entrepreneurial rural China surged in the 1980s, but more recently urban, state-controlled China has called the march. If you don't believe him, consider the heavy-handed orchestration of the Olympics. [Economist, Amazon, Foreign Policy]

Psychology | Girding for road rage? People, be they male or female, like angry-faced, masculine-looking cars, a University of Vienna study finds, raising the question of whether they see a dominant-looking car as a benefit in daily battles with traffic. A third of the subjects associated a human or animal face with at least 90 percent of the cars. [Science Daily, Live Science]

A prominent horse racing bettor told industry regulators in Kentucky on Monday that most tracks do not even monitor the start times of their races. He says that allows widespread abuse of the system — including bets placed after horses break from the gate.

Houston Astros pitcher Brandon Backe was among 10 people arrested during a brawl with the police at a weekend wedding reception in a hotel bar in Galveston, Tex. A police spokesman, Capt. Walter Braun, said an internal affairs investigation had been started. The 30-year-old Backe, a member of the wedding party, ignored orders from the police to back away from the fight, and struggled with officers who attempted to handcuff him, according to police reports. He was charged with two misdemeanors and released on $1,500 bond.

The former N.B.A. coach Paul Westphal was hired as the Dallas Mavericks’ executive vice president for basketball operations. Westphal, who was a Dallas assistant last season, will assist General Manager Donnie Nelson and work in scouting.

It was the first timed workout for Curlin since he won the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park on Sept. 27 .Curlin might defend his title in the $5 million Breeders’ Cup Classic on Oct. 25 at Santa Anita, depending on how he adapts to the new Pro-Ride surface. Austria-Hungary announced the annexation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a report from London says, calling it "the second and culminating step in the Austro-Bulgarian program for the aggrandizement of themselves at the expense of the status established by the Treaty of Berlin" (the first step being the proclamation of Bulgaria's independence from Turkey, on Oct. 5). "The present situation is as follows: Turkey calls upon the powers to preserve to her what they guaranteed to her by that treaty. Austria and Bulgaria strongly declare their determination to keep what they have taken. Servia is protesting belligerently against being hemmed in more strongly between two unpopular neighbors and against having the Servians in Bosnia absorbed into the Austro-Hungarian nationality." Austria Takes Two Provinces

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Mario Maya, an influential flamenco dancer and choreographer, misstated the date he died. It was Sept. 27, not Sept. 29.

An article on Friday about the suspected suicide of Choi Jin-sil, a South Korean actress, which the police linked to malicious rumors about her on the Internet, misspelled the name of a South Korean singer who killed herself last year after rumors were spread online that she had undergone plastic surgery. She is Yuni, not Yoo Na.
An obituary on Sept. 19 about Henry Z. Steinway, the last family member to run the piano maker Steinway & Sons, omitted a survivor. She is his sister, Lydia Cochrane of Chicago.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about a battle between Wells Fargo and Citigroup over the purchase of the Wachovia Corporation misspelled, in some editions, the surname of Wachovia’s chief executive, who was shown with lawyers outside a federal court. The article also misstated his middle initial in some editions. He is Robert K. Steel, not Robert S. Steele.

An article on Saturday about plans by the Treasury Department to carry out the new bailout program for financial institutions misstated the name of the investment fund of Joshua S. Siegel, who commented on recruiting people to oversee the bailout effort. (The error also appeared in the attribution for the Quotation of the Day by Mr. Siegel.) The fund is StoneCastle Partners, not Stone Capital Partners.

An article on Monday about European efforts to shore up struggling banks omitted part of one sentence in some copies. The passage should have read, “In Iceland, government officials and banking chiefs were discussing a possible rescue plan for the country’s commercial banks.”.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about declining automobile sales, using information from The Associated Press, referred incorrectly to the status of a Toyota dealership shown in Alameda, Calif. The dealership, Toyota of Alameda, remains open for business; it is not closed.

An article and a headline on Monday about plans by Vizio, a seller of televisions, to expand into new countries referred incorrectly to the company and its ambitions. Vizio is based in Irvine, Calif., and hopes to expand to other countries based on its success in the United States. It is not a Taiwanese company that is considering worldwide expansion because of success in the American marketplace. (A Taiwanese company, Amtran Technology, owns a 23 percent stake in Vizio and makes more than 80 percent of Vizio’s TV.).

A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds, who played at the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, misidentified Mr. Cave’s nationality. Although he lives in Britain, he is Australian, not British.

An article on Sept. 23 about Willie Bosket, a New York State prisoner who has spent two decades in a cell isolated from other inmates, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the state’s correctional agency and misstated the agency’s name. The spokesman is Erik Kriss, not Criss, and he works for the State Department of Correctional Services, not the Department of Corrections.

An article on Thursday about a scheduled vote by the Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh on whether to secede from the national church misstated the process for selecting a new administration for the diocese in the event of secession. Because the diocese did indeed vote to secede on Saturday, the remaining local church members — not the national church — will now choose the administration.

BENDER--Julius, 90, born October 19th, 1917. Beloved husband of the late Flora Bender, father of Lois Bender and Charles Bender, grandfather of Lea and Emilie. Julius, 90 years young was a well-loved friend, businessman, husband, father and grandpa, truly a rock for his family. Remembered for his strength of character, eternal optimism and life-force, we greatly miss him. Funeral services Tuesday, October 7th at Riverside Nassau North Chapels at 12 noon.

BICKFORD--Lawrence, 86, physicist of NYC, died on October 2, 2008. He graduated from Alfred University in 1943, received his master's in physics from Penn State in 1944, served during WWII as a Navy Lieutenant from 1944-1946, received a Ph.D. in physics from MIT in 1949, and taught at Alfred University until 1954 when he joined the research labs of IBM. His 28 year IBM career included assignments in New York, Holland, Japan, and San Jose. Lawrence is survived by three daughters, Marcia Bollard, Suzanne Bruni, and Deborah Bickford; four grandchildren: Kristin Jones, Laura Bruni, Nicholas Ward, and Suzanne Ward; and one greatgrandchild, Logan Jones. At his request a private family service will be planned at a future date. Remembrances in his memory can be made to Alfred University.

The Brooklyn- Queens Expressway was closed in both directions around Brooklyn Heights on Monday after a truck fire sent heavy smoke billowing under the approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. Officials said the fire, which was reported around 1:15 p.m., was the result of a collision between the truck and a black Lexus with New Jersey license plates. The fire broke out where the expressway meets Cadman Plaza. One minor injury was reported.

The Wall Street the world knew seven months ago exists no more. Sparked by the bursting of the housing bubble last year, the seizing up of the credit markets has reshaped the financial landscape, felling decades-old investment banks and spurring the government into some of its most sweeping market interventions since the era of Franklin D. Roosevelt. Some of these companies, like Bear Stearns and the American International Group, were salvaged, though at great cost. Others, like Lehman Brothers, were not. Among these rescuers are some of the biggest names in finance, including chief executives like James Dimon of JPMorgan Chase. But overshadowing them all is the increasingly powerful trio of Henry M. Paulson Jr., the Treasury secretary; Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman; and Timothy F. Geithner, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. We've linked the players to the deals they've worked on, illustrating the increasingly more complex web of financial rescue workers. Each deal is denoted with a different color. With little end to the credit crisis in sight, the list of bailouts may grow larger.

JETS ADD CHATMAN The Jets added running back Jesse Chatman to their 53-man roster. Chatman was suspended the first four games for violating the N.F.L.'s policy on steroids and related substances. He will take the roster spot of safety Eric Smith, who was suspended for one game and fined $50,000 for his helmet-to-helmet hit on Anquan Boldin.

ALBRIGHT--Harry W., Jr., died on Sunday, October 5. He was born in Albany, NY on March 19, 1925 to Ruth Agnes Kerwin and Harry W. Albright. He graduated from the Albany Academy and served in the United States Infantry during World War II. He was a graduate of Yale University and Cornell Law School. He practiced law in Albany, NY for Degraff Foy Conway & Holt Harris before working for Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller, for whom he served as appointment secretary and then as New York State Superintendant of Banks. He and his family moved to Pocantico Hills in 1975 when he became President and CEO of The Dime Savings Bank of New York. He was appointed as Trustee of First American Bankshares and served as Chairman of Battery Park City Authority. He served on the boards of Pratt Institute, Marymount College and the Museum of Jewish Heritage, among others. He is predeceased by his beloved wife of 54 years, Joan Diekman Albright, and his sister Shirley Durgin. He is survived by his sister Marjorie Billings, six children, Kim Vaugeois of Washington, DC, Deborah Albright and her husband Joel Mercurio of Bronxville, NY, Harry Wesley Albright III, of White Plains, NY, Peter Diekman Albright and his partner Renato Grussu of Manhattan, Joan Albright Shannon and her husband Craig of Pocantico Hills and John Albright and his wife Michelle of Weston, CT and eight grandchildren: Christophe and Melissa Vaugeois, Tim and Annie Mercurio, Nicola and Alexander Shannon, and Maya and Lillian Albright. He was a spectacular husband, brother and father. Family and music were central to his life; he played the piano enthusiastically, composed music, read voraciously, loved to play tennis and swim. He loved his summers at Queechy Lake, his family vacations on Nantucket and his good friends in Longboat Key, Florida. He was proud of his many years dedicated to public service. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday, October 9, 2008 at 10 am at St. Mary's Church, Lodge & Pine Streets, Albany. Family and friends are invited to call on Thursday from 4 to 7 pm at Tebbutt Funeral Home, 633 Central Avenue, Albany.

Gene has been involved with Jewish Home Lifecare for over 15 years and has shared, not only his insightful leadership, but his interest in system-wide education, research, palliative care and opportunities for staff training. We are grateful for his longstanding support and our thoughts will be with the family during their time of loss. The Board of Trustees of Jewish Home Lifecare Stanley H. Pantowich Chairman-elect Audrey S. Weiner, DSW President/CEO

BLUH--Bonnie, age 82, died suddenly in New York City on October 2, 2008. The cause was an aortic dissection. Noted Feminist Author, playwright, actor, teacher, lecturer and performer. Bluh's sharp, insightful nonfiction narrative of the emergence of the European feminist movement, ''Woman to Woman'' (1974), is a landmark account of the second wave of feminism and her book is used in classrooms across the world. Her popular, comic novel ''Banana'' (1976) is considered by some the first truly feminist novel ever to be published. Bluh (pronounced blue), as friends and family knew her, was brought up in Sunnyside Queens, had lived in cities from coast to coast as well as Israel and Spain, but always called New York City her home. Since 1985 Bluh had lived at the Westbeth Artists Community in the West Village. In a building filled with interesting artists of all stripes she was known as one of the more outgoing, colorful characters. She was as devoted to her family as she was to her writing. And she never stopped fighting for the great causes of her time. The world will be a poorer, paler place without her. Bluh is survived by her sons, Craig, Kenn, and Brian Lowy, Brian's wife Karen Ilardi-Lowy whom Bluh considered a daughter, two granddaughters, Allee and Mariah, and her devoted friend Mordechai. Instead of flowers please plant a tree in Israel with JNF (www.jnf.org/ trees) or make a donation in Bluh's name to ArtsConnection, 520 Eighth Avenue, Suite 321, New York, NY 10018.

PLAYER In Italy, Giuseppe Rossi, a striker who was born in the United States and grew up in Clifton, N.J., was named to the Italian senior national team for the first time, for World Cup qualifiers at Bulgaria (Saturday) and against Montenegro (Oct. 15). Coach Marcello Lippi said he was impressed with Rossi's play at the Beijing Olympics. CLUB In France, Olympique Lyon, which has won the Ligue 1 title seven years in a row, lost its first match of the season, 3-0, to Rennes on Sunday on three goals by the 35-year-old striker Mickael Pagis.

Kathy was born in Belmont, MA on October 6, 1935 to Henry Miles and Eleanor Shea O' Bryan. She was a graduate of Smith College where she earned a BA and continued on to Yale University where she completed her Masters in Teaching. She is survived by her three children, Jennifer, Ed and Melissa, daughter-in-law Mary, son-inlaw Patrick and soon to be son-in-law Rick, grandchildren Seth, Zoe, Shea, Allie, Reilly and Julia, brother Henry, sisters Elly and Sarah and admirer, Peter. She was an active member of the Smith College Alumnae Association and a docent at the New York Botanical Gardens. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to Smith College of Northampton, MA and Jansen Hospice and Palliative Care of Tuckahoe, NY. A memorial service was held on October 6, 2008 at the Reformed Church, Bronxville, NY.

KOCH--Robert W., Sr., of Alpine, NJ and North Palm Beach, FL on October 4, 2008. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn G. (nee Vorbach). Devoted father of Lynne M. Ketcham, Robert W. Jr., Steven J., Michael J., Cora S. Koch, Charles W., John J., Nancy J. Leccese, Paul A. Sr and the late Peter R. Dear brother of Julia Chisholm, Daniel and the late Karl II, Gladys Brown, Cornelia Landers, Delores Palmer, Patricia Bracken and Jerome A Sr. Also survived by 21 grandchildren, six great-grandchildren and 63 nieces and nephews. Robert Koch was named president of the Karl Koch Erecting Co. in 1955. Under his leadership he changed the company focus from subcontractor to General Contractor specializing in bridge reconstruction. Robert and his company gained notoriety in New York City with its first successful major bridge reconstruction of the Manhattan Bridge in 1959. During his tenure as president, the company successfully completed major rehabilitation on all of the major New York metropolitan bridges. In 1967 through the insistence of Robert Koch his firm was awarded the entire steel erection project for the World Trade Center. Included in the project was the erection of both towers, the 13 acre plaza area and the customs house. This consisted of more than 250,000 tons of steel and still remains as the single largest steel project ever awarded. Other notable projects completed by his firm under his direction were Giants Stadium (1975), Yankee Stadium reconstruction (1976) and The Jacob Javits Convention Center (1982). He was the past president and co-founder of The National Erectors Association. Robert was a WWII Navy veteran and member of St. Mary's RC Church in Closter NJ. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive Tenafly, NJ on Tuesday 2-4pm & 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Wednesday 10am St. Mary's Church Closter NJ. Interment Mt. Carmel Cemetery Tenafly, NJ. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to charity of your choice. For directions visit: barrettfuneralhome.net

GRAUSTEIN--E. Phyllis (Lucas), age 99, died peacefully at Whitney Center, Hamden, Connecticut on September 27, 2008. She came to the United States in 1946, and for 46 years was the loving wife of the late Archibald R. Graustein, Jr. of Tenafly, New Jersey. Phyllis was born on December 10, 1908 in Rockhampton, Queensland, Australia, to Ernest and Ethyl Lucas. She was a communicant of the Church of the Atonement in Tenafly and an active member of the Tenafly Garden Club and the Woman's Club of Tenafly. She and her husband were avid golfers and were longtime members of the Knickerbocker Country Club. Phyllis was a loyal member of the Daughters of the British Empire. She moved to Hamden in 1999. She is survived in the United States by her stepson John A. Graustein and his wife Barbara, of Portland Maine, Maxine Andrews of Fryeburg Maine, the widow of her late stepson Robert S. Graustein, by brother-in-law William Graustein and his wife Jean of New Haven, Connecticut, by grandchildren Stephen, Scott, Kent, Andrew and Bradley Graustein and four great-grandchildren. The last survivor of seven siblings, she leaves many nieces, nephews, great nieces, great-nephews and cousins in Australia. A Memorial Service will be held at Trinity Church on the Green in New Haven at 3:00pm on Sunday, November 16th.

Looking for spare tickets to that joint concert on Oct. 16 by Bruce Springsteen and Billy Joel for Senator Barack Obama's presidential campaign? Beware. On Monday, a ticket resale site, TicketNetwork.com, was selling a pair of tickets in Section 105, Row K, of the Hammerstein Ballroom in New York City for $4,455 each. Another pair in Section 203, Row K, was listed for $3,555 each, with a pair of balcony seats listed for $1,679 each. An ad posted on Craigslist on Sept. 30 listed two tickets for $25,000 each. But the Obama campaign said Monday that it planned to check for identification at the fund-raiser and enlist a ticketing company to help prevent scalping.

At least six million questions have been submitted via the Internet to be asked at the town-hall-style presidential debate Tuesday in Nashville between Senators Barack Obama and John McCain. That's a lot of queries for 90 minutes, and obviously they won't all get asked -- there will be time for only 15 to 20. The moderator, Tom Brokaw of NBC News, is sifting through those millions of questions to find six or seven that he might pose. The other dozen or so questions will come from among an audience of about 80 likely voters from the Nashville area who will be on stage with the candidates.

POWERS--Stephen B., of Greenwich, Connecticut, died on October 5th, 2008 at age 45. He was born in New Rochelle, New York on June 7th, 1963 to Frederic and Virginia Powers. He is survived by his wife Christina; two daughters, Alexis 16, and Sydney 13; mother Virginia and brothers Jeffrey, Christopher and Frederic III. Stephen met Christina Polcini while they were students at Scarsdale High School in 1981, and married in 1990. Stephen graduated with honors from Iona College, New Rochelle in 1986 with a BS in Computer Science. Stephen was Executive Vice President of Powers Fasteners, a global company, which he ran with his three brothers in Brewster, NY. Stephen managed the Information Technology sector for the company and was the Business Manager for Powers Global overseas companies in eight countries. He was an avid skier and golfer, and a member of Winged Foot Golf Club. A wake will be held at the Leo P. Gallagher & Sons Funeral Home (telephone 203-869-1513), 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT 06830 on Wednesday, October 8 and Thursday, October 9, 2008 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. His funeral mass will be held at St. Paul's Church, 84 Sherwood Avenue, Greenwich, CT on Friday October 10th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations be sent in his memory to Sound Shore Medical Center, 16 Guion Place, New Rochelle, NY 10801 .

Loving mother of Allen and Lissy Kaplan, Rachel and Howard Hershenhorn. Adoring grandmother of Lauren and Phil, Meryl and B.J., Matthew, Michel, and Sarah. Greatgrandmother of Mia, Spencer, and Casey. The matriarch of our family. Wisdom, dignity and courage defines our beautiful mother's life. You are an inspiration to all of us. You will live in our hearts forever. The Kaplan and Hershenhorn Families KAPLAN--Selma. Our deepest condolences on the passing of our adored friend, Selma, of over 37 years. The recollection of many fabulous occasions you provided under your leadership will be cherished forever. As the matriarch of an astonishing family, tireless leader of the temple and motivating director of the hospital, your central ending was everybody's well being and happiness. Even during your own courageous fight, you could not decelerate benevolence to others. I was privileged to be in your presence countless times while you were honored. Your private expression to me this week was significant and I'm appreciative. You are FAN-tastic! Our parting comes way to soon. The Kalick Family KAPLAN--Selma. An eternal light will reflect on Selma Kaplan, our matriarch and mentor remembered for her leadership and brilliant words. The Group Family, The Gross Family, and The Gelb Family KAPLAN--Selma. Our Congregation is bereaved by the loss of its President of more than a quarter of a century. Her generosity was unbounded, her love of Temple BethEl of Rockaway Park had no limits. She touched the lives of young and old. Her influence on all of us is her legacy. We express our condolences to her children, Allen and Lissy, Rachel and Howard, her grandchildren and great-children. Services in the sanctuary of Temple Beth-El of Rockaway Park, 201 Beach 121st St., Rockaway Park, NY on Tuesday October 7, at 11am. Dr. Allan Blaine, Rabbi Temple Beth-El of Rockaway Park KAPLAN--Selma. We have lost our best friend. Grandma Selma, we will think of you always and honor all the wonderful life lessons you have taught us. You will be in our hearts forever. We love you, Lauren and Phil Meryl and B.J. KAPLAN--Selma. A true lady of valor. A tower of strength. A great mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. She will be sorely missed and will remain an inspiration for all whom she loved. Our deepest condolences to her dear Allen, Lissy, Rachel, Howie and their entire families. Marilyn, Steve, Lauren, Josh KAPLAN--Selma. Grandma, we loved you so much. You were beautiful, funny and so loving. We will miss you terribly. Matthew, Michael and Sarah

MASSEY--Clifford Milton. The partners of Fagenson, Frankel & Streicher mourn the passing of our longtime partner and friend, Cliff Massey. His smile, humor and friendship will always be missed. Our hearts go out to Gwen and the rest of his family. A member of the New York Stock Exchange for 18 years, his professionalism and integrity were an example for all to follow. My Thursday column is about the Bush administration's decision to cut off contraceptive supplies to Marie Stopes International, a British aid group. It's the latest in a series of actions that curb access to family planning for some of the poorest and most voiceless women on the planet. The upshot will be more unwanted pregnancies, more abortions and more women dying in childbirth.

Some really cool innovating is going on in the GPS world. I love the debut of speech recognition (say "123 East 43rd Street" instead of typing a tiny on-screen keyboard). And Garmin's recently announced 7X5 series offers free traffic reporting (most GPS units require you to pay a monthly fee forever to see this data on your screen), lane assistance (suggests which lane to get into, so you'll be ready for the next turn or exit), and semi-transparent, photorealistic 3-D buildings in major cities, which make it easier to get your bearings.

For months now, even as job cuts mounted and the financial crisis worsened, we journalists have had to include a caveat when talking about the economy: it still isn't clear that the economy is even in a recession. We may soon be able to drop the caveat.

The Concacaf rivalry between the United States and Mexico -- as heated as any in world soccer -- grew increasingly close Wednesday when FIFA announced its latest world rankings. The Americans can take some pride ahead of Saturday's World Cup qualifier against Cuba: the U.S.A. jumped seven spots to No. 21. Mexico, under the eye and prominent brow of Swedish coach Sven Goran Eriksson, stayed put at No. 24. It's the closest the two teams have been ranked since August when the Americans were No. 31 and Mexico was ranked 32nd.

I will not be writing here tomorrow. I will be in synagogue observing Yom Kippur with my husband and my children. And if past years are any indication, those children will be none too enthusiastic about being there. They see religious services the way that I did when I was their age - as a boring obligation to be ducked as soon as the grown-ups aren't looking. And yet, as an adult, I find myself repeating what I chafed against, and dragging them along with me because it is "part of being a family."

Science | Human evolution is pretty much over, a British geneticist says, and the human race is pretty much as good as it's going to get. Religion | Why Kol Nidre, chanted for Yom Kippur, is "the anti-Semite's favorite Jewish prayer": it's taken out of context and misinterpreted as evidence of Jewish duplicity. The passage that says pledges "shall not bind us nor have power over us" refers only to internal personal vows, not vows to other people. Think New Year's resolutions, not treaties. [Slate]

RUBIN--Alexander, 101, passed away October 6, 2008 after a valiant struggle to survive, astonishing all with his determination and strength. A proud graduate of Columbia University School of Law in 1933, he practiced law in NYC before moving to Miami in 1947. As investor, mentor and advisor he achieved success, and his knowledge of Florida real estate was widely praised and sought. Son of the late Morris and Rose Rubin and brother of the late Joseph (Ann) and the late Estelle. Most proud father of Robert (Judy), former United States Secretary of the Treasury under William J. Clinton, and Jane, a psychiatrist. Beloved grandfather of Jamie (Gretchen), Philip (Lauren), Annie (Jason) and David (Michele) and great-grandfather of Eliza, Eleanor, Henry, Amira, Isaih, Sasha and Jacob. St. Martin's Press recently published ''Rough and Tumble,'' the first novel by the former Giant Mark Bavaro, below. ''Rough and Tumble'' is a frequently gritty story about a professional football player at the end of his career who is forced to confront some of the ugliness in the sport, and in himself, over the course of a momentous season. Bavaro peppers his tale with football action, a kind of bone-jarring realism only a former player can provide. Bavaro recently answered a few questions via e-mail. The full interview, and an excerpt from Bavaro's book, can be found at nytimes.com/fifthdown.

Ruedi Rymann, a Swiss farmer and cheesemaker renowned in his home country as a yodeler and the man who recorded what came to be known as ''Switzerland's greatest hit,'' died on Sept. 10 at his home in Giswil, south of Zurich. He was 75. His family told the Swiss newspaper Blick that he had been suffering from liver cancer and decided in June to end chemotherapy treatments. He is survived by his wife and six children.

Jerome R. Corsi went to Kenya on Tuesday to publicize his newest book, ''The Obama Nation,'' a work full of unsubstantiated accusations about Senator Barack Obama's drug use, his connections to Islam and his relationships with Kenyan politicians, among other things. The chairs and microphone were all set up in one of the biggest hotels in Nairobi, and the room was crowded with journalists eager to hear what Mr. Corsi would say about the man who is adored in Kenya like a native son. (Mr. Obama's father was Kenyan.) But the presentation was not to be.

Peter Y. Solmssen may have an important title as general counsel of the German engineering company Siemens, but he is just one of about 400,000 employees. Which is why his job as the enforcer of anticorruption rules is so difficult. Mr. Solmssen, who joined Siemens in 2007 after nine years at General Electric, got a taste of what he was up against on a recent swing through the Americas. At a meeting with employees in Mexico, he explained the need for Siemens to change its ways after an extensive bribery scandal two years ago. Then, Mr. Solmssen took questions.

ANGELERI--Carl J., at 96. Carl passed away October 2, 2008 to join his beloved wife of 50 years, Lucy. Remembered for his kindness, strength and smile, Carl was a 1932 graduate of the New England Conservatory of Music and he was a veteran of World War II. His varied careers included music and serving as an orchestra leader on the Grace Line Ships as well as real estate brokerage. During his retirement, he worked with the Fresh Meadows Poets, and as a cameraman/producer for Queens Public TV. Carl is survived by his daughter, Sandra, stepsons, Michael and Alvin, nine grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren.

BLUH--Bonnie, age 82, died suddenly in New York City on October 2, 2008. The cause was an aortic dissection. Noted Feminist Author, playwright, actor, teacher, lecturer and performer. Bluh's sharp, insightful nonfiction narrative of the emergence of the European feminist movement, ''Woman to Woman'' (1974), is a landmark account of the second wave of feminism and her book is used in classrooms across the world. Her popular, comic novel ''Banana'' (1976) is considered by some the first truly feminist novel ever to be published. Bluh (pronounced blue), as friends and family knew her, was brought up in Sunnyside Queens, had lived in cities from coast to coast as well as Israel and Spain, but always called New York City her home. Since 1985 Bluh had lived at the Westbeth Artists Community in the West Village. In a building filled with interesting artists of all stripes she was known as one of the more outgoing, colorful characters. She was as devoted to her family as she was to her writing. And she never stopped fighting for the great causes of her time. The world will be a poorer, paler place without her. Bluh is survived by her sons, Craig, Kenn, and Brian Lowy, Brian's wife Karen Ilardi-Lowy whom Bluh considered a daughter, two granddaughters, Allee and Mariah, and her devoted friend Mordechai. Instead of flowers please plant a tree in Israel with JNF (www.jnf.org/ trees) or make a donation in Bluh's name to ArtsConnection, 520 Eighth Avenue, Suite 321, New York, NY 10018.

Around the League The Saints' Reggie Bush, who leads the N.F.L. with 38 receptions, is on pace for 121, which would be a record for a running back. Larry Centers has the record with 101, in 1995 for Arizona. The last running back to lead the league in receptions was Roger Craig in 1985. ... Michael Turner, the league's leading rusher, has more yards in his first season with the Falcons (543) than he had in any of his four years as LaDainian Tomlinson's backup in San Diego. ... Peyton Manning won his 107th game as a starter, tying Terry Bradshaw for seventh on the league's career list. ... The Ravens have not allowed a 100-yard rusher in 27 games, the longest active streak in the league. ... The Cardinals are 8-2 at home under Coach Ken Whisenhunt. They are 3-8 elsewhere. ... The Bengals' Chris Perry has a league-leading five fumbles in five games. (NYT)

PETERSEN--Elizabeth M.J.F., A doyen of Greenwich society, died October 2nd in Aurora, CO. She was 85 and is survived by five children, five grandchildren, and two greatgrandchildren. Betty was born in 1922 in Rye, NY, but her family soon relocated to London, where she lived until the age of nine. But her real home was Greenwich, CT, where her family permanently settled in 1931. Betty graduated from Madeira School in 1941 and Vassar College four years later. She maintained strong lifelong ties to both as a fund raiser and advisor. Shortly after college, she moved to New York where she worked at NBC. In 1948 she married William P. Jeffery, Jr., and returned to Greenwich, which remained her home for the next 57 years. Betty maintained a lifelong interest in education. While raising five children, she spent much of her life ministering to the learning disabled, and she was one of the original founders of the Greenwich Association for Retarded Children. At age 50 she enrolled at Manhattanville College, where she received not one but two advanced degrees in education. At age 55 she entered the Fairfield County and Westchester county school systems as a special education teacher, a role she continued to play until she was in her late seventies. Betty belonged to a myriad of local clubs and organizations, including the St. Barnabas Church choir, the Greenwich chapter of the DAR, the Bruce Museum, the Greenwich Garden Club, the Field Club of Greenwich, and the Round Hill Club. Her love of the outdoors and outdoor sports was unbounded. Tennis was her forte, but she was an accomplished skier well into her seventies. She will be remembered for her charisma, quick intelligence, her exuberant sense of humor, and her limitless intellectual and physical energy. A service in honor of Betty's life will be held at St. Barnabas Church in Greenwich, CT on Saturday, October 11th at 11am. In lieu of flowers the family asks that you give to a charity of your choice.

FRIEDMAN--Michael Jeffery, 19, aspiring scientist and oncologist. Harvard University, Class of 2011. His goal was to find a cure for cancer, but he succumbed to it after a four year battle. Mikey was known for his warm personality, acute sense of humor, unparalleled intellect and ability to evoke spontaneous laughter with his antics. His accomplishments included publication of his papers ''In the Depths of Human Circumstance'' in the Journal of Palliative and Supportive Care and Small Molecule Targeted Therapy and Cancer Treatment published by the Harvard Science Review. At the time of his death, he was studying cancer vaccines at Harvard Medical School. Mikey's proudest achievement was the charity he founded in 2005, the Mikey's Way Foundation, which distributes electronic games to pediatric oncology patients and was featured on NBC Nightly News. Connecticut Governor Rell declared April 29, 2006 to be Mikey Friedman Day and he was named a ''Hometown Hero'' by the Connecticut State Legislature. He received Hero of the Year Award from the Boys and Girls Clubs of Hudson County, NJ in 2006. His family and friends from Staples Elementary, Joel Barlow High School, and Harvard University deeply loved him and will miss him. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Mikey's Way Foundation, P.O. Box 76, Easton, CT 06612.

It's not every day that the head of a federal agency in a Republican administration writes a glowing thank-you note to the Democratic presidential nominee. But Michael D. Griffin, the administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, wrote to Senator Barack Obama last Thursday that he was ''deeply grateful to you, personally'' for Mr. Obama's aid in getting Congress to approve an important measure for the space program. The problem for NASA was a bill -- the Iran, North Korea, and Syria Nonproliferation Act -- that bans spending federal money in Russia because of that nation's dealings with hostile countries. NASA relies heavily on Russia for transport to and from the International Space Station aboard Soyuz spacecraft, and after 2010, when NASA shuts down the space shuttle program, the Soyuz, above, will be the only vehicle taking people to the station.

ALBRIGHT--Harry. The Trustees and Staff of the Museum of Jewish HeritageA Living Memorial to the Holocaust mourn the passing of our dear friend and Trustee, Harry Albright, Jr. Harry saw us through the lean times and the moments of great celebration, and we shall miss him greatly. We send our condolences to Harry's sister, six children, and eight grandchildren. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chair David G. Marwell, Ph.D., Director ALBRIGHT--Harry W., Jr., died on Sunday, October 5. He was born in Albany, NY on March 19, 1925 to Ruth Agnes Kerwin and Harry W. Albright. He graduated from the Albany Academy and served in the United States Infantry during World War II. He was a graduate of Yale University and Cornell Law School. He practiced law in Albany, NY for Degraff Foy Conway & Holt Harris before working for Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller, for whom he served as appointment secretary and then as New York State Superintendant of Banks. He and his family moved to Pocantico Hills in 1975 when he became President and CEO of The Dime Savings Bank of New York. He was appointed as Trustee of First American Bankshares and served as Chairman of Battery Park City Authority. He served on the boards of Pratt Institute, Marymount College and the Museum of Jewish Heritage, among others. He is predeceased by his beloved wife of 54 years, Joan Diekman Albright, and his sister Shirley Durgin. He is survived by his sister Marjorie Billings, six children, Kim Vaugeois of Washington, DC, Deborah Albright and her husband Joel Mercurio of Bronxville, NY, Harry Wesley Albright III, of White Plains, NY, Peter Diekman Albright and his partner Renato Grussu of Manhattan, Joan Albright Shannon and her husband Craig of Pocantico Hills and John Albright and his wife Michelle of Weston, CT and eight grandchildren: Christophe and Melissa Vaugeois, Tim and Annie Mercurio, Nicola and Alexander Shannon, and Maya and Lillian Albright. He was a spectacular husband, brother and father. Family and music were central to his life; he played the piano enthusiastically, composed music, read voraciously, loved to play tennis and swim. He loved his summers at Queechy Lake, his family vacations on Nantucket and his good friends in Longboat Key, Florida. He was proud of his many years dedicated to public service. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday, October 10, 2008 at 10 am at St. Mary's Church, Lodge & Pine Streets, Albany. Family and friends are invited to call on Thursday from 4 to 7 pm at Tebbutt Funeral Home, 633 Central Avenue, Albany.

CONNELL--Eugene P., of Tenafly, NJ, a retired telecommunications executive in New York, died October 2 in Vermont after a long illness. The cause was a heart attack. He met his wife, Carol Misar Connell, while both were attending Tenafly High School. Connell was a resident of Haworth, where his father, Edward Connell, was mayor. He graduated from Colgate University in 1960 and went to work for New York Telephone after graduation. After 37 years of service including his assignment as president and chief executive officer of NYNEX CableComms Group, the NYNEX affiliate in the United Kingdom, he retired as vice-president of marketing for Verizon in l997. During the 1980 subway strike, he was working with Mayor Edward Koch while on loan from the telephone company and helped guide the administration through extensive and complex transportation issues. The Connells lived in Rockland County for many years, where he was president of the Board of Education in Clarkstown, NY. After retiring, Eugene became a member of the Tenafly Board of Adjustment. In addition to his wife, he is survived by three sons, Brian of Blauvelt, NY; Michael of Orangeburg, NY; and Barry of Chester, NJ; their wives, Robyn, Karen, and Lisa and nine grandchildren. Survivors also include two brothers, Edward and Barry, and a sister, Elyse, and her husband, Roger, as well as many nieces and nephews. For Eugene and his wife, family was first, last and always. Most summer weekends were spent with friends and family on the Metedeconk River in Bricktown, NJ. He loved painting, sailing, reading, tennis, history and music. A memorial service is scheduled for October 25 at 1pm at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, Tenafly, NJ, with a reception immediately following at Knickerbocker Country Club in Tenafly. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to: The Lung Failure Fund, New York Presbyterian Hospital, c/o Byron M. Thomashow, M.D., 161 Fort Washington Ave., New York, NY 10032.

Respect is the lifeblood of the teaching profession. We depend on parents to teach children to respect us as teachers; we depend on respect to get and keep students’ attention and focus. When I began teaching, I knew that not all my students would have had previous experience with Deaf people. Some of my students, true, were Deaf themselves; others came from families with Deaf people (we call them CODA’s, children of Deaf adults; we also have SODA’s, siblings of Deaf adults.) But some would be students from the community; some would be students who wanted to learn to sign, but some would not. This was part of the public school nature of our institution. I entered our school aware that this meant I’d have to work at earning the respect of different students in very different ways.

It was another awful day in the stock market with the Dow dropping more than 7 percent and the Nasdaq more than 5 percent. Internet companies were not immune, as a growing chorus of analysts are now saying that the financial crisis and downturn in the economy are going to affect just about everyone in the sector. It is the latest sign that the downturn is going to temper the mood in always-upbeat Silicon Valley.

When buildings in New York City are demolished, the public reaction can range from joy to grief. Rarely, though, is the public invited to actually watch. At noon Friday, the Governors Island Preservation and Education Corporation will do just that, opening the island to visitors as giant machines destroy a complex of 10 three-story buildings known as Liberty Village.The buildings were built in 1988 as housing for the Coast Guard, which stopped using the island in 1996. The federal government transferred the island to the state and city of New York in 2003.
With today's plunge in the stock market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has now fallen 42 percent over the last year. Just how bad is that?
Every year, when Oct. 19 approaches, people speak darkly of the crash. On that day in 1987, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 20.5 percent. This is the crash of 2008.

Ed's post below, on monkfish, reminded me of this fisherman in Connecticut, this goes back 30 years. He was catching monkfish like mad, so I told him to go try to sell it to this chef friend nearby. The chef -- an old-fashioned French guy -- said, "no, thank you, I'm buying lotte from France." Lotte, as neither of them knew, is French for monkfish. So the fisherman began selling his monkfish to an exporter, who sent it to France. Where perhaps it returned to America as lotte. Talk about carbon miles! --MB

Although most of the drivers and spectators certainly prefer the Suzuka circuit to the Fuji circuit, my first visit to Fuji today was a wonderful surprise. I did not come here last year, so I suppose I only had the dark and stormy night scenario in my head. I arrived late today after a "lost in translation" kind of travel trip from Tokyo - which I will not bore you with - and immediately felt a release at the beauty of the landscape that surrounds the circuit. Clean good air, beautiful hills everywhere, it's a delightful place. Funny enough, the area around Fuji actually reminded me a lot of Mont Tremblant, where F1 used to race in Canada.

Every now and then in this line of work, you hear wistful tributes to the era of The Saturday Evening Post, when literature counted as pop entertainment and the mass-market glossies offered writers an easy path to a regular paycheck. Those days are gone. But we may be in a different kind of golden age right now, with the big-circulation magazines encouraging novelists to write journalism or personal essays. As Jenny Schuessler mentioned a few months ago in this space, Newsweek tapped the novelist Claire Messud to observe the Obama campaign. Meanwhile, Real Simple - our era's unlikely equivalent of The Saturday Evening Post? - has been quietly collecting an impressive roster of bylines. In April, Meg Wolitzer wrote about becoming a parent; in August, Erica Wagner wrote about trying to recapture the perfect tuna sandwich of her youth; and the current issue features both Mary Gordon (remembering her grandmother) and the comic novelist Steve Almond (trying to go a week without spending any money). Only the Almond appears to be available online (you can find it here), but they're all worth tracking down.

Many college football fans have been surprised, nay, agog, at the sudden excellence of Alabama, the undefeated and second-ranked team that has already walloped highly ranked opponents Clemson and Georgia. But close followers of the Southeastern Conference, as well as football coaches everywhere, realized that the Tide was entering the mythical, second season under a new coach — in this case, Nick Saban, he of the cannily-timed contract-jump — and that meant great things were in the offing.

Many people are afraid to cook duck, and not entirely without reason. Roasting the whole bird long enough to release most or all of the fat dries out the meat, but undercooking leaves the leg meat tough. But there's a simple procedure that not only keeps the breast meat moist, but also makes the legs ultratender: roast the duck, then braise it briefly with juicy sauerkraut.

This past April, the Book Review ran a front-page review by the historian Niall Ferguson of Philip Bobbitt's rich and difficult work "Terror and Consent: The Wars for the Twenty-First Century." It couldn't have been more of a rave. "This is quite simply the most profound book to have been written on the subject of American foreign policy since the attacks of 9/11, indeed, since the end of the cold war," Ferguson exclaimed.

Friday is the deadline for New Yorkers to register to vote in this year's presidential election. Around the state, municipal boards of elections are processing a surge of new voter applications, an indication of the high level of interest in this year's contest between John McCain, the Republican candidate, and Barack Obama, the Democratic candidate.But with that surge of new applications comes backlogs, delays -- and complaints from some of our readers that election officials are saying their forms may not be processed in time for them to vote next month. We're interested in hearing from more of our readers about these kinds of problems. If you've had difficulty in registering to vote, or found that a form you mailed weeks ago has not been processed, or had any other kind of problem, please post a comment below or send us an e-mail.

Life insurer MetLife recently approached life and property insurer Hartford Financial Services Group about a merger transaction, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the discussions.

The Federal Reserve Board said Wednesday that it would provide up to $37.8 billion to the embattled insurer the American International Group to help it deal with a rapidly dwindling supply of cash, The New York Times's Barry Meier and Marry Williams Walsh reported.

The team behind the new DreamWorks film studio is putting plans to pitch Wall Street a loan package on ice for about a month, in order to give the markets a little more time to stabilize, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

As I mentioned on Monday, I'm surrounded by heaps of promising books that are closely related to core themes of Dot Earth - population and consumption patterns, environmental science and ethics, our nonhuman neighbors on this small planet, and more. But I rarely have time to read them, given the never-ending need to track and respond to news as well as develop more thorough print pieces. So I recently decided to start Dot Earth conversations about books by having specialists in various fields, other writers and Dot Earth contributors read new or pending releases and offer some reactions here. These are not formal reviews, but starting points for discussions.

War | A military historian says an emerging Petraeus Doctrine is being forged from the bottom up -- not by generals but "mid-career officers-lieutenant colonels and colonels," who learned hard lessons in Iraq. Out: the Powell Doctrine of overwhelming force. In: a view of war as "protracted, ambiguous, and continuous-with the application of force becoming a lesser part of the soldier's repertoire." [Atlantic]

In a bold move to restore confidence, Britain announced an unprecedented 50 billion pound government lifeline for the nation's banks Wednesday that it hailed as a quicker solution to the credit crisis than a $700 billion American plan to buy impaired mortgage assets from troubled financial institutions.
A tentative cheer: Paulson may have been dragged kicking and screaming into doing the right thing to rescue the financial system:

The homeowner assistance plan that Senator John McCain announced without detail in the presidential debate Tuesday night would allow millions of financially stretched Americans to refinance their mortgages with government help, but it would leave taxpayers to cover the losses, rather than the financial institutions that hold the original mortgages, The New York Times's Jackie Calmes reported.

With the fiscal health of the nation's most populous state in serious decline, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and California legislative leaders promised Wednesday that, despite their differences, they would find the billions of dollars need to avert drastic cuts in services.

New members of the European Union in Central and Eastern Europe have - so far - avoided much of the upheaval caused by the crisis of confidence in the global financial system, The New York Times's Judy Dempsey reports.
Russia finds itself stuck between a rock and a hard place when it comes the deteriorating situation of its financial markets, Breakingviews says.

Having tried without success to unlock frozen credit markets, the Treasury Department is considering taking ownership stakes in many United States banks to try to restore confidence in the financial system, The New York Times's Edmund L. Andrews and Mark Landler reported, citing government officials.

As the deadline for enrollment neared on Wednesday, four of the nation's best-known mutual fund companies said they had joined the new federal program aimed at restoring confidence in the nation's money market funds, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques writes.
At what point is a stock market no longer a functioning stock market?

Some Asian stock markets posted gains Thursday following the previous day's dramatic selloff but the recovery failed to prevent Tokyo from closing down 0.5 percent, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener writes.

Bank of America has agreed to buy back as much as $4.7 billion in auction-rate securities to settle charges that it misled thousands of customers about the risky investments, federal and New York state regulators said Wednesday.
Morgan Stanley is struggling to attract additional investors for an Atlantic City casino project, TheStreet.com's Dan Freed reported.

Race | White Americans have learned not to talk about race for fear of seeming racist, says a Tufts University researcher, but his work shows that avoiding race when it's clearly relevant may impair decision-making skills. "This probably means that egalitarian whites think they're doing the right thing by avoiding race," says a colleague, but they may not be. [Science Now]

Literature | A writer takes on "Literary Darwinism" -- the strain of literary criticism that uses empirical data to show how "responses to works of literature can be traced back to biological impulses in the same way that, say, our desire for sweet foods is explained as a survival instinct." But it winds up belaboring the obvious: protagonists are good-looking and women in Jane Austen novels like to get married. Duh. Such "thrilling insights." [Smart Set]

You certainly didn't come to Rome to see the work of a Haitian Latino graffiti-style artist who lived in Brooklyn and died of a heroin overdose in 1988. Still, the Jean Michel Basquiat exhibit that opened this week at Rome's Palazzo Ruspoli is extraordinary -- well worth taking a break from the Emporer's Forums and the Vatican Museums, treasure troves of distant eras.

World | An article sees a "global epidemic of sameness" descending upon us as cultures, languages and species down to the microbial level rapidly vanish, leaving the Earth "monochromatic, monocultural, and homogeneous." Cross-disciplinary movements are forming -- "joining biologist with anthropologist, scientist with storyteller" -- to figure it all out. [Seed]

Technology | A tech writer comments on Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak's offhand remark this week that the iPod (just 7 years old) will go the way of the transistor radio: "News flash: it's already there," because "Apple passed its mantle of innovation to the first iPhone a year ago." [Cnet]

India | Bollywood culture is becoming something of a social leveler in India: "In a diverse neighborhood, in which the real estate broker from Siwan in Bihar lives next door to Banias from Rajasthan and Punjabi Khatris from Delhi, Bollywood song and dance is palpably a tradition that everybody can be part of, no matter where they come from and what caste they are." A sociologist: "A national language has come into being." [Outlook India]

Literature | Just before the Nobel literature award, writers weigh in on the furor over that Nobel honcho's contention that American writers are "too insular": They'd "have to revoke William Faulkner's Nobel Prize, since the Mississippi novelist confined his fictions to the tiny postage stamp of Yoknapatawpha County. Sinclair Lewis never moved his prose from Main Street to the Champs Elysées." And more. [Inside Higher Ed]
Despite a slowdown in many parts of Asia, prices for luxury houses in Hong Kong rose by more than 140 percent between 2003 and 2007, a new study found.
The International Olympic Committee said it would retest blood samples collected from athletes at the Beijing Games to check for a new blood-boosting drug most often used by endurance athletes.

1. Kurt Warner's wife telling Yahoo.com that her husband was considering immediate retirement and that he communicated that to her via a text message shortly after the hard hit on Anquan Boldin. He said it was a misunderstanding.

The Chicago Cubs beat the New York Giants yesterday afternoon in a rare playoff game. The Cubs' pitcher, Mordecai "Three-Fingered" Brown, is the subject of the flamboyant sentence that leads the Times report: "A rather bulky person, with a persistent and annoying habit of twisting his arms and legs into cabalistic designs and then shooting a ball with terrific speed and snakelike twist toward a man sixty feet away took the National League championship pennant away from the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday and gave it to the Chicago team in a deciding game the like of which, for spectacular setting, had never been witnessed in the history of baseball." The vast frenzied crowd that tried to see the game, including one fan who died in the attempt, claimed more ink on the front page than the game itself. The Cubs will face the Tigers in the World Series. The Cubs Win the Pennant
