Illegal doping isn’t the only drug-related quandary in sports, if a new study of World Cup soccer players is any indication. In the study, published this month in the British Journal of Sports Medicine, the world’s best soccer players downed a mix of legal, prescription drugs and nutritional supplements before and during almost every match of the 2002 and 2006 World Cup competitions. Using data supplied by team physicians, the researchers found that on average, each player used about two drugs or supplements per match. Some players were taking as many as seven different legal substances at the same time.

Soccer players are worshiped in Brazil. So it’s fitting that the new soccer museum in Sao Paulo, the first truly national museum of its kind in the soccer-mad country, is like entering a hall filled with busts of Greek gods, The Times reports. Suspended on glass screens some eight feet tall in the darkened chamber are the outlines of a dozen or so of Brazil’s soccer legends in action.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Friday with the continuation of a front-page article about fighting between the Pakistani army and Taliban militants in Pakistan’s tribal regions misstated the location of a Red Cross hospital where a boy shown in the photograph had been treated for shrapnel wounds. It is in the northwest Pakistan city of Peshawar — not Bajaur, a Taliban stronghold near the Afghanistan border where the boy had been wounded.

The Big City column on Sept. 29, about hard times at Jefferson Market, a gourmet grocery in the West Village, misstated the market’s location and the proximity of a competitor, Citarella. Jefferson Market is just north of 10th Street, not 11th, and Citarella is one block south, not two.

An obituary on Sept. 23 about Nancy Hicks Maynard, a newspaper publisher and journalism educator, attributed an erroneous distinction to her, and a correction in this space on Sept. 25 repeated the error. She was one of the first black women to become a reporter at The New York Times, but not the first; at least one, Bernadette Carey, a reporter in society news, preceded her.

An article on Saturday about the tax proposals of Senators Barack Obama and John McCain misidentified the organization that analyzed the impact of their plans on taxpayers. It is the Tax Policy Center — not the Center for Tax Policy, another group that evaluates tax policies.

An article and a picture caption in some editions on Tuesday about the discovery of two rare porcelain fireplace plaques at the Greenpoint Reformed Church in Brooklyn showing Robert Fulton, the 19th-century steamboat designer, and Robert Livingston, his business partner, reversed their identifications. Fulton is the standing figure at left, and Livingston is the one seated.

An article on Wednesday about concerns on Broadway over the possible effects of the financial crisis misstated the status of the revival of “Guys and Dolls.” It is to open March 1 at the Nederlander Theater; it has not been canceled. (More information about the show is in the “Arts, Briefly” column on page C2.).

An article on Friday about signs that Senator Barack Obama is gaining support in Florida because of economic woes misstated the job history of Jim Piccillo, a former Republican who now volunteers for Mr. Obama. Mr. Piccillo says he was laid off while in a training program to become an assistant vice president at a bank; he was not, as he initially said, a bank vice president when he lost his job in August.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about four new books on birds was incomplete. The picture, “Bell’s Vireo” by Rosamond Purcell, showed a Bell’s Vireo nest into which the bird had woven bits of newspaper (including a scrap that mentioned Adolph S. Ochs, founder of the modern New York Times).

Because of an editing error, an exhibition review on Tuesday about “The Dead Sea Scrolls: Mysteries of the Ancient World,” at the Jewish Museum, misstated the surname of one author of the book “The Complete World of the Dead Sea Scrolls” and misspelled the given name and surname of another. In addition to Philip R. Davies, the authors are George J. Brooke (not Brooks) and Phillip R. Callaway (not Philip R. Calaway).

A chart on Oct. 1 with the continuation of a front-page article about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s expected announcement that he would seek a third term misstated the time in office of two previous mayors, George B. McClellan and James J. Walker. McClellan served six years as mayor, not more than seven, and Walker served six years and eight months, not just six.

An obituary on Sept. 29 about Marian Griffiths, the former director of the Sculpture Center in New York, misidentified a gallery where she once worked. She was director of the Amos Eno Gallery; she did not work for the A.I.R. Gallery.

An article on Sept. 25 about indoor plantings in a Manhattan penthouse misidentified the designer who chose plants for the master bathroom. It was r2P Studio, not Diana Balmori, another designer on the project. The article also misstated Ms. Balmori’s title. She is a landscape designer, not a landscape architect.

A picture caption last Thursday with an article about sukkahs, huts built for the Jewish holiday Sukkot, misstated the given name of the 4-month-old son of Michael Zis, who had a sukkah in his backyard. He is Meyer Zis, not Saul.

The Shopping With column last Thursday, about the interior designer David Serrano’s ideas for planning a birthday party, misstated the name of his new home-furnishings shop in Los Angeles. It is Outside Downtown, not Downtown Outdoor.

An article on Sept. 25 about fitness clubs that try to conserve energy misstated the effectiveness of stationary bikes that are connected to generators. Their average energy output per unit of time, 200 watts, is enough to power the gym’s stereo, LCD television and laptop for as long as the bikes are being pedaled — not for just an hour.

Chunks of granite crashed to the Yosemite Valley floor, injuring at least three people and destroying several cabins and trees at one of the park’s most popular lodging areas, officials said. The rock slide was the second in two days in the area called Curry Village, an area defined by dramatic sheer cliffs. The slide destroyed five cabins and partly damaged at least three others, according to a park statement. Three visitors were treated for minor injuries. The volume of rocks cascading from the granite face was estimated at about 1,800 cubic yards, or about 180 truckloads, said Vickie Mates, a park spokeswoman. There was a smaller slide in the same area on Tuesday. In 1996, a rock slide in the same area sent as much as 162,000 tons of rock plummeting more than 2,000 feet, killing one visitor and felling 500 trees. Curry Village, founded in 1899 in south-central Yosemite, has 610 canvas and wood cabins in rows among huge boulders, which geologists say are there because of prehistoric rock falls.

A moment of supersilence, please: In Action Comics No. 870, released on Wednesday, Jonathan Kent, the adoptive father of Superman, suffers a fatal heart attack. His death comes after the supervillain Brainiac attacks the Kent farmhouse in an attempt to hurt Superman; despite all his mighty power, the Man of Steel is unable to save his dad. Superman “lost one of the biggest tethers to Earth and his human life,” said Geoff Johns, the writer of Action Comics. “It’s going to be pretty brutal for him to deal with the fallout.” This is at least the fourth death of Jonathan Kent in the Superman mythos, following previous demises in comic books (in 1939), the “Superman” feature film (in 1978) and the television series “Smallville” (2006). Rest in peace (again), Pa.

Signals were mixed on Wednesday about the progress of ransom negotiations for the arms-laden Ukrainian freighter hijacked by Somali pirates nearly two weeks ago. Associates of the pirates said that a deal to pay them millions of dollars was close and that the freighter would be released. But maritime officials in Kenya said that crucial details, including the pirates' demand for a guarantee that they would not be captured after releasing the freighter, had yet to be worked out. A Western diplomat said the Ukrainians and the pirates were still talking through intermediaries.

ANOTHER DIVISION SERIES The Phillies have won only five pennants, but if they play Tampa Bay in the 2008 World Series, they will be the only team that has faced every team from the same division in the World Series. The Phillies played the Red Sox in 1915, the Yankees in 1950, the Orioles in 1983 and the Blue Jays in 1993. The Phillies could complete their tour of the A.L. East by facing the Rays, who could probably then begin planning a victory parade: the Phillies lost all of those previous World Series, winning only against Kansas City in 1980. TYLER KEPNER

The prime minister of Malaysia, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, said on Wednesday that he would resign in March. His departure is likely to pave the way for his chosen successor to take control of the governing party. Mr. Abdullah, who has been widely criticized in his party and elsewhere for a languid leadership style, has been prime minister for five years. Since he led his party to a narrow election victory in March, calls for his resignation have increased amid ethnic tensions and ire over rising prices. It was not certain that his chosen successor, Deputy Prime Minister Najib Razak, would get the top job. He must first win party elections in March.

PALADE--George. Palade, George Emil-the members of Herzfeld & Rubin, P.C. and its Romanian affiliate Rubin Meyer Doru and Trandafir, spca, join the family and the many distinguished members of the scientific community who mourn the passing on October 8, at age 95. Professor Palade, Romanian born and trained, was the 1974 Noble Prize winner in Physiology-Medicine for his pioneering cell biology studies at the Rockefeller Institute. His seminal contributions continued during his tenure as professor at Yale University and Dean of Scientific Affairs at the University of California at San Diego until his final illness. Our condolences go in particular to his daughter, Georgia Palade van Dusen, son, Professor Philip Palade and to his wife, Professor Marilyn G. Farquhar. Memorial services will be announced by the family. Herbert Rubin, President

WITH high gas prices and a struggling economy, interest in cycling as a way to get around is attracting a new audience. ''Until recently, bike commuting was for the super-dedicated bike person, but that whole notion has been thrown out the window in the last year,'' says Tim Blumenthal, executive director at Bikes Belong, a nationwide cycling advocacy group. ''Now, all kinds of people are riding bikes.'' And products that have been introduced in the last two years have made it easier for even casual pedalers to leave their cars parked and still be able to haul gear and groceries, or take work home without resorting to a sweat-producing backpack or messenger bag.

Daisuke Matsuzaka and James Shields will be the starters when the Boston Red Sox and the Tampa Bay Rays play Game 1 of the American League Championship Series on Friday night in St. Petersburg, Fla. While Matsuzaka was expected to start in the opener, the Red Sox debated who would follow him. Manager Terry Francona could have used Jon Lester, who has become the team's ace, on regular rest in Game 2 on Saturday. But Francona decided to start Josh Beckett, who has a strained oblique muscle, in the second game against Scott Kazmir. Francona will use Lester against Matt Garza in Game 3 on Monday afternoon at Fenway Park. Boston's Tim Wakefield and Tampa Bay's Andy Sonnanstine are slated to start the fourth game Tuesday at Fenway.

Great-grandmother to Hope and William Dejoux, and Chloe Acquavella. The service is private. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to The Edward S. Harkness Eye Institute, 635 West 165th St., Suite 214, NY, NY 10032.

LINDSAY--Lt. Colonel Samuel McCune II, US Army Retired, died on 14 September 2008 in Tenerife, Spain where he resided since his retirement from active duty in 1976. After attending Horace Mann School he graduated from Peekskill Military Academy and the College of William and Mary before joining the Army in 1952. He served in Germany, Korea and Vietnam where he received the Bronze Star for meritorious service. He is survived by his wife, Amy. Interment will be in Union, Connecticut. Sam was a dear friend for many years and he will be missed.

The television audience for the debate between Senators Barack Obama and John McCain grew significantly from their first encounter, but it still paled in comparison with the audience of 73 million that Gov. Sarah Palin and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. attracted last Thursday. Nielsen Media Research reported an audience of 63.2 million for Tuesday's town-hall-style debate. PBS, which was not included in the average, estimated that 2.8 million viewers tuned in. That total viewership of 66 million beat the 55 million who tuned in for the first presidential debate, on Sept. 26.

CERNIA--Professor Enrico., (Naples 1924/Rome 2008), passed away on September 30. A leading scientist and chemist in the fields of polymer and biochemical science and nano technology. Former assistant to Prof. Herman Mark, at Princeton and speaker in numerous American scientific arenas. Professor Cernia taught at the University of Rome for more than 60 years, having been the youngest tenured professor in Italy. Committed intellectual and an activist in the Italian Socialist Party, Prof. Cernia, was a unique human being, gifted with wit and compassion. His wife Elena and daughter Francesca Cernia Slovin, son-in-law Bruce Slovin and granddaughter Karen pay homage to his life.

Springs shoes are noteworthy for their architecture: soaring heights and fretwork. There were the caged booties at Saint Laurent (with evening heels in a silver grid pattern), surrealist wedges at Fendi, and Dior stilettos with heels molded in the shape of African fertility symbols. John Galliano's metal platforms were perplexing as well as noisy as they tapped down the runway; the heel and sole seemed to be reflected duplicated. Hard to tell. Feather pompoms kissed the backs of Chanel's silvery shoes. Louis Vuitton's standout shoes seemed in concert with its sculptural jewelry. Jil Sander's black suede stilettos were shapely and modern, some with a wide strap around the ankles. There were lots and lots of monster-truck platforms-at Dolce, Marni, Cavalli-ready to drive through next spring.

That is what CNBC says about a week that saw the market drop by some 18 percent. Every day brought yet another triple digit loss, the worst being Thursday's 679-point drop. My column on Saturday is a meditation on why human beings -- knowing what we know about the bouts of financial insanity that led to previous bubbles -- can't seem to prevent them from happening. It turns out that preventing crashes is something we're just not able to learn from history.

Transportation | A new study says closing roads might cut congestion. Come again? Yes: Close some roads, and drivers are less likely to bounce around herd-like, clogging up one possible route and then the next. (It never works out that half choose one route, half the other.) You'll have time to absorb this while stuck along your "shortcut" this evening. [Wired]

My colleagues at our Green Inc. blog have posted this week on a heap of themes of interest to Dot Earth:- A report on a debate over international climate policy between Yvo DeBoer, the head of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, and Jeffrey Sachs, the economist who heads Columbia University's Earth Institute. - An exploration of the impact of economic turmoil and dropping oil prices on environmental goals.- A report on a new global database of parks, preserves and other protected areas.- A look at how Poland, the country hosting the next round of climate-treaty talks, is fighting European Union efforts to reform restrictions on greenhouse-gas emissions.

Although the Big 12 is getting a lot of love leading up to Oklahoma/Texas, it wouldn't very well be a big-time Saturday without the SEC getting involved. No big deal, the last two national title winners are only squaring off at night in the Swamp. What's Les Miles going to do for an encore this year? What's that? Florida and L.S.U. not scoring enough points for you? Click on over to Oklahoma State and Missouri during the commercials. That's a game in which one team's starting offense hasn't gone three and out all year and the over-under opened at about 80 points. You know it's a big week when Penn State hosting Wisconsin is an afterthought. Get excited. Week 7 only comes around once a year and this one is going to be fun. Sometimes I wonder about how Formula One intends to "improve the show." Maybe today's practice session was not THE most exciting. But it was interesting. And for me the most interesting point is not that Timo Glock got the fastest time in the Toyota, as it's their home track and who knows what they were doing. But the interesting point is that although we tend to look at the times in the usual way, with the stronger cars at the top - hey, again, Fernando Alonso second fastest as he continues his regain in form since Singapore - and the weaker ones at the bottom (well, all right, not Nick Heidfeld). But read through the lines: There was only one second separating the first car and the 18th car. I haven't had a chance to check it, but Force India called it the tightest practice session all year.

NOT TOO LONG AGO I was on a panel about Internet advertising, and I had nothing to say. I listened blankly while the other panelists debated whether online ads were most effective in "prerolls," which are ads that come up before videos start, or "overlays," which are transparent banners that appear during videos.

The tart is a masterpiece of minimalism. The ingredients for the crust (which is really a big cookie) can be combined in the food processor in about a minute, and the crust itself can be rolled out or simply pressed flat with your fingers. It's covered with thinly sliced apples or pears, and then baked with a little brown sugar and butter. That's it.

FOR CHILDREN BHUTAN! FAMILY DAY (Saturday) Bhutan is a remote kingdom in the Himalayas, but visiting its culture will be easy on Saturday, when the Rubin Museum of Art presents the region's music, stories, crafts and visual art in a celebration connected with its exhibition ''The Dragon's Gift: The Sacred Arts of Bhutan.'' Activities will include spinning Bhutanese-style yarn, designing model fortresses and going on a scavenger hunt. Bhutanese dancers will perform, and Ensemble 3/5pi 4/5 will give a concert of Asian music. From 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., 150 West 17th Street, Chelsea, (212) 620-5000, rmanyc.org. Free with admission: $10; $7 for 65+, middle and high school students and residents of ZIP codes 10011 and 10001; $2 for college students; free for children under 12.

AALL--Christian H. , 95, of Honolulu, Hawaii, formerly of Combloux, France, New York City and Princeton, NJ, passed away on October 5, 2008. He was born in Oslo, Norway, received his Ph.D. in chemical engineering from the University of Grenoble in France, and served in the Royal Norwegian Army in the Resistance Movement and then in England. He moved to the United States in 1947, where he worked in various executive positions, initially at Monsanto Chemical Co. and later at American Metals Climax. On his retirement, mountain climbing became his passion, and he reached the summit of Mont Blanc on his 80th birthday. His wife Sally Sample Ely Aall predeceased him. He will be deeply missed by his four children, Cecilia Mathews, Mea Kaemmerlen, Pamela McPherson and Christian Aall and their spouses, his seven grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren.

MILLS--C. Crawford III, ''Tres'' , 47, of Woodbury, CT, died unexpectedly on Monday October 6, 2008. He was born February 23, 1961 in Los Angeles, CA. A son of Crawford and Mary Wilson Mills, formerly of Riverside, CT and currently residing in Durham, NH. Tres was a graduate of Brunswick School in Greenwich, CT and Ohio Wesleyan University. After graduating college, Tres went onto a long career of acting in theater, television and film. He was the owner of Language Services International, a company that provided spontaneous interpretation services to international and governmental entities. Tres had a passion for justice and an abiding love for his family and friends. He is survived by his parents Mary and Crawford Mills, his sister Amy Mills Cunningham of Durham, NH, his brother Andrew Mills of Los Angeles, CA, his nephews and nieces, James Cunningham and Cecilia Cunningham of Durham, NH, and Frank Mills and Bridget Mills of Los Angeles, CA. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. A funeral service will be held on Saturday October 11, 2008 at 2pm at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, CT. Donations in memory of Tres may be made to the Salvation Army.

I KIFFE NY For many years French culture has been almost synonymous with highbrow -- or, as in the case of films by Godard and music by Piaf, eventually came to be regarded as such. But the large influx of African and Arab immigrants into the poorer neighborhoods outside Paris, unknown to most Americans until the 2005 riots, has redefined French society, and therefore its art.

FLEISSIG--Morris B. , at 93. National leader in public housing, urban renewal and city planning. Vice President of Candeub, Fleissig & Associates, the country's largest planning firm in the 1960s. Predeceased by loving wife, Sylvia. Beloved father of Rosalie Friend, Susan Weltman, and Edythe Sparkman, father-in-law of Alan Friend and Steven Jervis, grandfather of Eric Weltman, Josh Sparkman and Julia Friend, greatgrandfather of Zachary Bennett Weltman. A native of the Lower East Side, he was known for love of family and friends and his great concern for social justice. Contributions in his name are welcome to the Center for an Urban Future (www.nycfuture.org) or Jews for Racial and Economic Justice (www.jfrej.org). Services Sunday, October 12, 9:30am, Plaza Jewish Chapel, 90th Street and Amsterdam.

SMITH--Carter , of Sharon, CT, died suddenly at home on Tuesday, October 7, 2008. Carter was born in Mobile, Alabama on January 14, 1930, the only child of Carter and Sidney Adair Smith. After graduating from The University of the South in Sewanee, Tennessee, he served as a war correspondent in Korea for Stars and Stripes, the U.S. military newspaper. Carter began his career in Chicago working for McCann Erickson Advertising and later for Encyclopedia Britannica. In 1967, he moved to New York, to become Director of Marketing for Time-Life Books. In 1970, he founded Media Projects, Inc., one of the first independent book production companies in the United States, where he served as president for the next 30 years. In 1980, he helped found the American Book Producers Association, and served as its first president. Media Projects specialized in non-fiction illustrated books, ranging from the annual Best of Gourmet cookbook series to numerous history books done in association with the Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution. An avid lover of history and the arts, he served on the Madison Council of the Library of Congress, and on its Acquisitions Committee. He was also a member of The Century Association in New York. Carter is survived by his wife of 49 years, Betsy Covington Smith; his daughter, Adair Smith of Torrington CT; his sons, Carter Smith III of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY and Adam Smith of St. Petersburg, FL; and by four beloved grandchildren. Funeral services will be held October 11th, 11am at Christ Church Sharon. The family requests that any donations in his name be made to The Sharon Historical Society, 18 Main St., Sharon, CT 06069.

Adam Jones, who may be better known for his brushes with the law than for his prodigious football talent, might be in trouble again. The National Football League is investigating an incident in which Jones, the Dallas Cowboys cornerback, got into a scuffle late Tuesday night with a bodyguard assigned to keep him out of trouble. The incident, called a minor disturbance by the police, occurred in a restroom at a Dallas hotel just weeks after Jerry Jones, the Cowboys' owner, told Jones to keep a low profile and avoid situations that could prove troublesome. According to the Dallas police, hotel employees heard a scuffle in the bathroom, but no witnesses came forward to say there was an assault.

PALADE--George . Palade, George Emil-the members of Herzfeld & Rubin, P.C. and its Romanian affiliate Rubin Meyer Doru and Trandafir, spca, join the family and the many distinguished members of the scientific community who mourn the passing on October 8, at age 95. Professor Palade, Romanian born and trained, was the 1974 Noble Prize winner in Physiology-Medicine for his pioneering cell biology studies at the Rockefeller Institute. His seminal contributions continued during his tenure as professor at Yale University and Dean of Scientific Affairs at the University of California at San Diego until his final illness. Our condolences go in particular to his daughter, Georgia Palade van Dusen, son, Professor Philip Palade and to his wife, Professor Marilyn G. Farquhar. Memorial services will be announced by the family. Herbert Rubin, President

HARTFORD--Bill . Our wonderful Bill lost his 12-year battle with non-Hodgkins lymphoma Thursday morning, October 9. Bill had a long career at Popular Mechanics magazine, serving as auto editor and managing editor until his retirement in 1990 when he became a freelance editor and writer. Most recently, Bill was on the masthead of the Battery Park City Broadsheet, contributing local interest stories before 9/ 11, and then continuing to report from his downtown neighborhood after the attacks when home became ground zero. He is survived by his loving wife Shari, daughter Amy, son Chris, daughter - in - law Tammeil, and five grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother, Robert and sister, Doris. Shiva will be at his former residence Saturday, Sunday and Monday, 1-5pm and 7-9pm. The family requests donations be made in his memory to Dr. Bruce G. Raphael, NYU Hematology Research Fund, 160 East 34th Street, New York, NY 10016.

'THE SELFISH GIANT' Children know that giants don't live just in fairy tales. Some occupy every household: though they may seem fundamentally benevolent, they can also be grouchy, peevishly arbitrary, colossally self-absorbed and unable to connect with the young. They're called adults.

NELKIN--Barbara . Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our devoted member. We extend our condolences to her family. Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Richard C. Laskey, President NELKIN--Barbara. We mourn the loss of our dear friend. Knowing her was a privilege and special gift. She will live on in our hearts. Bob, Louise Hersh & family NELKIN--Barbara, passed Wednesday, October 8. She was a loving wife, mother, sister and friend to all who knew her. She was born October 11, 1931, in Brooklyn, NY, with a childhood spent in Middlebury, VT. She graduated from Tilden High School in Brooklyn, NY and earned her bachelors degree in education from Adelphi University in Garden City, NY. She began her career as an elementary school teacher. Barbara was absolutely beautiful and glamorous. The first things you'd noticed about her were her blue eyes and gorgeous smile. She was known for her impeccable taste, her tremendous intellect and quick wit. She was a perfectionist and a stickler for detail, Barbara was a racious and dignified woman. Loved by many, all of who were considered and treated as extended family. She was a generous, compassionate woman and supporter of many charities. Wife of the late Myron Nelkin; survived by their children, Mindy Nelkin, Henry L. Nelkin, Cathy Nelkin Miller and her husband Charles Miller; cherished grandchildren, Rachel, John and James Schwartz and Robert Miller; brother, Robert Norinsberg; brother and sister-in-law, William and Trudi Nelkin; cousin of the late Sheila Fink (wife of Dr. Victor Fink); loving aunt to Michael and Jon Norinsberg, Michael, Barbara Rose, and the late Laurie Nelkin, Dr. Nancy Levine, Dr. Robert Fink and Branwen Jones. All of her children and grandchildren have inherited her talents. She was a gifted artist, with an extraordinary sense of color and design. She had the most beautiful singing voice, and a passion for the arts. Barbara was the epitome of grace and elegance. Her style was emulated by all who knew and loved her. A graveside service will be held Friday, October 10, at 12:45pm at the Beth David Cemetery (300 Elmont Rd, Elmont, NY. 516-328-1300). Immediately following the service there will be a reception in honor of Barbara in the Cotillion Suite at The Garden City Hotel (2nd floor) from 2pm-6pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the following; Temple Sinai (Roslyn), North Shore Hospital (Manhasset) or Tilles Center for the Performing Arts.

In a victory for antigovernment demonstrators, a Thai appeals court on Thursday dropped charges of treason against nine leaders of a protest at the prime minister's office compound, calling evidence against them too ''vague.'' The court upheld a charge of inciting unrest. Six of the leaders then turned themselves in to the authorities on lesser charges Friday, though they expect to be released on bail. In a separate ruling, a criminal court on Thursday allowed bail for the top leader of the protest, Chamlong Srimuang, 73, a former army general who was arrested Sunday.

SMITH--Marity B. , October 8th, 2008. Beloved wife of Michael, cherished daughter of Rita and the late James Brody. Loving sister of Megan, William and the late Dr. James Brody and borther-inlaw Peter Chernin. Adored niece of Mary P. Brody. Favorite aunt of her nieces and nephews. Friends may call Friday, October 10th, 6-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, October 11th, 9:30am at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue and 84th Street. SMITH--Marity B. The members and staff of the New York Bankers Association (NYBA) mourn the sudden passing of Marity Smith, beloved wife of our President and CEO Michael P. Smith. Marity was an enthusiastic and energetic member of the NYBA family, and she will be greatly missed.
ART Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

GOTTLIEB--Suzanne (Rosenwasser) , passed away on October 8, 2008. Survived by much loved family, son Jonathan Gottlieb and daughter-in-law Elisabeth Youngerman of Hamden, CT, granddaughter Annie Gottlieb Youngerman, dearest cousins, and the very best of friends. She will be missed.

The current global crisis and the Asian/Russian/Latin American crisis of the late 90s have a lot in common, although there are also some big differences. Some of my more wonkish readers might be interested in an Asian-crisis-model paper I wrote in 1999, which stressed balance sheets and leverage. Because I had Indonesia on my mind, the foreign exchange market, rather than the mortgage-backed-securities market, was at the heart of the story. But there's a clear family resemblance. The paper (pdf) is here.

We can no longer look at the differences between Formula One teams as being phenomenally large. These days we tend to keep the same paradigm in our minds about the top teams and the rest. But yesterday's practice session, and now today's qualifying session, have shown just how close the performances are between the Formula One cars today. It's no good laughing at Force India as being an eternal tail-ender and way off the mark, when we know that although they finished last and second last in the first qualifying period, Adrian Sutil, in 19th place was only 1 second off Lewis Hamilton, in the fastest spot. Likewise, in the second qualifying period, David Coulthard missed the top 10 by .08 seconds, while Mark Webber in the other Red Bull, finished 13th by being less than .2 off his teammate. In the final qualifying period the top eight drivers were all within the same .6 of a second.This is all so insanely close when you really think about it, that it really makes you open your eyes about what the teams are achieving up and down the grid. How frustrating it must be for the teams at the back to know that they are only a second off the leaders. Remember the days of the six second differences?

Media | A columnist looks askance at journalism that finds silver linings in the scary downturn (like all those stories suggesting it might be good for your health). Television | Branded entertainment now "involves not merely sponsored props but elaborate interweavings of brands into scripts, ads indistinguishable from the show itself." For this you can thank cheap reality shows and their "integrated sponsorships," which changed the economics of scripted TV shows. Adapt or get voted off the prime-time lineup. [New York]

A mob was fought off yesterday at the county jail in Spartanburg, S.C., by a sheriff and his deputies, who last night were reinforced by state troops. In the the jail was an African-American, John Irby, accused of "making an attack on Miss Lillie Dempsey in the outskirts of the city. The young woman was not seriously hurt." The article as written assumes Irby is guilty. Three rioters and the sheriff were wounded by gunfire. Also being held in the jail were two more African-Americans: John Foster, described as "twice convicted" of killing John Young, a white man, and Clarence Agnew, awaiting trial on charges of causing a train wreck that killed an engineer and a fireman. The article also assumes that Agnew is guilty. It was feared that if undeterred, the mob would lynch all three of the men in jail. Mob Fights Troops to Get At Negro

An article in some editions on Friday about a rise in the number of Con Edison customers whose electricity has been shut off for nonpayment misstated the time frame, using information from the utility, during which those shutoffs occurred. In September alone — not the 12 months through September — 9,639 residential customers lost their electricity. And, again, in September alone — not from January through September — 342,073 residential customers were in arrears for more than 60 days.
An article on Friday about the stock market’s plunge misstated the number of shares that were traded on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday. It was nearly 8.3 billion — not million.

An article on Friday about entertainment bargains in New York referred incorrectly to a ticket discount at the New York Theater Workshop. Tickets are $20 for Sunday evening performances, but not for Sunday matinees.
A brief art review on Friday about a show of the work of Stan VanDerBeek, at the Guild & Greyshkul gallery in SoHo, misstated the gallery’s address. It is 28 Wooster Street, not 328.

The Advertising column on Sept. 30, about the Wachovia Corporation’s suspending a decision to hire new agencies after reaching an agreement to be acquired by Citigroup, misstated the name of one of the WPP Group agencies that would have worked for Wachovia. It is Maxus, not Maxum. (Wachovia has since entered into a new agreement to be acquired by Wells Fargo.).

An article on Oct. 3 about the discovery of remains at the crash site of a plane flown by the millionaire adventurer Steve Fossett misidentified the device that signals an aircraft’s location after a crash. It is an Emergency Locator Transmitter — not a transponder, which helps ground-based controllers locate and identify an airplane in flight.

An obituary on Oct. 2 about Elinor Guggenheimer, a New York City civic leader, misstated the year that her off-Broadway musical spoof, “Potholes,” was produced at the Cherry Lane Theater. It was 1979, not 1983.

Senator John McCain may have had some luck at the gambling tables. But one watchdog group thinks he needs to report his gambling winnings to the federal government. MAIORANA--Ronald. Anthony L. Watson, CEO and Chair, the Board of Directors and staff of EmblemHealth, the parent company of HIP Health Insurance Plan of New York and GHI, mourn the passing of Ronald Maiorana, a retired senior vice president of public affairs and a consultant to EmblemHealth at the time of his death. A former reporter for the New York Times and later press secretary and advisor to New York Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller, he was 78 and died Thursday after a short illness at his home in East Quogue. Mr. Maiorana joined The Times as a copy boy in 1951 as a college freshman in night school and was promoted to reporter in 1955, covering a broad range of assignments in the New York metropolitan area and in Albany. He left The Times in 1968 to join Governor Rockefeller as an assistant press secretary. In 1969, the Governor appointed Mr. Maiorana as his press secretary and principal spokesperson. He accompanied the Governor on government and political trips across the nation and throughout South America. After Governor Rockefeller left office, Mr. Maiorana served as New York State Commissioner of Wagering Systems (1974-1975). He then joined the New York State Special Prosecutor for the Criminal Justice System as a director (1975-1976). He later worked with political consultants David Garth and Maureen Connelly on the U.S. Senate campaign of H. John Heinz of Pennsylvania and on all of Rudolph Giulianis campaigns for Mayor of New York City. He joined the administration of Mayor Giuliani as a senior advisor in 1994 and was appointed Commissioner of the New York City Community Assistance Unit in 1995. He left his city position to join HIP as a managing consultant for public affairs in 1996 and joined the health care company's executive staff full time in 1998. He retired April 30, 2007. At HIP, he was a trusted advisor to CEO Anthony L. Watson during a period of profound change in the firm, culminating with the affiliation with GHI to form EmblemHealth earlier this year. Mr. Maiorana also was a talented artist, an avocation he pursued for 60 years, opening his first exhibit AbstRactions in July. Two of his abstracts on canvas are in the Nelson Rockefeller collection. The EmblemHealth family extends its prayers and best wishes to Mr. Maiorana's family: his son Ronald Peter Maiorana and wife, Kelly Allman, and daughters Linda Catherine Williams and her husband Trevor Williams, and Janice Virginia Maiorana-Browne, and her husband Christopher Browne, and Mr. Maiorana's brother Victor and his wife, Rosalie. His wife, Phyllis, was killed accidentally when struck by a branch that fell from a tree on September 11, 2002. They had been married 47 years. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Little Flower Children and Family Services of Wading River, New York 11792. Friends may call Sunday from 2pm to 6pm at Fred H. McGrath's Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street, Bronxville, 914 337-6770. A Memorial Service will be conducted Monday at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, 15 Cedar Street, Bronxville, with interment at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla to follow.

SMITH--Carter, of Sharon, CT, died suddenly at home on Tuesday, October 7, 2008. Carter was born in Mobile, Alabama on January 14, 1930, the only child of Carter and Sidney Adair Smith. After graduating from The University of the South in Sewanee, Tennessee, he served as a war correspondent in Korea for Stars and Stripes, the U.S. military newspaper. Carter began his career in Chicago working for McCann Erickson Advertising and later for Encyclopedia Britannica. In 1967, he moved to New York, to become Director of Marketing for Time-Life Books. In 1970, he founded Media Projects, Inc., one of the first independent book production companies in the United States, where he served as president for the next 30 years. In 1980, he helped found the American Book Producers Association, and served as its first president. Media Projects specialized in non-fiction illustrated books, ranging from the annual Best of Gourmet cookbook series to numerous history books done in association with the Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution. An avid lover of history and the arts, he served on the Madison Council of the Library of Congress, and on its Acquisitions Committee. He was also a member of The Century Association in New York. Carter is survived by his wife of 49 years, Betsy Covington Smith; his daughter, Adair Smith of Torrington CT; his sons, Carter Smith III of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY and Adam Smith of St. Petersburg, FL; and by four beloved grandchildren. Funeral services will be held October 11th, 11am at Christ Church Sharon. The family requests that any donations in his name be made to The Sharon Historical Society, 18 Main St., Sharon, CT 06069.

Minnesota's highly competitive race for the Senate took another twist Friday when Senator Norm Coleman, the Republican incumbent trying to hold off his Democratic challenger, Al Franken, below right, announced that he was ordering all of his negative campaign advertising off the air. It is a risky move given that it could leave Mr. Coleman, below center, who has fallen behind in at least one poll, unable to level criticism at his opponent, the former comedy writer and radio talk show host. But it could also pay dividends given that Minnesota voters have been bombarded with negative advertisements from both candidates and independent groups and are no doubt tired of them, particularly with the financial crisis spreading.

A hot-air balloon crashed into power lines on Friday during Albuquerque's annual balloon festival and burst into flames. The two men aboard were thrown to the ground, and one of them was killed. Witnesses said that winds had picked up a bit and that many of the balloons were flying low just before the Wings of Wind balloon crashed in Bernalillo, just north of Albuquerque. The balloonist who was killed was identified as Stephen Lachendro of Butler, Pa.; his colleague, Keith Sproul of North Brunswick, N.J., was critically injured.

Campaign buttons are a staple of any political season, but this year they are also central to yet another dispute about the rights of classroom teachers. The dispute has both a K-12 and a college version. In New York City, Department of Education Chancellor Joel Klein announced that his administration would enforce a longstanding policy prohibiting teachers from wearing campaign buttons when they are at work. In Illinois, the state university ethics office stated in its newsletter that faculty are barred not only from wearing campaign buttons in the classroom, but also from placing political bumper stickers on their cars and attending political rallies on campus.

Three of the Top 5 teams -- No. 1 Oklahoma, No. 3 Missouri and No. 4 L.S.U. have gone down, and the sport ends another binge of unexpected results with some Sunday morning uncertainty.
Florida’s victory over L.S.U., No. 5 Texas’ 45-35 victory over No. 1 Oklahoma and No. 17 Oklahoma State’s 28-23 road upset of No. 3 Missouri provided yet another day of chaos.

Two minutes after take-off in an international balloon race yesterday, a balloon with two Americans aboard burst at an altitude of 4,000 feet over the Berlin suburb of Schmargendorf, plunged 2,000 feet "like a bullet, the aeronauts clinging to the overhead ring, and then the torn silk spread out like a parachute and the rapidity of the descent was checked." The balloonists, A. Holland Forbes and Augustus C. Post, "escaped with slight injuries" after the basket they were riding in "smashed into the roof of a house." Two other American balloons are competing in the three-day race, which started with 23 entries. It is the second part of a three-race competition for the James Gordon Bennett Cup. Michael Rhoads’s recipe, while undoubtedly absolutely delicious, is not challah (Food: Recipe Redux, Sept. 28). Challah, a ceremonial bread eaten for Sabbath and holiday meals, must be parve, that is, without dairy or meat ingredients. This is because of the biblical prohibition against mixing dairy- and meat-based foods in the same meal. Most major holiday meals feature some kind of meat, and the bread needs to be compatible. So basically no butter in challah, unless you want to call it coffee cake.

David Leonhardt states that Phil Gramm, the former senator, was largely responsible for the Commodity Futures Modernization Act (Reconsideration, Sept. 28). He would have provided useful perspective by noting that under the first President Bush, Gramm’s wife, Wendy, headed the Commodity Futures Trading Commission when it exempted Enron and other energy companies from regulation in trading on energy derivatives, after which she joined Enron’s board, serving on its audit committee.

A recent high-profile U.S. Senate race does not support William Safire’s suggestion that when race is involved, voters lie to pollsters about their intentions (On Language, Sept. 28). In Tennessee’s 2006 race, the Chattanooga mayor, Bob Corker, beat Representative Harold Ford Jr. by 50,000 votes, or 2.7 percent. The day before the election, one poll had Corker up by 4 percent, another by 3 percent.

Noah Feldman frames his discussion of the Medellín v. Texas case in terms of whether U.S. laws should supersede a decision by the International Court of Justice (Sept. 28). I believe the issue was much narrower. The Constitution clearly states that “all treaties made . . . under the authority of the United States, shall be the supreme law of the land; and the judges in every state shall be bound thereby, any thing in the Constitution or laws of any state to the contrary notwithstanding.” The Supreme Court should have ruled that the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations was clearly the law of the land, and that they themselves and the state of Texas were bound by the provisions of that treaty, including the right of accused foreign nationals to consular access. Both the U.S. Supreme Court and the state of Texas violated their constitutional obligations with respect to Medellín.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about whether Americans’ faith in the free market would be shaken by the credit crisis misattributed a quotation about the belief that a more regulated economy is likely to emerge. It was Jeffrey Garten, a professor at the Yale School of Management, who said: “I’m scared about the next year but I’m very optimistic we’ll come out of this in good shape. We very well may come out of this horrible situation with a better version of American capitalism — it’ll be a little tamer; it’ll be a little more regulated.” The comment was not by David Ruder, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and now a professor emeritus at the Northwestern University School of Law.

An article on Sept. 28 about the history of Pakistan’s lawless border areas misidentified the position held by the top interior ministry official in Pakistan’s new government. The official, Rehman Malik, is the senior adviser in the ministry, not the interior minister. The article also misspelled the middle name of the prime minister. He is Yousaf Raza Gilani, not Yousaf Raja Gilani.

An article on Sept. 28 about the designer Jean-Paul Gaultier’s favorite places in Paris misstated the Web address of the Crazy Horse, a cabaret. It is www.lecrazyhorseparis.com. And a map with the article misstated the name of one of his favorites and misspelled the name of another. One place is the Galeries de Paléontologie et d’Anatomie Comparée, not Galeries de Palétontologie et d’Anatomie, and another is Le Grand Rex, not Le Grande Rex.

Two years ago, the New York City chef Christine Carroll was painting a New Orleans high school with a post-Katrina volunteer group when she realized that she was no painter. But she could cook; so could everyone she knew. And New Orleans needed nourishment. Once home, she started organizing CulinaryCorps, a charity that recruits squads of chefs and culinary students for weeklong trips to New Orleans, where they might be asked to cook dinner for a Habitat for Humanity crew one night and the still-stoveless residents of the Lower Ninth Ward the next. Mornings are spent volunteering: teaching elementary-school kids about growing vegetables or helping to recover flood-damaged cookbooks from venerated restaurants. The focus is not just on feeding the hungry but also on keeping the city's food traditions alive. ''We give them our version of shrimp and grits, and then when they come back for seconds, they share their secret family recipes,'' says Carroll. Of the 75 chefs who have gone through the program, two have moved to New Orleans to make culinary philanthropy -- or ''culanthropy'' -- a full-time project. Next year, Carroll says, she hopes to take her Sauciers Sans Frontières idea to places like Appalachia and Puerto Rico. ADAM FISHER

An initiative in Chad and Darfur is taking the low-tech concept of solar cooking to a higher level. Run by Jewish World Watch, a coalition of Los Angelesarea synagogues founded in 2004 to address modern genocide, the Solar Cooker Project provides refugee-camp residents with the materials -- aluminum foil, cardboard and glue -- to build cookers.Thirty dollars covers the cost of two cookers, cloth potholders -- and training. Harnessing the sun's energy doesn't just mean fewer girls searching for firewood (often putting them at risk of being raped along the way) and fewer people suffering from the injuries associated with live-fire cooking; it also provides relief for the denuded Chadian and Sudanese countryside. The nearly-three-year-old project has supplied and trained more than 10,000 women and girls in the Iridimi and Touloum camps and recently began work with 28,000 residents of the Oure Cassoni camp. In Iridimi, trips to collect firewood have decreased by 86 percent. The program director, Rachel Andres, who was recently awarded the Charles Bronfman Prize for her work, says it's been successful ''because it's so simple,'' she said. ''You realize that, yes, all the other pieces of fighting this genocide are important -- it's important to write letters to the head of the U.N. and to President Bush and to members of Congress and to anyone who will listen -- but this is one area in which you can do something concrete.'' JOCELYN CRAUGH ZUCKERMAN

CUT AND SPLURGE This question will no doubt arise this week at a conference on ''Media and Money'' in New York: Which media and entertainment companies are most vulnerable in a downturn? One of the participants in the conference, sponsored by Dow Jones and Nielsen, will be John S. Riccitiello, chief executive of the video game maker Electronic Arts. Interviewed last week, he said the industry was in ''an expanding period, driven by new technology, new platforms'' and wider adoption of broadband. ''Historically those factors have been 5 to 10 times more important than underlying economic trends.''

He is survived by his mother, his brother Monte Van Norden (Kathy) of Concord, MA, and his two sisters, Kristina Anderson (John) of Telluride, CO and Juliana Van Norden (Craig Wynne) of Westport, CT. He is also survived by six devoted nieces and nephews. Adam was a gentle soul who was loved by all. His loss will be felt always. ''Good night sweet prince and flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.'' We love you

Last April, after winning a competition at the University of Wisconsin School of Business, Keith Agoada, who was then still a student, decided to turn his sustainable-urban-farming plan into a business and created Sky Vegetables. The concept takes advantage of the ''fields'' of flat rooftops found atop supermarkets by using that space to grow crops. Agoada says Sky Vegetables will have benefits beyond sustainable local produce. The plants and greenhouses will absorb sunlight, making it easier for supermarkets to cool their buildings; in the winter they will add insulation. And an heirloom tomato grown a few feet up from the aisle in which it's sold won't come with any guilt-inducing air miles. The farms will use rainwater for irrigation and solar panels for some of their energy needs. No greenhouses have been installed yet, but Agoada and his partner say they hope to begin construction on a prototype next year; they are currently talking to supermarkets in the Bay Area. LIA MILLER

LITTLEFIELD--William Rose. Bill died peacefully September 29. He was 82 and lived a full rich life. He was devoted to Karen Marshall, his partner of 33 years. He was incredibly proud of his children, Josh and wife Kate, their children Molly, Jordan and Hank; his daughter Amy and husband Mike Norton, and their children Zack and Emma. His brothers Donald and wife Lydia and Brad; and sister Isobel and husband Don Shapleigh; and many nieces and nephews survive him. Bill loved, loved words and traveling the world. He was always ready for a new adventure. He shared his curiosity and enthusiasms with as many people as possible. He wrote children's books and had a long career writing and directing industrial films and print work. For the past 12 years he was a dedicated volunteer literacy tutor for the New York Public Library at the Saint Agnes Center for Reading and Writing. As Francis Bacon wrote, ''Reading maketh a full man, conference a ready man, and writing an exact man.... Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested.'' Bill spent his life happily chewing and digesting and helping others to do the same. He will be missed by so many. He leaves an emptiness that will be hard to fill. Bill's family and friends will gather to celebrate his life Saturday November 8 from 36pm. Call 212-663-8327 for details. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Public Library, Harlem Center for Reading and Writing c/o The Friends Office, 476 5th Ave. Room 6, New York, NY 10018.

MCLAUGHLIN--Peter J., 80, of Ft. Myers, FL passed away September 20, 2008. He was born July 21, 1928 in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by a sister, Julia Powers of Ft. Myers, FL, nieces and a nephew. Also, survived by wife Helen of Kinnelon, NJ. Peter Mclaughlin's career with Union Camp Corp. began in 1945 as a ditto machine operator. He retired as Chairman and CEO of Union Camp Corp., a Fortune 500 Company in 1985. Union Camp was acquired by the International Paper Company in 1999. He was a retired director, Mutual Benefit Life, First Fidelity Bancorp of NJ, and the American Paper Institute. He earned a B.B.A. from Pace University in 1954, and a J.D. from Fordham University School of Law in 1960. He served in the U.S. Army from 1954 to 1956 including one year at 8th Army Headquarters in Korea. After retirement he lived in the Landings near Savannah, GA and Tiburon and San Francisco, Naples, FL and Ft. Myers, FL.

In April, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals offered $1 million to the first successful candidate to produce a commercially viable chicken product in a laboratory -- real chicken, but without killing a chicken. The idea isn't just science fiction. In 2005, the Dutch government gave a grant of 1.7 million euros to three universities to pursue ''in vitro'' meat research in the hope that a commercially acceptable product might come to replace slaughterhouses and feedlots. The basic science draws on the work of tissue engineers who have created skin and cartilage by cultivating stem cells in a growth medium. There are several technological obstacles to applying this to meat. The most cost-effective growth medium on the market at the moment is made from fetal calf's blood -- hardly animal friendly. And if the new cultivated meat cells are not properly stretched and stimulated -- mimicking muscle activity -- the resulting product has a stomach-churning consistency that one tissue scientist described as ''jelly on fabric.'' Oron Catts, a biologist and artist at the University of Western Australia, grew some small frog steaks in vitro several years ago and set up a performance-art piece where eight people sat down to have them for dinner. Four of the diners spat their portions out. Catts got his steak down, but he has been a vegetarian ever since. CHARLES WILSON

An art entry in the Week Ahead report on Sept. 14 and a review in the Weekend section on Sept. 19 attributed an erroneous distinction to the survey of Giorgio Morandi's works at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The exhibition is the second Morandi retrospective in the United States, not the first. (The Des Moines Art Center organized a Morandi survey that traveled to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the Guggenheim Museum in 1981 before being shown in Iowa in 1982.)

He graduated from Seton Hall University in 1952, was a veteran of World War II and held a variety of positions at United Parcel Services Manhattan and Greenwich, CT headquarters for 31 years, retiring in 1987. He is survived by his beloved wife Gloria (nee Witzmann) of Monroe, CT, cherished children Robert and Karen of Shelton, CT, Richard and Melissa of Newtown, CT and Ken of Monroe, CT and his five beautiful grandchildren Michael, Kristen, Arianna, Aidan and Addison. He is also survived by his most precious sisters Ceil Crawford of Palm City, FL, Marjorie Litcholt of Neptune City, NJ and Louise Porcelli (Pete) of Iselin, NJ, as well as many nephews and nieces. There are about 1,300 seed banks around the world, repositories in which plant seeds are preserved for future study and use. They house anywhere from a few hundred to more than half a million samples. The Global Crop Diversity Trust, a nonprofit organization based in Rome that is involved in running Svalbard Global Seed Vault in Norway, is spearheading an effort to connect these far-flung inventories into one easily searchable, public, online database. ''In the context of climate change or a new disease striking a crop, it's incredibly inefficient to search for the genetic resources you need gene bank by gene bank,'' says Cary Fowler, executive director of the organization. Users will be able to type criteria into a search engine and learn the location of a sample. Fowler estimates that in three years the database will encompass several million seed types, tissue cultures and tubers -- a majority of the diversity of the world's major crops. LIA MILLER (MM74)

TRICARD--Louise Mead. Cape Canaveral, FL, 72, passed away on Tuesday, September 30, 2008, in the Bronx, NY, after a long, courageous battle with cancer. Louise was born September 26, 1936, in Manhattan, NY. She was predeceased by her parents, Edna Hawelka Mead and Clarence Mead, and her husband, John. She is survived by her sister, Jane Peter and nephew Jonathan Peter of South Salem, NY. Louise received a B.A. in 1958 and M.S. in 1961, Hunter College, and M.Ed. in 1974, Columbia University. Louise loved Persian cats and Greece; but her life was track and field. As a member of the NYC PAL track team, her track highlights included being on the 1959 Pan American Team, representing the US in the 200 meters and setting an A.A.U. American Indoor record in the 440 yard run in 1960. Louise developed the New York State high school program for girls track in 1975, and in 1976 founded the Empire Track and Field Camp for Girls. She managed US teams, nationally and internationally, from 1978-1987. Louise was inducted into the Hunter College Athletic Hall of Fame in 1988. After retirement as a NYS guidance counselor, she participated in the Masters National and World Championships and worked with the USA Track and Field Association. In 1992 she received the Athletics Congress/USA Presidents Award. In 2000, at the age of 64, Louise completed the NYC marathon. As a track historian, Louise Mead Tricard authored many articles and two books, ''American Women's Track and Field, A History, 1895 through 1980;'' second volume ''1981-2000.'' A burial service will be held on Friday, October 17, 2008 at 1pm at Florida National Cemetery in Bushnell, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent, in Louise's name, to Florida Athletics, Inc., 3250 Lakeview Boulevard, Delray Beach, FL 33445 or Louise Mead Tricard Girls' Track & Field Scholarships, Armory Foundation, 216 Fort Washington Ave., NY, NY 10032.

Because of a condition called micronutrient malnutrition, the global food crisis, even if it eases soon, will have repercussions for decades to come. This so-called ''hidden hunger,'' which stems from a lack of vitamins and minerals in the diet, can leave children blind, permanently lower their I.Q.'s and make them targets for long-term illnesses and early death. Cheap, filling staples like maize, beans and cassava have long been mainstays of the poor, which is why the agricultural economist Howarth Bouis thought to breed micronutrients directly into those crops in the early '90s. Today HarvestPlus, the nonprofit that Bouis founded in 2003, operates in 50 countries and has plans to release seven ''biofortified'' crops within five years. ''Biofortification is really the last hope for the poorest of the poor,'' says Fil Randazzo, a senior program officer at the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, which has contributed $38 million to HarvestPlus over the last five years. Bouis's idea is sowing seeds of change: just a few months ago, biofortification -- which is achieved through conventional breeding, though HarvestPlus devotes a fraction of its resources to research into genetic modification -- took the No. 5 slot at the Copenhagen Consensus, a meeting of economists that prioritizes solutions to global challenges based on a cost-benefit analysis. JOCELYN CRAUGH ZUCKERMAN

MILLAR--Onaway, 89, artist, poet and inspiration to all who knew her, is free from the weight of the world. Loved by daughter Laurie, family and devoted friends... Beautiful, luminous, Onaway! Your creative spirit remains! 2+2=5!

In college, Severine von Tscharner Fleming's ''violent allergic reaction to L.A.'' drove her to help set up a guerrilla farming club, visit farmers on the West Coast in a vegetable-oil pickup truck and form the Society for Agriculture and Food Ecology at the University of California, Berkeley. Now von Tscharner Fleming, the child of urban planners from Cambridge, Mass., wants her peers to get dirty. ''Farming is an attractive path for people who are getting out of school and feeling like there's kind of a toxic consumerism and not feeling too excited about working for the Man, especially seeing as he's been spoiling our politics and a lot of our ecology,'' she said. She started serveyourcountryfood.net, an interactive map charting farmers under 40, and is making ''The Greenhorns,'' a documentary on ''organic entrepreneurs.'' ''I want to show how sweet and honest and brave and purposeful they are,'' she said of her subjects. With an office in the village of Red Hook and farmland she is renting in the Hudson River Valley, von Tscharner Fleming knows she needs to go beyond the field in order to effect real policy change: ''They're making some kind of sausage in Washington, and I felt like some young farmer flavor would be appropriate.'' Anna Lappé didn't know it when she read Bryant Terry's name in the ''Future 500,'' a who's-who of youth advocates and organizations, but she would end up writing a book with him. The pair, who were then neighbors in Brooklyn, published ''Grub: Ideas for an Urban Organic Kitchen'' in 2006 as a way to cool-ify healthful, local, sustainable food, with a side of social justice. It was an easy fit. Lappé is the daughter of Frances Moore Lappé, whose 1971 best seller, ''Diet for a Small Planet,'' changed how people thought about world hunger; the two created the Small Planet Institute in 2001 to foster what they call ''a living democracy.'' At that time, Terry -- moved by the fact that the inner-city children in his workshops ate the ''worst possible food'' -- founded b-healthy! to teach low-income children the importance of fresh food.

JONES--Carlisle, 80, of New York, NY and Lawrenceville, NJ died at his home in New York City on October 9. He is survived by his wife Jeanne M. His children DeborahSteven Lupton, Leslie-John Brittain, Geoffrey Jones-Caroline Jones, Elizabeth-Tyler Hall and Andrew Jones. Stepchildren Joseph Fusco Pamela, William Fusco, John Fusco, Thomas Fusco-Laurie, Stephen Fusco and Julie Lanning-Michael. He also leaves behind 26 grandchildren. Carlisle had a long and distinguished career as an Investment advisor with A.W. Jones, S.W. Seligman City Associates, Brimberg and Company and Invemed and Co. He was a member of the New York Stock Exchange for over 30 years. He was renowned for his idea sharing round table and as a great mentor. Carlisle was an avid hunter and fisherman and a lover of the great outdoors. He will be fondly remembered by all those he touched, for his wonderful sense of humor and the joyful way he journeyed through life. Beyond farmers' markets, beyond organic-everything, beyond the newly fashionable Victory Garden lies the eco-fringe: urban homesteading. The idea is to get off the grid while living in a city. There are two new books on the subject, Kelly Coyne and Erik Knutzen's how-to guide, ''The Urban Homestead,'' and Novella Carpenter's forthcoming ''FarmCity,'' a memoir. Home growing is a first step, but backyard livestock is the real aim: bees, quail, chickens, duck and rabbits. Foraging is the next frontier. Coyne and Knutzen encourage throwing seed balls (''the Molotov cocktail of the urban homesteader'') into vacant lots; viewing dumpsters as akin to fruit trees; and thinking of edible weeds as ''a very casual crop.'' Martha Stewart it's not. There is a radical vibe, and some of the most extreme practices -- composting your own waste into ''humanure'' for example -- are technically illegal. But the rest of it is home economics as our great-grandparents knew it: composting, canning, pickling, wild yeasts, mail-order seeds, brewing and even making moonshine

DAVID STEELE was tired. He slumped on the subway platform bench, elbows on knees, his white tank top plastered to his sweaty back and streaked with grime. He had been underground for two hours, riding downtown and uptown on the Nos. 4 and 5 express trains. He had $123 to show for it: a good day. Many a New York artist has claimed to be the hardest-working person in showbiz, but Mr. Steele, 30, should make any short list. His many hats include entrepreneur, comedian and manager. But at heart he is a dancer, one who performs at least 30 times in a midday shift, sometimes twice that if he does a night shift.

BAWN-HUFFORD-Elizabeth, died September 30, 2008 at St. Vincent's Hospital. Mother of Peter Daniel Kirsch and John Christopher Kirsch. Born Elizabeth Ann (Betty) Bawn in St. Louis, November 7, 1932. Attended St. Joseph's Academy-Fontbonne, St. Louis University (Commerce and Finance) and Washington University (Fine Arts) in St. Louis. Arrived hometown Manhattan to live on her own November, 1953, knowing no one, but with a couple of phone numbers. Within a week she'd been photographed by Richard Avedon and befriended by some good people of talent. Worked as a high-fashion runway model, fashion reporter and fashion publicist. In the mid-fifties, she and her first husband founded a travel agency which accepted international clients by referral only. Their 54th / Madison Avenue office was a daily gathering spot for industrialists as well as nobility, stage and film stars, visual artists, great composers and lyricists. In the mid-sixties, Elizabeth was an award-winning copywriter with deGarmo, Grey and BBDO, whose contributions made some of the most successful campaigns possible. In the 1980s and 1990s she was the voice on many national TV and radio commercials. During the SAG/AFTRA commercials strike of April, 1988, Elizabeth a trained mason under the aegis of BAC local 34 worked as a bricklayer on the ABC building at 67th/Columbus. She also worked as a bartender, Pratt Institute professor, sales rep, hospital staff secretary, purchasing agent, but it was always writing that was integral to Elizabeth's being. All the others were simply good jobs. For the past 20 years, Elizabeth was a Sunday Lector at the Church of St. Thomas More and was a yoga teacher (Parashkti) at the Integral Yoga Institute. A longtime Mensa member, life member of SAG and AFTRA, Equity. Funeral private. No flowers. No memorial planned at this time. It was Elizabeth's specific wish that anyone who remembers her have a good meal with one(s) you love. Anyone wishing to donate, Elizabeth's favorites: New York Society Library, The Doe Fund, Bide-a-Wee. Survived by beloved son Peter, Sindee Sours and former husband Robert Garlick.

Communities are supporting all kinds of agriculture these days. C.S.A.'s -- short for community-supported agriculture, in which members pay a share of the costs of running a farm in return for a portion of the farm's bounty -- have traditionally offered only produce, but today some include items like milk, eggs, grains, honey and meats. And now there are C.S.F.'s, community-supported fisheries. With advance payment, members receive a portion of their local fisherman's weekly catch. C.S.F.'s are thriving in four coastal towns in Maine -- there are even two lobster C.S.F.'s. The term ''community supported'' is now being applied beyond fields and oceans. With no membership fee, customers of Berkeley's Three Stone Hearth, which calls itself a community-supported kitchen, can buy as little or as much as they choose from a weekly changing menu of traditional, nutritious, homemade meals. Clients are invited to assist in the kitchen and to attend monthly farmers' dinners. For Jessica Prentice and her four Three Stone Hearth co-founders, ''there was a missing link between all the wonderful foods in a C.S.A. box and dinner on the table,'' Prentice said. ''Communities need farms, but they also need kitchens.'' JILL SANTOPIETRO (MM77)

CAMPAIGN STOPS There's a fever on the land, and it both excites and upsets me. Some friends speak to me of the coming apocalypse -- financial collapse, dogs howling at the moon, the scorched earth of Mad Max and Cormac McCarthy. Others are sanguine, still play golf on the weekend and remain on cordial terms with their brokers. I don't know what the line is in Vegas. I'm here to learn. I had a plan, of course. I couldn't follow John Steinbeck's exact route, not with the price of gas and a miserly budget, but I could pinch out six weeks of travel and make it to San Francisco before the election. That meant shower knobs that break off in your hand and even the tyranny of franchise food, but I felt game for it. If the apocalypse is looming, it might be useful to adapt to Arby's and Nathan's Finest.

ANDORS--Irving. Born in Brooklyn only 44 years after the end of the Civil War, Irving died on October 9th, three days before his 99th birthday. His life encompassed the entire sweep of 20th Century history, and until his last year he continued to evince unflagging interest in the news about the tumultuous beginnings of the 21st. Starting his working life as a mechanic for the Mack Truck Company in the 1930s, he then founded his own printing business where he did many lithographs for the American artist William Gropper. Like millions in his generation he started his family in Brooklyn during the 1940s, then moved to the Long Island suburbs in the early 1950s and in the 1970s, retired and spent the remainder of his life in South Florida. He was a classical music lover and an avid tennis player, a successful businessman and a good boss. But most of all he was a sweet, kind, intelligent, stubborn man and a good father. His wife Gertrude and his youngest child Ellen predeceased him. He is survived by two sons; Stephen of Brooklyn Heights, NY and Leon of Pittstown, NJ, and by five grandchildren; Jessica, Andrea, Stefanie, Zachary and Nora.

The French say vines must suffer to make great wine. Stress from heat and lack of water helps produce concentrated flavors in grapes. Yet there's fear that many red-wine regions, which tend to be hot and dry already, will become too hot and dry with global warming. Now a vineyard in Jumilla, in southeast Spain, says it has found an irrigation technique to conserve water and make flavorful low-alcohol wines. ''We use less water,'' says Juan Manuel Gomez, agriculturalist of the Casa de la Ermita winery, ''and can create a product that might attract the consumer in a crowded market.'' Other vineyards employ drip-irrigation systems, which dole out water bit by bit. ''There's a worldwide effort to find ways to use water efficiently,'' says David Smart of the Viticulture and Enology Department at the University of California, Davis. Gomez says his vineyard has discovered a way to manage the timing, quantity and frequency of water to control sugar. Sugar converts to alcohol during fermentation; so less sugar in the grapes means lower alcohol. Altos de la Ermita, Gomez's wine, is around 6.5 percent alcohol, with help from a less-efficient fermentation and the application of an alcohol-removing machine. EDWARD LEWINE

But now that he is mostly in cash, Mr. Prokhorov is on top of the world, while the global economic crisis upends the rules by which the Kremlin and the immensely wealthy industrialists known as oligarchs do business. Those who were in favor expanded. And they are now in trouble.

The marine biologist Carl Safina gives frequent talks on the state of the sea, at which he often gets the same question: What kind of fish can I eat? So Safina and his conservation organization, Blue Ocean Institute, developed FishPhone, a text-messaging service that provides real-time answers to hamstrung consumers mulling their options in the restaurant or supermarket aisle. Texting 30644 with the message ''Fish Salmon'' will reveal that wild Alaskan varieties are safe, or ''green,'' while farmed salmon comes back with a red label and a health advisory noting the possible presence of PCBs, dioxins and pesticides. Researchers at the Blue Ocean Institute continually update the status of more than 70 species of edible marine life, including oysters and mussels. A complementary sushi guide will make its debut at the end of the month. JILLIAN DUNHAM

SPATZ--Martin. The Board of Trustees, faculty, staff, and students of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Martin Spatz, M.D., an alumnus, faculty member, benefactor, and dear friend. A 1936 graduate of Washington Square College and 1940 graduate of NYU College of Medicine, he was a distinguished urologist who had served on our faculty since 1970, most recently as clinical associate professor. In 2000 Dr. Spatz generously endowed the chair for NYU's Department of Urology, the first department of its kind in the country. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Spatz family. Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman, Board of Trustees, NYU Langone Medical Center Robert I. Grossman, M.D., Dean and CEO Herbert Lepor, M.D., Professor and Martin Spatz, Chairman, Department of Urology SPATZ--Dr. Martin, age 93, a prominent physician and professor of urology passed away at Winthrop University Hospital on October 3, 2008. Born July 23, 1915 to Morris and Lena Spatz. A graduate of NYU Medical School, he maintained an active practice for over 40 years. Held professorships in urology at NYU and Stony Brook University. He served as a governor for the American College of Surgeons. He was noted for his many contributions to the Advancement of Urologic Medicine. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 52 years, Dr. Polly Reaves Spatz. He is survived by brother and sister-in-law, Jack and Joan Reaves, nieces Kathleen Reaves Pierce and Carol Reaves Price and children, Stuart, Mitchell and Kelsey, his cousins, Morris Lippner and Shirley Loshen of Florida. He leaves rnany devoted friends including Dr. Joseph Greensher, his wife Lyn and family. Donations in his memory may be made to Winthrop University Hospital or NYU Department of Urology.

When the singer-turned-Urban-Farming-organizer Taja Sevelle saw an architect's model of a plant-covered wall for an Anthropologie store, she thought, Can you grow food on it? She imagined vertical produce on Skid Row in Los Angeles, free for the picking. Robin Osler of Elmslie Osler Architects in New York helped her vision bear fruit. In August, Urban Farming Food Chain walls were installed at two Skid Row homeless housing facilities, a nearby food bank and a high school, their clip-on trays preplanted with strawberries, peppers, lettuces and other edibles. The next goal is to design a mobile kitchen for cooking demonstrations. Osler sees the wall as something that can go up anywhere in the U.S. ''It's not using valuable horizontal real estate; it's not creating economic issues for a developer to battle against,'' she said. CHRISTINE MUHLKE (MM72)

The United States Olympic Committee is set to begin its next four-year Olympic cycle in 2009 with $103 million in its coffers, $63 million more than it had to start the previous cycle, U.S.O.C. officials said Saturday at the U.S. Olympic Assembly in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. Jim Scherr, chief executive of the committee, said that different sources of revenue, including corporate sponsorships and television rights fees, helped create the surplus. Better management of expenses also played a role, he said. ''We had to borrow $55 million to get from 2003 to 2004, so this is a tremendous improvement for us,'' Scherr said. JULIET MACUR
