MAIORANA--Ronald. Anthony L. Watson, CEO and Chair, the Board of Directors and staff of EmblemHealth, the parent company of HIP Health Insurance Plan of New York and GHI, mourn the passing of Ronald Maiorana, a retired senior vice president of public affairs and a consultant to EmblemHealth at the time of his death. A former reporter for the New York Times and later press secretary and advisor to New York Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller, he was 78 and died Thursday after a short illness at his home in East Quogue. Mr. Maiorana joined The Times as a copy boy in 1951 as a college freshman in night school and was promoted to reporter in 1955, covering a broad range of assignments in the New York metropolitan area and in Albany. He left The Times in 1968 to join Governor Rockefeller as an assistant press secretary. In 1969, the Governor appointed Mr. Maiorana as his press secretary and principal spokesperson. He accompanied the Governor on government and political trips across the nation and throughout South America. After Governor Rockefeller left office, Mr. Maiorana served as New York State Commissioner of Wagering Systems (1974-1975). He then joined the New York State Special Prosecutor for the Criminal Justice System as a director (1975-1976). He later worked with political consultants David Garth and Maureen Connelly on the U.S. Senate campaign of H. John Heinz of Pennsylvania and on all of Rudolph Giulianis campaigns for Mayor of New York City. He joined the administration of Mayor Giuliani as a senior advisor in 1994 and was appointed Commissioner of the New York City Community Assistance Unit in 1995. He left his city position to join HIP as a managing consultant for public affairs in 1996 and joined the health care company's executive staff full time in 1998. He retired April 30, 2007. At HIP, he was a trusted advisor to CEO Anthony L. Watson during a period of profound change in the firm, culminating with the affiliation with GHI to form EmblemHealth earlier this year. Mr. Maiorana also was a talented artist, an avocation he pursued for 60 years, opening his first exhibit AbstRactions in July. Two of his abstracts on canvas are in the Nelson Rockefeller collection. The EmblemHealth family extends its prayers and best wishes to Mr. Maiorana's family: his son Ronald Peter Maiorana and wife, Kelly Allman, and daughters Linda Catherine Williams and her husband Trevor Williams, and Janice Virginia Maiorana-Browne, and her husband Christopher Browne, and Mr. Maiorana's brother Victor and his wife, Rosalie. His wife, Phyllis, was killed accidentally when struck by a branch that fell from a tree on September 11, 2002. They had been married 47 years. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Little Flower Children and Family Services of Wading River, New York 11792. Friends may call Sunday from 2pm to 6pm at Fred H. McGrath's Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street, Bronxville, 914 337-6770. A Memorial Service will be conducted Monday at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, 15 Cedar Street, Bronxville, with interment at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla to follow.

Each year food waste makes up more than 30 percent of Seattle's garbage -- about 150,000 tons. A new program is expected to cut that by more than half. Starting in April, all single-family homes in the the city will be required to subscribe to a weekly food-waste recycling program. ''The main change is in what we call organics,'' said Timothy Croll, the solid-waste director of the public-utilities department in Seattle. In addition to vegetative waste and food-contaminated paper (like paper towels or plates), people will also be able to recycle meat and dairy products.The recycled waste will be used as compost for parks and gardens. By 2012, Seattle aspires to recycle 60 percent of its waste; up from the 48.7 percent of waste now diverted from the landfill. ''If we keep it out of the landfill,'' Croll says, ''we'll save money on our disposable costs. We can reuse resources rather than using fresh, virgin sources.'' S. KIRK WALSH

In a rematch of last season's American Football Conference championship game, the San Diego Chargers host the New England Patriots. But the game finds the two teams much different from last winter. First of all, they have each lost to Miami in recent weeks. The Chargers were a popular pick to reach the Super Bowl, but as they did last season, they have started slowly at 2-3. They have even lost the coin toss in all five games. Coming off its lowest-scoring game since Week 17 of the 2005 season, San Diego has not received the usual production from running back LaDainian Tomlinson and tight end Antonio Gates, neither of whom are completely healthy. The top receivers Chris Chambers and Vincent Jackson are also banged up.

CAPTURING THE SIGHTS OF NEW YORK HARBOR, SEPT. 24, 2008 Jozsef Reketye, 50, an insurance company employee from Budapest, films the Statue of Liberty from the deck of a ferry. ''We were on a four-day vacation, just being tourists. It was my third time there -- I first visited in 1992 and had loved New York. I enjoyed the way of life very much. I had already seen all the tourist spots, but my wife and I wanted to show our two children because they had never seen any of it before. So we went sightseeing on a hop-on, hop-off bus, and we saw everything: the Empire State Building, ground zero, Times Square, Wall Street, Broadway, Central Park and the Statue of Liberty. It was fantastic. Everything was beautiful, and the people were friendly. I enjoy traveling because I want to get to know people in other countries, to know about their lives. I think it's important nowadays for promoting peace. If people traveled more and met one another, maybe they would understand each other better.''

WILL the new federal tax credit for plug-in hybrid cars, part of the sprawling $700 billion bailout bill signed into law last week by President Bush, reward stellar green performance or just big battery packs? The larger the battery pack, the bigger the subsidy. The law calls for a base credit of $2,500 for plug-in hybrid purchases, which increases by $417 for each kilowatt-hour of battery capacity over four kilowatt-hours, to a maximum of $7,500. So the Chevrolet Volt, scheduled to go on sale in late 2010 with a 16 kilowatt-hour pack, would presumably qualify for the full subsidy. Other vehicles with smaller packs, including a possible plug-in version of the Toyota Prius, would get a smaller credit even if the car had superior performance and range.

For decades, fast-food menus have remained stubbornly resistant to the whims of the seasons. But as some innovative fast-food restaurants have sought to source their food locally, they have given birth to something entirely new in the industry: a seasonal menu. At Burgerville, a family-owned chain with 39 restaurants in Oregon and Washington, the Walla Walla sweet-onion rings are available only during the summer. ''You can't freeze or dry these onions, or they'll lose their texture and taste,'' says Burgerville's Jack Graves. Similarly, the blackberry milkshake -- made from fresh berries picked at Liepold Farms, in Boring, Ore. -- is available only from July to September, followed in the fall by limited-time sweet-potato fries. Local Burger, in Lawrence, Kan., has featured seasonal arugula and watermelon smoothies. And the trend is spreading: Larger chains like Panera Bread have introduced items like summer-corn chowder, and in Maine, McDonald's sometimes even offers a lobster roll. CHARLES WILSON

Forget April in Paris. The exciting time is autumn, with the Eiffel Tower bathed in blue light and stylish women everywhere -- a time of rebirth after the summer doldrums. Paris in 2008 looked much like my first visit in 1950: bicycles crowding the streets and women dressed in one-piece day dresses, top left, like those from Christian Dior circa 1949. Everything has changed from 1950, yet nothing has. It remains a capital of fashion and beauty.

THE United States Postal Service has issued a set of five commemorative postage stamps with artwork showing classic American cars of the 1950s. The theme of fins and chrome is expressed on first-class stamps that depict a 1957 Chrysler 300C, a 1957 Lincoln Premiere, a 1957 Pontiac Safari, a 1957 Studebaker Golden Hawk and a 1959 Cadillac Eldorado. A similar set was issued in 2005 with a theme of sporty cars of the '50s that included the Studebaker Starliner, Nash-Healey, Ford Thunderbird, Kaiser Darrin and Chevrolet Corvette.

Now that ''local'' has replaced ''organic'' as the conscientious eater's buzzword, even the gargantuan food distributor Sysco -- a $37 billion company that supplies food to restaurants, hospitals and colleges across North America -- has begun shifting its stance under the leadership of the chief executive, Rick Schnieders. Responding to customers' demands for fresher, more specialized products, Schnieders has partnered with small farms, appointed a vice president of agricultural sustainability and started programs to help farmers market their products regionally. ''A lot of people fear the big company, but that shouldn't be the case here,'' said David Yandow, the executive vice president of sales at Fowler FreshPoint, a Connecticut produce subsidiary of Sysco. Yandow works with 140 New England farmers to supply regional businesses with the seasonal (and often specialty) produce they're requesting. ''The climate has changed for us,'' he says. ''There's the opportunity for everybody to do the right thing.'' HANNAH WALLACE

JACOBS--Jay. Born April 19, 1923, New York, New York, died October 2, 2008 Sherwood, Oregon. He was loved. ''Dinner with Jay'' was memorable while enjoying his tasty tidbits, both anecdotal and culinary. His vivid stories celebrated renowned and little know artists, chefs, restaurateurs, and tablemates. His published books include ''RFK: His Life and Death'', 1968, ''New York A La Carte'', 1978, ''Winning the Restaurant Game'', 1980, ''La Cucina di Lidia'', 1990, and memoir ''A Glutton For Punishment'', 1991. He was project Editorin-Charge at both American Heritage and Horizon Books; Executive Editor, ARTSmagazine; Senior Editor, Portfolio; Managing Editor, Art News Annual; Contributing Editor, Art in America and Gourmet; Editor, theARTgallery. He was NYC Restaurant Reviewer for Gourmet from 1972-1986. He was awarded the International First Prize for food journalism ''Maria Duchessa di Parma'' Parma, Italy in 1986. He is survived by his wife, Pam McCormick in Oregon and his sons, by his first marriage, Roger and Mathieu in New York, Peter in California and Sumner in Thailand. Memorial service: Church of the Ascension, 12 W. 11th St, New York, November 1, 2008, 3pm.

IT survives only as segments of other highways, as a right of way for power lines and as a bike trail, but the Long Island Motor Parkway still holds a sense of magic as what some historians say is the country's first road built specifically for the automobile. It opened 100 years ago last Friday as a rich man's dream. As detailed in a new book, ''The Long Island Motor Parkway'' by Howard Kroplick and Al Velocci (Arcadia Publishing), the parkway ran about 45 miles across Long Island, from Queens to Ronkonkoma, and was created by William Kissam Vanderbilt II, the great-grandson of Cornelius Vanderbilt.

EKLUND--Coy, retired Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, passed away on October 5 in Delray Beach, Florida. He was 93. He began his 70-year career with the company in 1938. After guiding the Detroit Agency to become the number one in 1959, he moved to company headquarters in New York City and advanced from Vice President and Assistant to President, to Agency Vice President, to Senior Vice President. In 1965, he was elected to the Board of Directors. He became Executive Vice President in 1969, Equitable's President in 1973, and Chief Executive Officer in 1975. Coy retired from The Equitable in 1983, but continued on the Board until 1987. He served as a consultant to AXA Equitable until his passing, making over 11,000 motivational phone calls to Hall of Fame members. Coy also had a distinguished military career during World War II, serving in the U.S. Army on the Third Army staff of General George Patton. He completed his military duty as a Lieutenant Colonel, was awarded five Battle Stars, and was decorated with the Croix de Guerre by France's General Charles de Gaulle. He championed the causes of women and minorities in the workplace. From 1978 to 1983, Coy served as President of The National Urban League, and was recognized by Ms. Magazine as a leader in the advancement of women in business. A private memorial service will be held. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to The Salk Institute for Biological Studies, P.O. Box 85800, San Diego, CA, 92186-5800, or Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407, www.hpbc.com

Amid last week's market tumult, Mark Cuban, chairman of HDNet and owner of the Dallas Mavericks, tackled the subject of ''How to Get Rich.'' His advice may not be a mood-lifter. ''There are no shortcuts,'' Mr. Cuban wrote in his blog, called Blog Maverick. His recipe includes being extremely frugal and saving as much money as possible: ''Instead of coffee, drink water. Instead of going to McDonald's, eat Mac and Cheese. Cut up your credit cards.'' He recommends holding the savings in six-month C.D.'s.

THE NEWS Americans awoke to news that European nations were scrambling to prevent the collapse of major banks, then watched as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 800 points before regaining some ground. BEHIND THE NEWS It was the type of day when a 369-point decline in the Dow came as a relief. The damage was worse abroad: Asian markets were hammered; the Russian market dropped 19 percent; major indexes in Europe lost from 7 percent to 9 percent of their value; and stocks in Latin America took their worst fall in a decade. The carnage reflected fears of a global recession. ''Everybody is going to get caught up in this,'' said one leading economist.

When bags of spinach contaminated with E. coli began poisoning diners in 26 states two years ago, it was more than a month before the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention were able to trace the outbreak back to its source: Natural Selection Foods in San Juan Bautista, Calif. Frustrated with the faltering federal response and the spiraling hysteria that accompanied it, two social scientists at Michigan State University proposed a second resource for consumers: a ''mass collaboration'' Web site where sick diners could post their symptoms and food intake anonymously. Modeled after open-source information systems like Wikipedia and the illness map whoissick.org, the academics suggested in a paper last November that an anonymous symptom aggregator ''would provide more information, more quickly, and at finer geographic scales than is possible from government agencies.'' While Laura DeLind and Philip Howard, the authors, acknowledge that accuracy in such a system would be dependent on its participants, they say it could lessen the public's dependence on federal oversight and protect smaller farms not responsible for industrial-scale outbreaks. At least that's the idea -- the map has yet to be developed by the professors or anyone else. JILLIAN DUNHAM (MM75)

-- two-thirds of them from Monsanto, BASF and Syngenta -- have been filed on the genes intended for use in crops designed to withstand environmental stresses. ''We're talking about a grab on strategic genes in the world's most important food crops,'' says Hope Shand, the research director for the watchdog organization ETC Group. ''This simply shouldn't be allowed.'' Jonathan Bryant, the director of North American business for BASF, which in 2007 signed a $1.5 billion deal to collaborate with Monsanto on the development of drought-tolerant crops, calls the patents ''a very small protection amongst a sea of opportunity.'' The continued consolidation of intellectual property combined with the sort of corporate cooperation currently being enjoyed by BASF and Monsanto is considered a recipe for disaster by some. The anti-genetic-modification activist Vandana Shiva, whose New Delhibased Navdanya group builds seed banks for the sharing of climate-resilient crops,says consolidation isn't just bad economics and bad social policy; it's bad science. ''As a physicist,'' she says, ''I can tell you that it is crazy in times of unpredictability to have centralized uniformity. If you are going to have climate chaos, what you need is lots of diversity, and you want that diversity in lots of places, in a very decentralized way.'' JOCELYN CRAUGH ZUCKERMAN

International food prices spiked almost 40 percent last year, indicating that the monetary price is finally catching up with the true costs of cheap food: obesity in the U.S., malnutrition in developing countries and environmental degradation everywhere. This issue is devoted to these problems and some possible solutions, many of them sprinkled throughout the essays and reports.

AS THE LEGENDARY bon vivant Ludwig Bemelmans once noted of restaurateurs: ''The most strenuous customer-versus-proprietor battles occur in the smart restaurants of Paris and New York. This kind of restaurant, as a rule, is small. It is benefited by a certain type of guest and injured by another, and the latter must be discouraged from coming. In a man confronted daily with the task of separating the wanted from the unwanted, a degree of arrogance is indispensable.'' Confronted daily with the task of deciding who gets to eat at Shopsin's General Store, his 20-seat restaurant in New York's Essex Street Market, the cook and owner Kenny Shopsin separates the wanted from the unwanted with a degree of foulmouthed eloquence that makes Lenny Bruce look like Sirio Maccioni. This is food politics in its rawest form. ''We have a really wonderful relationship with our customers for the most part,'' he said. ''We kick [expletive] out. Regularly.'' Up to three times a day.
Television Mike Hale

NURBAKSHS--Javad, 82, Master of the Nimatullahi Sufi Order for over 55 years, died on October 9, 2008 at the Order's Headquarters near Banbury, England where he had been living for over two decades. Under his leadership, the Nimatullahi Order expanded from its original base in Iran, establishing numerous centers worldwide, including many in the United States. His teaching of the centuries old Sufi path of love of God and service to others emphasized tolerance and respect for peoples of all faiths and the equality of men and women in all aspects of life and spiritual practice. Dr. Nurbakhsh wrote numerous books on Sufism that are available in English. Dr. Nurbakhsh was born in Kerman, Iran and graduated from the medical school of Tehran University, where he later served as Professor of Psychiatry and Head of the Department of Psychiatry until his retirement. He was also Director of Ruzbeh Psychiatric Hospital in Tehran for many years. He is survived by his wife, Parvaneh, five children, Alireza, Safa, Rabe'ah, Vafa and Safoura, and 11 grandchildren.

RECENTLY I MET Roger Barlow, the president of the Catfish Institute in Jackson, Miss., for a catfish lunch. Plates of blackened catfish Caesar salad, catfish in a crawfish étouffée and Southern-fried catfish lay between us, as did a P.R. folder embossed with the phrase ''U.S. Farm-raised Catfish: Safety You Can Trust.'' As the North American catfish's principal advocate, Barlow wanted to focus on the positive. He described how U.S. catfish adhered to the world's toughest quality standards; how, in their farm-raised form, catfish weren't scavengers, as in nature, but rather sweet-tasting surface-feeders, raised in well water and fattened on corn and soy. But by and by our discussion reached a point at which Barlow revealed some impending changes. Very soon U.S. farm-raised catfish, some of it anyway, would not be called catfish. 'The name we have chosen, and the name we have market-tested,'' he said, pausing slightly, ''is Delacata.'' Delacata, he explained, was going to be a specially filleted Grade-A piece of the best of the farmed North American channel catfish. It was being tested at high-end bistros in California, and the ''Iron Chef America'' judge Cat Cora had signed on to endorse it.

Two years ago, there was a scandal in Paris when an International Food Salon award for innovation went to a Spaniard who doesn't force-feed his geese. Intrigued, the New York chef Dan Barber traveled to Eduardo Sousa's farm, where the Sousa family has been making cruelty-free foie gras since 1812. Barber had what he called ''a great culinary experience.'' Here's what he saw: 1,000 geeseroaming through orchards and eating acorns, olives and figs. Sousa, who says he pampers his geese so much that wild flocks land on his farm and stay, takes advantage of the birds' natural tendencyto gorge in preparation for winter; he slaughters only in the fall or winter. When Barber got back from his trip, he was inspired to try the same thing. So some of the 70 geese that were already being raised at Barber's Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., were chosen for the experiment and are now fattening up for slaughter. Naturally. ADAM FISHER

In his campaign against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to extend term limits, United States Representative Anthony D. Weiner harshly criticized the City Council and its speaker, Christine C. Quinn, who has come out in favor of the mayor's plan. Mr. Weiner, who plans to run for mayor next year, urged ordinary New Yorkers to show up in large numbers to testify at City Hall on Thursday.
An equities trader at Renaissance Capital, a Russian investment bank, lost the company about $10 million by placing unauthorized bets on the stock market just as it collapsed, the bank said Monday.

Meteorologists issue intensely brisk warning:

BOSTON - Just a couple of hours before the Red Sox and Rays squared off in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series, there was still one place to get tickets for the game (at face value, too). The line was snaking down Lansdowne Street and anyone could just walk up and stand there.
Vikram Pandit was there. So were Lloyd Blankfein and John Thain, for that matter.

Ray Bendici, substituting for Brian Bassett of the Jets Blog, hands out the grades this week. Ray, from Shelton, Conn., is a Jets fan (despite being the son of a Patriots fan) and a regular contributor to thejetsblog.com. His father still talks to him anyway.
On a day of stunning gains on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing more than 11 percent on Monday, General Electric stood out as the only loser among the Dow 30.

Nineteen-year-old Russian forward Alexei Cherepanov, who was a Rangers first-round draft choice in 2007 and considered one of the organization's top prospects, died on Monday after collapsing near the end of a game between his K.H.L. team Avangard Omsk and another team, Vityaz, in Chekhov, a city outside Moscow.

Updated, October 13, 5:44 p.m. An earlier version of this entry incorrectly stated that Lewis Hamilton and Felipe Massa got stop-and-go penalties for their erratic driving moves. They were hit with drive-through penalties.

Medicine | A twangy high note for brain surgery: the bluegrass musician Eddie Adcock plays his banjo during an operation to treat a hand tremor. During the procedure, which someone filmed, surgeons in Nashville used Adcock's playing to isolate the tremor and install a brain electrode connected to a pacemaker to shut it down. [BBC, Mindhacks, ABC News]

Columbus Day has been a federal holiday since 1937 -- and, in New York City, where there has been a substantial Italian population since the 19th century, the occasion for a parade going back at least as far as 1929. But that doesn't mean the holiday always feel sufficiently appreciated.
The financial crisis has made sealing deals pretty difficult this year. And much to the chagrin of investment bankers, it appears to be getting even worse.
A Charvet-inspired polo and a leather bomber jacket from Black Block.
BAGHDAD - An old Arab saying goes something like this: Early learning is like etching on stone.

Sports reigned supreme in the ratings on Sunday as football and baseball coverage lifted the Fox Network to a narrow victory on the night just ahead of NBC's "Sunday Night Football," according to Nielsen's estimates adjusted for time zone discrepancies where possible.

Arts and Science | In an article, Malcolm Gladwell presents evidence that genius is not the province of youthful precocity. Look at Frost, Hitchcock, Cézanne. Late bloomers don't "start with a clear idea" as the young do; they're willing to search for it in an "open-ended exploration." The book will go over well with the AARP crowd. [New Yorker]

Updated, 5:27 p.m. | The fire that swept through an apartment in Chelsea on Saturday, killing five members of a single family, appears to have been caused by a child playing with a lighter or with matches, a Fire Department spokesman said on Monday.
When ESPN takes its cameras and crews on the road to cover United States World Cup qualifying matches, it all about the logistics, logistics, logistics (to paraphrase the real-estate bromide).

When Australia's Ansett Airlines collapsed in 2001, pilot John Nicholls decided to give up on flying and follow his dream of creating a $100 computer capable of going up against products from hardware giants like Hewlett-Packard and Dell. Mr. Nicholls sold his house, acquired government grants and set to work building a machine that consumes only a few watts of energy and is just a bit bigger than a deck of cards.

Film | A critic at a conservative newspaper zeroes in on the problem with the conservative film comedy "An American Carol." The director David Zucker and company "have fallen into the same trap their enemies on the left have embraced: message over movie." Now studio execs will be justified in saying, "Conservative doesn't sell." [Washington Times]
Last week the Well blog featured a special report from the staff of Science Times called "Decoding Your Health,'' which focused on how to navigate in a sea of health information.

The Cowboys' aw-shuckin' quarterback Tony Romo has broken the pinkie finger on his right hand, an injury that will force him to miss at least the next four weeks -- a stretch that includes the Cowboys' game against the Giants at the Meadowlands on Nov. 2. The injury took place on the first play of overtime in Sunday's loss to the Cardinals.
While this may be Paul Krugman's big day, it's another Times columnist who's written the most argued-about column of the moment. "It's time for John McCain to fire his campaign," writes Bill Kristol.
Here are the lineups for the Rays and the Red Sox for Game 3 of the A.L.C.S. at Fenway Park. Alex Cora, Boston's super sub, is starting at shortstop over Jed Lowrie.
Canned tomatoes are essential in a healthy pantry and can be used in pasta dishes that require nothing more than ingredients you can easily keep on hand.

Opera | If you go to the premiere of "Doctor Atomic" at the Met tonight -- about the development of the A-bomb -- don't congratulate yourself for being at the cutting edge: "Since the dawn of the millennium, the outré has become ordinary in opera." That includes insects, teleportation, metamorphosis, Jerry Springer and Al Gore. [Newsweek]

This season began with so much promise for Clemson. The Tigers were ranked No. 9 in the preseason and considered the favorite to win the Atlantic Coast Conference championship. But things quickly turned sour, with a 34-10 loss to Alabama in the season opener just the beginning of a disappointing season.

Last week, the Ford Motor Company announced the MyKey system, which allows parents a bit of control over their teenage drivers. The system limits drivers to a top speed of 80 miles an hour and sounds a chime whenever the vehicle travels above 45, 55 or 65 m.p.h., caps the volume on the car stereo (it can also mute the radio) and requires seat belt use, again by repeatedly sounding a chime.

There's a little parking lot off Cross Bay Boulevard, just south of Howard Beach, that abuts Jamaica Bay. People park there and watch the planes take off and land at Kennedy International Airport. Others barbecue or play cricket. Many Hindus hold services there and, on Sundays, pray on the beach and toss offerings into the water.

I like free stuff as much as the next guy. And I certainly don't have any interest in telecom oligopolies being able to raise prices without competition. But there is something that strikes me as unfair about the Federal Communications Commission's plan to auction off a block of spectrum under the specific proviso that it be used to offer free wireless service to the public.
Curators as models: Julien Fronsacq (Palais de Tokyo, Paris); Olivier Sailliard (Musée de la Mode et du Textile, Paris); Hans Ulrich Obrist (Serpentine Gallery, London)

For those who felt it was somewhat tasteless, in the worst financial crisis since the Hoover administration, to open the "Rooms" feature with a visit to a $30,000-a-night hotel room, we had hoped to make this week's offering the Merrill Lynch boardroom -- or what may soon be the former Merrill Lynch boardroom. We actually visited the boardroom over the summer, just before the financial world blew up.Unfortunately, we didn't get a picture at the time. And now, because of circumstances beyond our control (re: Bank of America buys out Merrill), the Merrill P.R. department wasn't keen to have us back.
As Detroit shrinks, could "green jobs" - so beloved of presidential candidates - ride to the rescue of industrial America?
It's only Monday, but this one is going to be hard to top. Nice to see somebody is thriving while the world around us collapses....

Africa | A columnist says Uganda doesn't have enough money to give all of its tribal kings a state funeral, not while "newborn babies are being eaten by rats in hospitals" and public servants go unpaid. That recent funeral -- it's part of the political expediency of bribes for tribes. [Monitor]
Bengali immigrants who love to cook up bait fish catch their own in Jamaica Bay, Queens.

In a sign of difficult times to come for the venture capital industry, institutions that invest in venture funds put less money into fewer funds in the third quarter, according to data released Monday by Thomson Reuters and the National Venture Capital Association.

When the City Council begins hearings on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to extend term limits, the proceedings will be overseen by Councilman Simcha Felder, who chairs the governmental operations committee.

The stock market is bouncing back Monday because, perhaps in honor of Columbus Day, the government has discovered the new world of nationalizing (at least partly) the banks. Many tech stocks are up even more than the market over all. So I tried to comb the news for something other than cutbacks and layoffs. I was only partly successful.

The Boeing Company, which was struck last month by members of the machinists union, went back to the negotiating table this weekend for the first time since the walkout started.

I'm sad to report that David Lett, founder of the Eyrie Vineyards, which pioneered the production of fine pinot noir in Oregon, died last Thursday at his home in Dundee Oregon. He was 69 years old.
Signs of heart disease are more likely to be blamed on stress when the patient is a woman, new research shows.

My children are asking questions, prompted by the constant talk of money on the news. Some I can't yet answer because I don't really know: How much have we lost? What does this mean for my college fund?

Wine | Two wine critics are stumped over how Brie and Chablis ever came to epitomize liberals. After all, 37 percent of conservatives, versus only 24 percent of liberals, say wine is their libation of choice. Besides, the pair sniff, Brie and Chablis "don't work together very well anyway," for the most part. A better, snootier choice might be Brie and Champagne. [Wall Street Journal]

The Times's Jennifer Steinhauer and Monica Almeida are traversing the country from the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco to the George Washington Bridge in New York, chatting with voters about the presidential campaign. Follow along here.

Just a week ago, the government of the United Kingdom said it would spend billions of pounds to take stakes in the nation's major banks. But by Monday, the plan had greatly expanded, becoming far more costly and risky to the nation's taxpayers. Such is the trouble with bailouts these days: What seemed big enough to contain the problem one week can quickly be seen as inadequate the next.

-- Tina Fey is just about the hottest star in show business at the moment, Bill Carter writes in Monday's New York Times, so why hasn't NBC debuted "30 Rock" yet? Ben Silverman says the show was scheduled to start in late October to improve its chances of emerging as a hit.

Chicken with vinegar is one of the great poultry dishes from the area around Lyons, France, where the chickens are considered by many to be the best in the world. This version was taught to me by a student of the great chef Paul Bocuse. Bocuse popularized this peasant dish at La Mere Brazier in Lyons; his student's name: Jean-Georges Vongerichten.

The directors Chris Hegedus and D. A. Pennebaker call their new political documentary "The Return of the War Room." But the political strategists who inhabited that fabled room - the one where, in 1992, Bill Clinton's upstart presidential campaign was waged - never really left.

As mothers of soldiers who have been deployed to Iraq, both Gov. Sarah Palin and Cindy McCain accused Senator Barack Obama last week of voting not to fund American troops there. A McCain campaign ad called "Dangerous" goes further, saying that Mr. Obama and other "congressional liberals voted repeatedly to cut off funding to our active troops," thereby "increasing the risk on their lives."

Film | Noting a postal stamp showing Bette Davis without her cigarette, the critic Roger Ebert defends smoking in the movies. "Movies can't rewrite reality," he writes. But he doesn't deal with all the glamorous smoking in "Mad Men" on TV and the "integrated sponsorships" trend in entertainment. Is it worth considering where all this could lead? [Roger Ebert's Journal]

Over the weekend, I asked Herman Daly, the specialist in "ecological economics" at the University of Maryland, about the recent financial turmoil. He pointed me to a short piece he wrote that was posted on the Oil Drum blog a few days ago and that he gave me permission to post below. It's mostly about economic theory, but does get at one of the keystone concepts explored here -- which is how many people, consuming how much stuff, can one livable planet support? [UPDATE 10/14: George Soros weighs in, too.]
This race has been filled with surprises, so it would almost be a surprise if something else didn’t happen before the polls open.

"Venezuela's daily oil production has fallen by a quarter since President Hugo Chavez won power, depriving his 'Bolivarian Revolution' of much of the benefit of the global boom in oil prices," reports The Telegraph of London. "To win allies and forge an anti-American front, Mr Chavez sells oil to friendly countries at low prices. Ironically, the only big customer buying Venezuelan oil at the full market price is the United States, which the president routinely denounces as the 'Empire'."

Politics | Congratulations on the economics Nobel to our colleague, the liberal Op-Ed columnist Paul Krugman. Tidings aside, it's sure to stir debate about intellectuals with authority in a primary field who venture into politics. Recall the conservative historian Paul Johnson taking to task Noam Chomsky, linguist, and the like for venturing "where they might be supposed to have no more right to a hearing than anyone else." [Amazon, p. 339]

Senator John McCain, seeking to both acknowledge and change the narrative that has begun to dominate the presidential campaign, plans to unveil a retooled stump speech today. He and his running mate will be in Virginia, a state that has been leaning blue in some parts -- and is now considered a breakaway threat from the Republican strongholds in the South.
Two weeks ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg boasted to his aides that he would easily win passage of a measure to give himself the chance to run for a third term.

So if you've been joining social networking sites and never taking the time to complete your profile -- or if you've been hitting the delete button when friends and colleagues invite you to connect on a new online platform, now is a good time to start paying more attention. Here are a few things to think about as you take the plunge or take your social networking to the next level.

Industry observers are painting a gloomy outlook for the survival of the fund of hedge funds industry, The Wall Street Journal reported.

After a whirl of emergency weekend meetings on both sides of the Atlantic aimed at rescuing the global financial system, Britain began propping up three banks with taxpayer funds on Monday while the Federal Reserve and three European central banks announced that they will offer financial institutions unlimited dollars to ease the banking crisis, The New York Times reported.

In what could set an important precedent, federal officials assured a big Japanese bank late Sunday that its planned investment in the embattled Wall Street giant Morgan Stanley would be protected, The New York Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin reported, citing people involved in the talks.
Banco Santander of Spain confirmed Monday that it is in talks to buy U.S. bank Sovereign Bancorp, but said that no deal has yet been reached.

At the turn of the 20th century, toward the end of a brutal and surprisingly difficult victory in the Second Boer War, the people of Britain began to contemplate the possibility that theirs was a nation in decline. They worried that London's big financial sector was draining resources from the industrial economy and wondered whether Britain's schools were inadequate. In 1905, a new book - a fictional history, set in the year 2005 - appeared under the title, "The Decline and Fall of the British Empire."

Despite signals that Senator John McCain would have new prescriptions for the economic crisis after a weekend of meetings, his campaign said Sunday that Mr. McCain, the Republican presidential nominee, would not have any more proposals this week unless developments call for some, The New York Times's Jackie Calmes reported.

Top executives at American International Group knew of potential problems in valuing derivatives contracts, known as credit default swaps, long before questions about the risky transactions caused its stock to plummet, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing documents released by congressional investigators.

Politics | Why an Obama win might not be such a great triumph over racism: polls suggest the economy trumps race this time for white voters who still harbor prejudice against blacks. Also, the same article says, racism is a bigger factor among Democrats and independents than Republicans because the latter have plenty of reasons other than race to disagree with Obama. (Further reading: the Week in Review on race and polling.) [Slate]

There has been a lot of good journalism in recent weeks about the people whose decisions helped cause the credit crisis. The current issue of Business Week takes another angle on crisis and looks at the people who tried, unsuccessfully, to prevent the crisis.

Economy | Still to come after Wall Street's worst week ever: credit-card debt defaults. Previously unscathed consumer banks like JPMorgan and Bank of America are vulnerable. Some are raising rates to clean up their balance sheets but worsening defaults. And the debt, while small compared to mortgages, is unsecured, unlike mortgages. Yet it underlies $365 billion in securities sold worldwide. That sounds familiar. [Business Week]

History | Happy Columbus Day! Now read about a "forgotten explorateur," Samuel de Champlain, today "an obscure figure, except to those who live near a certain upstate New York lake." (His journey retraced.) In a new biography, the historian David Hackett Fischer focuses on "the ideas of tolerance and peaceful co-existence that Champlain championed." Also, he was something of a gourmand. Beaver tail, anyone? [Wall Street Journal]

Earlier this month the Montreal Ritz Carlton officially started selling 50 new residences, advertised as the most expensive apartments in the city, in terms of price per square foot. Prices start at $1.75 million for the apartments, which range from 1,060 to 5,640 square feet (98 square meters to 524 square meters)

Zach Johnson won the Texas Open in San Antonio for his fourth PGA Tour title. He followed his third-round 62 with a six-under-par 64 for a two-stroke victory over Charlie Wi, Mark Wilson and Tim Wilkinson. Johnson had a 19-under 261 total on La Cantera Golf Club’s Resort Course.

Robinho, Kaká and Adriano scored for Brazil, which easily defeated host Venezuela, 4-0, in a World Cup qualifier and secured second place at the halfway point of the South American qualifying tournament. It was the fourth straight defeat for Venezuela, which has never qualified for the World Cup.

Top-ranked Jelena Jankovic won her third title in three weeks, beating Vera Zvonareva, 6-2, 6-4, in the final of the Kremlin Cup in Moscow. On the men’s side, Igor Kunitsyn upset Marat Safin for his first ATP Tour title. Kunitsyn overcame the seventh-seeded Safin’s 21 aces to win, 7-6 (6), 6-7 (4), 6-3.

The rookies Kyle Turris and Mikkel Boedker each scored for the first time in the N.H.L., and Ilya Bryzgalov made 34 saves against his former Anaheim teammates to lead the Phoenix Coyotes to a 4-2 victory that spoiled the Ducks’ home opener.

Fernando Alonso won the Japanese Grand Prix in Oyama on Sunday in a race that provided another twist in the Formula One title fight. Alonso made it back-to-back wins in his Renault, but the race’s history of season-defining incidents between title rivals gained a new chapter when Lewis Hamilton and Felipe Massa tangled in a second-lap collision. Both drivers received pit drive-through penalties before Hamilton finished out of the points for McLaren. Massa came in seventh after a postrace stewards decision that elevated him from eighth. Hamilton’s championship lead was cut to 5 points, from 7, with two races remaining.

When 168 countries in the International Maritime Organization decided last week to cut emissions from the smokestacks of ocean-going ships, both environmental advocates and shipping interests cheered.
A look at presidential campaign buttons from 1940 to the present day that have been designed to court Jewish voters.

LOS ANGELES -- As fights in Game 3 of an L.C.S. go, the one we saw at Dodger Stadium on Sunday was not Pedro Martinez flinging Don Zimmer to the ground at Fenway Park. No punches were thrown, but the benches and bullpens did empty after Shane Victorino objected to a pitch over his head by Hiroki Kuroda.

LOS ANGELES -- Jamie Moyer was right about those sharks in the Dodger lineup. He faced 11 hitters in Game 3, getting only four outs. Moyer allowed six hits, one hit batter and six runs as the Dodgers drubbed the Phillies, 7-2.

When you consider that two N.F.L. coaches have already lost their jobs this season, it wasn't surprising that fans were chanting for another one to be fired during the Vikings-Lions game on Sunday. What was surprising was that the coach in the crosshairs was not Detroit's Rod Marinelli, whose team dropped to 0-5, but Minnesota's Brad Childress, whose Vikings won, 12-10, to move into a first-place tie in the N.F.C. North.

Voter registration in advance of the presidential election jumped yesterday to close at 681,900 for the city, 6,491 below the level of 1904. "The apathy which has been spoken of on every registration day this year disappeared at an astonishing rate on the last day. Manhattan and the Bronx showed a decided loss, approximately 20,000, but the other boroughs, with the exception of Richmond, showed gains that very nearly equalized the loss." Registration Close to 1904 Figures

In what could set an important precedent, federal officials assured a big Japanese bank late Sunday that its planned investment in the embattled Wall Street giant Morgan Stanley would be protected, according to people involved in the talks. After two days of tense negotiations, Treasury officials urged a hesitant Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group to proceed with its $9 billion investment in Morgan Stanley, which has sought the capital infusion to reassure investors and customers about its stability. The deal is considered a crucial step in the government's strategy for revitalizing the financial system by luring outside investment while it considers buying stock in banks directly. The transaction's failure would deal a blow to that effort and potentially unnerve the financial markets.

MAIORANA--Ronald. Anthony L. Watson, CEO and Chair, the Board of Directors and staff of EmblemHealth, the parent company of HIP Health Insurance Plan of New York and GHI, mourn the passing of Ronald Maiorana, a retired senior vice president of public affairs and a consultant to EmblemHealth at the time of his death. A former reporter for the New York Times and later press secretary and advisor to New York Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller, he was 78 and died Thursday after a short illness at his home in East Quogue. Mr. Maiorana joined The Times as a copy boy in 1951 as a college freshman in night school and was promoted to reporter in 1955, covering a broad range of assignments in the New York metropolitan area and in Albany. He left The Times in 1968 to join Governor Rockefeller as an assistant press secretary. In 1969, the Governor appointed Mr. Maiorana as his press secretary and principal spokesperson. He accompanied the Governor on government and political trips across the nation and throughout South America. After Governor Rockefeller left office, Mr. Maiorana served as New York State Commissioner of Wagering Systems (1974-1975). He then joined the New York State Special Prosecutor for the Criminal Justice System as a director (1975-1976). He later worked with political consultants David Garth and Maureen Connelly on the U.S. Senate campaign of H. John Heinz of Pennsylvania and on all of Rudolph Giulianis campaigns for Mayor of New York City. He joined the administration of Mayor Giuliani as a senior advisor in 1994 and was appointed Commissioner of the New York City Community Assistance Unit in 1995. He left his city position to join HIP as a managing consultant for public affairs in 1996 and joined the health care company's executive staff full time in 1998. He retired April 30, 2007. At HIP, he was a trusted advisor to CEO Anthony L. Watson during a period of profound change in the firm, culminating with the affiliation with GHI to form EmblemHealth earlier this year. Mr. Maiorana also was a talented artist, an avocation he pursued for 60 years, opening his first exhibit AbstRactions in July. Two of his abstracts on canvas are in the Nelson Rockefeller collection. The EmblemHealth family extends its prayers and best wishes to Mr. Maiorana's family: his son Ronald Peter Maiorana and wife, Kelly Allman, and daughters Linda Catherine Williams and her husband Trevor Williams, and Janice Virginia Maiorana-Browne, and her husband Christopher Browne, and Mr. Maiorana's brother Victor and his wife, Rosalie. His wife, Phyllis, was killed accidentally when struck by a branch that fell from a tree on September 11, 2002. They had been married 47 years. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Little Flower Children and Family Services of Wading River, New York 11792. Friends may call Sunday from 2pm to 6pm at Fred H. McGrath's Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street, Bronxville, 914 337-6770. A Memorial Service will be conducted Monday at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, 15 Cedar Street, Bronxville, with interment at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla to follow.

JONES--Carlisle, 80, of New York, NY and Lawrenceville, NJ died at his home in New York City on October 9. He is survived by his wife Jeanne M. His children DeborahSteven Lupton, Leslie-John Brittain, Geoffrey Jones-Caroline Jones, Elizabeth-Tyler Hall and Andrew Jones. Stepchildren Joseph Fusco Pamela, William Fusco, John Fusco, Thomas Fusco-Laurie, Stephen Fusco and Julie Lanning-Michael. He also leaves behind 26 grandchildren. Carlisle had a long and distinguished career as an Investment advisor with A.W. Jones, S.W. Seligman City Associates, Brimberg and Company and Invemed and Co. He was a member of the New York Stock Exchange for over 30 years. He was renowned for his idea sharing round table and as a great mentor. Carlisle was an avid hunter and fisherman and a lover of the great outdoors. He will be fondly remembered by all those he touched, for his wonderful sense of humor and the joyful way he journeyed through life. A celebration of his life will be held at the Racquet Club on 370 Park Ave., October 15 from 6pm-9pm. Contributions may be made to the New York Botanical Garden and the Central Conservancy.

McCABE--Frances (Micki), 70, of Manhattan and East Hampton, NY, died on Thursday October 9, 2008. Born in Brooklyn and raised in Lawrence, MA, she was the daughter of the late P. Harold and Sally T. (Scanlon) McCabe. Micki graduated from Merrimack College in North Andover, MA and from Fordham University and the Psychoanalytical Institute for Clinical Social Work in Manhattan. Micki was a psychotherapist in private practice in Manhattan for many years until her passing. Previously, she was an adjunct professor at Fordham and worked for the Catholic Home Bureau and Convenant House. Micki was active in the Democratic Party in both New York and East Hampton. She loved the East Hampton community and was an active member of the East Hampton Ladies Village Improvement Society (LVIS). She was the loving wife of Allan Feldman. Micki is also survived by many beloved cousins, family members and close friends. Donations can be made to PBS or to the Childhood Disorders section of NARSAD, a mental health charity. Services Tuesday October 14, 12 noon at Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, 94 Pantigo Road, East Hampton. Interment Green River Cemetery, Springs, East Hampton.

Once again this year, opponents of women's reproductive rights have managed to get initiatives aimed at ending or limiting abortion rights on ballots -- in South Dakota, Colorado and California. These measures, which violate women's privacy and threaten their health, have implications far beyond those states. If voters approve them, they will become a weapon in the right-wing campaign to overturn Roe v Wade. The South Dakota initiative is a near twin of the sweeping abortion ban handily rejected by South Dakota voters just two years ago. To make the ban seem less harsh, its backers have included language purporting to make exceptions for incest, rape or the life and health of the mother. But no one should be fooled. The exceptions were drafted to make it nearly impossible to get an abortion, even during the first trimester of pregnancy.

''Little Honey'' (Lost Highway) There are flashes of uncharacteristic joy on ''Little Honey,'' Lucinda Williams's ninth studio album; they're notable because for the better part of her 30-year career she's managed to avoid this feeling. Ms. Williams's voice is a broken, collapsed sigh and, in the last decade especially, she has used it to masterly effect, extracting a battered beauty from songs about disappointment, frustration and sometimes even sneering anger.

During the week ended Oct. 4, the search terms that had the largest increase over the previous week included only three about the economic crisis. Two searches were related to the government bailout and the third to online information offered by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The economic crisis dominated television, online and print news reports, from market movements around the globe to efforts by governments to shore up their banking industries. As always, it was what people wanted to know about celebrities that sent them to the Web. SHELLY FREIERMAN

RISE AGAINST ''Appeal to Reason'' (DGC/Interscope) Righteousness grows more tuneful with every album by Rise Against, a band from Chicago that started blasting in 1999. In the punk and hardcore heritage that Rise Against has proudly continued, galloping beats and relentless guitars backed up testimonials of stubborn alienation on the band's 2001 debut album, ''The Unraveling.''

The Very Rev. Francis B. Sayre Jr., who in his 27 years as dean of the National Cathedral in Washington raised his sonorous voice against McCarthyism, segregation, poverty and the Vietnam War while presiding over construction of the cathedral's majestic Gloria in Excelsis Tower, died Oct. 3 at his home on Martha's Vineyard, in Massachusetts. He was 93. The death was confirmed by Elizabeth Mullen, a spokeswoman for the Episcopal cathedral, one of the most influential religious institutions in the nation.

With 21 days to go until Nov. 4, the week ahead is about numbers: what to do about shrinking 401(k)'s, how to move the polls and whether the third and final presidential debate will draw large numbers of viewers who will either solidify the state of the race or set it on a new course. The debate, scheduled to begin at 9 p.m. on Wednesday, Eastern time, will be held at Hofstra University on Long Island. The candidates will face off in a standard debate format, on domestic issues, with Bob Schieffer of CBS News moderating.

ROSENFIELD--Allan G. The faculty, staff, students, alumni, and Board of Overseers of Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health mourn the passing of their beloved friend, colleague, mentor, and Dean Emeritus, Dr. Allan Rosenfield. A worldrenowned leader in public health, he brought his considerable intellect, passion, courage, and persistence to addressing the public health concerns of vulnerable populations around the globe. His 22 year tenure as Dean marked a period of unprecedented growth and recognition for the School. He worked tirelessly to develop family planning and reproductive health service programs in the School's backyard of Northern Manhattan. His pioneering work on women's reproductive health and human rights, innovative family planning studies, strategies to address the tragedy of maternal deaths in poor countries, and the HIV/ AIDS pandemic had an impact on millions of lives globally. Because of his extraordinary efforts, faculty members at the School now serve the public's health in over 100 countries. He never shied away from asking the difficult questions; developing critical, and sometimes controversial, solutions to seemingly intractable problems; and relentlessly working to save the lives of women and children around the globe. He was never too busy to take a personal interest in the lives of those who worked with him or for him. He energized the field, inspired action, and left a legacy of leadership, knowledge, integrity, and kindness. He dedicated his life to improving the lives of others and motivated those fortunate enough to know him to do the same. Known as the ''Dean of Deans'' and a ''doctor to millions'', he will be greatly missed. The Mailman School community extends their deepest sympathy to his wife Clare, son Paul and his wife Rachel, daughter Jill and her husband Marc Baker, brother Jim, his five grandchildren, and the entire family. Service at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Today 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Allan Rosenfield Fund, Mailman School of Public Health, 722 W. 168th St., 14th Fl, New York, NY 10032. James Harden, Chairman Susan Patricof, Vice Chair Phyllis Mailman, Member Board of Overseers Linda P. Fried, Dean

Yet, outside the art world, few people talk about the difficulties that female artists face when rising up in the ranks. As in these other fields, experts say the reason there are fewer women at the top is largely because of the difficulties in establishing or maintaining a careers while also raising children.

Senator John McCain put out his newest tax proposals today, billed as helping those most damaged by the financial crisis. The last time Tim Wakefield started a Game 4 - or started in the postseason for that matter - was just under a year ago in Cleveland. It did not go well. He allowed five runs in four and two-thirds innings.

When Evan Longoria rushed in from third to field Jason Bay's grounder in the bottom of the second here, he had two things to focus on. One was fielding the ball cleanly and the other was the splintered bat hurtling above him. Broken at about hand-level, the bat chopped through the air and landed near third base as Longoria first bobbled the ball and then threw wide of first base. Score that E-5.

Last week, the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) released its latest report on the state of the world's species. It makes for gloomy reading. Although there have been a few triumphs - species increasing their numbers thanks to conservation efforts - the general picture is one of decline. A quarter of all mammal species are now endangered, mostly because their habitat is disappearing. But of all the mammals now on the endangered list, from the fishing cat to the Caspian seal, the most startling is the Tasmanian devil.

For a while now, nearly a dozen Senate races have captured our attention as the Democrats battle mightily to expand their thin majority in a year that would seem to favor them. On the other side, the Republicans aren't surrendering without a fight and are poised, according to some reports, with new cash infusions in the closing weeks.

Fresh reports on the glaring disparities between the world's richest and poorest communities don't often make the news. They have a high "M.E.G.O. factor," to reprise an expression I learned from a journalism professor at Columbia University in the early 1980s. (Translation? My Eyes Glaze Over.) But I think they're worth posting here on Dot Earth, if only as a reminder of the "slow drips" hampering global progress even as the richest billion live ever longer, and the global middle class rapidly expands.

When the studio clock at WBLS-FM (107.5) is reflecting the face of Champaine around 3:30, it is a.m., not p.m. She says she wanted to work at that station from the time she was in the fifth grade, and in 1983 the station manager, Frankie Crocker, granted her wish. Champaine, a native of Staten Island, has been at WBLS ever since, most of the time carrying her listeners through the night.

More than a quarter of working families in New York State in 2006 were low-income -- defined as making less than twice the federal poverty line -- and 69 percent spent more than one-third of their income on housing, an increase from 59 percent in 2002, according to a national study of low-income working families released on Tuesday. The study updated findings of a similar report last conducted in 2004.

The first game of the world championship match between Viswanathan Anand of India, the title holder, and Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, a former champion, was drawn in 32 moves after Kramnik, who had White, failed to achieve any real advantage out of the opening. The match is being played in Bonn, Germany, and is organized by Universal Event Promotion under the auspices of the World Chess Federation, the governing body of chess. The match's Web site has information about the players, their record against each other, photographs and interviews. The match is a best of 12, with a win counting as one point and a draw as a half point.

The economic value of family caregiving in 2006 was $350 billion, according to recent research, a figure that exceeded the total spending for either Medicaid ($342 billion) or Medicare ($300 billion) in 2005. Without the unpaid labor of family caregivers -- provided at great physical, emotional and financial cost -- the long-term care system in this country (if you can call it a "system'') would collapse. Nursing homes, far and away the most expensive form of care, would burst at the seams with elderly men and women who might otherwise have been supervised in the community by adult children and spouses.

Environment | A mega-shredder in Wales can "chew up a Camry and spit it out as metal confetti in less than two minutes" and "digest 450 cars an hour." The recycling operation reportedly saves enough energy in steel production to power about 82,000 British households. [Wired, with graphic]

Societe Generale said it remained profitable in the third quarter at the net level, even when including charges related to the collapse of investment bank Lehman Brothers.
Citigroup said it expects JPMorgan Chase to post a loss in the third quarter, reflecting its estimates for loan loss provisions and write-downs at the U.S. banking giant.

A round of far-reaching announcements came from European capitals Monday, with Britain effectively taking control of two of its largest banks, and leaders in Paris, Berlin, Madrid and elsewhere offering more than a trillion euros in loan guarantees and other support intended to restore trust between banks and thaw frozen credit markets.

For 30 years, the nation's political system has been tilted in favor of business deregulation and against new rules. But that is about to change, now that the government has been forced to intervene in the once high-flying financial industry to avert an economywide crash, The New York Times's Jackie Calmes says.

The rally in global stocks carried over for a second day, with Japanese stocks rocketing Tuesday and European markets posting solid gains in the wake of global financial bailouts and the massive recovery on Wall Street.
John J. Mack got his deal - and, at long last, some relief on Wall Street, The New York Times' Louise Story writes.

Behavior | Rumors aren't such a bad thing, researchers are finding. They're driven by "the desire to know more information," and even scurrilous ones "serve as glue for people's social networks." So, the Obama and McCain campaigns were probably right to address recent rumors head-on. "No comment" is perhaps the worst thing you can say. [Boston Globe]

Last Friday, in an interview with Bill Moyers on PBS, George Soros, who has made billions of dollars based on his ability to read the ebb and flow of markets, suggested that investing in alternative energy technologies, refurbishing aging electricity grids and pursuing household energy efficiency, among other green strategies, could yet save the global economy.

Music | Huh? A band that's "the love child of Pavement and Neutral Milk Hotel"? What's the point of all that band-name-dropping in music reviews? Band comparisons are an unavoidable shorthand, critics say, born of the difficulty of describing music in writing. But it's also a hipper-than-thou shield for idiots who don't know what they're talking about. [Gelf]

Science | A new Army grant aims to send messages by thought alone. It's known as synthetic telepathy, and the idea is to read electrical activity in the brain -- "that little voice in your head" -- then send the message to someone else who receives it as text or a voice mail. Victim's of Lou Gehrig's disease might eventually benefit. [Discovery]

Travel | A writer visits Monument Valley in Utah, setting of epic John Ford/John Wayne westerns. The sets Ford build are long gone, "as is just about everyone who worked on them." But Goulding's Lodge, where Ford stayed, remains in business. Still, it's not easy to find "The Searchers" today on the landscape of the American myth. [Washington Post]
Tiger Woods is putting his name on an ambitious project on the Baja coast of Mexico, south of Ensenada.

Books | A funny thing happens to book titles when they cross the Atlantic: they get sexed up. The acclaimed but obscure-sounding "The Carhullan Army" becomes "Daughters of the North" in America. Simon Winchester's staid "The Man Who Loved China" becomes the spy-novel-esque "Bomb, Book and Compass" in Britain. And "Pompeii: The Life of a Roman Town" becomes "The Fires of Vesuvius" in the United States. [Brainiac, Guardian]
A look at a villa in a small village in Indonesia.
John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC discusses whether John McCain can overcome Barack Obama this late in the campaign.

Among the primary themes running through the World Conservation Congress last week in Barcelona was how economics, markets and business increasingly relate to environmental causes. Equally prominent was the role big business could play in helping reduce negative impacts of commerce and industry on plant and animal species.
The Cleveland Browns thrashed the New York Giants, 35-14, handing the defending Super Bowl champions their first loss of the season.

We were about to post our usual daily European hockey report on Monday afternoon when we learned that Avangard's Alexei Cherepanov had just collapsed and died in Chekhov, outside of Moscow. Our report on that incident appears in this post, filed on Monday.

Magic Johnson joined ESPN and ABC as a part-time N.B.A. studio analyst.

English soccer authorities vetoed Madrid as a venue for a proposed exhibition game against Spain because of the racist abuse the team faced the last time it played there. The Spanish federation was fined more than $75,000 when Shaun Wright-Phillips, Ashley Cole, Rio Ferdinand, Jermain Defoe and Jermaine Jenas were subjected to racial taunts at Santiago Bernabeu Stadium in November 2004. Spain won that exhibition, 1-0, and the teams have not played in Spain since.

The ball from the last home run hit at Yankee Stadium will be sold at auction this weekend in New York. The man who snagged it, Steve Harshman of Casper, Wyo., said he had heard estimates that the ball would fetch at least $200,000.

Tommy Bowden resigned as Clemson’s football coach Monday, telling Athletic Director Terry Don Phillips that he was stepping aside for the future of the program. Phillips said he was surprised by Bowden’s decision. “There wasn’t a gun to his head,” Phillips said.
Matt Stairs crunched a two-run homer deep into the right-field bleachers, breaking a tie in the eighth inning and powering the Phillies to a victory over Los Angeles.

In London yesterday, crowds campaigning for women's suffrage "hemmed in Parliament and stopped the traffic in all streets leading to Westminster. For more than three hours the crowds scuffled good-naturedly with the police, interfered with theatregoers, broke windows, and disorganized things generally in the centre of London. The heroine of the day was Mrs. Travers Symons, formerly secretary to James Keir Hardie, the Socialist and Independent member of Parliament, who reached the door of the House of Commons by strategy. The house was solemnly debating a bill to prevent children from cigarette smoking, when the woman dashed past the doorkeeper to a position in front of the Speaker's chair and shouted shrilly: 'Leave off discussing children and talk about the women.' " She was ejected and "an order was issued that hereafter women should not be admitted to the building on any pretext whatsoever." Suffragette Mob Storms Parliament

An art review on Friday about “Live Forever: Elizabeth Peyton,” at the New Museum, referred incorrectly to her solo show at the Chelsea Hotel in 1993. Her first solo show was at the Althea Viafora Gallery in SoHo in 1987; it was not the show at the Chelsea Hotel.

An article on Monday about Andy Martin, who has been a source of some of the false rumors about Senator Barack Obama’s background, referred incorrectly to an academic institution where a study of the rumors’ origins was conducted by Prof. Danielle Allen. The Institute for Advanced Study is located in Princeton, N.J., but is not part of Princeton University.

An obituary on Saturday about the ballerina Nadia Nerina misstated her age when she moved from her native South Africa to London. According to the Royal Ballet, the company in which she spent most of her career, she moved to London in 1945, when she was 17 or 18. She was not 16.

An article on Friday about a study asserting that the United States is failing to develop students’ math skills referred incorrectly to the high school education of Melanie Wood, a member of the United States Mathematical Olympiad team in 1998. She graduated from a private, not a public, school — Park Tudor in Indianapolis.

An article on Sunday about the successful career of Pat Gillick, the general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, misstated the age of the veteran pitcher Jamie Moyer, who has played for Gillick in Seattle and Philadelphia. Moyer is 45 — not 46, which he turns next month.

An article in some copies on Saturday about Colgate running back Jordan Scott, a leading player in the N.C.A.A.’s Football Championship Subdivision, misidentified the team against which he rushed for 272 yards. It was Fordham, not Princeton.

ROSENFIELD--Allan G. The Board of Directors and the staff of the Guttmacher Institute mourn the passing of our beloved friend, colleague and supporter. Allan was a giant in the sexual and reproductive health field. His enduring commitment to helping women around the world obtain the family planning services and other reproductive health care they need to improve their lives was an inspiration to us all. We are grateful that Allan was a member of the Guttmacher Board for more than 20 years, and served as its chair from 1993 to 1995; he became an emeritus member in 2006. His intellect and vision helped make the Guttmacher Institute a stronger, more effective organization. We extend our deepest sympathy to Allan's family and share their loss of this remarkable man. ROSENFIELD--Allan G., M.D. The New York-Presbyterian Hospital community deeply mourns the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Allan Rosenfield. A brilliant man and a leader in the field of public health for more than 40 years, Dr. Rosenfield made lasting improvements to the health and human rights of people here in New York and around the world. As its dean, he made the Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health one of the best there is. An obstetrician - gynecologist, he helped establish women's health as a subspecialty, and was among the first to draw attention to the women's health crisis in the developing world. He established the pioneering Averting Maternal Death and Disability program, supporting more than 85 projects in 50 countries. Locally, he expanded access to health clinics in the Washington Heights community. Passionate and personable, he inspired everyone he knew, bringing people together to accomplish even the most difficult challenges. A true humanitarian and tireless advocate for health of the most vulnerable populations, he will forever serve as a model of compassion and courage. Our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Rosenfield's wife, Clare, and the entire Rosenfield family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital ROSENFIELD--Allan. The New York Academy of Medicine acknowledges with profound sorrow the death of Allan Rosenfield, M.D., Fellow and Trustee of the Academy and the 2006 recipient of the Stephen Smith Award for Lifetime Achievement in Public Health. We join many in honoring his outstanding international accomplish ments and lifelong commitment to championing the rights and health of women, promoting interventions to improve maternal and child health, and fighting for health policies to protect the poor and disadvantaged. He was a transformational leader of the Columbia School of Public Health, tireless contributor to countless organizations and individuals, and deeply valued friend and colleague. We are especially grateful for his support of the Academy. The Academy Board, Fellows and staff extend deepest condolences to his family. Jo Ivey Boufford, M.D. President Thomas Q. Morris, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees ROSENFIELD--Dr. Allan. To say I knew this man, who touched so many millions of lives in such profound ways, is humbling. The world is diminished by his death, indeed as it has benefitted so much by his extraordinary life. My thoughts are with Clare and her family. Robert Mitchell ROSENFIELD--Allan. The board and staff of Public Health Solutions send our condolences to the Rosenfield family and Allan's many friends. While the world has lost a true humanitarian, his accomplishments will continue to benefit public health. Deborah M. Sale, Chairperson and Ellen Rautenberg, President and CEO ROSENFIELD--Allan. The staff of The New Yorkew Jersey AIDS Education and Training Center at Columbia University mourn the loss of Allan Rosenfield, M.D. An initial founder of this project, and a longtime supporter, he cared deeply about people affected by HIV/AIDS. ROSENFIELD--Allan, M.D. Columbia University Medical Center salutes the vision, commitment, energy, and legacy of Allan Rosenfield, our medical school graduate, faculty member, and dean emeritus of the Mailman School of Public Health. His dedication to public health and bringing health care to the underserved in our medical center backyard and around the world will be remembered through the programs he initiated, the faculty he recruited, the students he taught, and the awareness he raised of environmental health, maternal health, disaster preparedness, public health infrastructure, family planning, and HIV and AIDS in the developing world. Many organizations benefited from Dr. Rosenfield's 50year legacy in obstetrics, gynecology, and public health, but no organization benefited for as long as Columbia University did. Dr. Rosenfield served as dean of the Mailman School for 22 years, he was on the faculty of the medical school and public health school for 33 years, he contributed significantly to the evolution of public health from a small program in the medical school into a full-fledged school of public health, and he raised the stature of Columbia's public health education, research, and outreach to the top of national standings. His renowned leadership is a legacy we will devote ourselves to preserving for future generations of healthcare professionals and public health scholars. We send our condolences to Dr. Rosenfield's family and his large circle of friends and colleagues. Lee Goldman, M.D., Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine, Columbia University And the Columbia University Medical Center Community ROSENFIELD--Allan. We mourn the passing of our dear friend and mentor, Dr. Allan Rosenfield whose life was an example of service and courage. Allan's heroic dedication to improving global public health and stopping the spread of HIV/AIDS inspires us to work harder to find a cure. He will be missed but never forgotten. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Clare, children and family. Kenneth and Maria Cole

STATE COLLEGE, Pa. -- Lunch time on a Sunday in a college town. You know how that goes. Some students enjoy sandwiches in their pajama bottoms with sweatshirts thrown on top. Others fiddle with their iPods when they should be studying. But bring up the presidential race among these first-time voters and there is excitement. ''It's like one of my rights,'' said Gabrielle Bedeian, a freshman here at Pennsylvania State University from the Main Line of Philadelphia. ''For me, it's the first one that came to mind when I turned 18.''

JONES--Carlisle, 80, of New York, NY and Lawrenceville, NJ died at his home in New York City on October 9. He is survived by his wife Jeanne M. His children DeborahSteven Lupton, Leslie-John Brittain, Geoffrey Jones-Caroline Jones, Elizabeth-Tyler Hall and Andrew Jones. Stepchildren Joseph Fusco Pamela, William Fusco, John Fusco, Thomas Fusco-Laurie, Stephen Fusco and Julie Lanning-Michael. He also leaves behind 26 grandchildren. Carlisle had a long and distinguished career as an Investment advisor with A.W. Jones, S.W. Seligman City Associates, Brimberg and Company and Invemed and Co. He was a member of the New York Stock Exchange for over 30 years. He was renowned for his idea sharing round table and as a great mentor. Carlisle was an avid hunter and fisherman and a lover of the great outdoors. He will be fondly remembered by all those he touched, for his wonderful sense of humor and the joyful way he journeyed through life. A celebration of his life will be held at the Racquet Club on 370 Park Ave., October 15, 6pm-9pm. Contribution may be made to the New York Botanical Garden and the Central Park Conservancy.

Magic Johnson joined ESPN and ABC as a part-time N.B.A. studio analyst, a role like the one he had for seven years at TNT. ESPN and ABC also gave a long-term contract extension to Jeff Van Gundy, who shares the lead game analyst job with Mark Jackson.

10 P.M. (Discovery) TOUGHEST RACE ON EARTH: IDITAROD Each year since 1973, mushers and their sled dog teams have raced 1,150 miles through the wilds of Alaska, from Anchorage to Nome. Of the 96 teams that started this year's competition, only 78 completed the race. This new reality series follows seven competitors, including the four-time Iditarod winner Martin Buser (who holds the record for the fastest time: 8 days 22 hours 46 minutes 2 seconds in 2002) and the rookie Rick Holt, as they traverse forests, mountain ranges, frozen rivers and tundra on their way to the finish line, where $69,000 and a pickup truck await the winner, and a red lantern greets the last musher to finish. (John Schultz's 1973 record of 32 days 15 hours 9 minutes 1 second still stands.) 7 A.M. Since 1929, Republicans and Democrats have each controlled the presidency for nearly 40 years. So which party has been better for American pocketbooks and capitalism as a whole? Well, here's an experiment: imagine that during these years you had to invest exclusively under either Democratic or Republican administrations. How would you have fared? As of Friday, a $10,000 investment in the S.& P. stock market index* would have grown to $11,733 if invested under Republican presidents only, although that would be $51,211 if we exclude Herbert Hoover's presidency during the Great Depression. Invested under Democratic presidents only, $10,000 would have grown to $300,671 at a compound rate of 8.9 percent over nearly 40 years.

Big Brown, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, injured his right front hoof Monday morning during a workout at Aqueduct and was immediately retired. That thwarted an anticipated showdown with Curlin, the 2007 Horse of the Year, on Oct. 25 in the Breeders' Cup Classic. It was another setback for horse racing this year. The filly Eight Belles broke down and had to be euthanized after finishing second in the Derby, and the industry was scolded by a United States congressional subcommittee in June for its lax drug policies and faulty breeding.
