Buoyed by the biggest intervention in the American banking system since the Depression and similar moves in Europe, stock markets around the world staged one of the most powerful one-day rallies in history on Monday. The Treasury Department, in its boldest move yet, is expected to announce a plan on Tuesday to invest up to $250 billion in banks, according to officials. The United States is also expected to guarantee new debt issued by banks for three years -- a measure meant to encourage the banks to resume lending to one another and to customers, officials said.

MARGULIES--Ned L., 85, of Fort Lee, NJ, died peacefully Saturday evening, October 11, surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of Harriett for 59 years, he was the devoted father of Alan (and Gale) Margulies, Alissa Margulies (and partner Emily Eyre), and loving brother of Elaine Freinberg. Born and raised in New York City, Ned graduated from Baruch College, CCNY, class of 1943 and immediately joined the Army, serving in the Pacific. Longtime president of State Container Corp. of Moonachie, NJ, Ned was liked and respected by employees, colleagues, and competitors. He was the life of every party, never let anyone else pick up the check, and enjoyed himself to the fullest. He will be sorely missed by friends and family, and as he always said, ''I had a good run''. Funeral service will be Thursday, October 16, 3pm at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park St. Hackensack, NJ, 201-489-3800. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Baruch College and PBS.

Flush with cash, the Republican National Committee is beginning to open its wallet to broadcast new advertisements against Senator Barack Obama. In a single day, the committee paid for a $5 million advertising purchase by OnMessage, a media firm in Alexandria, Va., that represents Republican candidates. It was the fourth independent expenditure -- a campaign finance technicality that allows the party to name Mr. Obama in the advertisements -- made by the committee in the presidential race.

As mothers of soldiers who have been deployed to Iraq, both Gov. Sarah Palin and Cindy McCain accused Senator Barack Obama last week of voting not to finance American troops there. A McCain campaign advertisement called ''Dangerous'' goes further, saying that Mr. Obama and other ''Congressional liberals voted repeatedly to cut off funding to our active troops,'' thereby ''increasing the risk on their lives.'' On the campaign trail, Ms. Palin also claims that Mr. Obama ''said too that our troops in Afghanistan are just, quote, 'air-raiding villages and killing civilians.' '' In an interview with Fox News last week, she described Mr. Obama's Afghanistan remark as ''reckless'' and said that, in her view, it was sufficient to ''disqualify someone from consideration for the next commander in chief.''

RODGERS--Christopher Raymond Perry (Knobby), of Gulf Stream, FL, died on October 7th at his summer home in Brooklin, ME; he was 87. Son of C. Raymond P. and Alice A. (Meyer) Rodgers, he was born November 29, 1920. He graduated from St. George's School in Newport, RI and from Princeton University with the class of 1942. He served in the United States Navy during WWII overseeing radar operations on the aircraft carrier ''San Jacinto'' in the South Pacific, after which he returned to Princeton, NJ where he made his home for many years. His entire career was spent at CitiBank from which he retired as a Vice President after 35 years of service. A skilled athlete, he was a goalie on the 1948 US Olympic Hockey team and played for many years with the St. Nick's Hockey Club. Dedicated to the game of golf, he was a founding member of the Bedens Brook Club in Skillman, NJ, a former member of Pine Valley Golf Club, served as President of the Gulf Stream Golf Club in Florida and was a member of the United States Seniors' Golf Association. He was a generous supporter of many charities, especially those associated with veterans, and served on the vestries of Trinity Church in Princeton and Trinity Church in New York. Predeceased by his sisters Alicia and Virginia, three wives, the former Charlotte Hundley, Mary Pardee, and Katharine Parson and one stepson Ario, he is survived by 10 children, Perry Rodgers of Hopewell, NJ, Emily Rodgers of Bucksport, ME, Mary Elizabeth Alexander of NYC, James Rodgers of Phoenix, MD, Sam Rodgers of Leverett, MA, Sally Smith of Exeter, NH, Alice Celestino of Sarasota, FL, Virginia Hoyt of Lake Placid, NY, John Rodgers of Sweden, Julie Alpert of Naples, FL, two stepchildren, Arrel Lindermann of Boston and Ann Parson of South Dartmouth, MA, 30 grandchildren and four great - grandchildren. Burial will be private; a memorial service is planned for January in Gulf Stream, FL. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Francis By the Sea Episcopal Church, PO BOX 76, Blue Hill, ME 04614 or St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 188 S. Swinton Ave., Delray Beach, FL 33444.

Last weekend, the chairman of the Republican Party in Virginia climbed on a folding chair and addressed campaign volunteers with a rallying cry linking Senator Barack Obama and Osama bin Laden. ''Both have friends that bombed the Pentagon,'' said the chairman, Jeffrey M. Frederick. ''That is scary.'' The comment, exaggerating Mr. Obama's association with the 1960s radical William Ayers, was reported by Karen Tumulty in Time magazine and it set off a commotion in the blogosphere.

ROSENFIELD--Allan, M.D. amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research, mourns the passing of Dr. Allan Rosenfield, dean emeritus of Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health, Chairman of amfAR's Program Board, and a longtime member of the Foundation's Board of Trustees. Combining expertise in obstetrics/ gynecology, family planning, public health, and HIV/AIDS with ardent advocacy of women's health and human rights, Dr. Rosenfield improved and enriched the lives of countless men, women, and children around the world. Dr. Rosenfield's guidance and leadership will be missed by all at amfAR, and he will be remembered with abiding admiration, gratitude, and affection. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Clare, children, and grandchildren. Kenneth Cole, Chairman of the Board Mathilde Krim, Ph.D., Founding Chairman Kevin Robert Frost, Chief Executive Officer ROSENFIELD--Allan. The board, staff and global grassroots partners of American Jewish World Service mourn the passing of a distinguished member of our board who has contributed immeasurably to the work of AJWS and to the global fight against HIV/ AIDS and the promotion of health care for women. Allan was a leader in the public health community, a brilliant program innovator and a passionate believer in the importance of a world committed to a greater degree of health and justice for all. He demonstrated how to cope with illness and adversity without abandoning hope; we are all privileged to have known and worked with him and are diminished by his passing. We extend our deepest condolences to Clare, Paul, Rachel, Mark and Jill. Ruth Messinger, President Jim Meier, Board Chair ROSENFIELD--Allan G., M.D. The depth of our gratitude to Allan is beyond expression. He taught us, he inspired us, and we are ever enriched for having known him. A life superbly lived, we hope that comforts Clare and his entire family. The family of Joseph L. Mailman ROSENFIELD--Dr. Allan. The Nathaniel Wharton Fund mourns the loss of our esteemed founding Board member, Dr. Allan Rosenfield, Dean Emeritus of the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University. Dr. Rosenfield was an internationally respected leader and passionate advocate for the advancement of public health, and for improved care of the sick. He was a voice for the disadvantaged and recognized the importance not only of biological, but also psychological and social factors in health. His loss will be felt by everyone both at The Wharton Fund and at Columbia University. We extend our sympathy to his family. Ralph N. Wharton, M.D., Executive Director, The Nathaniel Wharton Fund for Research and Education in Brain, Body and Behavior ROSENFIELDALLAN ST#

DUGAN--Anne B., died October 10, 2008 in Gig Harbor, Washington. Anne was a native of Brooklyn, NY and a graduate of Erasmus Hall High School, where she received her secretarial training. She attended Brooklyn College and the University of New Hampshire. Her career included assignments at the 1939-40 World's Fair in New York, the Navy Department in Washington DC during World War II, and 25 years in the NYC public school system. A wonderful, loyal, and generous sister, wife, mother, grandmother and aunt, Anne is survived by her daughter Mary Quistorff (Ned), son Brendan Dugan (Debs), her daughter-in-law Mary Ann Dugan, grandchildren Timothy, Brian, Liam, Deirdre, Hud, Anna, and Claire, three great grandchildren, one great-great grandchild, her sister Norine Hannah and several nieces and nephews. Anne is predeceased by her husband Vincent, son Brian, sister Marion, and brothers Timothy and James. Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Thursday, October 16, 2008, 11 am, at St. Patrick Catholic Church, Tacoma, WA. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations in memory of Anne may be made to the American Red Cross. Please leave online condolences at www.GaffneyCares.com. Services by Gaffney Funeral Home, 253-572-6003.
